Researchers investigated how genetic variations in the 3' end of genes affect gene expression in human lymphoblast cells. They found that the position of the 3' end of a gene does not occur randomly, but is influenced by regulatory elements such as microRNA sites. The length of the 3' end also varies between individuals and is predicted by genetic variations in polyadenylation signals and other 3' motifs. These variations affect the expression of the gene. Experiments confirmed the effect of polyadenylation on gene expression and validated the role of 3' regulatory elements. The study focused on the immune regulator IRF and found that natural variation in 3' end processing affects response to antigen stimulation. The results highlight the importance of 3' end mechanisms in genetics and suggest integrating 3 end positions with 3 motifs will be a useful tool for understanding human variation.
Researchers have studied the effectiveness of the SIVΔne vaccine, a weakened form of the simian immunodeficiency virus, in inducing protection against the wild-type virus. They used deep sequencing technology to analyze the CD8 T cell response, a type of immune cell that fights infection, in vaccinated animals. The results show that the initial CD8 response targets variable parts of the virus, but the virus quickly mutates and escapes. However, the CD8 cells adapt by targeting conserved parts of the virus and generating new responses to mutated variants. This adaptation correlates with the vaccine's protection. The study highlights the importance of targeting conserved regions and expanding the CD8 cell repertoire for successful vaccine design.
Researchers studied the role of interleukin-1 (IL-1) in the body's defense against fungal infections caused by Candida albicans in the mouth. They used a mouse model of oral candidiasis and found that IL-1 signaling is crucial for controlling the infection by regulating neutrophils, a type of white blood cell. IL-1 acts in two ways: by recruiting neutils from the bloodstream to the site of infection and mobilizing new neutils from the bone marrow. Without IL-1, mice had impaired chemokine production and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in response to Candida. Surprisingly, endothelial cells were the primary source of G-CS, responding to IL-α from keratinocytes in infected tissue. In vitro, IL- dependent communication between different blood cell types was confirmed using a kerocyte and endothelial cell line. The study established a link between IL and granulopoies in fungal infection. Two mechanisms coordinating neutil response in the mucosa were identified, preventing fungal growth and protecting the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filari (GPE) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals via mass administration of anti-filar drugs in at-risk areas for 4-6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were calculated by quantifying the number of clinical manifestations averted and associated with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and healthcare for affected individuals. Reviewing multiple sources, including the World Health Organization, International Fund, and Labour, an estimated $21.8 billion in economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GPE. This includes $2.3 billion from protection of nearly 3 million individuals from acquiring lymphatic filari as a result of being born in areas freed transmission. Additionally, 28 million infected benefit from GLF halting progression, resulting in $19.5 billion economic benefit. At-risk individuals decreased services with reduced morbidity save health systems approximately $2.2 billion. The Programme offers significant economic benefits, with favorable implementation largely due to donated drugs from the pharmaceutical industry, showing a high return on investment. 

The GPE was initiated in 200 to guide endemic countries implementing single-dose, yearly mass administration using albend+iverect or alb+DEC for 4-6 years. The Programme delivered nearly 2 billion treatments and reached 570 individuals in 83 countries. As a result, 31.4 million will gain benefits over lifetime from direct and indirect costs. Lymphatic filari imposes a severe socioeconomic burden on 1.3 billion at-risk in 83 countries. This study offers an economic analysis, estimating $21.8 billion benefits for infected and non-infected in M-treated areas, plus $2.
Researchers have created a new animal model to study Gaucher disease, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene. This model, called GBA-/-medaka, lacks the enzyme glucerebrosidase activity, which leads to the accumulation of harmful substances in the body. Unlike humans and mice without this enzyme, G-aka lived for months, allowing scientists to study the progression of the disease. G-aka showed symptoms similar to human Gaucher disease, including brain cell infiltration, neuron loss, and inflammation. Detailed analysis revealed abnormal lysosomes in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-s) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disrupting α-s did not improve lifespan, axonal swellings, neuron loss, or inflammation in G-aka. This study provides a new model for Gaucher disease and reveals how α-s accumulation is caused by glucerebrosase deficiency and its minimal contribution to the disease. Gaucher is the most common lysosomal disease, caused by homozygous mutations in GBA, leading to decreased enzymatic activity and accumulation of glucerebrosidase substrates. It is divided into three types: non-neuronopathic, acute neuronopathic, and subacute. Long-term survival of Gaka allowed observation of disease progression, revealing lysosomal dysfunction in neurons and α-s accumulation in axonal autophag. Axonal transport of α-s may play a role in G mutations leading to Parkinson's disease and be a target for therapy. Patients with type 1 Gaucher have increased risk of Parkinson's disease, carrying G mutations show intraneural α-s accumulation, Lewy bodies and neurites, hallmarks of sporadic PD. Several studies indicate association between G mutations and α-s accumulation. The observed phenotypes in Gaka brains were caused by G mutation. α-s overexpression causes neurotoxicity, neuroflammation observed in PD brains, promoting disease progression.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Listeria monocytogen interacts with the immune system to cause infection. L monocogen is a type of bacteria that lives inside cells and triggers a strong immune response. To cause long-lasting protection, the bacteria must escape from the cell's recycling compartment called the phagosome and enter the cell's inner space. The study found that the immune response to bacteria trapped in the phag is not weak because it's not presented to the immune cells, but because the immune is actively suppressed. This suppression affects not only the response to bacteria in the phag but also to those in the cell's inner space. When both types of bacteria are present, the immune response is weakened and specific cells that fight the bacteria in the inner space are reduced. Bacteria in the phag suppress inflammation and produce a protein called IL-10, which blocks the immune response. Blocking IL-10 or removing a key protein called MyD restored the immune response. The study shows that bacteria in phag can impact the immune system by blocking pathways that create inflammation and protective cells.
Researchers have identified six genetic variants in the SIX gene associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), a leading cause of blindness worldwide. The study sequenced the SIX gene in 262 PO cases and 256 controls and found six nonsynonymous coding variants, including a rare and common variant AsnHis (rs12345), which was significantly associated with PO (OR=1.27, p=4.2×10-10) in the NEIGH/GLUG datasets. The variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complement assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye and optic structure. Five variants found in PO cases were hypomorphic or null, while one found in controls was benign. One variant in the SIX enhancer increased SIX expression and disrupted its regulation. The study found a clinical feature in PO patients dependent on SIX genotype: those homozygous for the SIX risk allele (His) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than homozyg for the non-risk (As) allele. The results, combined with previous SIX work, suggest SIX variants disrupt development leading to reduced retinal cells, increasing glcoma vision loss.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch that controls the production of flagella and toxins in Clostridium difficile, a human intestinal pathogen that causes diarrhea. This switch, called the flagellar switch, is a 154-base pair sequence that can be flipped to two different orientations. When in one orientation, the bacteria produce flagella and secrete toxins, while in the other orientation they do not. The orientation of the flag switch can change during growth in a lab dish. The researchers found that a protein called RecV is responsible for flipping the switch, and that this affects the production of toxins and flagella. Bacteria with the switch in the "on" orientation are motile and produce toxins, while those with the switch in the "off" orientation are not motile and produce less toxins. The flag switch also affects the production of toxins by controlling a gene called sigmaD, which is important for toxin production. The researchers found that RecV also controls the phase variation of a cell wall protein and is responsible for flipping the flag switch in both directions.
Researchers studied the process of sporulation in the bacterium Clostridium difficile, an intestinal pathogen that forms highly resistant spores. This process is crucial for its infectious cycle. They compared it to Bacillus subtilis, a well-studied model organism, and found differences in the regulation of sporulation factors. In B. subtilis, four sigma factors (σF, E, G, K) control gene expression in the forespore and mother cell during sporulation. In C. difficile, σE activity is independent of σF, σG is dependent on σ, and σK does not require σ. σK is not necessary for spore formation. The researchers also found reduced temporal segregation between early and late sigma factors and altered signaling pathways. Despite these differences, the sporulation network is conserved across species, with sigma factors regulating the pathway established 2.5 billion years ago in the Firmicutes phylum.
Researchers have developed a new framework to model the behavior of allosteric multisite proteins, which are proteins that change shape and function in response to multiple signals. This framework uses a single variable to replicate the complex behavior of multisite systems, such as the Monod-Wy-Change alloster model. The model shows that optimal sensitivity is achieved when activation of the protein by individual sites is concerted and redundant. This makes it useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems where multiple proteins interact. As an example, the researchers applied the model to a newly discovered signaling pathway in yeast that monitors cell growth at the plasma membrane. They found that components of the pathway form a hysteretic switch, a system that responds only when a signal reaches a certain threshold indicating sufficient growth has occurred. The model can be extended to other types of multisite modifications, such as ligand binding, transcription, methylation, and ubiquitination. To test the model's versatility, it was applied to a cell size checkpoint in yeast. The model assumes a protein is phosphorylated by a kinase at multiple sites and dephosphorylated by a phosphatase. The system is non-sequential, with different phospho forms and a large number of sites. The model shows bistability, hysteresis, and limit cycles, which are common in regulatory processes involving multis proteins.
Researchers have uncovered the underlying mechanism of a "switch" in the quorum sensing (QS) system of E. coli, a process that allows bacteria to communicate and gain a selective advantage over populations. Quorum sensing is a complex phenomenon where genetic circuits and regulation are intertwined, making it difficult to understand. A combination of experimental and mathematical models was used to study the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) QS system in E. coli. The network was separated into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms. A new negative interaction was hypothesized and tested with a simple model, revealing the importance of the Lsr regulator and its role in the E coli QS switch. A "bottom-up" approach was used to understand gene regulation, which will help unravel complex network architectures and direct emergent behaviors.

The QS system consists of an auto-regulatory network with a double motif, providing a population response. The connectivity and signal propagation of AI-2 in the system were examined. Regulatory motifs were studied in isolation, then combined to represent the system as a network. Further analysis will shed light on regulatory pathways in bacterial metabolic networks and guide new phenotypes. A model was built based on results, incorporating the new element, capturing predictions and simulating the network and sub-systems. The mechanistic basis for Lsr-mediated E coli switch was revealed, buried in the native system but effective.

The AI-2 mechanism, a main module in AI-2 QS E coli, was taken apart and sub-systems analyzed in isolation. Modules were separated, leading to speculation of new interactions within the network. A "bottom-up approach isolating regulatory elements is effective to analyze biological networks with positive and negative regulations. Study of modules allows constructing a hypothetical system and predicting new mechanisms.
A study was conducted in rural Gabon to investigate the effect of schistosiasis, a soil-transmitted helminth, on Plasmod falcum infection in school-age children. The study found that schosias increased the risk of Plmod infection, especially when combined with Trichuris trichi or hookworm infection. Children infected with schos had a higher incidence of malaria over time compared to non-infected children, with a significant delay in time to first malaria event in those aged 6-10 years. The prevalence of schos and Plmod co-infection was 23% and 9, respectively. The study suggests that STH enhances Plmod risk in schos-positive children and increases susceptibility to malaria in young children, but not older children.
Researchers studied how the body's immune response to Leishmania infection, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis. They found that a protein called IRF-5, which triggers inflammation, limits the growth of a type of immune cell called CD8 T cells. IRF-5 activates genes that produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-6 and TNF. The study shows that IR-5-induced inflammation hinders CD8 T cell expansion and development by inducing HIF-1 in dendritic cells. HIF-1 in dendritic cells impairs their function. When H-1 is blocked in dendritic cells, there are more CD8 T cells and less parasite in the spleen. Mice with blocked H-1 in dendritic cells have lower parasite burden, suggesting H-1 is a mechanism used by Leish to establish infection.
Researchers conducted a systematic review to identify factors associated with poor outcomes in patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Latin America. They analyzed 14 studies and found that jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 and over 40 years, neutropenia, dyspnea, bacterial infections, edema, and low hemoglobin concentration were linked to unfavorable outcomes. The strongest predictors were jaundice, thromocytopenia, hemorrh, and HIV coinfection. The review highlights the need for validated prognostic models to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes. 

VL is a serious health issue in endemic regions, particularly in the Indian subcontinent, North Africa, and South America, and is one of the world's most neglected diseases, associated with poverty and scarce effective treatments. The Brazilian Ministry of Health recommends platelet transfusion for patients with counts under 10,000 platelets/mm3. Leishmania-HIV coinfection was a prognostic factor for adverse VL evolution in all studies and multivariate analyses showed coinfected individuals had higher risk of poor prognosis.
Researchers in Algeria studied the susceptibility of Leishmania parasites to antimonial drugs over a 30-year period. Antimonial drugs are used to treat visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, but high selective pressure may lead to resistant parasites. The study analyzed 106 isolates from humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines collected between 1976-2013 in Algeria and 18 from dogs in France. The isolates were from areas where leishiasis is common. Potassium antimony tarate and sodium stibogluconate were tested on promastigotes and amastigotes. The 50 inhibitory concentrations were 23.83 μg/mL and 15.91 μg for visceral and cutaneous leishias, respectively. A trend of increasing susceptibility in visceral isolates was found, but cutaneous isolates became more resistant. The emergence of resistant isolates correlates with L. kili (L. trop) causing cutaneous leishias that emerged in Algeria. The study provides insight into spatiotemporal dynamics of Leish antimony susceptibility and highlights the need for effective methodology to detect resistant strains.
Researchers investigated the link between acute gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition of unknown etiology. They found that exposure to foodborne pathogens causing gastroenteritis increases the risk of CD in the post-infect period, but the mechanism behind this relationship was unclear. To study this, they developed two models of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimium or Citrobacterium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia (AIE), a pathion linked to CD. Results showed that disease activity in the post-infect period after gastroenter is driven by the tissue expansion of resident AIE pathion, with increased immunology defects, barrier, and delayed mucosal restitution following path clearance. This was due to AIE resistance to host peptides and inflammatory response to enteric pathogen. The study suggests individuals colonized by AIE at the time of infectious gastroenter may be at risk for CD onset. Importantly, AIE was identified as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in development of interventions following gastroenter in-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two cells: the egg cell and the central cell, surrounded by five accessory cells. These cells are essential for fertilization, but the mechanisms controlling their formation and fate are unknown. Researchers isolated the lach (lis) mutant, which forms extra egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells become egg cells, indicating LIS prevents accessory cells from becoming egg cells. LIS is involved in a mechanism that suppresses egg fate in accessory cells. Its expression suggests this mechanism occurs in egg cells. LIS is similar to yeast splicing factor PR4, indicating splicing components participate in cell decisions.

 Studies show all cells in the gamophyte can become egg cells and LIS is involved in suppressing egg fate in accessory cells. In lis mutants, the central cell also becomes egg, suggesting LIS suppresses egg fate in the central cell. The lis mutant reveals two levels of cell regulation: between egg and accessory, and between egg and central. Marker genes indicate distinct Arabidopsis cell fates occur after cellularization.

The female gamophyte forms from a single spore through three divisions, resulting in a syncytium of eight nuclei that differentiates into four cell types. In lis mutants, synergids become egg at the expense of syner cell. A syner marker is expressed in lis gamophytes, showing not all accessory and egg fate are exclusive. Over time, lis/LIS plants become more distinct from wild type. Results suggest accessory cells in lis mutants become egg cells. The lis mutation is in At2g00, a protein with seven WD repeats.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in a rural Ethiopian highland community to understand the barriers to wearing shoes, which is crucial for preventing Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs). They used the PRECE-PRO model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, and educational factors influencing shoe-wearing. The study gathered information from 242 respondents through focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and case studies. Results showed that shoe-wearing norms are changing, with going barefoot seen as shameful. Shoes are thought to confer dignity and protection against injury, but many practical and social barriers prevent desire to wear from practice. Limited resources mean people can't buy more than one pair or afford quality shoes. As a result, shoes are preserved for special occasions and not provided for children until a certain age. Underlying barriers like poverty, price, unsuitability, and low perception are likely relevant to range of NTDs. Established models of health behavior adoption identified barriers to shoe-wearing amenable to intervention, which will benefit NTD prevention through shoe distribution.

In a community endemic for podoiosis, a NTD triggered by soil exposure, researchers found behaviors and practices relevant to other NTDs. In Ethiopia, shoes are distributed to children to prevent podoiosis. Recurring barriers mentioned were financial and poor suitability for common activities. Constraints influence possession, type, age, consistency, replacement, and activities. Theories argue importance of targeting beliefs, attitudes, and perceived capabilities to prevent podoiosis and reduce risk. The study aimed to understand barriers to consistent shoe use in a setting. Respondents aspired to wear, but reality was different. Many possessed shoes, but not worn regularly. Barriers included financial, access, perceptions, and disease risk. Podoiosis faced difficulty finding sizes and stigma.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of infected sympathetic neurons. Without Us, mutants are defective in anterograde transmission in vivo. Researchers investigated how Us promotes axonal sorting of many viral proteins. They found that glyroteins B, C, D, and E are associated with lipid microdomains on infected cells and directed into ax in Us-dependent manner. This study determined Us is associated with lipid rafts, critical for Us-mediated sorting viral proteins. 

In non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, Us is highly in detergent-resistant membranes (DR). Reducing Us affinity for lipid ra inhibited antograde transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. Association Us with lipid ra is key for targeting proteins to axons, consequence for spread PR from pre-synaptic to postynaptic neurons in mammalian nervous system. Without Us, axons do not contain vesicles with viral glyrote or virus. However, mechanism unclear. Glycoprote B, C, D, E associated lipid ra on infected cells, directed ax in Us manner. Model viralids and proteins traffic ax as mature particles within vesicle. 

Us is in DR non-polar and polarized PC cells, enrichment critical axonal and neuron-to-cell spread. Enrichment cholesterol, essential Us-mediated antog spread primary SC neurons. Us responsible ax sorting viralids, glyrote B, C, E. Us product, small, type II membrane protein, interest antog transport alpha viruses mammalian nervous. Directs membrane and caps to ax infected. Requirement antog neuron-cell and neuron-neuron virus. Overall, PC cells recapitulate Us phenotypes primary neurons, efficacious study Us biology.
Researchers have found that genetically identical yeast cells can exhibit varying growth rates and stress tolerance under constant conditions, a phenomenon known as nongenic heterogeneity, which has implications in tumors and microbial infections. They studied the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and found that growth rate correlates with susceptibility to heat stress at the single-cell level. Using genetic and chemical perturbations with high-throughput single-cell assays, they showed that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein A (PKA) pathway and its transcription factors M2 and M4 underlies nenic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, as shown by direct comparison of cAMP in subpopulations enriched for slower vs faster cells. An endogenous reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in cells. Paralogs M2 and M4 differ in roles inenic heterogeneity, demonstrating slow growth and stress are not linked. Heterogeneity in rate requires M2, whereas M4 is required for heterogeneity expression of T1, a subunit of trehalose synth that contributes to acute-stress. Perturbingenic heterogeneity by mutating genes in pathway or culturing wild-type with cell-perable cAMP analog 8-bromoAMP or PK inhibitor H89 impacts survival of acute stress.
Researchers analyzed the genetic diversity of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) during its rapid spread from Asia to the Americas in 2013. They used deep-sequencing to study viral samples from infected individuals in Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands in the center of the outbreak. The study found changes in the virus's genetic sequence and a range of minority variants present at different levels in the population. The diversity was reduced after the virus was grown in lab cells. A new 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was discovered, not found in nature, that helped the virus replicate in insect cells. This suggests CHV evolved quickly once it entered a new population. The study highlights the need for ongoing viral surveillance to understand the virus's potential.
Researchers have identified a new gene called UOR that plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and tumor formation through a signaling pathway called mTOR. This pathway is involved in various human diseases, including cancer. The study found that reducing UOR in cultured brain cells and nerve cells promotes growth, while overexpressing it suppresses tumor formation in cancer cells. Mechanistic studies showed that UOR stabilizes a component of the mTOR complex, called DEOR, to inhibit the pathway. In zebraf model, disrupting UOR gene increased mTOR activity and worsened tumor formation caused by a cancer-causing gene. UOR depletion also promoted tumor growth and m signaling in mice with human cancer cells. These findings demonstrate how UOR regulates growth and tumor through mTOR signaling. UOR is a previously unknown gene found only in vertebrates, with no known function despite extensive searches. It encodes a protein with no known domains. Reducing U in brain and nerve cells promotes growth, while depleting in other cells promotes growth, but overexpressing suppresses tumor formation. U interacts with DEOR and m complex to inhibit m signaling. Disrupting U in zraf increased m activity and worsened tumor caused by a cancer gene. U depletion also promoted growth and signaling in mice with human cancer cells.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein interactions in the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypanosomiasis in humans and Nagana in cattle. This parasite is difficult to study because most of its proteins have unknown functions, making it hard to understand its biology and how it causes disease. The researchers used a method called biochemical fractionation to study interactions between over 3,500 proteins in the parasite's early life stage. They found 128 high-confidence interactions involving 716 proteins, including 635 with no known functions. These interactions match known pathways and proteins across the parasite's life cycle, and suggest functions for many uncharacterized proteins. They validated several new proteins involved in RNA editing, a process that regulates the parasite's genes. This study provides a new view of the parasite's protein map and a resource for studying its proteins.

The map is the largest of its kind for trypanid parasites and can help form new hypotheses and leads. To show its usefulness, researchers used it to find new factors in the parasite's gene regulation and validated them with experiments. Trypanid parasites are distant from well-stud organisms like yeast and mammals, making it hard to guess their protein functions. Protein maps help identify functions of unknown proteins.

The study found 791 proteins in the parasite's gene regulation network. A previous study showed a protein's importance in the parasite's blood stage. Researchers used two methods to study protein interactions in the parasite and found many uncharacterized proteins. Predicted complexes matched previous findings. Some complexes are essential in all parasite stages, while others not in the early stage. The parasite has two stages: insect and mammal.
Researchers studied lymph nodes (LN) in macaques infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to understand how the bacteria persist in these organs. LNs are common sites of extrapulmonary tb infection and thoracic LNs are frequently infected in humans, but the dynamics of tb infection in LNs and their function are not well understood. The study used PET scans, bacterial burden, and immune function to analyze thoracic LNs from tb-infected macques. They found that LNs have different trajectories of activity, increasing or decreasing over time, even in the same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to tb than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. However, tb grows to same level in cynolg and rhes mac LNs, but cynolg macques control tb later while rhes do not. LNs are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation, but also persistence of significant numbers of tbilli. 

The study used PET imaging to track inflammation in thoracic L following tb infection and found variation in the number of L infected among macques and differences in pathology and bacterial burden between cynolg and rhes macques. Rhes mac have more infected L, higher burden, and pathology than cynolg macques. Extensive disease can lead to LN enlargement impinging on the airway, lung collapse. The study analyzed thoracic L in tb-infected cynolg andhes mac to identify how tb changes LNs. Found L increased PET-measured activity during infection and necy, almost all FD-avid L contained viable tb or persistent DNA. tb grows same in L of both species, but cynolg L controlled better than rhes. Compared to granulomas in lung, L had limited ability to kill tb.
Researchers have identified 47 new species of microsporidia, a type of fungus that infects animals, and studied their interactions with the nematode Caenorhabis elegans and other related nematodes. Microidia are obligate intracellular parasites, meaning they live inside their hosts, and are poorly understood. Caenorhabis elegans has been a model for studying microidia through its natural pathogen Nematida paris. However, it was unclear how widespread and diverse microidia infections are in Caenorhabis and other nematodes in the wild. The researchers isolated and cultured 47 nemodes with microidian infections. Nematida paris was found to be the most common microidian infecting Caenor in the wild. They also described six new species in the Nematida genus. Phylogenetic analysis identified two subclades distinct from Nematida, named Entersect and Ptospora. Unlike Nematida, these genera belong to the clade of microidia that includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and specifically infect intestinal cells, except Ptos epiga that replicates in the epidermis of Caenor host. At the cellular level, infected spores of Entersect show apical distribution and exit via budding off the membrane, unlike Nemat. Host specificity is broad for some microidia, narrow for others. Some microidia infect Osche but not its sister Osche, and vice versa. Nauseli fails to induce Caenor transcription of genes induced by Nemat species, suggesting evolved mechanisms to prevent host response.
Chemokine receptors, a type of protein receptor, play a crucial role in the immune system and are involved in cancer and HIV infection. Previous studies have shown that chemokine receptors can form homodimers and heteromers, which affect their function. However, little is known about the structure of these homomers and how they interact with cholesterol. This study used computer simulations to investigate homod and heterodimerization of chemine receptors CXCR, CCR, and CCR. The results show that closely related chemine receptors CCR and C2 have similar homodimer patterns, but differ from CXCR. Cholesterol affects homodimer interfaces in a subtype-specific way. Chemine heteromers have distinct patterns, with CX4/5 and CX/2 different from CX/2. Associations between CX and C5 show increased sensitivity to cholesterol compared to CX/2. This study provides a detailed view of the interaction between chemine receptors and how heterodization and environment affects their function.
Researchers have identified a new form of systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, which was previously thought to present with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting. The new form, referred to as "atypical", presents with one or two of these symptoms missing, and other symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and anemia. In a study of 160 patients with depressed immunity, 19.4% were found to have normal laboratory profiles but had macrophages laden with Leish parasites. This suggests systemic lemanis has a wider spectrum of symptoms than previously thought and is more common than previously diagnosed. The disease is not limited to the pediatric age group, as 31 adults were also affected. The researchers recommend considering atypical systemic leishiasis in patients with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Researchers have analyzed millions of genetic mutations and variations in the human genome to understand how they relate to diseases, reactions to medications, and age-related conditions such as brain and cardiovascular issues. They found that predicting the effects of a genetic variation is challenging. A new approach is to look at variations in similar proteins, called paralogs, to identify those with disease-causing effects. This study used a database of known disease-causing variations to identify pairs of variations at the same positions in paralog proteins. The results show that variations in paralog proteins are related and if one is disease-causing, the other is likely to be too. This information can help identify disease-causing variations, improve prioritization procedures, and provide candidates for diagnosis and treatment.

A dataset was used to identify pairs of variations at homolog positions in human genes. Variants co-occur at aligned amino pairs more than expected, suggesting similar constraints on paralog sequences result in coordinated distributions of disease and non-disease variants. Data show paralog genes and variantairs can be used for hypothesis generation and clinical research. Extending to paral genes not associated with disease can identify new candidates and uncharacterized variants with phenotyp consequences.

A collection of disease-causing variations from OM and HG was mapped to genes and sequences. This suggests algorithms based on sequence conservation miss instances. Paralog human might provide in silico characterization, complementary to approaches like SIFT and PolyPhen. Rare disease variants in paralog tend to pair. Alignments provide a resource for genomics.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of the malaria parasite Plasium falciparum in people with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua New Guinea. They used a technique called RNA sequencing to analyze the parasite's genes in 44 cases of severe and uncomplicated malaria. The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had changes in their gene expression, including a decrease in glycolysis, altered chromatin structure, and reduced expression of surface antigens called Pf1. These antigens are targets of protective immunity. The study also found associations between disease severity and Pf1 transcripts, domains, and smaller segments, and confirmed previous associations between expressed Pf1 sequences and disease. The findings can help identify targets for severe malaria vaccines and how parasites adapt to the host environment in severe malaria. 

The study differed from previous reports of increased expression of genes involved in Pf1 surface in severe malaria. However, 17 genes were downregulated, including skeleton protein 1, involved in Pf surface expression. Severe patients had lower levels of antibodies to Pf1 and recognized fewer Pf1 than uncomplicated patients. Parasites were older in uncomplicated patients, who had more immunity to Pf1 than severe patients. Severe had downregulated genes in Pf surface expression. Antigens encountered early in life are recognized by sera from immune children than uncomplicated. Expression of conserved Pf1 by severe parasites explains rapid immunity to severe than uncomplicated.
Researchers tested a new approach to prevent HIV infection by delivering antibodies through a virus-like particle called AAV directly into rhesus monkeys. The antibodies, called mAbs, were delivered in IgG form and persisted at high levels of up to 270 micrograms per milliliter in the monkeys. However, the monkeys' immune systems responded to the delivered antibodies in 9 out of 12 cases, limiting the amount of antibody that could be achieved. This resulted in a wide range of delivered antibody concentrations from 1-270 micrograms per millil. Despite this, six monkeys in the AAV-L Ig1 group showed protective effects against the difficult-to-neutralize SIV239 virus after repeated intravenous challenge. The effects included lower peak viral load, lower viral set point, and delay in time to peak viral load. These effects were statistically significant. One monkey with the highest antibody level resisted six successive SIV239 challenges, including a final challenge of 10 infectious units. The study shows promise for this approach to prevent HIV infection, but immune responses to the antibodies need to be understood for it to be effective.
Researchers studied the way proteins myosin and kinesin K1 respond to changes in their structure, such as when a ligand binds or detaches. They used a simplified model to analyze the proteins' conformational motions and found that the traditional assumption of a linear response is not accurate. This is especially true for kines K1, where the linear model fails to describe the protein's mechanical movements. The study suggests that the current understanding of protein dynamics may need to be revised. 

The researchers looked at the conformation changes in myos and kines K1 when a ligand binds or detaches. They used a simplified model to analyze the proteins' conformation motions and found that the traditional assumption of linear response is not accurate. This is especially true for kines K1, where the linear model fails to describe the protein's movements. The study suggests the understanding of protein dynamics may need to be revised.
Researchers have investigated the interaction between different endocytic pathways, specifically clathrin-independent endocytosis. They found that caveolins and cavin proteins, components of caveolae, regulate this process. Caveolin-1 and cavin-3, but not cavin-2 or cavin-4, inhibit the clath-independent/GPIAP enriched early endosomal (CL/GEE) endytic pathway. This occurs independently of caveol formation. Overexpression of caveolin and cavin leads to a reduction in CL/GEE carriers, detected by electron microscopy. The CL/G pathway is upregulated in cells lacking caveolin/cavin or with reduced cavin and cavin. Inhibition by caveol can be mimicked by the caveolin scaffolding domain, associated with perturbed lipid diffusion, revealed by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. Without caveol, caveolin is endocyted through the CL/G pathway, but loses polarization and sorting, affecting membrane dynamics and endytic in migrating cells and muscle tissue. Non-cave cavin-1 acts as a modulator of the CL/G regulator, C42. This study provides new insights into regulation of non-cave clath-independent endocyt by cave proteins, illustrating multiple levels of interaction between pathways. It shows a role for cavin in the CL/G pathway, a tool to study this pathway, and cave-independent functions of cavin, and a mechanism for inhibition of CL/G by caveolin.
Researchers have identified a new type of signaling system in bacteria and plants called Aspart-L Receiver (AL) domains. These domains are part of two-component signaling systems that help cells sense and respond to their environment. Unlike typical systems, AL domains don't have a conserved aspartate (Asp) residue, which is usually phosphorylated by a histidine kinase. The study found that AL domains are common and often attached to rare effector proteins. Analysis of AL structures and data showed that AL have reorganized their active sites to take on a constitutive role or accommodate signals other than phosphorylation. This defines AL as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into activation mechanisms between AL and REC domains.

The study found that most AL substitutions at the conserved phospho-As site are serine, threonine, and tyrosine, which are known to be phosphorylated by bacterial kinases. Some AL domains diversified to accommodate inputs like small molecules and serine phosphorylation through bacterial kinases and phosphatases, regulating cell envelope functions and virulence in microbes. Of 74,816 REC-containing proteins, 2,976 were missing or had substitutions at the conserved position, indicating up to 4% of domains don't have this residue. The subset was renamed Aspart-L Receivers (AL). AL sequences comprise 4% of all domains in bacteria and were defined as the Aspart-L Receiver (AL) domain of atypical RECs. 63 AL harbor arginine at the typical phosph-As position, which can be phosphorylated by kinases and phosphatases. The most common substitution was cysteine, sensing environmental changes in redox state.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes virus (OV) that targets cancer cells with a specific protein called HER2, which is found in many types of cancer. This virus is different from others because it is fully virulent, meaning it can cause an immune response in the body. They tested this new virus in mice with cancer and found it was safe and effective. The virus, called R115, was more effective than the other version, R113, in stopping the growth of the primary tumor and preventing the growth of new tumors in other parts of the body. The mice that survived the primary tumor were also protected from new tumors in other parts of the body. Analysis showed that R115 changed the environment around the tumor, making it harder for cancer to grow, and increased certain immune cells that fight cancer. The response was long-lasting and showed that the body's immune system learned to recognize and fight cancer cells with HER2 protein.
Researchers investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. They found that CD4 cells induced by the Adenovirus 5 (Ad) vector in a clinical trial were susceptible to HIV, but those induced by the ALVAC (canarypox) vector in another trial were less susceptible. The ALAC-specific CD4 cells had lower expression of HIV entry receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 and a Th1 phenotype with high IFN-γ and CCL4 (MIP-1) but low IL-17. In contrast, Ad5 and ALAC induced different CD8 and CD4 cell responses, with ALAC preferring CD8 and Ad CD4 proliferation. Depletion of ALAC CD8 cells increased HIV infection of ALAC CD4 cells, suggesting a protective role of ALAC CD8 cells. The study highlights the importance of evaluating vector responses in HIV vaccination.
Researchers studied how the evolution of X chromosome inactivation, a process where one X chromosome is silenced in female cells, in mammals. They found that the choice of which X to silence varies among species. Some species have strict paternal X inactivation (PX), where females are haploid for maternal alleles, while others have random X inactivation (RX), where both maternal and paternal alleles are equally expressed. The team analyzed how dominance, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence X inactivation evolution. They found that a single interaction between dominance and sex-differential selection can lead to a range of inactivation strategies, including unequal expression between maternal and paternal X chromosomes. RX is favored over PX when alleles are recessive to females, but is more restrictive when variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolution from PX to RX increases female fitness at the expense of male fitness. The study provides a framework for predicting X-linked gene expression and makes predictions for future studies on allele variation.

 Species properties and genetic variation affect X inactivation patterns. Sexual selection and mutation rates vary, influencing transmission of deleterious alleles between maternal and paternal X. X is a female-limited trait, so selection favors inactivation of the chromosome with more deleterious alleles. The team tested this by analyzing evolutionary stability of X strategies. Sex-differential selection, where fitness differs between males and females, affects large parts of the genome, can influence X diversification. Stronger selection against males than females decreases paternal X deleterious alleles. They also examined if sex-differential favors biased inactivation, unequal expression of maternal and paternal X. Results suggest conditions for biased inactivation are permissive.
Researchers investigated the antiviral potential of the host protein ZAP against three flaviviruses: Japanese encephalitis (JEV), dengue (DENV), and Zika (ZIK). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, but not DENV or ZIK, and depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3-5' exosome-mediated degradation. The zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and antiv activity against JEV. The 3'-UTR, especially the region with dumbbell structures and high content of dinucleotide, was mapped to bind Z and confer sensitivity to Z. The study identified J as the first Z-sensitive flavivirus. Z may act as intrinsic antiv factor through RNA binding against J infection. The researchers also found that the zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and antiv activity against J infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a significant pathogen that causes severe disease in humans and animals, particularly in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Researchers studied the immune response to wild-type and vaccine strains of RVV in mice to understand its pathogenesis. Mice infected with a live-attenuated vaccine survived with minimal disease and cytokine response, while wild-type infection was lethal, causing lymphocyte and platelet depletion and a strong cytokine response. The virus was found in the liver, with significant clinical and histological data supporting this. However, a pro-inflammatory response in the liver was not seen, but a chemokine response indicating immune cell infiltration was present. In the brain, a chemok and cytokine response was evident, but little pathology. The study suggests RVV pathogenesis in mice is liver failure due to necrosis and hepatitis, with long-term disease being neurologic, supported by human and mouse model observations.
Chemotherapy resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a significant challenge for improving patient survival. Researchers investigated the mechanisms of taxane chemoresistance in TNBC and found that C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20) is elevated during tax-containing chemotherapy in patients with non-pathologic response. C20 promotes self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCS) through protein kinase Cζ (PKζ) or mitogen-activated protein (MAP)-mediated activation of nuclear factor B (NF-κ) pathway, increasing taxane resistance of BC. C20 also increases ATP-binding subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug 1 (DR) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxane. Results suggest chemotherapy-induced C20 mediated chemoresis via upregulating CB1. NF-activation C20, forming a positive loop between NF- and C pathways, sustaining chemores in cancer cells. C20 can be a predictive marker for taxane response, and blocking C or its pathway may reverse tax resistance in breast cancer.
Toxoplas gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, infects virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Its ability to infect and manipulate host cells depends on transporting "GRA" proteins from secretory organelles called dense granules into host cells. GRAs have diverse roles in Toxopla's lifecycle, including hijacking host functions like cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRAs, like GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into parasitoph vacuole (PV) where Toop replicates and transported across PV membrane (PVM) into host, but translocation process and machinery are unclear. A previous study showed TMY1, cleaved by TASP into fragments, localizes PVM and is essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional proteins for effector transport, Toopla mutants defective in cyc-regulation were screened for ability to export GRA and GRA to host nucleus. Novel MY2 and MY3 play crucial role in translocation subset GR into host. MY2 and MY3 are secreted PV and co-localize with PVM and MY1. Consistent with transmembrane domains, all are membrane-associated, MY3 but MY stably with MY1, N-terminal and C-terminal disulf-linked. Fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to structured DH domain blocks transport, consistent trans-based model effector transport.
Researchers studied how a virus called papillomavirus (PV) replicates, or makes copies of itself, inside cells. They found that the virus's E2 protein binds to a host protein called origin recognition complex (ORC), which helps initiate DNA replication. However, ORC was not found at the viral origin, where replication starts. Depleting ORC increased PV replication in some cells, but not in others. This suggests ORC is not necessary for E2 to start replication, but instead suppresses its function. The study also found that high levels of E2 can prevent ORC from binding to host DNA, where it's needed for replication. This means ORC and E2 work together to control viral replication, especially in the amplification stage, where many copies are made.
Researchers investigated the presence of Brucella bacteria in the milk of cows in urban and peri-urban areas of Dush, Tajikistan. They found that 10.3% of 564 milk samples tested positive for Bruc DNA using a real-time PCR test. This is concerning because unpasteurified dairy products are commonly consumed in the region. Bruc DNA was detected in the milk of all seropositive cows, but also in 8.3% of seronegative cows. Sequence analysis suggested one cow was infected with B. abortus and another likely infected with B. melensis. The study highlights the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false negatives in Bruc surveillance and control programs. Vaccination of cattle with S19 and small ruminants Rev1 may be necessary to control Bruc infections, but further research is needed to understand Brella circulating in the region.
Researchers studied the role of histone H3 lysine methylation in maintaining chromosome stability in the fungus Zoseptoria trici. This fungus has eight accessory chromosomes that are unstable during meiosis and mitosis, and are transcriptionally repressed, with high enrichment of repetitive elements and heterochromatin marks, such as trimethylation of H3 lysine 9 or lys 27 (H3me3, H3me). To understand the impact of heterochatin on genome stability, the researchers deleted genes encoding the methyltransferases responsible for H3me and Hme, and generated a double mutant. They used experimental and genomic analyses to determine the impact of these deletions on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-q and RNA-seq were used to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure and differences in expression between mutant and wild-type strains. Results showed dramatic chromatin reorganization in Hme-deficient strains, with Hme mostly localized in regions with Hme in wild-type. Many rearrangements and formation of new chromosomes were found in Hme absence, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss Hme increased stability of accessory chromosomes under normal conditions in vitro, without large changes in gene activity. The study found that Hme is important for maintaining genome stability by preventing Hme in constitutive heterochatin regions. This reduces overall stability of accessory chromosomes, creating a "metable state for quasi-essential regions of the genome.
Researchers evaluated the cost-effectiveness of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies vaccination in low-income countries, where life-saving vaccines are often inaccessible and unaffordable to those most at risk. They found PEP to be an extremely cost-effective intervention, with a cost of less than $60 per death averted. Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) administration of P resulted in significant savings, reducing vaccine shortages and costs. To make P more accessible, financing mechanisms could subsidize costs for those in need and support existing rabies prevention programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility, leading to reduced rabies deaths and economical healthcare costs.

The study examined costs of IM versus ID administration in different settings, demonstrating ID to be more cost-effective in averting rab cases and lives. Clinic capacity affects vial sharing and cost-effectiveness. Rabies post-exposure vaccination is essential but out of reach for many, with shortages in developing countries and victims traveling long distances for vaccine, incurring costs and facing delays. Changes in P costs could improve affordability, providing incentives without compromising health budgets. Issues should be considered in P policy design to reduce rabies burden, increasing vaccines for the poor who bear the brunt in developing countries.

The researchers calculated cost-effectiveness in terms of dollars per death averted, including direct medical costs from the health provider's perspective. They found P to be cost-effective, with a cost-effectiveness ratio of less than $200 per death averted.
Toxoplas, an obligate intracellular parasite, replicates within mammalian cells in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One mechanism for nutrient acquisition is attracting host organelles to the PV. This study examines the exploitation of lipid droplets (LD), fat storage organelles, by Toxoplas. Toxoplas replication is reduced in cells depleted of LD or impaired lipolysis or fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, host LD number and LD-associated gene expression (AP, DG2) increase until parasite replication onset. PV are surrounded by host LD. Toxoplas accesses host lipids in LD and incorporates them into its membranes and LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis in host, resulting in large LD accumulation inside parasite. Tooplas intercepts and internalizes host LD, some associated with Rab7, wrapped by intravacolar network (IV) membranes. Mutants impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD in PV, suggesting IV's major role in LD processing and lipid release. Lipid gavage unveils Tooplas endytic structures containing material from PV lumen. This study highlights Tooplas reliance on LD for intracellular development and scavenging lipids from LD.
Researchers have identified a new compounds called chalcones that can inhibit the growth of Fasciola hepatica, a parasite that causes a disease in cattle and sheep. This parasite is considered an emerging zoonotic disease, meaning it can be transmitted from animals to humans. Currently, the main treatment is chemotherapy with the drug tricendazole, but resistance has been reported in several countries, making it urgent to find new treatments. The researchers searched a library of 40 flavonoids and found chalcones with phenyl and napht groups to be good inhibitors of the parasite's cystine proteases. One compound, C34, was found to bind to the enzyme FCL with an IC50 of 5.6 μM and is a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the enzyme's catalytic site. In vitro, C34 reduced the parasite's ability to migrate through the gut and caused death within a week, but was not toxic to bovine cells. This is the first report of non-peptide inhibitors of Fasciola catheps and opens avenues for developing new treatments for fluke infections and other helminthic diseases.
Researchers investigated how the visual system transmits information about fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. They used in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells transmit signals to the retina and found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filtering. Individual cells transmit through terminals of varying size, but smaller terminals generate faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Smaller terminals transmit higher frequencies more effectively. Modeling calcium dynamics of ves release indicated that variations in presynaptic compartments contribute directly to these differences in response.

Measurements of presynaptic calcium showed a strong rectifying function of light intensity, causing a graded increase in calcium with contrast. Voltage-dependent channels in the terminal of bipolar cells are responsible for the non-linear transformation of the signal. Variations in presaptic calcium impact the output of the synapse, with smaller terminals responding to light with higher release rates but resolution too low to detect modulations at frequencies over 1 Hz.

The next compartment in the pathway, the terminal of bipolar cells, showed rectification in output due to increase in stimulus causing increase in release rate even with constant luminance. To quantify time-dependent changes in gain, an "Adaptation" index was used, calculated as the ratio of peak response to steady-state. The model predicted rate of release would depress more in smaller terminals. Whole-cell recordings from goldfish retina showed presaptic signals in large and small compartments while controlling the terminal.
Researchers have developed a new method to detect and analyze individual synapses in the brain using fluorescence microscopy images. Synapses are the tiny connections between brain cells that allow them to communicate. Current methods to study synapses have limitations: fluorescence microscopy is fast and cheap but hard to distinguish between synapses and non-synaptic signals, while electron microscopy is reliable but slow and expensive. The new method, called probabilistic synapse detection, uses a combination of fluorescence and electron microscopy images to identify synapses. It takes into account molecular and morphological features of synapses and provides a map of probability of each voxel being part of a synapse. The researchers tested the method on human brain data and found it detected synapses as accurately as human annotators and reproduced known features of syn distributions. This opens the door to discovering new synapse types and density. The method can also be applied to standard and super-resolution fluorescence images where electron microscopy is not practical.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of action of ZnT, a protein responsible for accumulating zinc in secretory vesicles and releasing it into breast milk during lactation. They found that Zn2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter, meaning it uses a proton gradient to transport zinc into vesicles. This was demonstrated through experiments using Bafomycin A, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar protonase that alkalizes vesicles, which abolished Zn2-dependent zinc transport into vesicles. Additionally, using Lyso Red and Ly-pfluorin, they showed that upon Zn2 overexpression in vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc, vesicles underwent alkalization due to proton-zinc antiport, which was reversed in the presence of TP, a zinc chelator. Computational calculations suggest Zn2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2H+/Zn+ ion. This means Zn2 is a motive-driven, electrutral ves zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to cytoplasm.
Researchers have discovered a new role for 14-3 proteins in maintaining genome stability during DNA replication. They found that 14-3 proteins interact with Exonuclease 1 (Exo), an enzyme that processes stalled replication forks in yeast and mammalian cells. Without 14-3 proteins, Ex1 is hyperphosphorylated, leading to accumulation of single-stranded DNA gaps at forks. This causes persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. Using DNA electrophoresis, researchers showed that 14-3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide conditions. They propose that 14-3 assist in controlling Ex1 phosphorylation status and additional targets, promoting fork stability and restart in response to DNA stress.
Researchers studied the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They found that pDC are critical in producing type I interferons (IF-I), which suppress HIV-1 replication. However, p also contribute to HIV-induced immunopathogenesis by promoting death of human leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. A monoclonal antibody was developed to deplete p in lymphoid organs of humanized mice. When p were depleted before HIV-1 infection, IF-I and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) were abolished, and HIV-1 replication increased. In chronic infection, p depletion reduced IF-I and IS, but increased HIV replication. Interestingly, p depletion reduced death of human cells in lymphoid organs, but not blood, despite increased replication. The study suggests p play opposing roles in suppressing HIV-1 replication and promoting HIV-induced immunogenesis. Findings suggest p-depletion and IF-I blockade as novel strategies for treating HIV non-responsive patients with immune activation despite antiretroviral treatment.
Researchers have discovered that sulforaphane (SF), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, can inhibit HIV infection in macrophages, a type of immune cell that plays a key role in the body's defense against the virus. This is the first time it has been shown that SF blocks HIV infection in these cells, but not in other types of immune cells. The study found that SF works by activating a protein called nuclear erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2), which is also activated by other viruses such as Marburg, Kapos's sarcoma herpes and Dengue. When Nrf is activated, it reprograms gene expression in the cell, making it harder for HIV to infect. Depleting Nrf with siRNA increased HIV infectivity in macroages and reduced the anti-viral effects of SF treatment. This suggests that Nrf is key to SF's anti-viral activity. SF blocks HIV infection after reverse transcription, but before formation of 2-L circles, similar to type I interferon-induced proteins SAM1 and MX. However, these proteins were not upregulated. The study found that Nrf can potently block HIV infection and highlights a new way to trigger this inhibition.
A cross-sectional study in rural Kenya found that 76.2% of pregnant women were infected with at least one geohelth, with 52.3% with Ascaris lumicoid, 39.5 with hookworm, and 29 with Trichuris trura. Infection with at least geelth was associated with using an unprotected water source (OR 1.8, 95% CI 1.1-3) and lack of treated drinking water (OR 1.8, 95 CI 1.1-3). Geelth infections were not associated with symptoms or low body mass. Hookworm infection was associated with lower upper arm circumference (mean -0.7 cm, 95 CI 0.3-1.2). Hookworm with egg count 100/gram was associated lower hemoglobin (mean -1.5 g/dl, 95 0.3-2.7). Pregnant women 2 and 3 with A lumicoid were less likely to have malaria (OR 0.4, 95 0.2-0.8) compared to without A lumoid. Geel infections are common in this population, but few effects were observed. Routine antelmin treatment during antenatal visit is recommended, but evaluation of impact on pregnancy, malaria, and outcome useful.
Mycolone, a compound produced by the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been found to have anti-inflammatory effects on the nervous system. Research has shown that mycolone blocks the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells, leading to its analgesic and immunomodulatory properties. This study investigated myone's effects on inflammatory responses of nervous cells involved in pain perception and transmission, as well as neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain. Sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia were isolated from mice to assess myone cytotoxicity and immunomod activity. Results showed that prolonged exposure to myone induced cell death at concentrations >10ng/ml, but nanolar concentrations suppressed pro-inflammatory mediator production without affecting viability. Notably, myone prevented pro-inflammatory polarization of microglia, which contribute to neuroflamm. In a rat model of neuropathic pain, myone injected in the spinal canal decreased local inflammatory cytokine production without cytotoxicity. This study provides evidence that myone suppresses inflammatory responses of neurons, Schw cells, and microia without affecting viability, supporting previous studies suggesting myone analgesia is partially due to anti-inflammatory properties.
Researchers studied the genetic factors that influence the outcome of African trypanosomiasis, a disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambense, in humans in West Africa. They analyzed DNA samples from 425 individuals from Guinea, including 232 with the disease, 79 with a history of exposure but no symptoms, and 114 without the disease. The team looked at 28 genetic variations in 8 genes and found that one, IL6 rs1819, was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease. Another, MIF36071, was linked to increased risk but did not remain significant after correction. MIF12459 was associated with latent infection. They confirmed previous findings that AP1G2 was linked to higher risk and AP1 to lower risk of developing the disease. No associations were found with other genes. The study shows that genetics play a role in controlling Tryosoma bruce gambense infection and may lead to new tools for control.
Researchers have conducted whole-genome sequencing of 38 individuals from the Singapore Indian population to gain insights into the genetic diversity of South Asians. These individuals are primarily descendants of immigrants from Dravid-language-speaking states in south India and were compared to samples from the Singapore Malay population and the 1,000 Genomes Project. The study found that the Indian samples had greater genetic diversity and a higher heterozygous-to-homozygous ratio than other Asian populations. When compared to a panel of well-defined Indians, the samples were closely related but distinct from Europeans in autosomal SNPs. However, they had mitochondrial haplogroups and higher European admixture. Analysis of relatedness to archaic humans Denisovan and Neanderthal showed higher ancient admixture in East populations than the Indians. The data is publicly available and complements Asian samples in the 1,000 Genomes Project.
Researchers studied the genetic basis of antibiotic resistance in Burkholderia pseudallei isolates from Thailand. They found that most isolates are resistant to aminoglycosides and macrolides due to the AmABpr efflux pump. However, three isolates 708, 218, and 379 were susceptible to these antibiotics. Quantitative PCR showed that isolate 708 had no Amr transcripts, while 218 and 379 had reduced levels. When exposed to gentamicin, 218 and 379 became resistant to other aminoglyides and macides, but 708 did not. Transcript analysis revealed that resistance in 218 and 379 was due to upregulation of Ampr expression by unknown mechanisms. PCR showed that the Ampr operon was missing in 708, associated with a large deletion of genetic material. Rescuing the Ampr region from a library and sequencing revealed a 131-141 kb deletion in 708 compared to other strains. This deletion removed not only Ampr but also genes for malleactin and cobal synthesis and other genes. Whole genome analysis confirmed absence of these genes in 708. Despite missing virulence genes, 708 was virulent in a murine model.
Researchers studied how CD4 T helper cells, a type of immune cell, differentiate into Th1 or Th2 states. They found that these cells can express both Th1 and Th2 markers at the same time, not just one or the other. This is different from previous studies where cells were forced to choose between Th1 or Th2. Cytokines, signaling molecules from outside the cell, play a key role in this process. The team found that only a small group of cells express cytokines, and this is not related to the level of Th1 or Th markers inside the cell. This variation in cytokine expression is higher in early stages of differentiation than later on. When cytok signaling is blocked, Th1 and Th markers are mutually exclusive, showing that intracellular factors are overruled by extracellular signals. This suggests that CD4 cells acquire a mixed Th1/2 state early on, influenced by cytokines from outside. The study reveals interplay between extracellular and intracellular components in Th1/2 differentiation, a common strategy for cells to handle noisy cytokine expression.
In the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, the protein PAQR-2 plays a crucial role in adapting to low temperatures by regulating fatty acid desaturation. PA-2 is similar to insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors in mammals and is essential for growth at 15°C, a temperature that is usually not suitable for the organism. Researchers screened for PA-2 suppressors and found mutations in genes involved in phosphatidcholine synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. They found that PA-2, phosphidcholines, and Δ-9 desaturases form a pathway that increases unsaturated fatty acids to maintain membrane fluidity at low temperatures. This is supported by observations that PA-2 suppressors normalize saturated fatty acid levels and low detergents that increase fluidity can rescue PA-2 mutants.

 PA-2 is a transmembrane receptor that regulates fatty acid metabolism during cold adaptation. Mutants show abnormal fatty acid composition, excess lipid droplets, and are lethal with mutations in genes that promote fatty turnover. PA-2 increases unsaturation is essential for adaptation to 15°C in C. elegans. The study suggests PA-2 is a transmembrane protein regulating Δ-9 desases via phosphcholine and sb-1 during cold adaptation.
Researchers have used electron microscopy to study the structure of herpes simplex type-1 (HSV-1) virus particles. They found a previously unknown feature at the vertex of the virus, which connects the capsid to the viral membrane. This feature is similar to the tail of bacteriophages, which are viruses that infect bacteria. Bacterophages have a tail that helps them deliver their DNA into the bacterial cell. The HSV-1 virus also needs to deliver its DNA into human cells, so this tail-like feature may play a role in that process. 

HSV-1 is a common virus that causes cold sores and other diseases. It has a complex structure with a protein and DNA, surrounded by a protein layer, and a lipid envelope. Scientists thought HSV didn't need a tail because it infects human cells, not bacteria. However, the delivery of DNA into human cells is similar to delivery into bacteria. 

The HSV-1 particle is about 155-240 nanometers long, with a 125 nanometer diameter. It has pentons, hexons, and triplexes that make up its structure.
Researchers studied how the Schistosoma mansoni parasite's soluble egg antigen (SEA) affects HIV-1 infection in the body. They found that SEA can block HIV-1 from entering cells by binding to a protein on immune cells called DCIGN. When immune cells were exposed to SEA, they produced less of a protein called IFN-γ, which helps fight infection. This made them less susceptible to HIV-1 infection. However, SEA did not affect HIV-4 infection. The study also showed that a protein called omega-1, similar to SEA, had the same effect on immune cells, making them less susceptible to HIV-1. This could be important for people co-infected with both parasites and HIV, as it may help reduce disease progression. The study suggests that helminthic infections, like Schosoma mansoni, may have a protective effect against HIV-1. The researchers also found that immune cells exposed to SEA produced less of a protein called MIP-1, which helps fight infection, and had less of a protein called CCR5 on their surface, which HIV uses to enter cells.
Researchers have discovered that neural stimulation causes a 30% shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and astrocytes in grey and white matter under experimental conditions. This phenomenon is crucial for understanding basic aspects of potassium clearance and astrocyte function, but remains unexplained. A new model is presented that accounts for experimental data related to shrinkage in wild-type and gene knockout individuals. The model shows that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride, and passive channels of the Na/KATP pump, and osmotically transport of water through the astrocyte membrane are sufficient for shrinkage. However, taking into account ECS and astrocy ion concentrations with neuronal stimulation, the actions of the Na+/Cl (NK1) and NaHCO (NBC) cotransporters are critical for achieving observed levels of shrink. The model is sufficiently detailed to guide future experiments and pave the way for comprehensive astroglia-neuron models in normal and pathophysiological situations.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism for silencing transposons and repetitive DNA elements in plant genomes. These elements can be detrimental to the organism if expressed. In Arabidopsis thaliana, they are silenced by the siRNA-mediated transcriptional silencing pathway, where non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) produced by RNA Polymerase V (Pol) guide ARGONA4 (AGO) to chromatin and enzymes that establish repressive chrom modifications. It was unknown how chromatin enzymes are recruited to chrom. The study found that SPTLTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of S5 elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcription silencing. This occurs downstream of RNAase V but independently of 24-nt siRNA. SPTLTF and AGO are recruited to chrom in parallel and independently of each other. Methylation restriction enzymes show that binding of AGO and SPTLTF is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at several loci. The researchers propose that SPT and AGO create a platform for direct or indirect recruitment of chrom modifying enzymes.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Rpo regulon in the tick phase of the Borrelia burgdorferi life cycle, a bacterium that causes Lyme disease. They found that Rpo-dependent gene expression is necessary for the transmission of spirochetes by nymphs. Without Rpo, the spchet are confined to the midgut and transform into unusual round bodies during the later stages of the blood meal. This transformation is reversible and appears to be caused by reduced levels of Coenzyme disulf reductase, which provides NAD for glycolysis. The study suggests that spiroes default to an Rpo-independent program for round formation when energy for transmission is unfavorable. The Rpo regul is important during the tick phase of the cycle, but the spchete's transcriptome in ticks is not yet understood. Rpo is induced during the nymph blood meal but not in larvae or unfed nymphs, indicating a specific ON/OFF regulation. Expression of Rpo-dependent genes in ticks is more complex than a simple ON/OFF switch. The study reveals a new role for RSB in tick-to-mamm transmission and a default mode of round formation when spiroes can't produce energy for dissemination.
Researchers studied how gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) hormones control the growth of the stamen in Arabidopsis flowers. GA and JA are important for flower development, but their relationship is not well understood. The team found three MYB genes, MY21, MY24, and MY57, are controlled by GA. Without GA, these genes are not expressed, leading to short stamen and male sterility. They showed that GA breaks down DELLA proteins, which suppresses MYB expression. Without GA, DEL accumulates and suppresses MYB. The team also found that GA promotes JA production, which is necessary for MYB expression. In GA-deficient plants, JA is lower than normal. A triple mutant of MY21, MY24, and MY57 resulted in short stamen and sterility. Exogenous JA restored MY expression and st growth in GA-deficient plants, but exogenous GA did not. This suggests that GA regulates JA pathway to control MYB. The study shows a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA in stamen development.
Researchers investigated the role of hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in lifespan extension caused by dietary restriction (DR) in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that a deficiency in H-1 resulted in extended lifespan, similar to inhibition of the RSK-1/S6 kinase, a key component of the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway. Using a modified DR method, they showed that H-1 modulates longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner. H- loss-of-function extended lifespan under rich conditions but failed to show extension under DR. Conversely, a mutation in egl-9, which increases H- activity, diminished lifespan under DR. This effect was rescued by tissue-specific expression ofegl-9 in neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by H- was dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inos-requiring-1 (IRE-1) and associated with lower ER stress. The study suggests a tissue-specific role for H- in lifespan extension by the IRE-ER pathway.
Researchers have discovered that human skin cells called keratinocytes can change their behavior in response to different situations, such as when they differentiate or migrate.
