The study proposes pneumys plays a role in pneumoc mening by initiating glut release from astrocytes, leading to damage. This is the first demonstration of synaptic pathology in pneumoc mening and shows a bacterial toxin can disrupt glut control in the brain, causing damage.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are viruses that cause major human cancers, and researchers are developing new ways to prevent them, such as vaccines and microbicides. To do this, they need to understand the life cycle of HPVs. The HPV life cycle is linked to the state of the skin cells it infects, and the virus is only made in the final stage of cell division. It's known that HPV first infects the bottom layer of skin cells, but why this wasn't clear. This might be because of specific entry receptors, but that doesn't explain why some cells can be infected in a single layer. Researchers used biology to show that cell division is key for HPV. They used HPV particles with a full genome, synchronized skin cells, and watched for early gene expression. The cells must enter the first stage of division for HPV to infect. Late stage inhibitors had no effect, but early, middle, and final stages prevented infection. Cells must pass the first stage for successful HPV to start. This is why HPVs infect the bottom layer of skin, as only these cells divide. This discovery has implications for controlling HPVs.
Researchers have identified microRNA-like RNAs (milRNAs) in the dimorphic fungus Penicillium marneffi, which is a major cause of systemic mycosis in China and Southeast Asia. milRNAs play a crucial role in regulating gene expression in animals and plants, but their function in fungi was not well understood. The team used high-throughput sequencing to find milRN in mycelial and yeast phases of P. marffei and found 24 potential candidates, with 17 in mycel and 7 in yeast. Two genes, d-1 and d-2, encoding Dicer-like proteins, and q-2 encoding Argonaute, were identified. Phylogenetic analysis showed d-2 of P. marffei is closely related to homologs in other dimorphic pathogenic fungi, suggesting co-evolution. d-2 among thermal fungi. d-2 showed higher expression in mycel than yeast by 7-fold. Northern analysis confirmed expression of two milRN, PMil-M1 and PMil-M2, only in mycel. Knockout mutants showed biogenesis of milRN dependent on d-2 but not d- or q-. Targets of PMil-M were upregulated in knockdown PMilKD, supporting regulatory function of milRN. This is the first report of milRN in a thermal dim pathogenic fungus and differential expression in mycel and yeast.
Zika virus (ZIK) emerged in French Polynes in 2013 and spread through the Pacific between 2013 and 2017. Several Aedes mosquitoes may have contributed to ZIK transmission, including Aedes aegypt, the main vector in the region, and Aedes polynensis, vector of lymphatic filariasis and secondary vector deng virus. This study analyzed the ability of these vectors to transmit ZIK at a regional scale by comparing the competence of wild Ae. aegypt and Ae. polensis populations from Pacific islands for ZIK strain circulated during 2013-2017 outbreak. Field Ae. aegypt (three) and Ae. polensis (two) populations from Pacific were collected. Female mosquitoes were exposed to ZIK (107 TCID/mL) isolated in 2014. At 6, 9, 14, and 21 days post-infection, mosquito bodies, thorax and abdomen, and heads were analyzed to measure infection, dissemination, rates, and transmission, respectively. Results showed ZIK infection rates were heterogeneous between Ae. aegpt populations, but dissemination rates were moderate and homogenous between these. Ae. polensis infection rates were less heterogeneous between two tested populations. Transmission efficiency revealed low competence for ZIK of different Ae vector populations. Results indicated low ZIK transmission by Ae.egti and Ae. polensis from Pacific region. This was unexpected, suggesting other factors, such as vector density, lifespan, or immunologically naive fraction of population, contributed to rapid spread of ZIK in Pacific during 201-2017 outbreak.
Researchers have developed a new method called Targeted Structure-Seq to study the structure of non-coding RNA (nc) Xist, a key regulator of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. This method combines chemical probing of RNA structure with massively parallel sequencing to provide high coverage of the target RNA with few reads, making it a targeted and scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells. They used Targeted-StructureSeq to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA and developed new models for functional elements within X, including the repeat element at the 5' end of X. The analysis also identified new structural elements in X that are evolutionarily conserved, such as an element proximal to the repeats that is important for X function. The study demonstrates the utility of Targeted-Seq to study lnc conformation in mammalian cells and expect it to be useful for advancing mechanistic understanding of lRNAs.
Researchers have identified many genetic variants associated with complex diseases, but it's unclear if using genomic profiles to predict risk will be clinically useful. To evaluate the performance of genetic prediction models, new statistical measures are needed. Previous studies mainly used the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) to judge the value of genetic tests, but it has limitations and should be complemented by other measures. This study develops a unifying framework that connects various predictive indices. Given the overall disease probability and level of variance in liability (heritability) explained by variants, it's possible to estimate a range of metrics, such as AUC, mean difference between cases and non-cases, net reclassification, proportion of cases at highest risk, variance of predicted risks, and risk at any percentile. Graphs can also be constructed to visualize performance, like ROC, risk density, and predictiveness curves. Simulations match theoretical estimates. The framework is applied to nine diseases, evaluating predictive power of genetic tests based on known variants.
Researchers developed a new rapid diagnostic test for Trypanosoma brucei gambense infection, a parasite that causes African trypanosomiasis, a disease that affects 70 million people in sub-Saharan Africa. The test uses recombinant antigens, which are easier to produce than the native antigens used in current tests. The study compared the new test, called SDOL HAT 2.0, to the current test SDOLAT and the Cardagglutination Test Trypanosomias (CATT). The tests were used on 57,632 people in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with 260 confirmed cases of trypaniasis. The new test was most sensitive, detecting 71.2% of cases, followed by ATT 62.5% and SDAT 59%. The ATT was most specific, 99.2%, while SDOL and SDOL 2.0 were 98.9 and 98.1%. The tests were more sensitive in passive screening, where people were tested at health centers, than active, where teams went to people. Combining tests increased sensitivity: SDOL and SDOL 2.0 reached 98.4% in passive and 83% active. The new test was as sensitive and specific as SDAT, but less specific than ATT. Using multiple tests may improve diagnosis, but decrease specificity.
Chagas disease, a neglected tropical disease affecting millions of Latin Americans, has been controlled in most of Guatemala through indoor insecticide spraying. However, a few areas with persistent Triatoma infestation remain. One such area is Comapa, a municipality in southeastern Guatemala, where control efforts have been less effective. Researchers conducted three surveys in Comapa to evaluate a decade of vector control activities. Baseline serological and entomological surveys in 1999 and 2002 were followed by three rounds of insecticide applications 2005 and intermittent spraying of infested houses until 201. Household inspections determined entom indices and materials in 200, 7, and 201. Serological surveys in school children 199, 200, and 201, and women 15-44 in 201. After spraying, infestation decreased from 39 to 27. Household materials predicted less than 10 infested houses. Chagas seropreval in children declined 10-fold from 10 to 1. However, serreval in women remains 10. A decade of control in Comapa shows reduced transmission, but continued vector-borne and congenital transmission threaten the 202 elimination goal. Systematic control and Chagas screening for congen and vectororne disease are needed in regions with persistent infestation.
Citrobacterium is a natural pathogen that causes attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions in mice. It shares a virulence strategy with human pathogens Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and Enterohaemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) and is used to model pathogenesis. The complete genome of Citrobium ICC168 was previously sequenced, showing characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen. This study used PFGE sequencing, isolates variation, whole transcriptome analysis, and mobile elements to find that Citium's genome is unstable due to large-scale recombination and transposition of prophages. An additional Citium strain EX-33 was sequenced, showing ICC168 is representative and most mutations occurred early in the pathogen's evolution. Evolution parallels with other pathogens suggest Citium is a recently emerged path alongside mice development as a human disease model.

Citrobium isolates showed genome features of recently bottlenecked bacteria, pseudogenes and IS elements. This study investigates genomic flux in Citium, focusing on mobile elements' impact on evolution, demonstrating the pathogen's unstable genome. Citium shares virulence with EPEC and EHE. Different Citium isolates from mouse and hamster outbreaks in Japan and USA 1960s-80s were classified as atypical E. coli (M) or Citacterii (later reclassified Citrogenom species). Genetic and biochemical analyses suggested clonal origin, reclassifying Citrobium. The genome of Citium ICC168, from a 1972 outbreak, was previously sequenced. ICC and DB100, from same source, are most studied Citium isolates. Functions conferring Citium virulence to EPEC EHE are on mobile elements. Large genomic rearrangements and gene loss suggest Citium recently emerged as path, adapting lifestyle.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework to analyze stochastic gene expression, which is the random fluctuations in protein levels across cell populations. Despite many theoretical models explaining this phenomenon, there was a lack of a robust, assumption-free approach to infer the underlying mechanisms. The new method infers biochemical rates of chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation from protein distributions. It asks if these rates can be estimated from protein distributions without assumptions. The researchers derived analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution, found these moments capture the shape of distributions, and developed an efficient algorithm to infer expression constants from moments. Using this, they found most distributions are consistent with multiple biochemical constant sets, but the solution still informs the underlying mechanism. For example, it distinguishes between transcription bursting and constitutive production. The method agrees with the standard approach in its operating regime and identifies previously unobtainable constants. Without assumptions, it estimates biochemical constants or ratios in 91% of cases, and identifies all constants in some cases. This framework will be a powerful tool for deducing molecular contributions to gene expression patterns.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine approach to protect against monkeypox, a disease caused by the monkeypox virus (MPV). MPV is a neglected disease in rural areas of Africa and can be spread from animals to humans and humans. Smallpox vaccination protects against MPV, but the vaccination campaign ended in 1980, leaving many people unprotected. There are no approved treatments for MPV and current vaccines have safety concerns. This study used a new strategy with recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (Bo-4) vectors expressing MPV glycoproteins to protect against lethal MPV in mice. Three Bo-4 vectors were made and tested for safety and efficacy in mice. The results showed that Bo-4-E1-MRg106TK alone or with Bo-4-ALD and Bo-6 protected 100% and 80% of mice from mortality and morbidity. This demonstrates the use of Bo-4 as a vaccine platform.
Researchers have identified a new enzyme called ApH phosphatase AL1 (AL1) as the main enzyme responsible for removing the cap from messenger RNA (mRNA) in trypanosomes, a type of parasite. Unlike other cells, trypanosomes lack the usual enzymes that remove the cap from RNA. AL1 is found in a special granule at the back of the cell and works with another enzyme called X, which breaks down RNA. Without AL, RNA is capped but not yet broken down. This suggests AL acts after the cap is removed and before it's broken down. Experiments show AL1 can remove the cap from RNA in a test tube, but only if a special enzyme is added. This is different from how other enzymes that remove the cap. AL is the first time a enzyme like this has been found in animal cells, which have it from bacteria.
Researchers have discovered that inactivating the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells can trigger their conversion into functional β-like cells. This process involves the mobilization of ductal precursor cells to adopt an endocrine fate, with glucagon cells being converted into β-like cells upon Ar inhibition. The study found that Pax4 is not necessary for this process, indicating Ar is the main trigger for α-cell β-cell neogenesis. Loss of Ar in α-cells is sufficient to regenerate β-cell mass and reverse diabetes-induced β-cell depletion. The research suggests strategies targeting Ar expression or its molecular co-actors may treat diabetes.
Eukaryotic cells have mechanisms to prevent the initiation of DNA replication at thousands of origins in their genome to avoid genomic alterations. Global mechanisms reduce the activity of initiation proteins, but origins initiate with different efficiencies when these are disabled. This suggests an additional layer of control that can regulate initiation at distinct origins. Researchers identified elements necessary for preferential initiation of two origins and sufficient to confer preferential initiation on heterologous origins when control is partially deregulated. These elements do not enhance S phase timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and act as initiation promoters (RIPs). The IPs are ∼60 AT rich sequences that act in distance and sequence-dependent manner. During replication, Mc2 associates with origins that preferentially initiate and those that do not, indicating IPs can overcome block initiation imposed by Mc2 association. This study reveals a level of control in initiation. Local control creates a complex replication landscape that is revealed when global mechanisms are compromised. If replication contributes to alterations, as in cancer, some regions may be more susceptible than others.
Invasive amebias, caused by Entamoeba histolytica, is a growing concern among men who have sex with men (MSM) and co-infected with HIV-1 in East Asian countries. A study of 170 HIV-1-infected patients with amebias found similar clinical features to those in non-HIV patients: high fever, leukocytosis, and high CRP with extralinal ameb diseases. Two died from amebic colitis and three from unrelated causes. Metronidazole or tinidazole treatment was successful in 165 cases, but luminal treatment after did not prevent recurrence in 6 of those who received it. Recurrence was more common in HCV-antibody positive and syphilis acquired during follow-up. Various E histoly genotypes were identified, but no correlation with clinical features or outcome. Metronidazole tinazole treatment was excellent for uncomplicated amebias in HIV-1 individuals. Luminal treatment after metronidazole tinazole did not reduce recurrence in high-risk populations due to re-infection.

A retrospective analysis of 170 HIV-1-infected patients showed no impact on clinical forms of amebias. Physical and laboratory findings showed fever, leukocyt, and high CRP with extralinal ameb diseases. Results indicate excellent outcome for HIV-1 individuals with uncomplicated amebias treated metronazole tinazole, in agreement with previous reports. Conventional wisdom suggests luminal treatment after metronazole to eradicate cysts. Results emphasize difficulty preventing recurrence without new infection approach in high-risk groups, such as HIV-1-infected MSM. Spread of E histoly in MSM beyond Asia is a concern.
Researchers in Chad conducted a study to assess the effectiveness of adding tset control to medical activities in reducing the transmission of Gambian sleeping sickness, also known as African trypanosomiasis, in the Mandoul area. The disease is caused by Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by tse flies, and the global goal is to eliminate it as a public health problem by 2020 and stop transmission by 203. In the Mandoul area, around 100 cases were diagnosed and treated annually until 2013. The study found that adding tset control to case detection and treatment reduced the number of cases by 70.4% between 2013 and 2015, with 62.8% of the reduction due to tset control and 8.5% to enhanced detection. Mathematical modeling predicted that elimination as a public problem could be achieved by 2018 with continued vector control and screening. The study suggests that tset targets reduced numbers in the focus, interrupting transmission, and combining tset control with medical treatment reduced incidence in 2014 and 201.
Researchers studied 124 cases of strongyloidiasis, a parasitic infection, in Spain from 2009-2017. Most patients were immigrants from South America, with 66.9% of the total. Diagnosis was made through stool samples in 21.9% of cases, and serological tests in the rest. Eosinophilia was present in 82.2% of cases. Treatment with ivermectin was more effective than albendazole in achieving cure, with an odds ratio of 2.34. The study suggests screening for S. steralis infection should be mandatory for patients from or traveling to endemic areas, especially with immunosuppressed conditions due to long latency and risk of severe presentation.
Researchers have found that the amount of antigen or live pathogen in a vaccine, known as the inoculum dose, plays a crucial role in stimulating the immune response and causing side effects. Higher doses can lead to better protection but also increase the risk of severe side effects and limit vaccine availability during shortages. To determine the optimal dose, a combination of mathematical models and experimental data can be used. A study used data from mice infected with influenza A virus and rats with human parainfluenza virus at different inoculum doses to fit a mathematical model and map inoculum to immune protection and morbidity. The framework can be used to determine the impact of inoculum on outcomes such as protection and morbidity. The results show that inoculum's effect on protection and morbidity depend on the pathogen and do not always increase with higher doses. Once protection and morbidity levels are specified, the framework can help design vaccines and determine the optimal inoculum. 

A modeling framework was developed to predict the optimal inoculum for a vaccine using data from two experiments, influenza A and parainfluenza virus. The framework can be applied to specific vaccine candidates to determine the optimal dose efficiently. The study contributes to the development of a conceptual framework to rationally design and determine inoculum for any pathogen. Parameters were chosen to produce dynamics and explore inoculum's impact on protection and morbidity for a generic model. Simulations showed different inoculum doses and resulting protection and morbidity. For a vaccine, the optimal inoculum dose is desired, but there is no single definition. A framework was developed to systematically determine inoculum's impact on protection and morbidity. It was applied to data to illustrate the concept leading to insights, such as more inoculum does not always lead to more protection.
Researchers studied the expression of the hetR gene in Anaba filaments, a type of cyanobacteria, under different nitrogen conditions. The hetR is essential for heterocyst differentiation, specialized cells that fix nitrogen. They found that hetR expression in nearby cells is coupled, with a range of two to three cells, indicating interactions along the filament. This is different from unicellular organisms where fluctuations are independent. The coupling is due to intercellular transfer and cell division. Under nitrogen deprivation, fluctuations build on previous conditions. They found that under nitrogen-rich conditions, hetR expression is influenced by septal protein Sep and Het auto-regulation. In contrast, under nitrogen-poor conditions, Het inhibitor Pat and sept protein Fra/Fra play a role. The study shows that proteins involved in differentiation combine to control fluctuations in gene expression, leading to a one-dimensional pattern in the organism.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI) in China, as shown by molecular surveillance data. To confirm this shift at the seroepidemiological level, a serosurvey was conducted in non-vaccinated pigs, revealing an average ratio of GI/GIII of 1.87, indicating co-circulation of both genotypes with GI being more prevalent. To understand the reasons behind this shift, the replication of seven recently-isolated JEV isolates, including three GI and four GIII strains, was compared in C/36 cells, chicken fibroblast (DF-1) and porine artery endothelial (PIE) cells. GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII in DF-1 and PIE cells, particularly in DF-1 with titers 22.9-225.3 higher than GIII. This suggests enhanced replication of GI in avian cells. In vivo, young ducklings were used as a model and inoculated with GI and GIII at 2 post-hatching. GI-inoculated ducklings showed higher viremia and longer vmic duration than GIII-inoc ducklings. These results support the hypothesis of enhanced efficiency for GI in birds. There are 36 amino differences between GI and GIII, which may be responsible for the replication efficiency of GI in birds. The findings suggest that enhanced replication of GI in birds results in higher exposure and infection in mosquitoes, leading to increased transmission in the birds-mosquito-bird cycle, contributing to J genotype shift.
Researchers studied the genetic network of transcription factors that regulate Candida albicans biofilm formation, a key aspect of its pathology. They used a systematic approach to generate all possible double heterozygous mutants of the genes and analyze interactions between them. The network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with six heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation, similar to homozygous deletions. Many double heterozygous mutants are as severely affected as homozygous deletions, indicating a highly interdependent "small-world" network that is efficient but not robust. TEC1 is a component whose expression is sensitive to perturbations in other TFs. RO1 expression is dependent on auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other TFs. Heterozygous N80 mutant is hyperfilous under bio and hypha-inducing conditions in a T1-dependent manner. The study provides insights into individual TF functions and network topology in biofilm formation.
Researchers studied the enzyme asparagine synthase A (AS) in Leishmania infantum, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis, a disease. AS converts aspartate to asparagine using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. There are two types of AS: one that uses ammonia and one that uses glutamine. AS is not found in humans but present in trypanosomatids, making it a potential drug target. A previous study showed AS was essential in Leishmania donani, a related parasite, making it a promising target. This study found that Leish infant AS can use both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen sources. They created AS mutants by replacing the gene in Leish infant and found no significant growth or infectivity defects. However, severe growth impairment was seen in aspar limiting conditions. Results show AS is not essential for parasite survival or infectivity in normal conditions, making it unsuitable as a drug target.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy. The study included 11 case-control studies from 13 countries with a total of 474 participants, 215 with epilepsy and 259 without. The pooled odds ratio (OR) was 1.69 (95% CI 1.42-2.01) for the association between toxocari seropositivity and epilepsy. A positive association was found in restricted analysis of confirmatory diagnostic test, population, and population-based studies. Meta-regression showed no significant association between covariates and outcome. The meta-analysis provides epidemiological evidence of a positive association between toxari seropitivity and epilepsy, mainly supported by population studies. Health strategies to reduce toxara spp are advised. Further research is needed to understand the physiopathological mechanisms of toxara-associated epileptogenesis.
Researchers have identified a new pathway that helps cells respond to DNA damage caused by double-strand breaks (DSBs). This pathway involves a protein called ATM and a microRNA called miR-335. When cells are exposed to radiation, ATM is activated, which leads to a decrease in mi-335, a microRNA that targets a protein called CtIP. CtIP is important for a type of DNA repair called homologous recombination repair (HRR). The researchers found that a protein called CREB is responsible for most of mi-335 expression by binding to its promoter region. After radiation, CREB's activity is reduced, which is consistent with previous studies showing that ATM phosphorylates CRE to decrease its activity. Overexpressing mi-335 in cells resulted in lower Ct levels and reduced survival after radiation. In cancer cells with a "radiosensitive" phenotype, mi335 was elevated, Ct was low, and BRCA foci were reduced. Treatment with a mi-335 antisense oligonucleotide restored survival, BRCA foci, and Ct levels. This suggests an ATM-dependent CRE-mi-335-CtIP axis influences the choice of repair for certain DS lesions.
Researchers investigated how people's ability to attribute mental states, such as beliefs and emotions, to others affects their learning in social interactions. They created a game where participants played against artificial agents with varying levels of sophistication in mentalizing, or understanding others' mental states. Participants believed they were either playing against other people or in a casino, but results were the same. People won against sophisticated agents in social setting, lost in non-social. Their choices were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing models only in social setting. This shows mentalizing adds value in social interactions and can't decipher behavior without attributing mental states to others.
Researchers have developed a new algorithm called FastGM to efficiently infer Gaussian graphical models in biological networks. These models help analyze relationships between many variables, like genes or proteins, to understand diseases. Current methods are either not reliable or too slow for large datasets with thousands of variables. The new algorithm, based on a 2015 proposal, is faster by several orders of magnitude without losing accuracy. It was tested on simulated data and two real datasets: asthma and Alzheimer's disease. The algorithm built gene and protein networks for disease and healthy samples, showing interesting interactions and differences between cases and controls. The results are relevant to the diseases. FastGM is a fast and reliable way to construct graphical models for high-dimensional biological data. It's been implemented in an R package called "FastGM" available for download.
Researchers studied how striatal medium spiny neurons (MSN) in the brain's basal ganglia structure respond to changing activity from the cortex. These neurons form groups that fire together in sync with behaviorally relevant timescales. A model of MSN network showed synchronized activity only with realistic connectivity and inhibitory post-synaptic potentials (IPs). The study investigated how MSN population interacts with varying cortical activity, like in a task. At high connectivity, a "winner-takes-all" regime was found, where activity separated into fixed firing and quiet components. Only a few population rates interacted with cortical variations. Around a transition to a more active regime occurred, where cells switched between activity and quiet. In this regime, components wandered and were independent of cortical variations. Only in this regime, changes interacted with many components, allowing sequential assemblies to be activated for hundreds of milliseconds after stimulus onset, and peri-stimulus histograms showed strong stimulus specificity. This activity was maximized at realistic striatal connectivities and IP sizes. The MS network is optimized to respond to cortical variations, not too stable or too unstable, but to generate patterns for long periods.
Researchers have discovered a new link between polarized exocytosis and endocyt in yeast cells. Polarized exyt is the process of transporting components to specific locations on the cell surface, while endyt is the retrieval of these components before they can diffuse away. The two processes were thought to be separate events, but the study shows they are connected through a protein called Sec4. Sec4 is a GTPase that regulates actin polymerization, which is the formation of actin filaments in the cell cortex. After polar exocytic vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, Sec4 binds to actin subunits and promotes their assembly. Mutations in Sec4 or its guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) Sec2 inhibit actin formation, while activating Sec4 accelerates it. In vitro assays, Sec4 overrode S1 inhibition of Lasp-dependent actin nucleation. This suggests Sec4 relocates along the membrane from exytic sites to endytic sites, promoting actin polymerization and compensatory endyt, which refines cell polarization.
Acetamin-induced liver injury in mice is a widely used model for drug-induced liver injury in humans. Researchers have made progress in identifying molecular events and pathways involved, but a clear explanation for how damage occurs is still elusive. A key feature of acetamin-induced liver injury is that necrosis begins near the central vein of the liver lobule and spreads outward. A prevailing hypothesis is that differences in NQI formation within liver lobules are necessary and sufficient to explain this phenomenon, called the NQech hypothesis. However, challenging this hypothesis in mice is difficult because variables cannot be controlled and sequential measurements are needed at different locations within the same mouse. To test this, researchers used virtual hepatocytes with gradients to mimic location-dependent behaviors. Employing the NQech mechanism failed to achieve the phenomenon, suggesting at least one additional feature is needed. Two alternatives were explored: glutathione depletion in the direction and mitochondrial damage in the direction. Including one feature failed, but including both enabled achieving the phenomenon. This merged mechanism provides a multile explanation of acetamin hepatotoxicity in mice. Variants of the mechanism explain variation in necrosis among genetically diverse mouse strains after a single acetamin dose.
Researchers studied the diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection in infants born to infected mothers. Current guidelines rely on detecting parasites in blood samples or specific antibodies at 10-12 months old. The study quantified parasite levels in 51 congenitally infected children at 3 time points: 1 month, 6 months, and 1 year after birth. Infants diagnosed by microscopy at 1 month had high parasite levels (1,700/mL), those diagnosed at 6 months had lower levels (20-500/mL), and those diagnosed by antibodies at 1 year had even lower levels (5-20/mL). Parasites were isolated from 19 children, 18 were genotyped as DTU Tc and 1 as Tc. This is the first study to measure parasite levels in over 50 congenitally infected children. Results show some children (22/51) had parasite levels below detection limit of microscopy. Current treatment is effective, but more sensitive methods are needed for early diagnosis.

The study correlated parasite levels with ELISA and genotyped parasites to understand congenital transmission and improve diagnosis. The aim was to understand why not all neonates born to infected mothers can be diagnosed immediately after birth. Only infants with high parasite levels can be diagnosed at 1 month, microscopy has 94% sensitivity in 1-year follow-up. Three groups were studied: A) neonates diagnosed at 1 month, B) infants diagnosed at 6 months, and C) diagnosed by antibodies at 1 year. Babies diagnosed at 6 months had lower parasite levels, those diagnosed by antibodies at 1 had lowest levels.
Researchers have developed a simplified model of Escherichia coli, a type of bacteria, to understand how its growth and composition are affected by its genetic makeup. They assumed the bacteria are growing in a constant environment with plenty of resources. The model was tested with data from seven strains of E coli with different numbers of copies of a gene called the rRNA operon, ranging from one to seven, the normal amount. Results showed growth decreased for strains with fewer copies. The model reproduced these results and suggested that the amount of molecules inside the bacteria doesn't change with r operon number. It also predicted that having more than seven copies leads to a crowded cytoplasm with ribosomes and proteins, which slows down growth. The model suggests that changing the r operon number in normal E coli in a constant environment doesn't increase growth. Other observations, such as changes in cell shape and operon response, are consistent with the model. The researchers propose principles from the model and suggest further experiments to test its validity.
Researchers studied the role of R1, a protein in Arabidopsis, in seed germination and seedling development in response to abscic acid (ABA) and salinity. R1 is a member of the MYB family of transcription factors, which are involved in various biological processes, including stress responses to biotic and abiotic stresses. Previous studies suggested R1 may play a role in plant development, stress, and hormone signaling. However, the mechanisms of R1 action in response to abiotic stresses were unclear. The team found that downregulation or upregulation of R1 altered sensitivity of seed germination and cotyledon greening to ABA, NaCl, and mannitol in Arabidopsis. R1 expression was dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. The transcription factors HY5 and HYH regulated R1 via binding to R1 promoter. Genetic analysis revealed R1 mediated multiple functions of HY in seed germination, postgermination to A and abiotic stresses, and seedling to salinity. R1 interacted with HYH in vitro and in vivo. R1 and HYH may function as a module in response to A and abiotic stresses. R1 bound the promoter of ABI5, regulating its expression, while R1 interaction stimulated HY binding to ABI. However, no evidence supported R enhanced activation of ABI by HY. HY and R may converge on ABI promoter independently or dependently regulate ABI and ABI downstream A and abiotic-responsive genes, improving plant adaptation to environment.
Mitochondrial complex I, the largest and most complex proton pump of the respiratory chain, links electron transfer from NAD to ubiquinone to pumping four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. In humans, defects in complex I are involved in a range of degenerative disorders. Recent X-ray analysis of prokary and eukotic complex confirmed red reactions are confined to hydrophil peripheral of L-shaped molecule and take remarkable distance from membrane. This implies proton pumping within membrane of I is driven indirectly via long conformation coupling, but mechanism, number, identity, and localization of pump sites unclear.

A small subunit of complex I, Yia, was deleted, forming stable sub (nbm) lacking dist part of membrane domain. Single particle analysis revealed subunit composition of holo and sub by three proteomic approaches showed two (4 and 5) with homology to bacterial Na+/H antiporters missing in nb. Despite this, nb still pumps protons at stoichi of complete. Results show membrane of I harbors two distinct pump modules connected by long helical element identified by X-ray.

Mitochondrial I links electron transfer from NAD to ubiquone to pumping four protons from matrix into intermem space. Recent X-ray analysis proary and eukotic I confirmed red reactions confined to hydrophil peripheral of L-shaped and take remarkable from membrane. Respiratory I proton pumping NAD:ubiquin oxidoreduct is large integral multiprotein in energy membranes of bacteria and eukotes, central in energy metabolism, I defects implicated in bio diseases including neurodegener and aging.
Researchers investigated how fever affects the binding of antibodies to malaria and deng antigens in the body. They used a technique called Isothermal calorimetry to measure the strength of the bond between antibodies and antigens at different temperatures, including 37°C, 40°C, and 42°C. They found that at 40°C, the bond between antibodies and antigens was stronger than at 37°C or 42°C. This suggests that fever may play a positive role in helping the body fight off infections by making antibodies bind more strongly to antigens. The researchers also found that if the proteins were allowed to adjust to the temperature before measuring the bond, it made the bond even stronger. This could be important for understanding how the body's immune system works and how to improve tests for diseases with limited samples.
Researchers have studied how actomyosin cortical flow, a key process in cellular morphogenesis, is controlled by the interplay of force generation and dissipation in cross-linked networks of actin filaments and myosin motors. They used a computational model to explore how stress production and dissipation depend on motor activity, cross dynamics, network architecture, and filament turnover. The study found that filament turnover is necessary to maintain stress against external resistance and steady flow in response to external stress. Steady stress increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τ, then decreases with lifetime above τ. Effective viscosity increases with lifetime up to characteristic τ, then becomes independent of lifetime and dependent on cross dynamics. These dependencies define multiple regimes of steady flow. The model predicts that when lifetimes are shorter than both τ and τ, dependencies of viscosity and stress on turnover cancel, making flow insensitive to turnover and dependent on motor and cross dynamics. The study provides a framework for understanding how cells control cortical flow through network remodeling.
Researchers have identified a gene in Arabidopsis thalian that makes seedlings insensitive to high sugar levels of glucose and fructose. This gene, called GS11, was found in a population of Arabidopsis and confirmed in near-isogenic lines. The GS11 gene encodes a transcription factor called AN060, which is part of the NAC family. The AN060 allele makes seedlings insensitive to sugar, and is dominant over the sensitive allele. Analysis showed a single nucleotide polymorphism in AN060 affects splicing, adding 20 nucleotides to the mRNA and creating a stop codon. This results in a truncated protein without a transmembrane domain. The truncated AN060 is found in 12% of natural Arabidopsis accessions. Glucose induces GS11/AN060 expression, requiring abisic acid (ABA) signaling. ABI4 binds to the GS11AN060 promoter to activate transcription. AN060 reduces ABA sensitivity and ABA accumulation, and ABI is reduced in AN060 lines. The sugar-ABA cascade induces AN060, but the truncated AN060 attenuates ABA and signaling, making seedlings insensitive.
Researchers have discovered how the molecule c-di-G (cyclic guanosine monophosphate) signaling pathway in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a type of bacteria, gains specificity to control certain behaviors such as biofilm formation and motility. They found that the c-di-G synthase enzyme, Hsb, interacts with the Hpt regulatory pathway, which controls biofilm formation and motility. The interaction between Hsb and the anti-sigma factor HsA allows c-G signaling to be rewired into the Hpt cascade. This means that c-G signaling is not just a central hub, but can be localized to specific parts of the cell. The study shows that H and Sad, two different c-G synthases, have distinct roles in controlling P aerugin behaviors. Sad is involved in biofilm formation and swarming, while H is involved in swimming and twitching. The researchers propose that H acts at the cell poles and that both H and Sad intersect in the same regulatory network, Gacsm, which controls c-G levels for biofilm formation. They also found that Sad, a Gsm-controlled synth, is central for biofilm regulation and that H binds anti-sigma Flg, inducing flagellar expression. The Hpt pathway controls biofilm, swimming, swarming, and chemotaxis in P.
Researchers investigated how people learn to associate visual cues with motor responses in a pointing task. They found that participants can learn multiple associations between visual cues and motor responses when feedback is provided, but little is known about how this learning generalizes to new situations. To study this, participants performed a task where they had to point to targets with visual feedback that varied depending on the target's shape. The shapes were morphed between circular and spiky, and participants had to use different motor responses for each shape to hit it. After training, they tested performance without feedback on new shapes not seen before. Two hypotheses were tested: participants could explicitly learn the relationship between shape and motor response and generalize, or use a model that predicts generalization based on categorization. Results showed that learning requires awareness of cues' role, but participants apply mapping to most similar shape, consistent with the model. The model also predicts slower learning with more pairs, confirmed by results. A model of learning multiple visual-motor mappings was supported, indicating a possible mechanism for simultaneous learning.
Researchers studied how climbing fibers, one of the two main inputs to the cerebellum, transmit information from the inferior olivary nucleus. Climbing fibers are thought to be involved in timing motor commands and learning. When activated, they cause large action potentials in cerebellar Purkin cells, silencing them for a brief time. Previous studies showed that climbing fibers can transmit bursts of spikes, potentially increasing information transfer to the cerebell. The researchers used a detailed model of an inferioriv cell to investigate what determines the size of the climbing burst. They found that the size of the burst is related to the phase of the cell's subthreshold oscillation, but only in a limited range. The flow of charge between the cell's soma and dendrites is a major factor in determining the burst size. This suggests that phenomena like cell synchrony can affect the burst through dendritic junctions between cells.

 The cerebellum uses two main inputs: mossy fibers and climbing fibers. Mossy fibers carry information from many brain regions, while climbing fibers carry sensory events. It's thought that variability in olary cell spikes allows for more information transfer. The model predicts a phase dependency of burst size, but only in certain conditions. Inferior cells have a low firing rate, making it hard for some learning approaches to accurately represent the cerebell. To understand what the inferior can transfer, more investigation of its electrophysiological properties is needed. The model predicts a correlation between subthreshold oscillation phase and spike count, matching previous findings.
Researchers have created a detailed computational model of how the liver regulates iron levels in the body. Iron is essential for life, but too much of it can be toxic. The liver plays a key role in controlling iron levels, and misregulation is linked to many diseases. To better understand iron metabolism, a map of its fate in the body was created, but how its components interact to regulate it was unclear. A new model of human liver iron metabolism was developed, based on known mechanisms and kinetic properties. It was validated with published data and recreated experimental findings. A simulation of iron intake was compared to a clinical study and matched its dynamics. A simulation of hereditary hemochromatosis, a disease, was created by altering a gene mutation. The model shows how liver overload occurs in this disease. It supports the liver's role as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modeling to identify targets and design experiments.

The model allows for "what-if" experiments to test new hypotheses. No comprehensive liver metabolism model exists, only specific events like iron loading in ferritin have been modeled. A map of mammalian metabolism shows molecular interactions, but lacks detail. This model balances coverage and detail to address hepatic regulation. Quantitative modeling is challenging due to lack of interaction values. The model identifies predictions about regulation to investigate. It's the most detailed model to date, describing regulation. It links genotype to phenotype, as shown with hereditary hemochromosis.

Data from various sources, in vitro and animal, were used to parameterize the model. This is a clinical approach to improve human metabolism understanding. Iron absorption, transport, and regulation form a complex network. The liver regulates through hepcin secretion. The hepatic network was analyzed through a model and simulation.
Researchers have developed a computer simulation model to study how molecules move in and out of the cell's nucleus through the nuclear pore complex (NPC). The NPC is like a gate that controls what enters and leaves the nucleus, and it's crucial for cell function and survival. The process is fast, happening in milliseconds, but the details are unclear. The model focuses on interactions between proteins called karyopherins and FG repeat domains, which are key to transport. It takes into account the flexible nature of these proteins and their attraction to each other. The simulation shows that a 15-nanometer molecule takes about 2.6 milliseconds to pass through, with some variation. The molecule sticks to the wall and interacts with FG layers as it moves through. The attraction between karyins and FG is dynamic and fast, allowing efficient transport. Most binding sites on kary are used during transport. Without filaments, the NPC is more permeable to molecules, showing their role in selectivity.
Researchers have developed a new method to determine the optimal dose of a pathogen for non-human primate (NHP) models, which are commonly used to test interventions against human diseases such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. The goal is to find a dose that infects 50% of the animals, called the ID50. This is crucial for successful experiments, as too high or too low a dose can lead to false results and waste of animals. The new method minimizes the number of animals and resources while estimating the ID50 within 1.5-fold of the true value.

The method involves titrating the infectious agent to find the right dose, which only infects a fraction of animals. Too high a dose can lead to false negative results, while too low leads to insufficient infections. A 2-fold error in dose can impact the experiment's power. By following this method, researchers can reduce the number of animals and resources needed to define the pathogen dose in NPs.

On average, the protocol uses 15-25 animals, 3-5 rounds, and estimates ID50 within 40% of the true value. It is generalizable to any path and model, but critical for NPs where animal use is minimized. The ID50 is determined by iterative exposures of animals to path dilutions, adjusting dose between rounds to achieve 50% infection.
Researchers studied how a type of neuron in the auditory system of crickets, called AN2, adapts to changes in sound intensity. They found that the neuron's response to sound shifts towards higher intensities over time, with a time constant of 1.5 seconds for adaptation and recovery. This means that the neuron responds less to low-intensity sounds. The researchers tested whether this adaptation improves signal representation by comparing it to two theories: infom, which maximizes information about the entire signal, and selective, which enhances foreground signals while suppressing background. They presented signals with two or three peaks in amplitude, which the theories predict conflicting changes. Using data analysis, they found shifts in response curves with slight reduction in slopes and higher absolute thresholds than predicted by infom. Contrary to inf, adaptation reduces information when considering the whole signal. The response also doesn't match selective, as information about the loudest part doesn't increase but remains constant. Less is transmitted about lower-intensity signals.

The study explored properties of a single neuron in the cricket's auditory pathway, testing two principles: infom and selective coding. Adaptation's effect on the input curve depends on relevant information in context. In crickets, adaptation times at first neurons range from short to long. This study reports a time constant of about one second, previously unreported in AN of T. ocean and T. The first auditory stage's task is to maintain and condense information for object recognition. Several scales can be observed, similar to vertebrates and other modalities. Motivated by theories, they examined adaptation to ensembles of stimuli with different changes. Designed multimodal noise with two or three modes, mimicking scenes. The principles predict conflicting changes when a stimulus has more than one. Optimal selective shifts the curve to peak intensity. If inf, adaptation maximizes information conveyed.
Researchers studied the role of polybasic domains in prion protein (Pr) in the propagation of disease-causing prion (PrSc). They created prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains and used them as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification (sCA) reactions. After several rounds of sCA, prions lacking the central poly domain (Δ) were formed. Surprisingly, these prions could bind and convert poly domain mutant substrates into prions. However, they had reduced infectivity compared to wild-type prions. The study suggests that prion propagation may not depend on a single mechanism, but interaction through poly domains may be required for infectivity.
Researchers developed an inverse reinforcement learning (IRL) framework to identify animal behavioral strategies from time-series data. They applied this framework to Caenorhabditis elegans thermotaxis, a behavior regulated by specific strategies. When fed worms were cultivated at a constant temperature with food and placed on a thermal gradient without food, they showed an appetitive response to the temperature. The IR approach revealed that fed worms used both the absolute and temporal temperature and their behavior involved two strategies: directed migration (DM) towards the temperature and isothermal migration (IM) along constant temperature. DM efficiently reached specific temperatures, explaining thermot behavior when fed. In contrast, starved worms escaped the temperature using only the absolute but not the temporal of temperature.

The researchers also investigated the neural basis of these strategies by applying the method to thermosensory-deficient worms. The IR-based approach is useful for identifying animal strategies from behavioral data and can be applied to various studies, including decision-making in other organisms.
Researchers have sequenced the genome and transcriptome of Chrychromina tobin, a type of algae that plays a crucial role in aquatic ecosystems. Algae are important for absorbing carbon, forming harmful blooms, and serving as a food source for various species. They dominate freshwater and marine environments due to their mixotrophic nature. Despite their importance, only one alga, Emilian hley, has had its genome sequenced. This study reports the genome of Chrychromina and transcript data at seven points over a 24-hour cycle. The genome is small, compact, with 40% coding, and encodes 16,777 genes. Genes for fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct expression patterns over the circadian photoperiod. The genome harbors a hybrid polyketide synth/nonribosomal synthase complex, anti-microbial peptides, and proteins for multidrug and toxic extrusion. A new alga xanthodin was identified, with two RuBisCOases shared across algal lineages. The genome provides information on evolutionary, ecological, and economic importance of algae.
Researchers have found that breast cancers that lack the markers ESR1, PGR, and HER2 are often belong to the Basal molecular subtype, which is associated with defective RB, p53, and BRCA pathways. Studies in mice show that inactivating both RB and p53 pathways can suppress cell death in mammary epithelial cells, and concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant metastatic adenocarcinomas. These tumors are poorly differentiated and have histologic features common among BRCA-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplas, and necrosis. Gene analyses show tumors share attributes of Bas-like and Claudin-low signatures, two subtypes of the broader triple-negative class defined by clinical markers.

In humans, p53 is mutated in 20-30% of breast cancers and defective pathway intermediates increase breast risk. Nearly all Bas-like cancers with BR1 have conitant p mutation. BR1 mutation predisposes early-onset cancers that are triple-negative and correlate with Bas-like in microarray. Mouse models that mimic TNBC complexity will be tools for defining cellular behavior and triaging new candidates. Bas-like cancers inactivate three tumor suppressors infamous for roles in cancers: RB, p53, and BR1. Others argue Bas-like and Claudin signatures reflect progenitor and cell phenotypes, consistent with BR mediating stem/progen celluration. Loss BR activity may alter phenotype deregulation EMT inducer SL. CG analysis revealed CN consistent with human surveys.

This study shows mammary tumors by inactivating p family proteins (p, p, p, p) with BR1 and p53 mimic aggressive forms of cancer, rapid progression, poor differentiation, distant metastasis, necrosis, metlas, and genomic instability.
Researchers studied the population of Aedes aegypt, the primary vector of deng virus, in rural Kampha Phet, Thailand. To control deng transmission, it's essential to understand where and how many of these mosquitoes are produced. They found that Aegypt primarily develop in artificial water-holding containers, such as buckets and jars, near human habitations. Most adult mosquitoes don't travel far from where they were born, so containers near each other are more likely to be used as breeding sites. Containers that are used more often produce more mosquitoes. Most studies ignore how close these sites are to each other, but this study accounted for it. From 2004 to 2007, they surveyed 84,840 containers and used regression modeling to see how density, access to piped water, and season affected mosquito production. A special model was used to account for many zeros in counts. The number and density of breeding sites were key to Aegpt distribution and abundance. More containers produced more mosquitoes as density increased. Accounting for site density is crucial for predicting Aeg populations and controlling them.
Researchers have discovered a key mechanism by which the nematode C. elegans integrates information about its environment and internal state to make decisions about growth and development. They found that the TORC2 complex in the intestine sends signals to the brain about the quality and quantity of food available, allowing the animal to adjust its behavior and development accordingly. During larval development, TOR2 regulates the expression of daf-7 and d-28 genes in sensory neurons, which respond to bacterial food and temperature to decide whether to grow or enter a dormant dauer stage. In the adult, TOR2 modulates foraging behavior through a neuropeptide signaling pathway. The study also found genetic variation in TOR2 affects larval and adult traits and identified quantitative loci associated with these traits. This suggests TOR2 acts as a hub for gut-to-brain communication, influencing neuronal function by internal state.
Researchers have identified key genetic sequences that control the behavior of embryonic stem cells, which have the ability to develop into any cell type of tissue. These sequences, called cis-regulatory elements, were found in mouse and human embryonic stem cells. They are involved in gene expression, chromatin remodeling, cell cycle, and DNA repair. A new algorithm, Compoby, was developed to identify these sequences by comparing mouse and human genomes. Compoby found conserved motifs in genes upregulated in embryonic cells. These motifs are active in undifferentiated embryonic cells and act as enhancers with endogenous promoters. Importantly, their activity is conserved in human embryonic cells. A transcription factor, NF-Y, binds to one motif and is required for embryonic cell proliferation. This study provides insights into transcriptional networks of embryonic cells. The approach can be applied to other mammalian species.
Researchers have studied the structure of a complex between two proteins, N and P, which are essential for the replication of a type of virus called vesicular stomatitis virus. This virus has a non-segmented negative-strand RNA, meaning it needs a continuous supply of protein N in a complex with P to replicate. The researchers created a variant of N without its first 21 amino acids and a 60 amino acids of P, which includes a region that binds to RNA-free N. They crystallized this complex and solved its structure at 3.0 Å resolution, revealing how this region folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and polymerization. Small-angle X-ray scattering and NMR experiments confirmed the binding of this region and showed its flanking regions remain flexible in the complex. The structure suggests a mechanism for initiation of viral RNA synthesis and encapsidation of newly synthesized RNA. The N-binding region of N is disordered and has transient helical elements that constitute a molecular recognition element, which folds upon binding to its partner. The reconstituted complex is similar to the viral N-P complex and shows the region of P adopts a stable conformation upon binding to N, including residues 6-35, which is essential for maintaining N in a soluble form. The complex crystallized into a decamer, similar to previously crystallized N-RNA, and the structure reveals how N-binding region attaches to N. A variant of VSV that cannot bind RNA crystallized into decamer of empty N, which is an artifact of crystallization.
Researchers studied the role of gap junctions in the fly's visual system, specifically in the vertical network of cells that process visual information. Gap junctions are a type of electrical synapse that allow cells to directly communicate with each other. The study found that in this network, gap junctions enable the system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation of the fly's motion within 10 milliseconds of visual input. This efficiency is near-optimal, meaning it reaches the physical limits set by the structure of the visual input. The network is connected to downstream pathways through a subset of cells, and the presence of gap junctions in these cells makes them encode motion more efficiently than the whole network. This efficient encoding is necessary for the fly's ability to make sharp turns in evasive maneuvers. Gap junctions only affect the system's output, not the input, suggesting neural circuits may be more complex than previously thought. The study shows how specific connectivity leads to efficient sensory encoding.
Researchers have identified human-select glycoprotein ligand-1 (PS-1) as a receptor for enterovirus 71 (EV-71), a virus that causes hand, foot, and mouth disease in children and can lead to severe neurological diseases. PS-1 is a protein on the surface of white blood cells and helps them stick to the lining of blood vessels. To understand how PS-1 and EV-71 interact, scientists made PS-1 mutants and tested them for binding to EV-71. They found that tyrosine sulfation, but not O-glycosylation, of PS-1 is critical for binding to EV-71. Tyine sulfation is a chemical change that adds a group to the amino acid tyine in PS-1. Without tyine sulfation, PS-1 does not bind to EV-71. An inhibitor of sulfation, sodium chlorate, blocked PS-1-EV interaction and reduced EV-71 replication in cells. This study shows that tyine sulfation of PS-1 is important for EV-71 entry and replication in white blood cells.
Researchers have found that inhibitors of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) can be effective in treating leishmanias, a serious health problem affecting many people worldwide. Current treatments for leishiasis can be toxic and lead to resistant strains, making them ineffective in the long run. In this study, three mTOR inhibitors, rapamycin, G-645, and K-379, were tested in mice infected with Leish major. The results showed that a clinically relevant dose of rapycin or G-645, but not K-379, reduced foot swelling and parasite load in the lymph node. Importantly, rapycin did not kill the parasite in a lab test. The treatment also reduced IL-4 production in infected mice and increased the IFN-γ:IL-4 ratio, suggesting a T1-skewed cytokine profile. The expression of CD, an activation marker, on T cells was enhanced in rapycin-treated mice. These findings suggest that select mTOR inhibitors may be used in treating leishias. The benefits are thought to come from their immunomodulatory properties.
Researchers have studied the process of natural transformation in bacteria, where they take in DNA from their environment and change their genetic makeup. To prevent unwanted changes, some bacteria prefer to take in their own DNA, which has a specific sequence called DUS. They found that Com is the receptor for D in Neisseria species, a type of bacteria that causes meningitis. By changing Com levels in Neisser meningidis, they showed that taking in D is dependent on Com, and also happens without D. The inner bases of D are crucial, while outer bases are less important. Variants of D in human Neisser species, differing by one or two bases, are impaired for transformation in Neisser meningidis. They also found that Com from another Neisser species binds to its D variant and enhances transformation in a Com mutant Neisseridis. This shows a similar mechanism is used by Neisser species to take in their own or similar DNA. These findings reveal the early steps of natural transformation and how bacteria share genes in the same environment.
In the process of cell division in yeast, a contractile actomyosin ring (CAR) and septum formation are crucial for cell separation. While many CAR proteins have been identified, how they interact with septum enzymes to form the septum is unclear. A study in yeast shows that cooperation between Pxl, a protein required for ring integrity, and B1, enzyme for β-1,3 glucan synthesis and septum formation, is necessary for CAR anchorage to the plasma membrane before division and furrow formation. Without Pxl and B1, ring contraction fails and cell growth occurs without septum formation. Pxl concentration at CAR increases during cytokinesis and depends on the SH domain of protein Cdc15. B1 depletion in cells with cdcΔ3 allele causes ring disassembly and block, as in cells lacking P1. Absence of P1 is lethal when C15 function is affected, causing CAR sliding with septum material along cell cortex. Findings indicate CAR anchorage through C15 and P1, and conitant B1 activity are necessary for CAR and septum formation in yeast. B1 and P1 cooperate to maintain CAR position and integrity during cytokinesis, and are essential for septum synthesis. In yeast, R1 inactivation is required for septum formation. P1 deletion increases R1 activity, impeding septum formation in b1+ cells. Results suggest C15, through SH, and P1, cooperate with B1 to confer CAR stability and septum during cytokinesis.
Researchers investigated a recent outbreak of glanders, a highly infectious disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia malle, in Bahrain. They used high-resolution genotyping and whole-genome sequencing to analyze samples from infected horses and a camel, and compared them to samples from a 2004 outbreak in the United Arab Emirates. The results showed two distinct clusters, suggesting multiple introductions of different B. malle strains. The Bahrain samples were closely related to B. malle from horses in the UAE in 2004, indicating repeated importation from similar sources. High-resolution genotyping and whole-genome analysis revealed same phylogenetic patterns among samples. The close relationship between Dubai/UAE B. malle populations may indicate a shared geographic origin yet to be identified for infecting strains. The emergence of glanders with horse trading poses a new risk for human infections.
Researchers studied 43 patients in Colombia who did not respond to the standard treatment for cutaneous leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, with the medication Glucime. The study aimed to understand the clinical and parasitological features of these patients. Most patients (95.4%) were infected with Leishmania braziliensis, a species associated with treatment failure and relapse. Lesion size and parasite infectivity were negatively correlated with Glucime susceptibility. The study found that Leish brazili was the main species linked to treatment failure or relapse. The results suggest that a second round of treatment with pentavalent derivatives may not be effective for Leish brazili infections. The study included patients who had received at least one round of Glime 20mg/kg/day for 20 days and experienced ATF or relapse. Female patients and those with incomplete or no treatment were excluded. The study was a cross-sectional, recruiting patients from June 2013 to March 2014 in three reference centers for complicated cutaneous leishiasis in the Colombian Army. The new form of the disease tends to be more severe and last longer than the old. In Colombia, most cutaneous leishias are caused by Leish viannia subgenus, associated with more treatment failure than Leish leish subgenus.
Researchers studied the relationship between two biosynthetic pathways in Escheria coli that produce iron-scaveng molecules called siderores and genotoxin colactin. These pathways require a specific enzyme called 4-phosphate transferase (PT). Two PTases have been identified: Ent and ClA. Ent is part of the bacteria's core genome, while ClA is on a pathogenic island that codes for colactin. This island is associated with a high pathogenic island (H) in some virulent E. coli strains. H carries genes for yiniact synthesis, but not its PT. The researchers investigated if ClA could contribute to siderore synthesis. They found that ClA can help produce siderores. Inactivating both Ent and ClA made a virulent E. coli less virulent in a mouse model. Having either Ent or ClA was needed for E. coli to survive in the body. This is the first report of multiple PT pathways making distinct metabolites in a microorganism. The researchers think the association of the island with H is because ClA is a PT that can make both genoto and siderores. This shows complex interaction between virulence and functions. Identifying these points is key to understanding E. virulence and may lead to new treatments.
Researchers have developed a new probabilistic model for calculating the probability of a multiple sequence alignment given a phylogenetic tree and evolutionary model, which accounts for insertion and deletion events in addition to substitutions. The model, called probabilistic phylogenetic inference with insertions and deletions, uses a rate matrix to describe the probability of gap events and is based on a continuous Markov process. The model assumes insertion and deletion occur one residue at a time. The researchers applied this model to phylogenetic inference by extending the program dnaml in phyl, a widely used tool for phylogenetic inference. They tested the new model on simulated and real data, including ribosomal RNA alignments, and found it improved accuracy compared to ignoring gaps while retaining computational efficiency of the Felsen peeling algorithm. The Felsen algorithm is used in many phylogen tools due to its efficiency, scaling linearly with alignment length and number of sequences. However, most phylogen models only account for substitutions, not insertions and deletions. The new model aims to integrate evolutionary modeling into probabilistic models used in other sequence analysis, such as hidden Markov models and stochastic context-free grammars, which already account for insertions and deletions.
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infects the skin through the mucous membrane before entering nerve endings. In the skin, epidermal Langerh cells (LCs) are the first dendritic cells (DCs) to encounter HSV, but it is CD103+ dermal DCs that carry viral antigen to lymph nodes for presentation, suggesting cross-talk in the skin. This study compared topically HSV-1 infected human skin explants with biops of initial human herpes lesions and found that LCs are initially infected and emigrate into the dermis. LCs bearing markers of maturation and apoptosis formed large clusters with BD3+ dermal DCs, thought to be equivalent to murine CD+ dermal DC, and DC-S+ macrophages. HSV-expressing LC fragments were observed inside dermal DC/macrophages and BD3 dermal DC had upregulated damaged uptake receptor CLEC9. No infected epidermal cells interacted with dermal DCs. Correspondingly, LC isolated from skin and infected with HSV-1 in vitro underwent apoptosis and were taken by isolated BD3 dermal DC and S+ cells. A viral relay takes place where infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken by dermal DC for antigen presentation. This provides a rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or intradermal immunization.
Researchers studied how Leishmania parasites, a type of parasite that causes leishmaniasis, interact with host cells called macrophages. They used a technique called multidimensional imaging to observe how the parasites grow inside the cells. They compared two types of Leish parasites, L. major and L. amazonensis, and found differences in how they grow inside macrophages. L. major grows in small, tight-fitting vacuoles, while L. amazon grows in large, giant vacuoles. The researchers used a tool called Lysacker, a fluorescent probe that shows acidic parts of the cell, to study how the parasites grow. They found three key features of L. major growth: lysacker enters the vacole, the number of acidic vesicles in the cell decreases, and the vacole fuses with itself. L. amazon grows by fusing with other vacoles. This study helps understand how Leish parasites grow inside cells and could be useful for studying other microorganisms.
Researchers studied how chromatin structure affects the use of homologous sequences as donors for repair in gene conversion in chicken cells. They used the DT40 cell line as a model, where immunoglobulin genes undergo sequence diversification through gene conversion templated by pseudogene donors. They found that the immunoglobulin V pseudogene has histone modifications associated with active chromatin, indicating an open structure. To test the importance of chromatin, they created a system where heterochrom protein HP1 from Drosoph melanogaster was expressed as a fusion to Escheria lactose repressor, tethered to lactose operators within the pseudoλ donor. This reduced histone acetylation in the pseudoλ and altered the outcome, favoring non-templated mutations over templated mutations. Chromatin regulates homology-directed repair, suggesting histone modifications contribute to genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences.
Researchers studied how the cerebellum, a part of the brain that helps adjust motor behavior to changing situations, learns from past mistakes. It's thought that the cerebellum uses the difference between desired and actual behavior, or "error," to guide learning. This error not only affects immediate behavior but also causes lasting changes in connections between brain cells that help adjust behavior. Climbing fibers, which connect to these cells, are believed to carry error information for learning, but not memory. The study tested monkeys in a task that challenges this idea. They found a clear signal of error at the time of mistake and a repeat of this signal later, before new behavior, to improve it. This contradicts the idea that climbing fibers only communicate instant errors.

A previous studies supported this concept, but not all agreed that climbing fibers only communicate errors. One example is a study on short-term sacc adaptation, a model of cerebell learning, which found patterns that didn't match the idea. The study saw a shift between populations indicating sacc amplitude change by error in primary interval. Firing of simple spikes and complex spikes in learning is established, so they wondered if observed effects were secondary to error changes in simple discharge. They used a random sacc adaptation task to avoid gradual changes and error obscuring the error's fingerprint. The study found clear changes in complex spike rate, reflecting past errors before sacc. Discussions of climbing's role in sacc learning have had conflicting findings. The idea is that climbing conveys information for future behavior improvement through two types of fibers, one from the olive, is central.
Researchers have found a way to reduce the toxic effects of a protein called TDP-43, which is associated with a devastating neurodegenerative disease called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). They used a yeast model to study T-43's effects and found that overexpressing the protein S1, a type of chaperone, reduced T-43's toxicity and proteolysis. They also showed that overing the mammalian S1 homologue, DNA1, relieved T-43 mediated toxicity in rodent neurons. This suggests that S1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS. T-43 aggregation is a hallmark of ALS and other diseases, and overexpressed T-43 is toxic and forms cytoplasmic aggregates in yeast and mammalian neurons. The study found that T-43 inhibits clearance of misfolded protein by the ubiquitin proteome system, suggesting that some T-43 toxicity is caused by proteoly dysfunction. The researchers identified S1 as a modifier of T-43 toxicity and showed that overing it reduces T-43's effects. They also found that overing DNA1, a mammalian S1 homologue, reduces T-43 mediated toxicity in rodent neurons.
Researchers studied the parasite load and diversity of Trypanosoma cruzi in 65 patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. Chagas is a major health issue in Latin America, and finding a link between parasite types and disease symptoms is a challenge. The study used PCR and real-time PCR to type and quantify parasites in patients' blood. 53.8% of patients were positive, with 30.7% having the indeterminate form and 23.1% the cardiac form. The parasite load ranged from 0.12 to 153.66 per mL, with a median of 2.54. The load was higher in patients over 70 years old, 20.05 per mL. Using spiked blood samples, parasites were genotyped to 0.5 per mL with high specificity. 80% of positive patients had a parasite type, while 20% had partial results. Analysis showed 40% TVI, 17.1% TVII, and 14.3% mixed infections. Two patients had TV and one had TVI+II, all with chronic cardiomyopathy and from Bahia region. TVI had higher loads, 7.56 per mL, while TVI had 2.35. However, 50% of TVI and 16.7% TVII evolved to cardiomyopathy.
Researchers conducted a rabies surveillance program in Guatemala between 2009 and 2011, testing 672 bats from 31 species for the rabies virus (RV). The overall prevalence of RV was low, at 0.3%. However, two vampire bats (Desmodus rotus) had viral antigens and infectious virus isolated from their brains, and RV was also found in their oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys. Sequencing showed the viruses were 100% identical, but had one non-synonymous substitution in the glycoprotein gene. The viruses were related to those found in vampire bats in eastern Mexico and El Salvador. 7% of 398 bat sera showed RV neutralizing antibodies, with variation across troph guilds suggesting complex compartmentalization of RV perpetuation.

The study is the first to isolate RV from bats in Guatemala, with a low prevalence of 0.3% among all bats, and 1.3% among vampire bats. The viruses were phylogenetically related to those in eastern Mexico and El Salvador, due to geographic proximity. RNA was detected in multiple bat species, similar to other studies in Peru, Grenada, and Trinidad. Given bats' ecological importance, novel strategies are needed for prevention and control of bat-associated zoonoses.
Researchers have discovered a new role for A-type lamins in the regulation of herpes simplex virus (HSV) replication. A-type lamins are proteins that make up the nuclear lamina, a structure that provides support and organization to the cell's nucleus. The study found that A-type lamins help HSV target the virus to the edge of the nucleus, where it replicates, and reduce heterochatin, a type of chromatin that silences gene expression. Without A-type lam, the virus replication compartments are smaller and fail to reach the edge of the nucleus. The virus is associated with more heterochatin in cells lacking A-type lam. This suggests A-type lam is necessary for viral expression, replication, and growth, with greatest effect on replication at low infection levels. The lamina serves as a scaffold for DNA and proteins that regulate both euchatin and heterochatin modifications. The study provides evidence for A-type lam's role in heterochatin maintenance and silencing. HSV has been used to study cellular processes, and chromatin plays a role in gene regulation. The virus is not associated with histones. By regulating chrom on the virus, it determines productive or latent infection in cells.
