Further studies will determine how A-type is exploited by HSV to keep the genome active during infection. The lam may also provide a platform for viral and chrom-modifying enzymes to keep the genome active. The requirement for A was multiplicity-dependent, with 5-fold reduction at high MOI and 100-fold at low MO.
Researchers have studied the structure of the TOM (translocase of the outer membrane) complex in hydrogenosomes, a type of mitochondria found in the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. Mitochondria originated from proteobacteria and their transition to organelles was linked to the establishment of protein import pathways. The initial import of proteins is mediated by the TOM, which is common to all forms of mitochondria. However, diversity of subunits between eukotic lineages has been predicted, but knowledge is limited to few organisms. The study found that the highly divergent β-bar T. vaginalis TOM (Tv)40 forms a trans channel to conduct hydrogenosomal import. Tv40 is present in high weight complexes and analysis revealed four subunits. Two, Tom36 and Tom46, with heat shock protein (Hsp) and tetratopeptide repeat (PR) domains, bind hydrogenosomal proteins and likely function as receptors. A third sub, Tom-like, has short domain and conserved transmembrane but lacks domain. Fourth, hydrogenosomal outer protein 19 (Hom) has no homology. Data indicate TvOM is associated with sorting assembly (Sam) that in β-bar assembly. Electron microscopy revealed TvOM forms three pores with skull-like shape. Results suggest the triplet-p TOM, composed of conserved subunits, was present in last eukotic ancestor (LECA), while receptors for substrate evolved in eotic lineages.
Researchers studied how genetic variations in immune cells called CD4 and CD8 T cells contribute to autoimmune diseases. These cells play a key role in the immune system's response and can cause problems when not working properly. The study looked at genetic variations associated with several autoimmune diseases and found a specific location on chromosome 12 that affects regulation. They found a variation in the R26 gene that affects gene expression in CD4 and CD8 cells. A variation in the IL27 gene was linked to type 1 diabetes, reducing protein activity and expression of IR1 and STAT in CD4 cells. This suggests IL27 may promote autoimmunity in the pancreas by upregulating the STAT pathway. CD4 T cells, including regulatory T cells, control autoimmune diseases. Genome studies identified thousands of genetic variations associated with immune diseases. This study mapped genetic variations in CD4 and CD8 cells, revealing effects on genes associated with autoimmune diseases. Effects varied between cell types and were specific. A variation in the R26 gene may affect protein stability or translation of many mRNAs. The role of this variation in type 1 diabetes is unknown, as well as other genes in the region. A variation in IL27 was significant for IR1 and STAT in CD4 cells. This may promote autoimmunity in the pancreas by upregulating STAT.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in the Democratic Republic of Congo to understand barriers to treating African Trypanosomiasis (AT), a parasitic disease. They interviewed patients, healthcare workers, and program managers in two provinces with high AT prevalence. Participants mentioned strict rules to follow after treatment: no work, no sex, no food, and no sun exposure. Violating these rules was believed to cause serious or deadly complications. These rules were well-known and led some to avoid screening due to fear of following taboos if diagnosed. Originally to mitigate melarsol's side effects, they became outdated with new safer drugs. Health providers must address community concerns to adapt to changing treatment.

The study aimed to understand these prohibitions and their impact on AT control in the Democratic Republic of Congo, led by the National Program against African Trypanosomiasis. The researchers found that medical advice on AT management turned into strict taboos in these regions, affecting screening and treatment uptake. Tabos might be abandoned with safer options, as seen with NECT. Restrictions negatively affected participation and adherence. Their origin and basis unclear, self-imposed or provider-imposed. Given impact, they explored these aspects in-depth.

The study took place in provinces with high AT prevalence, where tabos identified. Not explored in areas with lower prevalence. Failure and adverse rates vary, e.g. 19.5% in Equateur, 0.45 in Bandu, 29.6 in Kasai. Follow-up no longer recommended by WHO. Non-participation compromises control objectives, due to multiple factors, including community-enforced prohibitions associated with AT.
In Eastern Sudan's Gedare State, visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a significant health burden. Médecins Sans Frontières has treated patients with VL at Tabarak Hospital since 2009. A survey was conducted to estimate VL incidence in villages around Tabarak. Between May 5th and June 17, 2011, an exhaustive door-to-door survey was done in 45 villages of Alure locality. Deaths were investigated by autopsies. Individuals with fever for at least two weeks, VL diagnosed and treated in previous year, and clinical post-kala-azar dermal leishiasis (PKDL) were referred to medical teams for ascertainment. A new VL case was clinical with positive rk39 rapid test or direct agglutination test. In 45 villages, 17,702 households were interviewed for 94,369 inhabitants. Crude rate over 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people. VL was possible probable cause for 19% deaths. VL-specific rate was 0.9/100 per year. Teams examined 551 individuals for fever at least weeks, 16 diagnosed primary VL. Incidence over year 7.0/100 persons or 7.9/100 when deaths included. 12.5% of population reported past treatment. VL represents significant burden in Gedare. Active case detection had low yield with access to care, not priority to enhance in similar contexts.
Researchers studied how supercoiling in bacterial chromosomes is controlled in Escherichia coli and Salmonella bacteria. Supercoiling is the twisting of DNA that makes chromosomes compact. There are two types of supercoiling: diffuse and constrained. Diffuse supercoiling moves freely around the chromosome, while constrained supercoiling is caused by proteins that bend, loop, or unwind DNA. Both types contribute equally to total supercoiling in normal cells. However, Escheria coli has 15% more supercoiling than Salmonella. To understand how diffuse supercoiling changes, researchers used a "supercoil sensor" in Salmonella. The sensor monitored supercoiling and transcription rates in normal and mutant bacteria. Transcription increased supercoiling upstream and decreased it downstream of highly expressed genes. Topoisomerase I relaxed excess supercoiling, while gyrase replenished it. Mutations in gyrase caused superco losses in some bacteria. Strains with gyrase mutations had 30-100% less supercoiling than normal. Supercoiling was influenced by transcription, as rifampicin caused superco to rebound. Mutations in gyrase also reduced transcription rates throughout the genome. The study found a link between RNA polymerase speed and gyrase, suggesting fast-growing bacteria may have more supercoiling than slow-growing species.
Researchers studied how the parasite Leishmania amazonensis, which causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, grows inside host cells. They found that the parasite grows in a structure called a parasitophorous vacuole (PV), which is similar to a late endosome or lysosome. The PV expands during infection, but its impact on parasite survival was unknown. The study showed that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate LYSTBe, a protein that regulates lysosome size. Mutations in LYSTBe caused PV to expand and parasite to grow more. However, overexpressing LBe led to small PV that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment with vacolin reversed this, expanding PV and promoting growth. In contrast, E-64 reduced PV size in LBe mutant cells and inhibited parasite growth. Enlarged PV protect parasites from damage, as inhibition of nitric oxide had no effect on Lensis within PV, but enhanced growth inBe small PV. The study found that upregulation of LBe in infected cells is a host response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV and survival.
Researchers have developed a zebraf model to study the mechanisms and treatment of Allan-Her-Dandy syndrome (AH), a genetic disorder characterized by delayed development, intellectual disability, muscle weakness, and spasticity, and thyroid hormone imbalances. The syndrome is linked to mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 (M8) gene, which regulates thyroid hormone (TH) transport. M8 knockout mice replicated abnormal TH levels but did not exhibit neurological symptoms, so a zeb model was created using zinc-finger nuclease (Z)-mediated gene editing. Elimination of M8 decreased TH receptors but not other TH-related genes. Similar to patients, zeb larvae showed neurological and behavioral deficiencies. High-throughput assays showed reduced locomotor activity, altered light response, and increased sleep. Deficiencies were associated with myelin and neuron formation. Time-lapse imaging revealed reduced filopodia, axon branching, and synaptic density in sensory and motor neurons. TH analogs restored myelin and axon growth in z larvae, suggesting M8 regulates neural assembly, mediating sensory and motor performance. Administration of analogs during development may reduce neurological damage in patients.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a common virus that affects newborns and people with weakened immune systems. It infects various cells using different entry pathways involving forms of the gL glycoprotein and the fusion glycoprotein B. However, the minimal machinery for cell fusion is just gL and B. Researchers found that CMV B and gL form a stable complex early after synthesis without other viral proteins. L can interact with B mutants unable to mediate cell fusion. B-L complexes make up to 16-50% of total L in CM virus particles. In contrast, small amounts of L and L-131 complexes are associated with B. Herpesviruses express B and L molecules, and most models suggest L interacts B to mediate fusion, but there's no direct evidence. For herpes simplex virus (HSV-1), it's suggested that after binding L binds B either before or with membrane fusion. The study's results contradict these models, showing CM B and L form stable B-L complexes in virions without receptor or membrane fusion. The data supports the proposal that L interacts B.
Researchers have discovered a gene called Gimap that plays a crucial role in regulating the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in a specific types of cells called leukocytes. Mitochondrial DNA is the genetic material found inside the energy-producing structures within cells called mitochondria. The segregation of mtDNA is important because it determines the onset and severity of certain diseases. In this study, scientists used a mouse model to show that Gimap, an outer membrane protein, regulates mtDNA in leukocytes. They found that Gimap is essential for cell development and survival, suggesting that cell survival may be a key factor in regulating mtDNA variants and diseases.

The study identified the first gene that influences mtDNA segregation in mammals. Gimap regulates the rate of mtDNA in hematopoietic tissues, which produce blood cells. The segregation of mtDNA in these cells is complex and age-dependent, but not related to the number of mtDNA copies. A variation in the G3 gene changes the protein sequence, but not the part that anchors it to the membrane.

The researchers found that Gimap is critical for regulating mtDNA in hematopoietic tissues. The protein does not directly interact with mtDNA as it does not span the membrane. Overexpression of G3 in cells had no effect on mt levels. This suggests a cell-specific pathway is required for mt segregation. The number of mt has been linked to segregation and mt mutations in humans.
Researchers in Victoria, Australia studied the incubation period of Buruli (BU), a skin and soft tissue infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, to understand how long it takes for symptoms to appear after exposure to the bacteria. Most people with BU live in areas where the disease is common, making it hard to estimate the incubation period. However, in Victoria, many people get BU after visiting these areas. The researchers looked at 443 cases from 2013 to 2016 and found the mean incubation period was 4.5 months, similar to a previous study from 2002 to 2012. They also found no link between incubation period and age, sex, location of exposure, or duration of exposure. The study confirms the incubation period of BU in Victoria is between 4 to 5 months, which can help guide clinicians and suggests the mode of transmission is similar in different regions.
Researchers have identified a protein in the Toxoplas parasite that is related to a human protein called Niemann-Pick type 1 (NPC). This protein, named TCR1, is involved in regulating lipids within the parasite. TCR has a similar structure to human NPC, but lacks targeting signals to endo-lysosomes, instead localizing to flattened vesicles beneath the parasite's membrane. When expressed in mammalian cells with NPC mutations, TCR restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from endo-lysosomes. Disrupting TCR in the parasite results in abnormal lipid accumulation of cholesterol esters, sphingomyins, and ceramides, and storage bodies and membranous tubules in the parasitoph vacuoles. Mutant parasites replicate faster and are more virulent than the parental strain. These findings suggest TCR regulates lipid homeostasis in Tooplas by controlling intracellular lipid levels, leading to stimulation of storage, biosynthesis, and division.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the SMOC1 gene as the cause of ophthalmoacelic syndrome (AS), a rare disorder characterized by eye malformations, including anophthalmia, and postaxial oligodactyly. Homozygosity mapping and targeted mutation analysis of the SM1 gene on chromosome 14q24 identified mutations in eight unrelated families, four of which were nonsense, frameshift, and two missense. Missense mutations were in the thyrogulin-1 domain of the protein. The mouse ortholog, Sm1, shows stage-specific expression during eye, limb, craniofacial, and somite development. A targeted gene-trap mutation of Sm1 reduced mRNA to 10% of wild-type levels, resulting in highly penetrant postax oligodactly in homozyg mutant animals. Eye malations, most coloma and cleft, occurred in a proportion of mutant embryos and pups. Loss of Sm1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the disease. SM1 is a mammalian paralog of Drosophila Pentone, an inhibitor of decaplegic, and Xenopus Sm1 functions as a BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagonism provides a plausible explanation for limb and eye phenotypes in humans and mice.
Researchers have found that a protein called TRIM22 plays a key role in restricting the replication of the HIV virus. They treated human cells with type 1 interferons, which are proteins that help fight off viruses, and identified TR22 as one of the most highly activated genes. They confirmed that overexpressing TR22 in cells blocked HIV replication. To see if TR22's role was important under normal conditions, they compared cells with and without TR22 and found that HIV release was higher without it. This suggests that TR22 acts as a natural antiviral agent. Studies showed that TR22 blocked the release of HIV particles containing the G protein, but not other viruses. This was because TR22 disrupted the normal movement of G to the cell membrane. Mutations of TR22 showed that two specific amino acids are needed for its antiral activity. This reveals a pathway by which type 1 interferons stop HIV replication.
Researchers studied the relationship between fig trees (Ficus) and their specific wasp pollinators (Agonidae) to understand why this mutualism is stable. In this mutualism, both species benefit, but cheaters should outcompete cooperative ones, leading to instability. Ficus trees have two types of ovules: inner and outer. Wasps avoid ovipositing into outer ovules, resulting in mutual stability, but the mechanism is unknown. In Ficus rubosa, outer ovules are vulnerable to parasitic wasps ovipositing from outside the sycon. Parasitism decreases towards the center, where inner ovules provide safe space for pollinator offspring. This may contribute to pollinators avoiding outer ovules and wasps focusing on a subset, reducing galling rates. This mechanism may explain stability in fig-poll mutualism independent of plant defenses or pollinator constraints. In most Ficus species, sycon receive foundresses exploit more ovules than wasps, leaving unexplained seed production. Three hypotheses failed to explain stability, suggesting pollin wasps favor innerules for oviposition. Variance in morphology and parasitic wasps across Ficus indicates parasitic wasps contribute to stability. Ficus and Agonid wasps are an obligate mutualism example. Wasps pollinate trees, trees provide was offspring. In monoec F, wasps ovip into receptive sycon, pollinating while depositing eggs into ovules. Parasitic wasps may contribute to stability by selecting innerules due to reduced parasitism. Our study shows pollin was gain fitness by selecting innerules due to reduced parasitism.
Researchers studied how genetic and environmental factors affect plant height in a type of grass called Setaria. They grew 12 sets of the same plants in different conditions to see how height changed. They found that height was reduced when water was limited and when plants were close together. They also found that environment, such as being in a field or a controlled room, affected height. The study suggests that height is a complex trait influenced by many genes and can be changed by environment. Some genes that control height are active at different times in plant's life. Genes from a wild Setaria parent made plants grow taller early, while genes from a domesticated Setaria parent made them grow taller later. The study found 37 genes that affect height in 12 experiments with different water and density. Most of these genes were not from known to affect height before. Plant growth is a process that changes over time and is influenced by genetics and environment. Understanding this is key to knowing how traits are formed. Height is a key part of plant architecture and easy to measure, so it's been studied for a long time.
A recent study in the Pantanal wetlands of western Brazil found evidence of the Ilus virus (ILV), a type of flavivirus, circulating in the region. Between 2005 and 2009, at least three flaviviruses, including ILV, were detected in horses in the area. To further investigate, researchers collected 3,234 mosquitoes from 16 species in 2009-2010 and tested them for virus and flaviral RNA. One pool of 50 non-engorged female Aedes aegypti mosquitoes tested positive for ILV by culture and real-time PCR, indicating an infection rate of 2.5 per 1,000. The full genomic sequence showed 95% identity to the only available ILV genome. This confirms IL circulation in the Pantanal.

The Pantanal region hosts diverse wildlife and hematophagous arthropods, favoring zoonotic virus circulation. Despite scarce data on arboirus vectors, local mosquito species reported as vectors have been found in the north and south Pantanal. In 2009, a flavirus survey in equines from the Ncolia sub-region detected past infection with increasing seroprevalence, Cipore virus, West virus, Louis encephalitis, and IL. The Pantanal is a seasonally flooded 140,000 km. The high prevalence of IL antibodies in horses combined with IL isolation in mosquitoes confirms an arv importance in the region.
Researchers conducted a preclinical study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of single-dose mectin (MO) as a new treatment for scabies compared to two-dose ivermectin (IVM) in a porcine model. Scabies is a common dermatological condition affecting millions globally, but current treatments are insufficient and resistance is emerging. MO has a more favorable pharmacological profile, making it a promising alternative. Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive MO (0.3mg/kg once) or IV (0.2mg twice) or no treatment. Treatment efficacy was assessed by mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-scab Ig antibodies. Plasma and skin pharmacokinetic profiles were determined. At day 14 post-treatment, all MO-treated pigs were mite-free, while only two IV-treated were. MO efficacy was 100% and unchanged until study-end, compared to 62% (26-100) for IV. Clinical scabies, pritus, and anti-s Ig antibodies disappeared in all MO-treated but 75% IV-treated. MO persisted 9 times longer in plasma and skin, covering mite life and enabling long-lasting efficacy. Data show single-dose MO was more effective than consecutive IV, supporting MO as therapeutic approach for scabies.
Researchers have identified the minimum number of proteins required for Staphylococcus aureus to synthesize its cell wall component peptoglycan (PG), a target of many antibiotics. By deleting seven of nine genes encoding PG enzymes from the S. aureus genome, they created a strain capable of PG synthesis catalyzed by only two proteins, penicillin-binding proteins P1 (PBP1) and bi-functional P2 (BP). However, this strain became highly susceptible to cell-targeting antibiotics and displayed impaired virulence in a Drosophila infection model, which depends on specific PG receptor proteins. The study shows that most PG enzymes are redundant in vitro, but important in clinically relevant environments for pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance. S. aureus can grow and divide with only two active synthesizing enzymes, identifying the minimal machinery of S. aureus. The research aims to develop antibiotics inhibiting final stages of PG synthesis. The study demonstrates plasticity of the process, as S. aure can synthesize PG using just two proteins, P1 and P2, performing transpeidation and transglyylation reactions. The strain MIN, encoding only P1 and P2, was viable in rich and minimal medium. Deletion of seven genes had little effect on viability, growth, morphology, or PG composition in rich medium. However, in vitro growth is not sufficient to study fitness of pathogen S. aure.
Researchers studied the bacterium Burkholderia pseudallei, which causes a difficult-to-treat disease called meloidosis. They wanted to understand how it infects, invades, and survives in the body and how it gets iron, a crucial for growth. Iron is hard to find in the body, so bacteria have ways to get it. They thought Burkia pseudalle used a common iron-getting system called siderophore, but found a strain that didn't have this system was still able to infect mice. This suggested other systems might be important. They deleted the main iron-getting systems in a strain and found a new way to get iron that wasn't known before. They also found that a system to get iron from hemoglobin, a protein in blood, was important. Without it, the bacterium couldn't get iron from hemoglobin. But, it could get iron from another source called ferritin. This means Burkia pseudalle might use a new way to get iron to grow in the body. This could help it survive and cause disease. The study suggests Burkia pseudalle adapts to body conditions and finds new ways to get iron when one system fails.
Researchers have developed a new tool called COMM (COnsensus Metabolic Model GENeration) to create more accurate and comprehensive models of how cells work. These models, called genome-scale constraint metabolic models (GSMs), are like detailed maps of a cell's metabolic processes, but often have inconsistencies that make them hard to use. COMM automatically identifies and resolves these inconsistencies between different models, creating a more complete and accurate representation of a cell's function. Tests on four organisms showed that the automatically generated models were predictive and more coherent than individual models. This tool is especially useful for complex cases where manual curation doesn't scale, such as in early organisms, microbial communities, and host-pathogen interactions.

Genome-scale metabolic models are both knowledge databases and mathematical models. A consensus model should be more comprehensive than individual models due to shared and unique parts, and accurate due to reconciling inconsistencies. COMM identifies similarities, differences, and complements of metabolic networks based on common problems during integration and algorithms to resolve. Identifying similar reactions in different compartments is difficult, but an extension could progress this by combining information from metabolites prior to matching. COMM bridges automation and high-quality manual curation for consensus model generation.

These models are organism-specific, containing thousands of metabolites, reactions, and genes. Automatically generated consensus models have higher predictive power than manually curated models and comparable to manually constructed models. COMM increases coherence with biological while maintaining predictive power, important for usability and reliability to elucidate cell interactions.
Researchers have identified two genes, famb and xyl1, that play a crucial role in the development of cartilage and bone in the body. Cartilage is a type of connective tissue that provides cushioning and support to joints, while bone is the hard, calcified tissue that makes up the skeleton. In the process of bone formation, cartilage cells, called chondrocytes, interact with a protein-rich matrix and undergo a transition, or maturation, to become bone. The researchers used zebraf fish to study the interaction between cartilage and bone and found that cartilage inhibits chrocy maturation, which determines the timing of bone formation. They isolated mutants with decreased cartilage and increased bone and identified the genes famb and xyl, which encode enzymes that synthesize proteoglycans, a type of protein in cartilage. Mutants lacked normal levels of proteoglycan sulfate, a key component of cartilage, and formed bone earlier than normal siblings. Chrotes in mutants initiated maturation prematurely, showing increased expression of certain markers and suppressed bone formation. Ultrastructural analysis showed abnormal matrix and cellular features of chrotes in mutants. The study confirms previous findings that fam and xyl are involved in proteoglycan synthesis and reveals their role in cartilage production and timing of skeletal development.
Researchers studied the role of Topoisomerase II (Top) in the separation of heterochromatic regions during meiosis in Drosoph melanogaster females. They found that knocking down Top in the later stages of meiosis caused defects in the separation of heteroch regions after spindle assembly. In Top-expressing oocytes, heteroch regions of achmate and chmate chromosomes failed to separate during prometaph and metaphase, and were stretched into long projections with centromeres localizing near the tips. Despite this, bipolar spindles formed in most Top-express oocytes, but achmate chromosomes failed to move towards the poles during prometaph. Both ach and chmate chromosomes showed defects in orientation. Euchromatic regions separate earlier in prophase, no defects were observed in their separation upon Top knockdown at midphase. Embryos from Top-express females failed to initiate mitotic divisions. The study suggests Topois II resolves heteroch DNA entang during meiosis and these entang must be resolved to complete meiosis.
Researchers conducted a field study to evaluate the effectiveness of using deltamethrin-impregnated collars to control and prevent visceral leishmanias in dogs in a highly endemic area in Brazil. The study took place in two areas: an intervention area where dogs were collared and a control area where conventional measures were applied. Dogs were tested for the disease at the beginning and end of the study and every 7-8 months in between. Dogs in the intervention area that tested positive received new collars and those that tested negative were included. Authorities were notified of positive dogs in both areas, which were euthanized as per Brazilian law. Initially, seroprevalence was similar in both areas, but at the second evaluation, a significant reduction was seen in both areas, with 6.0% in the intervention and 11.0% in control. The intervention showed a 55% protection against the disease. Although incidence didn't differ between areas, an increase was seen in control, possibly due to low seroconversion or loss to follow-up. The study suggests deltamrin-impregnated collars may provide protection over time, but its effectiveness as a public health measure was inconclusive.
Researchers investigated why the mammalian X chromosome has a non-random gene content, with some genes being highly expressed and others not. They proposed that this bias may be due to limitations on gene expression caused by the X being haploid, meaning it has only one copy. They tested this idea using data from the Encyclopedia of DNA (ENCODE) and Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome (FANT5) projects. The results showed that genes on the X chromosome have lower maximal expression levels than those on autosomes, with an average of three times lower. Genes on the X also have less increase in expression compared to their autosomal counterparts in the human-chimpanzee common ancestor. The "traffic jam" model explains why genes on the X have lower breadth of expression and why highly expressed genes are rare on the X but broadly expressed on autos. Tissue-specific genes are also rare on the X and tend to be low expressed, indicating the trend is due to maximal level not breadth. A limit on maximal expression explains biased tissue profiles of X-linked genes. Tissues with highly expressed genes (e.g. secretory, structural) are also have low expression on X. This cannot be fully explained by other models of biased expression. The idea that X is hard to highly express due to transcription jams provides a simple explanation for X's gene content, expression, and evolution.
A recent study investigated the prevalence and population structure of the gastric pathogen Helicobacter pylori in the Baka Pygmies, a subgroup of the Pygmy people in Cameroon. The researchers found that the Baka had a significantly lower infection rate of H. pylori (20.8%) compared to their neighboring agriculturalist non-Baka (80.2%). Multilocus haplotypes were generated for each H. pyl isolate, but no Baka-specific lineages were identified, and most isolates were assigned to the hpAfrica or hpAfrica populations. The hpAfrica population, associated with the Nilo-Saharan language family, was divided into East and West African subpopulations, and a new hp1 subpopulation was identified among Cameroonians, supporting the expansion of Bantu languages. An age-structured model showed that the low H. pyl prevalence among Baka is achievable within a few hundred years, suggesting demographic factors like small population size and low life expectancy led to eradication of H. pyl from individual populations. The Baka were either H. pyl-free or lost their lineages during demographic fluctuations. Coalescent simulations and phylogenetic inference showed Baka acquired extant H. pyl through contact with agricultural neighbors.
Dengue virus NS5 is a highly conserved protein that plays a crucial role in capping and replication of the virus genome, as well as interacting with host proteins to modulate immune responses. Unlike other flaviviruses, DENV2 NS localizes to the nucleus during infection, but its role in replication and pathogenesis is unclear. Researchers studied NS of DENV1 and 2, which differ in nuclear localization, using a combination of functional and structural analyses. They found that the C-terminal 18 amino acids (C18) of NS direct the protein to cytoplasm or nucleus, respectively. A low-mic affinity between C18 and nuclear receptor importin-alpha (Imp) allowed the complex to be purified and visualized at 2.2 Å resolution using x-ray crystallography. Structure-guided mutational analysis revealed important residues for NS subcell localization. Notably, a proline 884 allows Imp binding, and mutating it to threonine, present in D1 NS, results in mislocalization to cytoplasm without compromising virus fitness. In contrast, mutating arginine 888, conserved in all flaviviruses, to alanine results in non-viable virus, while R888 mutation leads to severely attenuated phenotype, though NS is in nucleus. R forms hydrogen bond with Y conserved in alliviruses, suggesting evolutionarily conserved function for C18, possibly in RNA interactions critical for replication, independent of subcell localization.
Researchers have developed a new method for mapping neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) that can be used by health ministries in endemic countries to determine if a threshold for public health interventions has been reached. The Integrated Mapping (IT) Methodology combines data for lymphatic filariasis (LF), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) and is designed to be efficient and practical. It uses World Health Organization (WHO) recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups. The study tested the protocol by comparing it to current mapping methods for each disease in one district in Mali and Senegal. Results showed that IT reached the same conclusions as WHO regarding public interventions for trach, LF, and STH but resulted in more targeted recommendations for schosiasis. The methodology was feasible and cost-effective compared to standard, non-integrated WHO methods. This integrated tool can facilitate implementation in endemic countries. 

The IT methodology determines if a disease has reached threshold for public health intervention by balancing epidemiologic rigor and practicality. It does not provide prevalence figures but aims to determine if a threshold has been reached. The approach is logistically practical, cost-efficient and flexible. For schosiasis, the approach results in more targeted interventions compared to district-level implementation by integrated NTD programs. The protocol uses age-specific indicators as recommended by WHO.
In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the phosphatase C14 is required for exit from mitosis and is anchored to nucleolar chromatin by the C1/Net protein until anaphase, when it is released into the nucleoplasm. Two pathways, FEAR and MEN, promote C14 release, but the mechanisms are poorly understood. Researchers found that ubiquitination of histone H2 by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase is necessary for C14 release from nucleolar chrom when MEN is inactivated. This process is mediated by histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79, but not histone deacetylase HD2, which associates with C14 onolar chrom as part of RENT. Defects in C14 release were also seen in cells lacking H3 lys 36 methylation and in cells with HD recruited by this modification. These histone modifications are new factors for FEAR components to act on nucleolar chrom. This contrasts with the idea that histone marks act in a combinator code for biological processes.
Researchers have developed a new computational method called GeneProgram to identify groups of genes that work together to perform specific functions in the human body. This method, based on a mathematical concept called Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes, addresses challenges in analyzing large datasets of gene expression data, such as differences in cell types and genetic variations across samples. GeneProgram organizes genes and tissues into overlapping groups with consistent behavior, producing maps of expression programs sorted by generality scores that automatically. Using synthetic and real data, Gene outperformed popular analysis methods. The researchers applied Gene to a dataset of 62 time-series gene expression, studying human responses to infectious agents and immune-modulating molecules. Gene produced a map of 104 expression programs, many of which were enriched for genes in key pathways and bound by NF-κ transcription factors. Gene also discovered programs implicating surprising pathways, such as Wnt and neurotransmitter receptors, in response to infection. The researchers believe this map will guide future experiments, with genes of low generality as potential targets and high generality maintaining common responses in disease states. Gene is a general method for large data and can be applied to new biological datasets.
Researchers have found that a specific type of immune cell, called NKGChi NK cells, plays a crucial role in fighting off cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. These cells produce interferon (IF-γ), a protein that helps fight off the virus. Similar to memory T cells, NKGChi cells can remember past infections and respond quickly to future threats. However, the mechanisms behind this memory-like behavior were not fully understood. The study found that NKGChi cells in people with CMV infection have a specific epigenetic mark on the IF locus, a region that controls IF-γ production. This mark, called CNS1, is also found in memory T cells and helps them produce IF-γ when triggered. The researchers showed that CNS is essential for NKG cells to produce IFγ in response to CMV. This epigenetic mark is a key mechanism for NKG cells to remember CMV and produce IFγ, providing a basis for their memory-like behavior.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which the bacterium Legionella pneumophila regulates its effectors within host cells. An effector proteins are molecules secreted by the bacterium to manipulate host cellular processes for infection. Temporal regulation of these effectors is crucial for distinct activities at different stages of infection. The study found a protein, Lub, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, hijacks the host proteome to target another effector, Sid, for degradation. Delayed delivery of Lub to the cytoplasm leads to shutdown of Sid at later stages of infection. This shows a sophisticated co-evolution between host and bacterium involving an effector as a key regulator of cognate effector function.

LubX acts as a negative regulator of Sid within host cells, the first example of an effector targeting a cognate eff within host. The researchers propose "metaeffector" for this class of bacterial effectors. Determinants of susceptibility are encoded in effectors themselves. Sid is an intrinsically stable within host, but Lub controls instability by targeting for ubiquination. Lub is a metaeff, regulating another eff within host. The targets of E ligases are largely unknown, previous studies aimed at host proteins. Sid is a target of bacterial E ligase. Future studies will reveal effectors implicated in ubiqu system functions as metaeff coordinating expression spatiemporally.

The role of Lub at late infection stages is unclear. Host kinase Cl1 is a substrate of Lub. With findings, one explanation is Lub has multiple targets including Sid and Cl. Accumulating evidence eff proteins as E ubiquinases are prevalent among pathogens.
Researchers studied the genetic changes that occur in the HIV virus when it first infects a new host. They analyzed data from 81 individuals who were infected with a single or closely related viruses and found that some parts of the virus's genetic code changed more quickly than expected. This rapid change could be due to the virus adapting to the host's immune system or reverting to a less fit form that was previously selected out by the immune system. The team identified 24 sites that changed rapidly and found that 14 were in areas targeted by the immune system's T-cells or in specific to the host's HLA. Some of these sites were also changed due to a process called APOB, which helps the virus escape the immune system. Ten sites couldn't be explained by immune escape or APO, including one in the fusion protein gp41. The study also looked at insertions and deletions in the virus and found that changes in the envelope protein's variable region were due to selection, not random mutations. This research provides insight into how HIV evolves when it first infects a new host, highlighting the role of immune escape and APO in shaping the virus's evolution.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to understand how epigenetic silencing works in yeast, focusing on two key chromatin marks: H4 acetylation and H3 methylation. They found that having both modifications is crucial for the stability of epigen states. The model shows that under certain conditions, chromatin can have both active and silenced marks, a state called bivalent. This bivalent state is stable under perturbations like mutations or changes in enzymatic activity. The researchers also found that a limited supply of silencing proteins can lead to counterintuitive responses. They investigated the design of the silencing system and compared it to experimental observations, including the role of Sir protein, spreading, and stability of silenced regions in mutants like Sas2 and Dot1. The model can be extended to include other silencing and active marks, like methylation, to understand which marks are essential for epigen fate and which reinforce one over another. The model captures mechanisms of cooperativity at the molecular level in yeast silencing, including histone modification and protein interactions. Active chromatin sites are not only acetylated but also hypermethylated at certain residues. One protein, Dot, methylates H79 and competes with Sir for the same patch on histone region. The co-occurrence of sil and active marks, called bivalent chromatin, has been discussed in Poly silencing and HP binding. The model shows how bivalent states emerge from known interactions.
Researchers in Uganda studied the gut microbiota (GM) of children hospitalized with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) to see if it differed between those with edemat and non-edemat forms of the condition. Edemat malnutrition, also known as kwashiork, is the most severe form of SAM. The study included 87 children aged 6-24 months, with 62% suffering from edemat malnutrition and 66% being boys with a mean age of 16.1 months. Fecal samples were collected at admission, DNA extracted, and analyzed by PCR and high-throughput sequencing. Results showed GM differed between the two groups, with non-edemat children having lower diversity. However, beta diversity analysis did not reveal differences between GM of edemat and non-ed SAM. The study suggests non-ed SAM children have lower GM diversity, but no clear compositional differences were found. A link between GM and malnutrition has been reported, with pathogenic bacteria found in malnour children. Transplanting fecal samples from Malian twins with edemat malnutrition into mice showed a direct relationship. GM dysbiosis is associated with malnutrition, but if GM differs between ed and non-ed SAM is unknown. The study's finding of GM diversity differences justifies further research on therapeutic strategies.
Researchers studied the variation in telomere length in 112 wild yeast isolates of Saccharomyces sensu stricto. They found significant variation in telere length among the isolates, with European strains having extremely short telomeres (less than 150 bp) and American isolates having telom approximately three times longer (over 400 bp). Inserting a URA gene near telom allowed analysis of individual telere lengths and telomere effect (TE). Crossing American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telere lengths consistent with multiple quantitative loci (QTL) involved in length. Variation in TE is quantitative but weakly correlated with telere length. Genotyping F1 segregants indicated several QTL associated with telere length and silencing. These QTL include candidate genes but also map to regions with no known telom properties. Transgressive segregation was detected for both phenotypes, validated by reciprocal hemizosity that YU80 and TLC are telere QTL in two S paradox subpopulations. Sequence divergence within Ku80 generates negative epistasis in allelic combinations (American-YU and EuropeanU) resulting in short telomeres.
Researchers have long sought to understand the cognitive and neural processes behind human decision-making by predicting when and how people choose. Sequential sampling models (SSMs) have advanced the field by assuming decisions emerge from a bounded accumulation process, making response times (RTs) predictable. However, these models fail when people are not forced to respond immediately but allowed to sample information sequentially, as the decision-maker may choose to delay and terminate the process, a scenario not accounted for by standard SS. A new SS was developed to predict RTs from electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies, where participants bought or rejected fictitious stocks based on sequentially presented cues, free to respond at any time. Standard SS did not describe RT distributions, but adding a mechanism for postponing decisions to the model obtained an accurate fit. Time-frequency analysis of EEG data revealed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta-frequencies (14-30Hz), indicating responses prepared and inhibited, supporting a decision to not decide. The model also accounted for results of an adapted paradigm where participants pressed a button for more information. Results show computational modeling decisions and RT support understanding hidden dynamics in cognition.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the SUVH2 gene as the cause of hereditary nasal parakerosis (HN) in Labrador Retrievers, a rare skin disorder causing crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study of 13 HN cases and 23 controls found a strong association on chromosome 2. Resequencing of one case's genome revealed 3 non-synonymous variants in the SUVH gene, with one perfectly associated with HN in a cohort of 500 dogs. The candidate variant is a missense in SUVH, a histone lysine 9 (H3) methyltransferase, mediating chromatin silencing. The variant c.972G>T changes a conserved asparagine to lysine in the catalytically active domain. Histopathological studies suggest HN is not due to hyperproliferation but delayed differentiation of kerocytes. SUVH is involved in epetic regulation of kerocyte differentiation, ensuring proper stratification and sealing of mammalian epidermis.
Researchers studied how the mixing of avian and swine influenza viruses in pigs can lead to the creation of new, potentially pandemic-causing strains. They found that when pigs are infected with both avian and swine viruses, genetic mixing occurs in the lower respiratory tract, and the type of virus that is shed from the pig is influenced by the type of cells in the respiratory tract. The study showed that pigs can serve as a "mixing vessel" for avian and swine viruses, which can then be transmitted to humans. By housing pigs infected with both avian and swine viruses, the researchers found 30 different types of reassortant viruses in the lower respiratory tract, but only a few were shed. The type of virus shed was influenced by its ability to replicate in pig nasal cells at 33°C. The study suggests that tissue tropism, or the type of cells in the respiratory tract, plays a key role in selecting which reassortant virus is shed.
A study investigated the effect of maternal Schistosoma mansoni infection and prazantel treatment during pregnancy on Schistoma mans infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at age five. Offspring of Schistoma-infected women in endemic areas may be sensitized in utero, which may influence their immune responsiveness to Schoma infection and associated morbidity. The study examined the effects of prazant treatment of S mans during pregnancy on the risk of S infection among offspring and their immune responses when exposed to S. In a trial in Uganda, offspring of women treated with prant or placebo during pregnancy were examined for S infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SW and SEA, as well as T cell expression FoxP at five years. Of 134 children, 2.4% had S infection at five years based on a single sample. Infection did not differ between children of treated or untreated mothers. Cytokine IFγ, IL-5, IL-10 and IL-13 and antibody IgG, Ig and IgE responses to SW and SEA, and FoxP expression were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazant treatment S during pregnancy had no effect on responses, except IL-10 to SW which was higher in offspring of women who received prazant than those who did. No evidence found that S mans infection and treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence and intensity S infection or immune response among offspring at five, but observed on IL-10 to SW suggest that S and treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoreg responsiveness in schosomias.
Researchers have discovered a new way that the body's immune cells, called macrophages, can quickly get rid of infectious material. Normally, macrophages use a process called phagocytosis to take in and destroy pathogens, but this process is slow. The scientists found that when macrophages are activated by inflammation, they switch to a faster process called macinocytosis, which allows them to quickly transfer material to lysosomes for destruction. This switch is controlled by a protein called coronin 1, which is activated by a chemical signal. When coron 1 is activated, it turns on an enzyme called PI-3-kinase, which is necessary for macinocytosis. Even without inflammation, expressing a special form of coron 1 can activate PI-3kinase and cause macocytosis. This means that macrophages can get rid of pathogens quickly and efficiently, which is important for the body's defense against infection.
Researchers conducted a study in Arua District, North Uganda to assess community acceptance of tset baits (insecticide-treated targets) in areas where they had not been used before. The study involved 16 focus group discussions with male and female participants in 8 villages across the district. Results showed that villagers who had never seen baits before expressed fear and anxiety, associating them with witchcraft and "ghosts from the river", which are linked to illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers in areas where ba had been used previously had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. They reported similar negative perceptions when tset control started a decade ago. The study suggests acceptance varies between villages and is related to duration with tse programs. Success of community-based interventions against tse will depend on engagement and sensitization that reaches all communities, especially in new areas.

The study was conducted in an area of West Nile, North Uganda, where ba have been used in government programs against Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT). Community acceptance is crucial for effective tse control, as seen in a previous study in Democratic Republic of Congo where negative attitudes led to damage and failure. Efforts to enhance participation include encouraging people to handle ba, construction, deployment, and maintenance in countries like Uganda, Kenya, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast, Ethiopia, and Sudan. In this area, 70 ba were deployed per year, but not regularly monitored, resulting in unsustainable control.

Sleeping sickness, caused by Trypanosoma brucei transmitted by tse, affects West and Central Africa, including the study area. Tse also transmit other species to livestock, causing losses. In H villages, no previous tse programs, ba were introduced as part of the study. 8 villages were included, 4 from H+ and 4 H-.
Researchers have studied the process of recombination in fruit flies (Drosophila melanaster) to understand how it affects evolution. Recombination is a key process that helps selection act on genetic variation in populations. However, previous studies have been limited due to lack of detailed information on recombination rates across and within species. This study mapped recombination in 5,860 female flies, genotyping 139 million SNPs and 106,964 recombination events at 2-kilobase resolution. They created whole-genome maps of recombination and variation among individuals. Results show recombination rates vary greatly at large and small scales. At large scales, recombination rates are highly variable and punctuated, with hotspots and coldspots. At small scales, recombination is associated with sequence motifs and occurs in transcript regions, suggesting chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. This study highlights the importance of considering recombination variation in population genetics and evolution.
Researchers have identified a protein called ID2 (ID2) that plays a crucial role in a process called RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) in the plant Arabidopsis plant. To understand how ID2 works, they purified the protein and found that it associates with two similar proteins, ID1 and ID2, which are part of the same family as ID2. They discovered that a specific part of ID2, called the coiled coil, is necessary for ID2 to bind to itself, but not to ID1 or ID2. Another part of ID, the X domain, is required for ID to bind to ID1 and ID2. The researchers also found that ID1 is necessary for DNA methylation, RNA accumulation, and gene silencing, while ID2 has similar but not identical roles. Unlike ID, ID1 and ID2 cannot bind double-stranded RNA, suggesting their roles differ from ID in the ID-ID1-ID2 complex. ID1 and ID2 are essential for the complex to function in RDM.
Exposure to Leishmania braziliensis triggers neutrophil activation and apoptosis. Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to the site of Leishmanial inoculation. During Leish braziliensis infection, depletion of neutrophils significantly increases the parasite load, whereas co-culture of neutils with L braziliensis has an opposite effect. The co-culture of infected macrophages and neutils induced parasite killing, leading to the question of how neutils respond to L brazili exposure. This study focused on the interaction between neutils and Lili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized Lili promastigotes mice neutil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 hours. In vitro exposure of thioglyateelic inflammatory bone neutils to Lili modulated expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CD62, and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-expressing Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected and bystander cells. Neutil activation with Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils with Lili displayed markers of early apoptosis. Lili induces neutil recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed to the parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This may impact parasite elimination, particularly at early stages of infection.
Researchers explored the potential of vaccination as a supplementary control measure for bovine tuberculosis (TB) in cattle. Currently, vaccination is not used in international control programs and is banned in the EU. Candidate vaccines based on Mycobacterium bovis bacillus Calmet-Guerin (BCG) interfere with the tuberculin skin test, used to determine if herds and countries are TB-free. New tests, Differentiated Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIV), can introduce vaccination into existing eradication programs. Using herd models from Britain, they estimated the feasibility of supplemental vaccination. The economic impact of TB on farmers is dominated by testing costs and restrictions. Farmers will adopt vaccination if it reduces burden and restrictions. In Britain's testing sequence, the DIV test's specificity, not sensitivity, is the barrier to herd benefit. Relaxing testing could mitigate negative effects, but increase hidden infection in officially free herds. Models explored DIV characteristics for herd benefit. A 99.85% specificity and 40% sensitivity is required. Data from infected animals suggest a cocktail of DIV antigens can achieve 99.85% specificity and 73.3% sensitivity.
Researchers have identified a new class of compounds called dihydrobenz[e][1,4]azin-2(3)-ones that show promise as a potential treatment for a parasitic worm infection called Trichuris. This worm infects around 500 million people worldwide, causing physical and educational problems. Current treatments are limited and not effective, making new options crucial. The researchers tested these compounds on a mouse model of the parasite, Truris, and found they paralyzed the adult worms and reduced the ability of eggs to infect a host. The most active compound, dihydrozoxazin O029, was as effective at 25-50 micromolar concentration, similar to existing treatments. Importantly, it showed low toxicity to mouse cells, indicating selectivity for the parasite. Developing a new treatment for a neglected disease is challenging, but dihydrozazones could be given orally or as a spray to interrupt the parasite lifecycle. These results show dihydroazones are a new class of treatment for Trichis, active against both egg and adult stages, with potential for further optimization to improve potency and pharmacokinetics for a clinical use.
Researchers have re-examined the concept of "date" and "party" hubs in protein-protein interaction networks, where "date" hubs have low expression with their partners and "party" hubs have high expression. They proposed that "party" hubs are local coordinators and "date" are global connectors. However, the study found that the importance of "date" hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small number of extremely central hubs, which do not display low expression, contradicting the idea of a link between quantity and function. The "date/party distinction was motivated by a bimodal distribution of hub-expression, but this feature is not robust to method changes. Topological properties of hubs do not correlate with expression, but there is a correlation between centrality and functional similarity of interacting proteins. The researchers suggest thinking in terms of "date/p dichotomy for protein networks is not meaningful, and it's more useful to consider roles of protein-protein interactions than individual proteins.
Researchers have developed methods to use whole-genome sequence data to track the spread of infectious diseases, but a major limitation is the need for genetic diversity to occur on a timescale of outbreaks. This means that only if mutations have accumulated between pathogen genomes can be used to determine the position of individuals in a transmission tree. To compare the usefulness of genetic data in different outbreaks, the concept of "transmission" was introduced, defined as the number of mutations between sequences from transmission pairs. Using literature values, simulations were run with two models to describe the transmission of major pathogens. Results showed that mean transmission varies between pathogens, but is generally low, with many outbreaks having many genetically identical pairs. This limits the ability to reconstruct outbreaks using genetic data, especially for pathogens like Streptoccus, Shigella, and Clostrid, which provide little to no information on individual events. The study highlights the limitations of genetic data in certain scenarios and the need to expand tools to include other types of data.
Researchers studied how genes on the X chromosome that escape inactivation, a process that silences most genes on the X chromosome in female mammals, in mouse tissues and cells. They used single nucleotide polymorphisms to distinguish between alleles and analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes. The study found a continuum between complete silencing and expression from the inactive X chromosome, with few genes escaping in most tissues, about 3-7%. However, in embryonic-kid-derived Pki cells, a higher number of genes escaped, 21%, representing both kidney-specific and cell-specific genes. Allele RNA polymerase occupancy and DNase hypersensitivity at gene promoters correlated with escape levels, indicating open chromatin structure. CTCF binding on the inactive X was denser in brain compared to Pki cells, possibly due to compartmentalized structure and fewer escape genes in brain.

The study identified genes expressed from both X chromosomes in mouse tissues, with a minority escaping in tissue and cell-specific manner, indicating tight control of X and escape. The probability of bi-allelic versus mono-allelic expression was calculated using a new algorithm. Surveys in human/mouse cells showed 8-15% consistently escape, 10-13 variable, and 10-20 varying between lines and individuals. Escape from X results in sexual dimorphisms and bi-alle expression of some genes is important for normal female phenotype. Mouse 3-7 genes may be exceptional compared to other mammals with similar human patterns.

Escape genes were distributed along the X, not influenced by distance from the X center, and play roles in regulation and translation, explaining consistent escape. Tissue-specific genes will help understanding sex differences.
Researchers have identified a new cystine protease in the parasite Plasium viv, a type of malaria that causes hundreds of millions of illnesses and deaths worldwide. This protease, called VX-4, has unique properties that allow it to break down different proteins at different pH levels. It is most active at acidic pH 5.5, where it breaks down a protein called Z-Arg-MCA, and at neutral pH 6.5-7.5, it breaks Z-Arg-MCA. VX-4 prefers positively charged amino acids at the first position and less specificity at third and fourth positions. Three amino acids in its pocket are different from similar proteases VX-2 and VX-3. Replacing one of these amino acids, Glu180, abolishes activity at neutral pH. VX-4 is found in the food vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocyte stage of P. viv. It breaks actin at neutral pH and P. viv plasm 4 and hemoglobin at acidic pH. VX-4 shows pH-dependent switching, allowing it to break different substrates in different environments. It might break hemoglobin in acidic foodu, P viv plasm 4 at neutral or acidic, and cytoskeleton in erythrocyte cytol.
Scientists have created a new model to better understand how a type of microbe called Clostridium ljungahli works. This microbe can turn many different substances into useful products, making it a good candidate for sustainable production of chemicals. However, understanding its biology was limited, making it hard to design new strategies. The new model, called iL965ME, includes all major pathways for making proteins, amino acids, nucleotides, lipids, and vitamins, as well as RNA and protein synthesis. It's the first for a Gram-positive bacterium and broadens predictability. The model shows how protein and media composition affect metabolism and energy in this microbe, and predicts multiple products like glycerol, a new product for this microbe. It also shows how changing metal availability affects secretion, opening up new ways to optimize fermentation and understand proteome and carbon flux.

The model includes all major metabolic, amino, acid, nucleotide, lipid, and vitamin synthesis pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for reactions. It also includes cofactors and mechanisms for energy conservation. The model predicts secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycer during carbon and metal availability, and how protein and media influence metabolic and energy in this microbe. Enzyme rates were approximated due to lack of data, set to 25s-1, average of acetogens. Macromolecular costs were coupled with reactions using COBrame formulation.
Researchers used a panel of human osteoblast cells (HO) to study the genetic control of transcript variation in these cells, similar to previous studies in lymphoblast cell lines (Ls). They found that HO and Ls have distinct gene expression profiles, with some genes specific to each cell type. By analyzing genetic variants, they found that expression of certain transcript forms in HO is controlled by genetic variants, both in a tissue-specific and tissue-independent way. These associations were confirmed by RT-PCR. The study suggests that multiple transcript forms are present in both tissues and genetic can affect the expression of one form over another, rather than an all-or-no effect. Examination of top SNPs from genome-wide association studies of bone density showed overlap with this study's associations, including the FAM118 gene, which was tested in additional studies revealing a novel transcript variant. This approach to examining transcript variation in multiple tissues is useful for detecting common genetic variation between cell types and identifying cell-specific variants that may be functionally important, a next step for genome-wide association studies.
Researchers studied the yeast Saccharomyces eayan, a parent of the lager-brew hybrid Saccharcesorian, to understand why it can't use maltotose, a key sugar in brewer's wort. Unlike most Saccharces cerevisiae and Saccharorian strains, Sacchar eayan can't use maltose because it lacks a maltose transporter gene. However, it has genes that help it use maltose, a similar sugar. To see if Sac eayan can use maltose, scientists made mutants that can't use maltose and grew them on maltose-rich wort. One mutant grew well and fermented maltose and maltose. Genome analysis showed a new maltose transporter gene, made from pieces of other genes. This new gene works like the original maltose transporters and lets Sac eayan grow on maltose. The new gene's structure is similar to Sacorian's maltose transporter, which is similar to cerevisiae and eayan maltose transporters. This suggests that Sacorian's ability to use maltose may have come from similar changes as seen in this study.
Researchers have found a link between the severity of influenza virus strains and how different they are from previous strains of the same type. This relationship helps predict how many deaths a new strain will cause. They developed a method to quickly estimate the impact of new influenza A H1N virus by measuring how different it is from previous H1 strains. This can help create a cost-effective plan to prevent and control the spread of the virus. The study used a simplified model of how the virus interacts with the host to find the connection between antigen variation and mortality. The model only considered strains that cause significant infection in humans, denoted as "antigen strains". The method, called EAD, predicted antigen distance with high accuracy and was tested on H1 virus. Results showed a strong correlation between predicted distance and observed mortality. The method can be used to estimate mortality of future H1 variants and with modification for H2 and B viruses.
Researchers have identified a small cysteine-rich protein, called PEC23, from the Asian soybean fungus Phakora pachyri, that suppresses plant immunity. This fungus causes severe disease in soybeans and its mechanisms of interaction with the plant are not well understood. PEC23 interacts with a soybean transcription factor, GSP12, which is a negative regulator of plant defenses. When GSP12 is silenced, soybeans have constitutively active immunity. The study suggests P23 is a virulence factor that suppresses plant immune responses and interacts with GSP12. P23 has a unique tandem cystine motif found in other rust fungi and interacts with GSP12. Silencing G12 shows it is a negative regulator of plant defense. Infection assays on G12-silenced and P23-silenced soybeans showed no change in disease phenotype, possibly due to redundancy of P. pachy effector proteins. Data show G12 acts as an immune suppressor to ensure plant growth in absence of infection.
Researchers have identified the EphA receptor, a protein on the surface of host cells, as a key player in the invasion and replication of the bacterium Chlamydia trachatis. This bacterium invades host cells and replicates inside a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion, where multiple host proteins are recruited to support its development. The researchers found that EphA activates a signaling pathway called PI3, which is necessary for the bacterium's replication. Interfering with EphA's binding to the bacter or downregulating its expression significantly reduced infection. The bacter interacts with Eph on the cell surface, internalizing it, and during replication, Eph remains active around the inclusion, interacting with a PIK subunit to activate the PI/Akt pathway. Overexpressing EphA, but not a mutant form lacking the intracellular domain, enhanced PI activation and infection. Despite depleting Eph from the surface, the bacter upregulates it through the ER pathway, keeping infected cells resistant to apoptosis. The study shows Eph is a receptor for invasion and intracellular signaling, a new mechanism by which Chydia subverts host cells and induces resistance.
Researchers have long known that neurons have voltage-gated ion channels in their dendrites, which can make them excitable. However, the role of this excitability in dendritic computation has remained unclear. A new study shows that the output of a model of an active dendritic tree is a highly non-linear function of afferent rate, with a dynamic range of over 50 decibels. This is similar to the double-sigmoid response observed in retinal ganglion cells. The researchers propose that the enhancement of dynamic range is the primary role of active dendritic conductances. They predict that neurons with larger dendritic trees will have a larger dynamic range and blocking active conductances will decrease it.

The study aims to examine the possibility that dendrites are the site of computation. Dendritic spikes are a result of excitable dynamics, but even without plasticity, dendrites can benefit from active conductances for increased range. Neurons have extensive dendritic trees, and much work has been done on their morphology and dynamics. The presence of active channels in dendrites was discovered recently.

The researchers propose that large dendrites amplify weak signals and saturate strong activity. This "dynamic range" problem is a trade-off between sensitivity and saturation, important for neurons, networks, organs, and organisms. The study suggests that under synaptic bombardment, dendritic spikes are responsible for a new prediction: the transfer function is not Hill-like, but double-sigmoid, as seen in retinal ganglion cells.
Researchers studied how to improve the accuracy of models that infer gene regulation from time-series data. Current methods assume mRNA levels represent protein concentrations and changes in gene expression are due to transcription factors, neglecting other effects. They investigated this bias using a combination of models and experiments on the Fli-FlM module in E. coli. coli. They measured gene activity in real-time and estimated protein concentrations and physiological effects using kinetic models. Results show correcting assumptions improves model quality, especially for systems with long protein half-lives and varying expression machinery activity. The approach is applicable to learn regulatory networks from time-series data. In the Fli-FlM module, results highlight global effects and regulation of Fli and FlM halfives for promoter dynamics.

They proposed controls for transcript experiments, constitutively-expressed genes and models to reconstruct protein concentrations and integrate physiological effects. Measuring global effects with a reporter driven constitutive promoter only marginally improved model fit. They estimated Fli and FlM concentrations from promoter activities and plausible halfives, creating a dataset to test mRNA and protein influences on inference. They inferred regulatory and quantitative function of Fli-dependent gene, not regulated by other factors. Estimating protein concentrations from promoter activities and halfives improved inference of interactions and regulation. A model with Fli and FlM as regulators and expression activity is compatible with data. Reconstructing concentrations and quantifying physiological effects have been proposed before, such as for E. coli genes in arginine biosynthesis.
Researchers studied the spatial and temporal distribution of Oligyomys fulcens, a rodent species that carries diseases, in the Agua Buena region of Panama. They analyzed data from a 4-year study of rodent populations in the area, from April 2006 to December 2009, using spatial and statistical methods. The study area was 6.43 square kilometers, with a 0.09 kilometer grid size. The researchers found that O. fulcens populations varied in density and dispersion across seasons and years. The species was absent in late transitional months and re-established in subsequent years. Populations recurred in the same area in first three years, but shifted south in the final year. Spatial analysis showed local populations were about 300-600 meters apart, with sharp borders between suitable and unsuitable habitats. O. fulens showed a changing pattern over time, with shifting hotspots of abundance. This was linked to seasonality and human activities, such as agriculture. These factors define the occurrence, timing, and duration of rodent populations affected by humans, and possible human exposure. The study provides a detailed spatio-temporal analysis of hotspots of rodent habitation and persistence. It highlights the challenges in predicting zoon disease outbreaks at population level, as populations fluctuate over time and are geographically restricted.
Researchers have developed a new method to understand how genetic changes in the influenza A (H3) virus affect its ability to evade the human immune system. This is crucial for creating effective vaccines. The method, called "antigenic tree," assigns weights to each change in the virus's surface protein to show its impact on the immune system. It was tested on data from 1968 to 2003 and found known and new sites that affect the virus's ability to evade the immune system. The technique can be used for other viruses and systems with genetic and phenotypic data.

The method was applied to the major protein of the influenza A (3) virus over 35 years. Branches on the tree represent antigen distances from human viruses and a maximum likelihood of the protein. The impact of amino acid changes on the virus's ability to evade the immune can be determined by experiments, but the new method is faster and less expensive. It uses least squares optimization to fit distances onto a tree for the antigen.

The method was tested on data from 196 to 200 and found areas of the tree corresponding to known antigen types and transitions. It identified isolates with large impact that need to be updated in vaccines. The method is not limited to influenza and can be used for any system with genetic and phenotypic data.
Researchers conducted a large-scale RNA interference (RNAi) screen to identify host factors required for human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) infection. They found that a cluster of mitotic genes, or genes involved in cell division, were necessary for the virus to enter the cell's nucleus. The study revealed a new mechanism for how the virus's DNA (vDNA) enters the nucleus: it relies on the breakdown of the nuclear envelope during cell division. In interphase, the virus is engulfed, routed to the perinuclear area, and uncoated, but the DNA fails to enter the nucleus. Upon nuclear envelope breakdown in interphase, HPV infection occurs. During mitosis, the DNA associates with host chromatin on the metaphase plate. The researchers propose that HPV requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis to access the DNA to the nucleoplasm. The study highlights the value of RNA screens in investigating viral infections and provides a resource for future virus-host interaction studies.
Black Sigat or black streak disease, caused by the Dothideomyc fungus Pseudococospora fiji (previously Mycoserella fiji), is a major threat to global banana production. The disease requires frequent fungicide applications, which increase economic and environmental costs, and lead to rapid evolution of fungicide-resistant strains. To combat this, two strains of P. fiji were sequenced and assembled with a new genetic map. The 74b genome of P. fiji is expanded by LTR transposons, making it the largest in Dothomycetes. Electrophoretic karyotyping and molecular markers showed chromosome polymorphisms and genetic diversity. Genetic differentiation was detected using neutral markers, suggesting selection and limited gene flow. Frequencies of fungicide in treated plantations were higher than untreated P. fiji populations. A homologue of Cladospor fulum Avr effector Pf4 was identified in P. fiji genome. Infiltration of Pf4 into leaves of resistant banana variety Calcut 4 resulted in hypersensitive response, suggesting Cal 4 carries unknown gene recognizing Pf4. The P. fiji genome will aid in fungicide treatment and banana breeding programs.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how specific genes are turned on or off in different species by tracing the evolution of binding sites where proteins attach to DNA. This approach, called the "birth-death model," doesn't rely on comparing DNA sequences between species, but instead looks at when and how often these sites appear in a lineage. The team applied this method to six transcription factors in humans and mice, finding that about 58-79% of their binding sites in humans appeared after they diverged from mice. Over 15% of these sites are unique to humans and are near genes involved in specific pathways, with more genetic variations than older sites. This suggests the method can identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and their role in gene regulation variation across species. Unlike previous approaches, this method uses lineage-specific sites, not just conserved ones, and doesn't rely on cross-species alignments, which can be inaccurate, especially in non-coding regions. The team used ChIP-seq data for six transcription factors, chosen for their diverse functions and well-documented motifs, and availability in human and mouse cell types. The results show lineage differences in evolutionary rates of motifs along a branch in the phylogeny. This study supports the method's ability to identify lineage-specific elements, a step towards understanding regulatory evolution's role in gene variation.
Researchers studied how light affects the circadian clock in zebraf, a vertebrate model that responds to light in most of its tissues. They found that light induces expression of certain genes, including clock genes, in zraf cells in vivo and vitro. However, the mechanism linking light to gene expression was unclear. To understand this, they focused on how light regulates the zraf period2 (per) gene. Using transgenic fish and stably transfected cell-based assays, they defined a Light Module (LRM) within the per promoter.
