Researchers have found a new perceptual bias that affects how people perceive visual stimuli in a two-alternative discrimination tasks. In these tasks, observers try to determine which of two stimuli caused a certain responses. To do this, they integrate noisy neural responses into a reliable representation of the likelihood of each stimulus. Ideally, they should evaluate the likelihood with high precision and consider only the relevant stimuli. However, a new study reveals that observers read the representation with low precision when discriminating spatial frequencies. By using spectrally filtered noise, an asymmetry was induced in the likelihood of spatial frequencies. This mainly affected frequencies irrelevant to the task, yet a significant shift in perceived frequency was found, indicating observers evaluate a range of irrelevant frequencies and discard prior knowledge of alternatives.

 In an experiment, filtered noise altered perception of known gratings in a two-altern spatial discrimination, shifting frequency to lower and higher frequencies in low-pass and high filtered conditions. Observers considered unlikely frequencies, lowering detectability and biasing perceived frequency. Log functions were asymmetrical around vertical frequency in low and high filtered noise. Gratings were presented at high contrasts, corresponding to 84% detection in broadband noise. High performance and steep psychometric functions indicate decisions based on vertical frequency.

The study differs from traditional models of visual encoding in noise, assuming external noise affects variability without changing average response. Grating detectability and discriminability were measured in filtered noise, showing dramatic alteration of perceived frequency. Low-pass noise decreased perceived frequency, while high-pass increased.
Researchers have discovered that in Caenorhabditis elegans, a type of worm, piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) play a crucial role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements. These piRNAs are derived from a long, polycistronic RNA, but in Caenorhabdis elegans, each piRNA is a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit. A 21-nucleotide pi sequence and a 50-nucleotide upstream motif are necessary for expression, and a single nucleotide in the motif determines germline enrichment. Over 70% of Caenorhabdis piRNAs are selectively expressed in male or female germl, suggesting these populations have evolved independently. The upstream motif acts as a promoter, specifying which sequences are expressed as piRNAs, how abundantly they are expressed, and in which germl. The Caenor genome encodes over 15,000 unique pi sequences, rivaling the number of mRNA genes. Researchers used computational and transgenic approaches to find the conserved motif defines the pi transcription cassette, specifying which sequences are expressed as Caenor piRNAs. The motif also encodes information for germl-specific expression of 21 RNAs. Autonomous expression of synthetic 21 RN was demonstrated from minimal transgenic cassettes with the 8 core motif, 40 intervening spacer, 21 RNA, and 100 flanking context. The organization of endogenous pi loci is dispensable for pi expression, suggesting each locus encodes necessary information for independent transcription.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which the bacterium Brucella uses to replicate within host cells. Bruc replicates in a membrane-bound compartment derived from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) called a vacuole. The study found that the IRE pathway of the unfolded protein response (UPR) is activated during Bruc infection, but not the PER and ATF pathways. The IRE pathway upregulates genes involved in the secretory pathway, including Sar, Sec, and SecD. These molecules form COI vesicles at the ER exit sites (E) of the cell. The researchers identified a novel host factor, YipA, which activates the IRE pathway in response to Bruc infection. YipA is responsible for phosphorylating IRE, allowing Ire molecules to assemble at ER sites. Without YA, Bruc fails to form ER-derived vacoles and remains in endosomal/lysosomal compartments. Autophagy proteins Atg and WI, but not DFC, are required for ER-derived compartment biogenesis. The study proposes a model for Bruc replication using host UPR and ER vacole machineries, both dependent on YA-mediated IRE activation.
Tomato bushy stunt virus (TBS) and carnation Italian ring spot virus (CV) recruit the cellular Vps34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PIK) into the viral replication compartment to support their replication. The kinase function of V34 is crucial for TBS replication, suggesting that PI(3) phosphoinoside is used by TBS to build the replication compartment. The expression of V34 and abundance of PI(3) increases in the presence of tombusiral proteins, leading to more efficient TBS replication. Overexpression of PI3 phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibits TBS replication on peroxomal membranes and CV on mitochondrial membranes. Purified PI phosphatase reduces TBS assembly in a cell-free system. Detection of PI with antibody or probe reveals enrichment of PI in replication. V34 is recruited to replication through interaction with p33 protein. Gene analysis in yeast shows TBS requires vesicle transport of V34. Without V34, TBS cannot recruit Rab-positive endosomes, providing membranes for TBS replication. V34 and PI are needed for stability of p33 protein, degraded by 26 proteasome when PI abundance is decreased by V34 inhibitor.
Researchers conducted a study in Iqu, Peru to assess the feasibility of feeding Aedes aegypt mosquitoes on deng virus-infected human volunteers for vector studies. The study aimed to examine the transmission of deng virus (DENV) from humans to mosquitoes, a critical component of deng epidemiology. Participants aged 5 years and older with fever were enrolled from clinic and neighborhood studies. Wild, laboratory-reared Aedes aegypt were fed on feile individuals or blood with or collected from participants treated with EDTA. Mosquitoes were tested after 14 days for DENV infection and dissemination. A total 58 participants with vireas from 1.3 × 102 to 2.9 × 106 focus-forming units/mL participated in one or more feeding methods. DENV infection rates were not different between direct and indirect-ED feeding, but lower for no additive. Dissemination rates were similar across methods. No differences were detected in D infection or dissemination in fed on participants with different deng severity. The study demonstrates direct and indirect feeding for field-based studies. Direct feeding is preferable in terms of ease, biosecurity, and reliability.
Researchers investigated why some cancer patients respond differently to chemotherapy drugs that target topoisomerase II, an enzyme essential for cell division. They used the worm Caenorhabditis elegans as a model and found that different strains vary in sensitivity to these drugs. An unbiased genetic approach revealed that a single amino acid substitution, methionine to glutamine in topoisomerase II, explains this variation. The non-polar methine residue increases hydrophobic interactions with the drug etoposide, leading to increased genomic instability. This residue is conserved from yeast to humans, where it differs between two topoisomerase isoforms, methion in hTOIα and glut in hIβ. The researchers showed that this difference affects cytotoxicity of topois II poisons in human cell lines. This explains why hIα and hβ are differentially affected by poisons and demonstrates the utility of C elegans in understanding drug responses.
Researchers studied the genetics of lifespan in long-lived rodents, specifically the African mole rat, to gain insights into mechanisms determining mammalian lifespan. They analyzed genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species and identified 250 genes associated with enhanced longevity, known as positively selected genes (PSGs). These genes showed an expression pattern in long-lived mole rats and short-lived rats that fits the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging, where genes have opposite effects at different stages of life. The PSGs were enriched in genes related to aging, including cellular respiration, ion homeostasis, and processes regulated by the mTOR pathway: translation, autophagy, and inflammation. Notably, PSGs included RHE, a regulator of mTOR, and IGF, central to aging pathways, as well as unknown genes like RBL, AM2, PSM1, and GER. Protein modeling suggests functional consequences of amino acid changes under selection. The study provides a resource to link genes and amino acids to aging and lifespan.

The researchers scanned PSG on branches of the African rat family and other rodents leading to longevity, examining more ancestral branches than previous studies. Consistent with observed patterns, lower expression of related genes and pharmacological inhibition was associated with longer lifespan in worms, killfish, and mice. mTOR regulates inflammatory and immune responses. Results indicate PSG changes during aging consistent with antagonistic pleiotropy theory. Gene ontology analysis showed significant downregulation in long-lived and upregulation in short-lived, fitting antagonistic pleiotropy. PSG cover processes regulated by mTOR, translation, autagy, and respiration.
Researchers have developed a new strategy to control the spread of diseases transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito by introducing a bacterium called Wolbachia that makes the mosquito sterile or reduces its ability to transmit viruses. They created a new line of Aedes aegypt, called ARP-M, by introducing Wolbach into the mosquito's genetic material. The researchers compared AR-M with the original Aedesegypt line, ARP, and a wild-type Aedesypt with the same genetic background. They found that AR-M had 100% inheritance of Wolbach and showed no difference in survival, fecundity, and fertility compared to the other two lines. However, AR-M males were unable to fertilize wild-type females, while wild males could fertilize AR-M females. When competing with wild males for females, AR-M induced sterility was higher than expected. The Wolbach density in AR-M females was 15 times higher than in AR, mostly due to Wolbach. This corresponded to reduced competence for chikunya and deng viruses, with 5 and 0% transmission rates at 14 and 21 days post-infection, compared to AR females. Results for Zika virus showed no difference between AR-M and AR, but none of AR-M females could transmit Zika. These findings suggest using Wolbach to suppress wild Aedesypt populations.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify peptide-mediated interactions between proteins using high-resolution 3D structures. These interactions occur when a globular protein domain recognizes a linear peptide from another protein, creating a small contact interface. Peptides are often found in unstructured regions of proteins and have a consensus motif complementary to their binding partner's surface. Unlike current methods, this approach focuses on how peptides adopt a defined structure when binding to their partner. Analysis of known peptide interactions showed that their structure can be characteristic of the consensus motif, even if they don't match established patterns. Peptides tend to be stretched and elongated, unlike other peptides of the same length. A Support Vector Machine was used with structure information to scan 50,000 3D protein complexes and identify unnoticed interactions. Derived patterns were compared to established motifs and domains. The method was validated by scanning interactomes of four organisms and found significant over-representations of 64 domain-peptide interactions, 46 of which were new, involving 6,000 interactions.
Researchers studied 49 adults in Zambia with environmental enteropathy, a condition linked to impaired nutrient absorption and vaccine responses. They used confocal endoscopy, histology, and mRNA sequencing to analyze intestinal biopsies and correlated with plasma lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and zinc uptake. Confocal images showed widespread small intestinal damage and epithelial defects at villi tips, confirmed by histology and claudin immunostaining. Multivariate analysis found circulating LPS correlated with cell shedding and serum glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2). Zinc uptake was reduced in 64% of individuals and correlated with GL-2 in multivariate analysis. Transcript analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in enteropathy, including protective peptides and proteins. Epithelial defects are probably sites of bacterial translocation, with increased epithelial surface area increasing translocation burden. GL-2 and other peptides may play a role in mucosal protection in EE.

The researchers also studied zinc uptake in healthy volunteers and found no correlation with epithelial surface area, but transcript analysis showed reduced DMT-1 expression in severe enteropathy, contributing to zinc uptake. Hypochlorhydria was common but not the cause of impaired uptake, as it doesn't depend on gastric acid. The study was restricted to adults and suggests many Zambian adults live with chronic inflammation. Epithelial defects were evaluated semi-quantitatively and quantified in a subset of biies. Claudin-4 immunostaining showed increased shedding and separation, associated with plasma LPS, a component of Gram-negative cell walls.
Researchers have studied a phenomenon called superinfection exclusion (SIE), where some viruses block re-infection of host cells by the same or similar viruses. They found that in turnip crinkle virus (TCV) uses a protein called p28 to achieve this. p28 is one of two proteins encoded by the virus and is responsible for SIE. When p28 is expressed, it blocks replication of TCV replicon, the part of the virus that replicates the virus. Transiently expressed p28, delivered with or before TCVon, also blocks replication. Interestingly, p28's ability to block is enhanced by C-terminal tags but weakened by N-terminal modifications. p28 also forms large, mobile inclusions that trap non-replicating, yet replication-competent p mutants. This suggests p28 forms multimer complexes that intercept fresh p monomers from superfect genomes, stopping replication. This mechanism could apply to other RNA viruses and offer new targets for antiviral therapy.
Researchers have developed a vaccine against Trypanosoma cruzi, a parasite that causes Chagas disease, using a plasmid DNA encoding Trypanosoma cruzi transialase (TS) and IL-15. They tested if adding IL-15 to the vaccine would improve long-term protection. Mice were immunized with TS alone or with TS and IL-15, then tested for immune responses and protection against the parasite. Mice with TS alone developed strong immune responses and survived the parasite within 3 months. Adding IL-15 did not improve responses or protection during this time. However, mice with both TS and IL-15 were more protected against the parasite 6 months later than those with TS alone. This was due to more TS-specific T cells that produced IF-γ and expanded well after restimulation. Adding IL-15 to the vaccine improved long-term T cell survival, expansion, and protection against the parasite.
Researchers have identified a protein called WDR1 that plays a crucial role in controlling the levels of a protein called TbK in the parasite Trypanosoma brucei. TbK is essential for the parasite's basal body, flagellum, and cell division. The researchers found that W1 interacts with a protein complex called Cull4 and another protein called D1 to break down TbK in the parasite's body and flagum. Without W1, the parasite's body and flagum do not separate properly, and the flagum does not attach correctly. This leads to problems with the parasite's division and movement. The researchers also found that W1 localizes to the parasite's body and flagum during certain stages of its life cycle. They suggest that W1 is a receptor for TbK in the Cull complex that breaks it down Tb in the body and flag. Without W, Tb builds up in the body and flag, causing problems with the parasite's division and movement.
Researchers have found that the RNA helicase DDX3 plays a crucial role in the body's innate immune system, which helps fight off infections. They studied mice without the DDX3 gene and found they were more susceptible to infection and had altered immune cells in their bone marrow and spleen. The study suggests DDX3 is essential for immune function and may contribute to differences in how men and women fight off infections and diseases. 

The study used mice without D3 in their immune system showed changes in bone and spleen cell populations and were highly susceptible to Listeria infection. Data shows a vital role of sex-specific D3 forms in immunity to Lister. This may be because male mice were used for experiments and D3 is weaker in male cells. Alternatively, macrophages may not produce high levels of cytokines. Loss of D3 impacts the immune system through its role in hematopoiesis and response to Lister infections.

The study looked at how D3 deficiency affects genes in macrophages using RNA analysis. Genes changed upon L-infection in male or female cells are enriched for immune terms and D3 altered the transcriptome depended on sex of cells. Researchers previously found D3 regulates IFN transcription in infected cells with viruses or Lister. D3 is in the DEAD RNA helase superfamily with functions in RNA metabolism, transcription, processing, splicing, and translation.
A computational model of the insect pherone transduction cascade has been developed, focusing on the post-effector processes in male moth olfactory neurons. The model includes the production and degradation of second messengers IP3 and DAG, the opening and closing of ionic channels, and Ca2+ extrusion mechanisms. It is regulated by modulators protein kinase and Ca2-calmodulin, which exert feedback inhibition on effector channels. The model simulates the evolution of chemical species and membrane potential in response to pherone stimulation of various intensities and captures the main features of the dose-response curve, including a wide range of amplitudes and rising and falling times. It also reproduces the second messenger kinetics. The model suggests that two types of depolarizing channels play different roles at low and high pherone concentrations, with the DAG-gated cation channel playing a major role at low concentrations and the Ca2-gated Cl channel playing a major role at middle and high concentrations.
Researchers studied how the tumor suppressor protein p53 responds to cellular stress by binding to specific DNA sequences and activating genes. They mapped p53 binding and histone H3me3 in human cells with and without the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin. The study examined relationships between p53 occupancy, gene expression, histone modifications, chromatin accessibility, and p53 sequence conservation. Results showed that p-regulated genes were associated with chromatin status. Highly p-regulated genes were suppressed and marked by repressive histone modifications or CTC binding. p53 sequences in open chromatin were weaker, while those in enhancers and repressed chrom were stronger. p occupancy was correlated with sequence similarity to the p53 consensus but inversely with nucleosome accessibility and conservation. p binding to transposable element repeats was higher and correlated with stronger sequences. However, this was not associated with gene activation. Occupied p in repeats were unique, displaying negative phylo scores and altered histone and DNase hypersensitivity. The study highlights the interaction between chromatin and p53 context in transactivation. The p response appears to be tuned by evolutionary processes leading to repression or utilization of p from transposable elements.
Researchers have developed a new understanding of a specific two-component signaling system in bacteria, where a single histidine kinase (HK) can phosphorylate two response regulator (RR) proteins. This system allows for rapid signal termination, where one RR acts as a "sink" for the other, and also exhibits a sigmoidal signal response, meaning the output remains low until a certain threshold is reached. The researchers identified conditions and parameters necessary for this sigmoid response and found that the level of sigmoidality can be controlled by the presence of the sink RR and an auxiliary protein that binds to HK. This system provides a tunable switch-like processing and a basis for developing threshold devices in synthetic biology.

The study analyzed the dynamics of a motif in bacterial signaling pathways where a single HK can reversibly phosphorylate two RRs, showing it accelerates signal termination and exhibits sigmoidal response. The findings offer a system perspective on natural signaling capabilities and avenues for reengineering. Exploiting the HK-RR system in synthetic circuits requires coupling an output (e.g. RR as transcription factor) to control HK activity. Two-component systems are used in bacteria, eukaryotes, and plants for signal transduction, consisting of HK and RR, with HK activity controlled by stimulus and autophosphorylation.

A generic model of HK-RR was developed and analyzed, showing it can enhance termination and implement threshold response, displaying sigmoidal relationship with low phosphorylated RR levels until threshold crossed. This has implications for bacterial physiology and synthetic circuits. The findings apply to two-component circuits with multiple regulators competing for phosphorylation.
Researchers used single-cell RNA sequencing to study how yeast cells respond to stress and found that individual cells within the same population show significant variation in tolerance to stress. This variation is not fully understood, so they used single-cell sequencing to quantify transcript changes in Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells with and without salt stress to explore population variation and identify cellular factors that influence stress response. They found significant variation in yeast cells before and after stress, and a subset of cells decouples ribosomal gene expression from stress response in a way related to cell cycle but not yeast metabolic cycle. Live-cell imaging of cells expressing fluorescent regulators revealed coordinated and decoupled nucleocytoplasmic shuttling. Transcript analysis suggests cells maintain a filter against decoupled bursts of factor activation but mount stress response coordinated, even in unstressed cells.

The study aimed to understand regulatory networks controlling heterogeneity in transcription and stress tolerance, which could lead to new ways to control population behavior. Results provide new insights into yeast stress response, but many questions remain. They addressed these through single-cell RNA-sequencing and single profiling of transcription factor dynamics before and after stress. Results show variable activation of ESR and condition regulators after stress and heterogeneity in ESR in unstressed due to coordinated and discordant induction E regulators. Cell-to-cell variation in M2 activation could explain heterogeneity stress in culture, but unclear if correlates with broader transcript changes or magnitude in unstressed cells mimics stressed.
Researchers have found that the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypaniasis, accumulates in the reproductive organs of male mice, including the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue, and fibrous tunics of the testis. However, it is not found in the lumen of epididym duct or seminifer tubules of the test. This suggests that the majority of parasites are not in immune-privileged sites. Instead, they are associated with inflammatory cell infiltration, degeneration, and tissue rupture of epididym duct, which may lead to reduced fertility. The study shows that, like in the bloodstream and other tissues, male organs, T. bruce is exposed to a strong immune response. Detection of a high number of parasites in this organ opens the possibility of using needle aspiration cytology as a diagnostic tool in African trypaniasis. 

The epididym and test are surrounded by adipose tissue, epidid adipose, a reservoir of T. bruce parasites. Immunohistochemistry with anti-VSG antibody analyzed presence and distribution of tryosomes in test, epidid and epidid adip tissue. Parasites infiltrate fibrous tun that encloses test, but not test itself. Immunoflucent assay may have misidentified test for epidid. The majority of parasites are in epidid stroma and epidid adip tissue, not protected by tissue barriers. Data show T bruce infection is associated with inflammation in male reproductive organs, in tissues with parasites, epidid and epid adip, also test with no parasites. Inflammation is associated with disruption of blood-test and epid barriers at infection stages.
Researchers studied how fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) respond to their environment through their sense of smell and taste. They found that the genes that help flies detect chemicals in their environment are regulated differently at different stages of life, between males and females, and in response to social interactions. When flies are exposed to the scent of the opposite sex, it changes which genes are turned on or off. This is different from when flies are in contact with the same or opposite sex. The researchers looked at how these genes work together and found that they are organized into small groups that respond to similar conditions. This allows the flies to fine-tune their sense of smell and taste in response to their environment. The study shows that the genes that help flies sense their environment are highly flexible and can change in response to different situations.
Studies of human trisomies have shown a link between abnormal meiotic recombination and nondisjunction at meiosis I or II. Specifically, failure to recombine or recombination events near or far from the centromeres are associated with human trisomies. Researchers used immunofluorescence to examine meiotic recombination in human females and studied crossover proteins (e.g., ML1) in fetal oocytes to analyze nondjunction-prone chromosomes and genome-wide recombination. Results show ML1 foci are lower than predicted, but pattern conforms to crossover protein expectations. Observations in individual chromosomes indicate "vulnerable" crossover in fetal oocytes, consistent with nondjunction events in adult oocytes.

Meiotic errors cause many chromosome abnormalities in humans, mostly from first division in oocyte. Studies over 10-20 years linked meiotic disturbances to human tris of maternal origin. Researchers evaluated ML1 as crossover marker in females and asked achmate and suboptimal crossover patterns in human meiosis. This report results on 103 prophase oocytes from 31 ovarian samples. Direct analyses crossover in fetal oocytes reveal "ulnerable" configurations consistent with tromic data (e.g., chromosome 16 distal exchanges, 21 proximal distal, achmate). If true, recombination patterns in tris reflected ML foci in pacheneocytes. However, not all clear, e.g., no "spikes" in dist or prox ML1 on 21, despite proximal dist associated tromy 21.
Exposure to the saliva of blood-feeding arthropods, such as mosquitoes and ticks, can have a significant impact on the progression of diseases they transmit. Research on Leishmaniasis and Arboviral infections suggests that pre-exposure to arthrop saliva can alter the immune response of the host, which can either exacerbate or limit symptoms, depending on the system in question. To understand how pre-exposure affects vector control, a model of vector-borne disease was developed. The study found that pre-exposed hosts should increase when control efforts moderately increase vector mortality rates. If pre-exposure leads to rapid clearance of infection, increasing mortality may achieve greater control than expected. However, if pre-ex prolongs duration of infection, control can increase total number of infected. Infections may go unnoticed unless active surveillance is used to detect subclinical individuals, who provide reservoir for transmission and long-term health consequences. Sensitivity analysis suggests negative consequences can be mitigated through integrated management. The immunological and clinical consequences of pre-exposure are largely uncharted for other vector-parite-host combinations. A range of epidemiological outcomes, positive and negative for health, underscore the need to quantify how pre-ex modulates recovery and transmission in vectororne diseases.
Leishmanias is a disease that affects 12 million people in 88 countries, with 2 million new cases every year. Leish amazonensis is a major agent in Brazil, causing forms from localized cutaneous (L) to diffuse cutaneous leishmanias (D). Researchers studied how the immune system affects Leish proteins by comparing proteomes of amastigotes from BAL/c and BAL nude mice. Thymic nude mice resemble patients with cutaneous leishias, considered T-cell hypersensitive or anergic to Leish antigens. The study found proteins related to oxidative stress and proteases, including oligopeptase and tryparedin peroxidase, which are known Leish virulence factors. Specific isoforms of these proteins were increased in parasites from nude mice, suggesting T cells restrain post-transl modifications in BAL mice. On the other hand, an iso of H70 was increased in amastotes from BAL mice. The study may identify virulence factors and ways of regulating expression.
Activation-induced cytosine deaminase (AID) plays a crucial role in immunoglobulin (Ig) gene diversification by deaminating cytosines in DNA, leading to somatic hypermutation (SH) and class recombination (CSR). However, A is highly mutagenic and causes genomic instability, contributing to chromosomal translocations in B cell malignancies. Researchers have found that A is regulated by the cell cycle, with degradation occurring more slowly in the G1 phase than in S or G-M phase. Mutations affecting phosphorylation or catalytic activity can alter A stability and abundance. To test the role of cell regulation, A was tagged with cell cycle regulators CDT and Gemin to be degraded outside G1 or S2-M phases. Results show that A accelerates SH and CSR in G1, but compromises viability in S2-M. This suggests cell regulates A abundance and determines the ability to respond to A-initiated DNA damage.

A's stability is limited by proteosomal degradation and CRM-dependent export. Catalytic activity can be improved by site mutations, but also stimulate translocations and compromise viability. A-initiated damage can have pathological outcomes, such as chromosomal translocations in B malignancies. Low A levels in G2 may lead to high levels in G1, as seen in A-merryCD1 transfectants. A is a site of regulation, and phosphorylation downregulates SH and CSR.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how a type of bacteria called Clostridium phyfermentans breaks down plant biomass, which is important for the environment, food, and industry. They used three techniques: carbohydrate-active enzyme (CAzyme) assays, RNA sequencing, and anaerobic growth to analyze how the bacteria metabolize plant polysaccharides. Polysacides are complex sugars that make up plant cell walls. The researchers found that the bacteria can break down different types of polysacides with varying efficiency and prioritize some over others. They used RNA sequencing to see how the bacteria respond to polysides by upregulating specific groups of CAymes, transporters, and enzymes to metabolize the sugars. Fifty-six upregulated CAymes were purified and shown to degrade polysides by multiple enzymes, often from the same family but with different specificities and localizations. These enzymes were tested in combination to identify synergies between acting on the same substrate with different catalytic mechanisms. This study advances understanding of how microbes break down plant biomass. Clostridium phymentans is a soil bacteria with 171 CAyme-encoding genes, including 116 glycoside hydrolases in 44 families. It grows on a panel of plantacides and sugars. RNA sequencing revealed genes whose expression changed on various substrates. Elucidating how microbes metabolize polysides is key to understanding plant-degrading microbial communities and developing enzyme mixtures and recombinant microbes for industrial processing biomass.
In Sierra Leone conducted three rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) to control lymphatic filariasis (LF) in 12 districts previously treated for onchocercias from 2008-2010. The MDAs had good geographic and drug coverage. A mid-term assessment in 2011 showed the impact on LF in these districts. Microfilaria (mf) prevalence fell from 2.6% to 0.3%, a decrease of 88.5%. Four districts had 0% prevalence: Bo, Moyamba, Kenema, and Kono. Seven districts had reductions of 70-95%: Bombali, Bonthe, Kail, Kambia, Koin, Kadugu, Portoko, and Tonkol. Pehun had 0% baseline prevalence, maintained. Bomb had 1.58% prevalence, the district with highest baseline 6.9%. Arithmetic mean mf density after MDs 17.59/ml, 65.4 decrease from 50.9/ml and 0.05/ml 96.2 decrease 1.32/ml. Results showed mf <1% in all but one district after MDs. Density reduced 65% among mf-positive and 95.8 for entire population.
Researchers have used high-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA profiling, to study microbial communities in oceans and the human gut. However, analyzing this data is challenging due to its compositional nature, meaning it's based on relative fractions of genes or species rather than absolute abundances. This can lead to unreliable results, as shown by Karl Pearson's work. Using simulated and real data from the Human Microbiome Project, researchers found that compositional effects can be widespread and severe, making many correlations artificial and opposite in sign. Diversity is a key factor that modulates the severity of these effects. A new approach, SparCC, was developed to estimate correlations from compositional data. It was applied to infer a network of interacting species across 18 human body sites. Compared to standard methods, SparCC found 3 spurious species interactions and missed 60% of true interactions in human microbiome data, with most errors in low-diversity samples.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of pneumonia, resists the antimicrobial effects of lysozym, an enzyme found on mucosal surfaces. They found that lyzym's ability to break down peptoglycan, a component of the bacterial cell wall, is key to its antimicrobial effect. Two enzymes, Pgd and Ad, modify peptogcan to make it resistant to lyzym. Experiments with mice showed that pneumocci with these modifications outcompeted those without them when lyzym was present, but not when it was absent. This suggests that peog modifications help pneumoc survive in the presence of lyzym. However, when lyzym was absent, pneumoc without modifications had an advantage. The study shows that peog modifications can be beneficial or harmful depending on the environment.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a major arthropod-borne viral disease causing significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. In Brazil, it is responsible for approximately 80% of deng cases in the Americas, with 5,944,270 cases reported since its introduction in 1986, including 21,596 deng hemorrhagic fever and 874 fatal cases. The study investigated the usefulness of NS1 capture as an alternative to detect DENV in tissue from confirmed deng fatal cases (n=23) in 2002. A total 74 tissue specimens were available: liver (n=23), lung (n=14), kidney (n=4), brain (n=10), heart (n=2), skin (n=1), spleen (n=15), thym (n=3), and lymph (n=2). Three tests for NS1 capture were evaluated: Deng Early ELISA (Pan Diagnostics), Plat NS1 (Bio Laboratories), and rapid NS1 Strip (Bio). Overall, deng fatal diagnosis based on tissues by Deng EL, Plat and NS1 was 34.7% (8/23), 60.8 (14), and 91.3 (21) respectively. Deng EL detected NS1 in 22.9 (17) of specimens and Plat NS in 45.9 (34). The highest sensitivity 78.3 (58) was achieved by NS Strip, with significant differences in sensitivities (p<0.05). NS Strip was most sensitive in liver (91.3), lung (71.4), kidney (100), brain (80), spleen (66.6), and thym (100) compared to other EL assays. This study shows DENV NS capture as a valuable postmortem deng confirmation.
Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of 718 multiple myeloma (MM) tumor samples from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation's Compass Interim Analysis 9 study to investigate differences in molecular alterations between African American (AA) and Caucasian (CA) cases. They used somatic whole-exome sequencing and RNA sequencing to identify mutations and correlated them with self-reported race and genetic ancestry. The study found significant differences in mutation frequencies between the two groups, with B7, BR3, and AUT2 showing higher frequencies in AA cases, which are involved in B-cell malignancies. TP53 and IRF4 mutations were more common in CA cases. This study is one of the most comprehensive genomic analyses of MM in patients of African descent and highlights potential ancestry-related differences in myelogenesis. Three genes known to be involved in B malignancy translocations are new candidates that may have been overlooked due to lack of AA in large genomic efforts. The study emphasizes the need for deeper understanding of oncogenic processes in multi-ethnic cohorts to address disparities in incidence and outcomes among AA patients.
Researchers have found that most mutations in cancer cells are "passengers," which don't affect the cell's ability to reproduce. Passengers can provide information about the cancer's history and serve as a molecular clock. They can also be targets for treatment or treatment resistance. Scientists studied the growth of cancer cells in tumors and metastases by looking forward in time and backward. They calculated the probability and frequency of passenger mutations by time of appearance. This helped create a tree of cancer evolution in individual patients. By looking backward, they estimated the number of cancer cells present when a mutation arose. They derived formulas for subclonal mutations and frequency. Fitting these formulas to sequencing data estimated birth and death rates of cancer cells during early stages.

The ratio of birth and death rates determines the cancer's tree shape, which is star-shaped for fast growth and linear for slow. If a mutation has a certain frequency, how many cells were present when it arose? The answer varies with death-birth ratio, which changes from 0 to 0.99. Frequencies of first and most passengers are influenced by mutation and death-birth ratio. If close to 1, several passengers may not be in the first cell but collected during expansion. If 0.99, about 150 passengers are in more than 1% cells. The formula can be fitted to data to describe the process and extract parameters. It was applied to colorectal cancer data and found neutral evolution during expansion. Passengers can be used to infer the process. For close to 1, the number of subcl above 50 is equal to collected during progression. Subtracting subcl above 50 from allcl will estimate the number in the first cell.
Researchers studied how a protein called huntingtin, which is linked to Huntington's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder. They looked at how a part of the protein called exon 1 (X1) misfolds when it has many glutamines, a type of amino acid. When there are too many glutamines, X1 can form clumps similar to those found in the disease. The team wanted to understand how X1 misolds to form these clumps. They used computer simulations to study X1 with and its surrounding regions, and found that these regions affect how X1 misolds. The more glutamines X1 has, the more likely it is to form a certain shape that leads to clumps. The surrounding regions of X1 also play a role in this process, with some parts helping to prevent X from forming clumps. The first 17 amino acids of X are more likely to form a certain shape when there are many glutamines. This study helps understand how X1 misolds and how it relates to disease.
Researchers have studied the CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Palindromic Repeats) system, a defense mechanism used by bacteria and archaea to protect against foreign DNA, such as viruses and plasmids. They analyzed over 700 metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project to explore the distribution and diversity of CRPRs in human microbiomes and discover new ones. A targeted assembly strategy was developed to reconstruct CRPR arrays that whole-genome assemblies failed to identify. For each known CRPR type, a consensus sequence was used to recruit reads from datasets and assemble into CRPR loci, extracting unique sequences for analysis. Novel CRPRs were also identified in whole-genome assemblies and targeted to comprehensively identify CRs across samples.

The distribution of CRPRs, including 64 known and 86 novel ones, were largely site-specific. Detailed analysis of several CRPR loci, including novel ones, showed that streptocococcal CRPRs were found in oral microbiomes with ~8,000 unique spacers. Samples from the same individual and site shared most spacers, while different sites from the same individual shared fewer, and individuals almost none. This indicates niche differences impact on CRPR evolution. CRPRs were also used to trace rare species and virus exposure in individuals. The study highlights the importance of identifying CRPR loci for microbiome ecology.

A targeted assembly strategy improved CRPR detection in metagenomic sequences, compared to whole-genome assemblies. Known CRPRs were identified in more human datasets, and novel ones in whole-genome assemblies. A list of known and novel CRPRs was prepared for further study. The strategy is efficient for comprehensive CRPR characterization in human datasets.
Scientists have studied the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to understand its circadian rhythms, or internal biological clocks that synchronize with environmental signals like light and temperature. Previous research showed behavioral rhythms in C. elegans were not robust, and no circadian transcriptional rhythms were identified. This study used genome-wide expression experiments to find light and temperature-entrained transcripts in C. elegans, which exhibited rhythmic expression with 24-hour periods and sustained under constant conditions, indicating circadian regulation. Light and temperature drove gene expression and entrained largely non-overlapping sets. Mutations in a cyclic nucleotide channel required for sensory transduction abolished light and temperature-entrained gene expression, suggesting environmental cues act non-autonomously entrain circadian rhythms. Findings demonstrate circadian-transcriptional rhythms in C. elegans and suggest further analysis will provide new information on the evolution and function of this biological clock.
Researchers have studied the effects of mutations in the RAD3 gene in yeast, which is a homolog of the human XPD gene involved in DNA repair and transcription. Two mutant alleles, rad-101 and rad-102, have defects in DNA repair and a hyper-recombination (hyper-Rec) phenotype. Previous studies suggested that the hyper-Rec phenotype is due to single-stranded DNA gaps converted to double-strand breaks (DSBs) by replication. However, these studies did not detect reciprocal products of mitotic recombination. The researchers used a system to recover reciprocal mitotic recombination products and found that rad-101 and rad-102 increased crossovers by 100-fold. Mapping showed that three-quarters of crosso reflect DSBs in both sister chromatids (double-chromat breaks, DSBs) and the remainder in single chromatids (SCBs). The ratio of DSBs to SCs is similar to spontaneous recombination in wild-type cells. They mapped 216 genomic alterations, including crosso, conversions, deletions, and duplications, and found an association with regions of recombination and gamma-H2AX. A hotspot for deletions and duplications was found at IMA and H11 near the end of chromosome XV. Comparison with spontaneous recombination in wild-type suggests that some events may be initiated by incomplete repair and DSBs that cannot be repaired by sisterchromatid recombination.
Helicobacter pylori, a gastric pathogen, has a set of simple sequence repeats (SSR) that generate heterogeneous populations through slipped mispairing, allowing adaptation to the changing host environment. Researchers found that an intergenic tract, via slipped mispair, operates as a rheostat to fine-tune expression of the sialic acid adhesin, SabA. They used isogenic strains with varying tract length to show that it affects Sab promoter output, altering H. pylori binding to sial-Lewis receptors on gastric mucosa. Analysis of post-infection clones revealed variable tract length in H. pylori, mirroring host-pathogen interplay where the bacterium generates clones with best-fit phenotypes. In silico and in vitro analyzes showed tract length affects DNA structure and RNA polymerase binding, shifting axial alignment between promoter and UP elements. Additional H. pyl genes with similar tracts show variations modulate promoter output. The study proposes a mechanism mediated by promoter-prox SSR for transcription regulation in bacteria with limited transacting factors.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) must evade the immune system to establish persistent infections and amplify its genome upon cell differentiation. Researchers found that the JAK/STAT transcription regulator, STAT5, activates the DNA damage pathway to induce HPV genome amplification in epithelial cells. STAT5 is a member of the J/STAT family that modulates the inflammatory response and plays a role in cell cycle progression in response to cytokines and growth factors. Studies show that HPV protein E7 activates STAT5 without altering total levels. Inhibiting STAT5 with a drug abolishes genome amplification and late expression in differentiating keratinocytes, but has no effect on undifferentiated cells maintaining episomes. Knockdown studies show STAT5 isoform is responsible and mediated through ATM damage response. Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) contributes to effects on ATM pathway. These findings identify a new mechanism where immune regulator STAT5 promotes viral replication through DNA damage response.
Researchers in Nepal identified 13 antigens from Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi that are expressed in the biliary tract of chronic carriers, but not in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area. These antigens include putative proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins. One antigen, YE (ST147), an uncharacterized with ATP-binding motif, gave prominent responses in screen. The response to YE in patients with biliary tract S. Typhi was compared to those without S. Typhi, patients with tyoid fever, and healthy controls. Seven of 10 (70%) chronic carriers, 0 of 8 (0%) bile-negative controls, 0 8 (0%) healthy, and 1 8 (12.5%) Bangladeshis with tyoid had detectable anti-YE IgG in blood. Ig responses were also present. Further evaluation of YE and other antigens by IVAT could lead to improved diagnostic for asymptomatic S. Ty carriers.
Researchers have discovered a new epigenetic phenomenon called transactivation, where non-functional copies of a gene can reactivate the expression of a silenced version of the same gene. This occurs when a non-functional allele of the white gene, which doesn't produce a coding transcript, interacts with a functional copy of the same gene silenced by heterochromatin. The study found that the presence of homologous RNA is necessary for transactivation, and mutations in genes involved in post-transcription silencing affect it. This new level of gene control by homolog RNA in heterochromatic genes was unexpected.

In experiments, non-functional white alleles of the classic marker gene transactivated the expression of a wild-type white gene silenced by heterochatin. The researchers called this phenomenon transactivation. They found that a gene producing only spurious transcription can reactivate a functional copy of the same gene silenced heterochatin, revealing a new level of gene control in heterromatic genes. Data indicate transactivation is a new epetic phenomenon controlling gene expression in heterochatin through homolog RNA.

The mechanisms and features of transactivation differ from other epigenetic events like paramutation, transduction, and transvection. In transactivation, non-coding RNAs influence the transcription state of homolog locus silenced heterochatin. Notably, non-functional white alleles increased the wmh transcript and opened chromatin at the wmh locus. Transactivation is heritable and relies on diffusible homolog RNA, and is affected by genes in postcription silencing.
Researchers have identified a protein called Boophil in the midgut of a tick, Rhipphalus microplus, which is a vector of babesiosis. This protein is a multifunctional enzyme inhibitor that targets thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein. The study aimed to determine how Boophil interacts with these enzymes, modulates platelet function, and inhibits thrombosis in vivo. Boophil was expressed in HEK cells and purified to homogeneity. Using amidolytic and surface plasmon resonance experiments, it was found that Boophil behaves as a classical non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin with respect to chromogenic substrates, dependent on both exosite and catalytic site. This inhibition is accompanied by blockade of plate aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot throm in vitro. Boophil also inhibits FXa, preventing activation and kikrein activity, indicating it targets the contact pathway. Additionally, it abates catheps G and plmin-induced plate aggregation and affects elastase cleavage of Tissue Pathway Inhibitor TF. Boophil inhibits carot artery occlusion in vivo by Fe3 and promotes bleeding in mice tail transection. Through inhibition of several enzymes in proteolytic cascades and cell activation, Boophil plays a role in keeping midut environment low hemost and inflammatory response, allowing ticks to digest blood for metabolism and egg development.
Researchers have developed a computer model called the Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue (SEMT) to study how inflammation affects the lining of the intestines. This lining, called the mucosa, is crucial for absorbing nutrients and protecting the body from harm. Its structure and function are closely linked, and changes in its architecture can lead to various diseases. Inflammation is a key factor in many gastrointestinal diseases and can alter the mucosa's shape. To understand how inflammation influences the mucosa, the researchers created SEMT to simulate how enteric epithelial cells behave under different conditions, from healthy to diseased. SEMT reproduces healthy mucosal dynamics and mimics experiments where certain genes are turned off. It also reveals mechanisms like how a protein, PTEN/PIK, connects inflammation and tissue growth, and how cell shedding helps protect against ischemia and chronic inflammation. These findings suggest SEMT can study inflammation in gastrointestinal diseases.

SEMT combines modules for cell signaling, inflammation, proliferation, movement, and morphogen diffusion to maintain mucosa architecture. An agent-based model simulates cellular and molecular interactions maintaining mucosal architecture. SE models crypt-villus tissue as cells replicate, migrate, differentiate, and respond to inflammation. SEMT can represent large epithelial surfaces and is a work in progress, with a minimal set of components to represent mechanisms maintaining mucosal morphogenesis and response to perturbations. Researchers propose diseases can be unified by viewing mucosal architecture as controlled by morph pathways, balancing multiple objectives in health, but disturbed in disease.
Researchers studied the effectiveness of Wolbachia, a bacterium that reduces arbovirus transmission, in controlling Aedes aegypt populations. Traditional methods like insecticide spraying and source reduction have limited success. Wolia was released in a community in Rio de Janeiro for 20 weeks, but failed to spread due to high pyreoid resistance in mosquitoes. A new strain, wRio, was created by crossing wBr females with males from the field to introduce pyre resistance. wRio increased mosquito survival but negatively affected fecundity. Despite this, wRio established where wBr failed, highlighting the importance of matching local genetics, especially pyre resistance, for invasion. Household support was high, reaching 90% for the second release. Temperature did not affect w expression on Brazilian background. Wolia should match insecticide profile of wild population for invasion. Pyre resistance is widespread in Ae populations, future deployments must maintain resistance in lab colonies.
Researchers studied the role of the vaccinia B protein in the poxvirus, a type of virus that causes smallpox and cowpox. They found that the B protein plays a crucial role inactivating a cellular antiviral factor called B, which helps the virus replicate. To understand how B works, they created a virus without the B gene and let it evolve over time to see how it adapts. They found that mutations in the B pseudokinase, a part of the B protein, gave the virus a fitness boost. This suggests that losing the pseudokinase can be beneficial for the virus. They also found that the pseudokin localizes to the nucleus, a rare for a poxiral protein, and reduces B phosphorylation when present, indicating it may enhance antiral activity of B. The study shows that a paralog kinase-pseudase pair can have an epistatic relationship, enhancing B conservation during pox evolution and orchestrating nuclear events during infection.
Researchers studied the behavior of two synthetic peptides, LKKKLLKKLL (L) and EAAEAAEAAE (E), designed to form an alpha-helix structure due to their amphipathic properties. These peptides are too short to form stable structures on their own and are often disordered in solution. The team used molecular simulations to analyze their conformation in bulk water and at macroscopic interfaces. They found that the peptides are neither random coils nor fully helices, but adopt multiple conformations with short lifetimes. Conformation changes with environment, such as pH or presence of interfaces. The peptides' response to interfaces depends on their inherent helical tendency in water and surface charge and hydrophobicity.
Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) is a common virus that infects humans in the first years of life and remains latent in various cell types. It can integrate its genome into the telomeres of host chromosomes in latently infected cells, but the mechanism of integration is unclear. Interestingly, HH-6 and other herpesviruses have telomeric repeats (TMR) similar to human telomeres at the end of their genomes. The HH-6 genome has two T arrays, perfect (pMR) and imperfect (impMR). To determine if T are involved in integration, researchers deleted p and imp in the HH-6 genome and reconstituted the virus. Replication was comparable to wild-type, indicating T are not essential for HH-6 replication. To assess integration, an in vitro system was established to evaluate efficiency and maintenance in latently infected cells. Integration of HH-6 was impaired without T and the genome was lost, suggesting integration is crucial for maintenance. Individual deletion of p and imp revealed p plays major role in HH-6 integration, while imp makes minor contribution, establishing a model for HH-6 integration. Data show T are dispensable for replication but crucial for integration and maintenance in latently infected cells.
Researchers have discovered the 2.6 Å crystal structure of the protein D13, a key component of the outer scaffold of vaccinia virus, a type of poxvirus. The structure reveals a double-barrel organization with two jellyroll domains and a head domain that assembles into trimers similar to those of adenovirus and icosahedral viruses. When attached to artificial membranes, D13 forms a honeycomb-like structure similar to the virus's immature particles. This suggests that poxviruses use an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral viruses, infecting all kingdoms of life. The protein D13 is essential for the first step of poxirus morphogenesis, as it can form immature particles without other viral factors, and its neutralization by mutation or rifampin inhibits assembly. The structure of D13 will aid in developing poxirus inhibitors.
Researchers studied the role of auxin and ethylene in root growth in the plant Brachypodium distyon. They found that a mutant with reduced tryptophanminotransferase activity, which is essential for auxin production, had longer roots due to enhanced cell elongation. This contrasts with Arabidopsis, where reduced tryophminotransferase activity leads to reduced root growth and lower auxin levels. In Brachodium, ethylene may inhibit the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis, making aux levels suboptimal for cell elongation. The study reveals a delicate balance between auxin and ethylene to control cell elongation in Brachodium roots and suggests alternative wiring of aux-ethylene crosstalk compared to Arabidopsis. Aux levels are elevated in Brach roots with reduced tryophminotransfer activity, not due to alternative biosynthesis pathways but increased expression of YCCA genes, which convert indole-3-pyruvic acid to auxin. YCCA expression is downregulated by ethylene precursor 1-aminoclopropane-1-carboxylic acid and upregulated in eth-signaling component ethylene 2-like 1, which also displays Brach root phenotype.
Researchers studied how genes in yeast species evolve at different rates and found that the organization of their promoters, called nucleosomes, plays a key role. Genes without a nucleosome-free region, called OP, vary widely between species, while those with a nucleosome region, DPN, remain similar. To see if early evolution affects this difference, they artificially selected for high expression of a protein and surprisingly, both OP and DPN genes increased equally. However, they adapted in different ways: DPN duplicated large regions, while OP favored mutations. When selection stopped, DPN returned to normal levels, but OP did not. This suggests that promoter organization affects early evolution and biases its path. 

In yeast, gene expression divergence is linked to nucleosome organization, connecting evolution with regulation. Genes that diverged quickly lack a nucleosome near start site, OP, while DPN remained conserved. When selection stopped, DPN returned to normal, but OP did not. Results suggest promoter impacts early dynamics and long-term evolution. To test if OP and DPN differ in response to selection, they selected high expression and examined genomic response. Dozens of proteins increased, regardless of class. Forty proteins with mid-to-high levels, no preference, were chosen, distributed between DPN and OP, quantified by nucleosome occupancy. Alternatively, DPN and OP may be subject to similar forces, but more easily satisfied by OP due flexible structure, supporting flexible organization directs evolution path.
Human T-cell lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) is a cancer-causing virus that activates a protein called Tax, which promotes cell growth and transformation. However, paradoxically, Tax also triggers a cellular aging process called senescence in most cells. Senescence is caused by increased levels of proteins p21 and p27, which are cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors that prevent cell division. Researchers found that senescence is a response to Tax's activation of a protein complex called IK/NF-κ, which is involved in cell growth and survival. Senesc induced by Tax in HeLa cells is reduced by mutations that decrease IK/NF-κ activation and prevented by blocking IK-α, a protein that regulates NF-κ. Knockdown of Rel, a subunit of NF-κ, shows it induces senescence by stabilizing p27 and p21 mRNA. The HT-1 anti-sense protein, HB, downregulates NF-κ, delaying Tax-induced senescence. The balance between Tax and HB expression determines HT-1 infection outcome. Elevated Tax drives IK/NF-κ activation and senesc, while HB modulates Tax replication and NF-κ, allowing HT- infected cells to proliferate and persist. Inactivation of senescence can lead to persistent NF- activation and leukemia.
Researchers have proposed a new model of how the frontal lobe, a part of the brain, helps us make decisions in uncertain and changing situations. Current models don't fully explain how we make decisions in everyday life. The new model, called PRO, shows how the frontal lobe works in real-life situations and why people make different choices. It says the frontalobe monitors up to four strategies at a time and chooses the best one that works. If one doesn't work, it tries a new one from memory and checks if it's good, then uses it. The model shows the frontalobe has a limit of four strategies, but makes up for it by creating new ones in uncertain situations. This helps us adapt to new situations.

The model, PRO, explains how the frontalobe creates, stores, and chooses strategies for action. It shows how it balances trying new and using what we already know to make good choices. The study supports the idea that the frontalobe uses reasoning, learning, and creativity to make good decisions. The model shows how the frontalobe makes many strategies for action in changing situations. It uses what we already know and creates new ones to make good choices.

The frontalobe manages what we do by using what we know from memory. It adjusts what we do to get the best outcome. But how do we make many strategies and choose new ones? Little is known about how the frontalobe chooses between using what we know, switching to new, or making new ones.
Researchers have developed a new approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT) to study the long-term effects of pharmacological treatments on diseases. This method uses mathematical modeling to predict how molecular adaptations change over time in response to treatment. A time-dependent parameters are used to describe the dynamics of these changes, making use of experimental data from different stages of the intervention. This approach provides insight into the underlying biological systems and identifies areas for further study to understand the treatment outcome.

ADAPT was used to investigate the effects of activating the liver receptor LXR, a potential target for treating atherosclerosis. Unexpectedly, the analysis showed that the liver's ability to clear cholesterol decreased with prolonged treatment, contradicting the expected increase in cholesterol efflux and excretion. This was confirmed by experimental measurements of the scavenger receptor B1 in liver membranes.

ADAPT can also identify potential side effects and design new interventions to prevent them. The method employs time-dependent parameters to capture interactions with the proteome and transcriptome, which are often not well understood. It was applied to a model of hepatic lipid and lipoprotein metabolism to predict adaptations upon treatment with the LXR agonist T131.
Researchers have proposed a new hypothesis on how the spinal and cerebellar neuronal circuitry works together to coordinate multi-segment limbs and bodies. They suggest that sensory and motor signals are combined in the neurons of the spinocerebell pathways, allowing for a wide range of functions, including spatial and temporal dependencies between limb segments. However, the number of granule cells limits the number of recombinations that can be represented in the cerebellum, making random recombination of sensory and motor signals not a good strategy. Instead, the spinal circuit provides useful recombinations, described as linear projections through multi-dimensional sensorimotor input space. Granule cells, aided by Golgi cells, enhance these projections, allowing Purkin cells to approximate non-linear functions. This hypothesis provides a new view on the function of spinal and cerebell gran layer, illustrating how the cerebellum's coordinating functions are supported by recombinations from the spinocbell system.

The spinocbell system avoids superfluous recombinations by combining signals and commands in individual neurons, allowing "good" recombinations to be formed with high probability. The spinal circuit makes sensorimotor functions available to the cerebell through SCT systems, and the granule receives this information. The spinocbell network's structure before the gran layer must be considered to lift the curse of dimensionality. A simplified example of controlling a planar double arm illustrates coordination. The researchers seek a theoretical explanation for these observations in terms of spinal and cerear circuitry, providing integration across dimensions for coordination.
Researchers used next-generation sequencing to study the regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs) in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes infected with the Chikungunya virus (CHV). They identified 88 known and 79 miRNAs in uninfected and CHV infected mosquitoes, respectively, and nine novel miRNAs in mosquitoes. The study found that CHV infection altered the expression of 77 miRNAs, specifically eight of which were upregulated. The researchers predicted the targets of these miRN and classified them into pathways. This study provides insight into the modification of miRN during CHV infection and identifies potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies. 

The researchers used next-generation sequencing to profile miRN in Aedes aegypt cell line upon CHV infection. They identified 90 miRN in mosquitoes, eight of which were common to uninf and infected and differentially regulated upon CHV. Computational analysis predicted the targets of modulated mi and studied pathways in mosquitoes. The study analyzed the distribution and abundance of mi and evaluated modulation upon CHV. Prediction and pathway analysis of mi shed light on the role of mi in CHV infection.
A study estimated the economic burden of Cysticercosis (CE) in Iran, a parasitic disease affecting humans and livestock. The study used data from hospitals, literature, and government reports to determine the prevalence and incidence of CE in humans and animals. It also obtained economic data on treatment costs, productivity losses, and livestock losses from national and international datasets. Monte Carlo methods were used to account for uncertainty. The study estimated 1,295 surgical cases of CE per year from 2000-2009 and 635,232 asymptomatic individuals living in the country. The overall cost of CE in Iran was estimated at $232.3 million, including direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was $93.3 million and livestock $132 million. The cost per case was $1,539. CE has a significant impact on Iran, costing 0.03% of the country's gross domestic product. A surveillance system and control program are necessary to reduce the burden. A cost-benefit analysis of control programs is recommended, incorporating losses due to CE in Iran.
Researchers have conducted a comprehensive analysis of mouse polyomavirus (MPV) infection in mouse cells to understand how the virus interacts with its host and regulates gene expression. They used deep sequencing to follow MPV infection in NIH3T cells at various times and analyzed both viral and cellular transcriptomes. The study revealed a dynamic regulation of viral and host gene expression, including widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts late in infection. By 36 hours, 359 host genes were upregulated and 857 downregulated. Gene ontology analysis showed transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated, while those in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc binding, SH domain, and GTP activation were downregulated. Noncoding RNAs were also altered, with MALAT1, involved in splicing and a marker in late cancers, downregulated and others upregulated. This study provides new insights into MPV lifecycle and its effects on cell growth and metabolism.
Hundreds of thousands of runners attempt to complete a marathon each year, but many experience severe performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, known as "hitting the wall," and drop out before the finish. Analyses of endurance have suggested that glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon, making "hitting the wall" inevitable, or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without "hitting the wall." However, a new study demonstrates that energetic constraints on runners are more subtle and depend on physiologic variables, including muscle mass, liver glycogen, and running intensity, in personalized and quantifiable ways. The study estimates the distance at which runners exhaust glyc stores as a function of intensity, providing a basis for guidelines to ensure safety and optimize performance by setting paces and prescribing mid-race fueling to avoid "the wall." The analysis sheds light on standards in marathon that have remained empirically defined, such as qualifying times for the Boston Marathon.

Carbohydrate loading before running influences performance by permitting a runner of given capacity and muscle to run at speeds without "hitting the wall," succumbing to exhaustion. Typical glyc loading allows runners to complete a marathon safely between four and five hours, as indicated by intersections with the border of the "Gcogen Supercompensation" region. The likelihood of "hitting" during a marathon peaks around mile 21, followed by a decline. The model incorporates running cost and dependence on exertion, revealing dependencies of distance to glyc depletion and fastest pace without exhausting stores.
Researchers studied how different strains of Toxoplas, a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis, interact with mouse immune cells called macrophages. They infected mouse macrophages with 29 different Tooplas strains from around the world and used a technique called RNA-sequencing to see how the parasite and host cells respond. The study found that different strains of Tooplas have unique ways of interacting with macrophages. Some strains activated a strong inflammatory response, while others did not. They also found that atypical strains, not part of the main group I, II, and III, activated a type of interferon called IFβ in macrophages, which helped kill the parasite. This was independent of another type of interferon, gamma, and dependent on receptors in the cell called Toll-like receptors and cytoplasmic retic acid-inducible gene 1 (RIG) in fibroblasts. The study showed that atypical strains have unique ways of interacting with host cells, which might explain why they cause more severe disease in humans. The research provides a global view of how cells and parasite respond to infection with both typical and atypical Tooplas, and identifies new host responses and parasite effectors specific to each strain.
Researchers have studied the process of recombination in enteroviruses, a mechanism that allows these viruses to acquire new genetic material and contribute to their diversity and the emergence of new strains. Despite its importance, the process is not well understood. They used a new approach to isolate chimeric polioviruses with duplicated sequences at the recombination site and found that these viruses with imprecise junctions had increased fitness. However, these viruses lost the duplicated sequences over time. Mutations that affected the polymerase or replication altered the yield of recombinants, but not non-recombinant viruses. This suggests that recombination is a replicative process that can be enhanced or reduced. The study proposes that recombinants result from a biphasic process: an initial recombination followed by resolution of extraneous sequences and optimization of fitness. This has implications for understanding evolution in positive-strand RNA viruses.
Researchers have identified a new route for the clearance of norepinephrine (NE) in white adipose tissue, which is mediated by the organic cation transporter 3 (Oct) in adipocytes. This route is distinct from previously known routes such as sympathetic neurons or macrophages. Oct is highly expressed in white adipose tissue and has the greatest uptake rate of NE compared to other routes. Adipocytes express high levels of enzymes for NE degradation, providing the basis for clearance by Oct. Administration of Oct ablation induces higher thermogenesis and lipolysis compared to controls. After cold challenge, white adipose tissue in Oct-deficient mice shows stronger browning and elevated thermogenic genes, involving β-adrenergic receptor activation. Glycolytic genes are reprogrammed to compensate for loss of ATP in Oct-deficient mice. Inhibition of β-AR abolishes lipolytic and thermogenic activities in Oct-deficient adipose. Reduced alleles of Oct are associated with increased basal metabolic rate. Oct governs β-activity as a NE transporter in adipocytes, offering therapeutic potential for metabolic disorders.
Researchers have found that the protein HP1 proteins, which play a crucial role in regulating gene expression, interact with a specific region of histone H3, a key component of chromatin, in addition to their known binding to methylated histone tails. This region, called the globular domain, is located at the entry/exit point of the nucleosome, the basic unit of chromatin structure, and is also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the SWI/SNF complex, which remodels chromatin. The interaction between HP1 and the glob domain of histone H is necessary for HP-mediated repression, as SW/S remodeling is inhibited in the presence of HP proteins. In contrast, SW/S functions as an activator, HP proteins are recruited by methylated histone tails and may function as sensors of unwanted SW activity, binding to uncovered nucleosomes and blocking the reaction. The study suggests that HP proteins use this property to detect and arrest chromatin remodeling.
Researchers have identified a property of RNA called self-containment, which refers to the tendency of a sequence to maintain its secondary structure regardless of its surrounding nucleotide context. They developed a scoring method called the self-containment index to measure this property and found that microRNAs (miRNAs) exhibit high self-containment, consistent with their requirement for structural invariance during biogenesis. In contrast, most other structured RNAs do not show self-containment. Analysis revealed a trend towards higher self-containment among conserved miRNAs, suggesting it may be a characteristic of miRN acquiring new genomic contexts. miRNAs display enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs, and a trend towards natural selection for self-cont in functional classes. The researchers suggest self-cont arises from selection for robustness against perturbations and invariance during biogenesis and modular composition of function. Self-cont will be important for RNA annotation and design.
Researchers have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that play a crucial role in limiting the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens, such as Botrytis cinerea and Plectphaella cucina. Mutants defective in any of these TFs showed increased susceptibility to these pathogens, indicating their importance in disease resistance. Transcriptome analysis revealed a common signature of 77 up-regulated genes in these mutants, including several encoding secreted peptides named PROIR (provulence factors). Forward and reverse genetic analysis showed many PROIRs contribute to disease susceptibility to necrophic pathogens. The TFs and PROIRs identified are novel determinants of plant susceptibility to necrophic fungal pathogens.
A protein called FOX1 plays a crucial role in making the uterus ready for embryo implantation. The uterus needs to be receptive for the embryo to attach and grow. If the uterus is not ready, it can lead to pregnancy loss or failed attempts at in vitro fertilization. Researchers found that removing FOX1 from the uterus in mice made them infertile due to changes in cell structure and increased cell death. They also found changes in gene expression related to cell invasion, transport, and signaling pathways that help the uterus prepare for implantation. One of these changes was an increase in progesterone receptor (PGR) signaling, which was due to PGR staying in the uterus cells during the implantation window. PGR and FOX1 have a reciprocal relationship, with P staying in the nucleus and FOX1 in the cytoplasm. This was also seen in human uterus samples during the menstrual cycle. The study suggests that FOX1 and PGR work together to make the uterus ready for implantation.
Researchers developed a statistical model to map the spread of deng cases in Bangladesh, accounting for the problem of under-reporting, where many cases go unrecorded. They analyzed district-level data from 2000 to 2009, using a negative binomial generalized linear mixed model that accounted for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal effects. The model found that mean temperature and its interaction with temperature range, lagged by two months, were significantly associated with deng incidence. Densely populated districts and those bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence. The model estimated that 92% of annual deng cases occurred between August and September. Cases were reported across the country, with 94% in the capital Dhaka, located in the middle. Less than half of affected districts reported cases as observed from surveillance data. The proportion varied by month, with higher in high-incidence districts but dropped towards the end of transmission.

The study provides model-based estimates of monthly deng distribution in Bangladesh, accounting for under-reporting. It contributes to prioritizing and targeting deng control and elimination across the country. However, under-reporting was not considered, nor geographical variation in transmission factors like climate and socio-demographics. The aim was to map monthly variation in deng incidence at district-level in relation to climatic and demographic factors, adjusting for under-report.
Researchers have discovered a new type of preferred places that mice visit in an open environments, which they call "knots". These places are characterized by high tortuous paths with twists and turns, and are typically visited sporadically during a session. Mice perform a behavior called "knot-scribling" while in these places, which involves tracing a winding path with twists and turns. Knots are distinct from "home" places, where mice spend most of their time, and are often located near the point of entry into the arena. Unlike home places, knots have high speed on the way in and low speed on the way out. The establishment of knots is influenced by stress and arousal, as injecting mice with saline and placing them in an exposed area enhances the formation of knots. In an environment without cues, mice create a self-generated landmark by twisting and turning, creating a centrally located knot.
