Knot-scribling may help mice obtain an overview of the environment, recalibrate their map and compass, and improve interpretation of the scene through vestibular input.
A new compound called NG04 has been identified as a potential treatment for fungal infections caused by the pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungus is a major cause of death worldwide, especially in people with weakened immune systems. NG04 was found to be effective in killing the fungus while sparing human cells. Researchers used high-resolution techniques to identify the protein Sec14 as the target of NG04. Sec14 is involved in the fungus's ability to cause disease and is also essential for its survival. Mutations in Sec14 made the fungus resistant to NG04. The team tested NG04 on clinical isolates of the fungus and found it inhibited growth. NG04 also showed activity against a strain resistant to the common treatment fluconazole. The study suggests NG04 as a starting point for new antifungal treatment.
Researchers have identified a potential new treatment for schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is often linked to poverty. The current treatment, praziquel, may not be effective due to parasite resistance, so new options are needed. Mefloquine, an antimal drug, shows promise in treating schosomiasis in mice. A single dose of meflo (200-400mg) reduced worm burden by 72-100% in mice infected with adult Schistoma mansoni or S japonicum. Importantly, young stages of the parasite were also affected. Both meflo enantiomers were effective in mice with subpatent or patent infections. Further studies will explore how meflo works and its effect on other parasites. Malaria and schosias coexist in some areas, so it will be interesting to see if meflo can treat both.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to map the distribution of podoiosis, a non-filar elephantiasis that causes massive swelling of the lower legs. Podoiosis was identified as a neglected disease by the World Health Organization in 2011. The study used a multi-stage sampling design and surveyed 76 villages from 40 districts in 10 regions of Cameroon. Individuals 15 years old or older were screened for lymphedema, and a clinical algorithm was used to diagnose podoiosis excluding filarial lymphema. Of 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated, 83 with lymphema were identified, but none were positive for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen or DNA. 52 cases of podoiosis were identified after applying the clinical algorithm, with a prevalence of 0.5% (95% CI 0.4-0.7). Podoiosis was found in every region except two villages in Adamawa, with 17 districts having no cases, 15 with 0.2-1% and 8 with 1.2-2.7%. The study demonstrates low but widespread distribution of podoiosis in Cameroon. Designing a podoiosis control is vital, a health response to the burden is important through surveillance and morbidity services.
Notch signaling plays a crucial role in regulating the adhesion of germline stem cells (GSCs) to their niche in Drosophila. As flies age, Notch signaling increases in GSCs, leading to their removal from the niche. Research shows that Gs with low levels of Notch signaling exhibit increased adhesion to the niche, outcompeting neighbors with higher levels of Notch. Adhesion is altered through regulation of E-cadherin expression. Enhancing Not signaling in Gs hastens age-dependent loss from niche, and is partially mediated by lethal. Disrupting Not signaling in Gs does not delay G loss during aging, nor affects BMP signaling, which promotes self-renewal of Gs. In contrast, Not activation in niche maintains niche integrity, mediating G retention, is reduced with age, indicating Not regulates niche occupancy both intrinsically and extrinsically.
Researchers studied the UL97 protein of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV), a kinase that phosphorylates the retinoblastoma (R) tumor suppressor and lamin A proteins, which are also substrates of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). They found that UL97 has authentic CDK-like activity. Seven human herpesviruses encode a kinase with sequence homology to UL97, termed conserved herpesvirus kinases (CHPs). To determine if CD-like activities of UL were shared by all CHPs, the researchers expressed epitope-tagged alleles of each protein in human cells to test R phosphorylation, lamin A and nuclear disruption, or S. cerevisiae to assay CD function. They found that ability to phosphorylate R and lamin was shared by all CHPs from beta and gamma-herpesviruses, but not alpha-herpesvir homologs. Similarly, all beta and gamma CHPs displayed CD activity in S. cerevis, while alpha did not. Researchers identified virally CD-like kinases, nomenclature abbreviated as v-CDs. They found other non-CD activities for UL (dispersion promylocytic leukemia nuclear bodies and cytoplasmic nuclear aggres) weakly conserved among CHPs, not segregating to viral families. Data indicate these kinases, targets of approved antiviral drugs, serve overlapping and non-overlapping functions during infections.
A systematic review was conducted to determine the global distribution of Burkholderia pseudallei, a bacterium that causes meloidosis, and to develop guidelines for environmental sampling. The review found that the distribution of B. pseudallei is patchy, with a lack of studies in areas where meloidosis is suspected to occur. The methods used to detect B. pseudi were variable and not robust. A consensus was developed to reduce false results and provide affordable methods for developed and developing countries. The guidelines aim to create a comprehensive global map of B. pseudi.

B. pseudi was detected in 82% of 61 studies using culture or PCR, but some isolates may be non-pathogenic Burkia spp. Negative surveys were reported in Kenya, Australia, and the USA, where a B. pseudi-like organism was later identified as B. okomens. Melosis is a disease caused by B. pseudi, first described in Burma in 1912, with most cases in Thailand and Darwin, Australia. 82% of studies detected B. pseudi using culture or PCR, with strains confirmed by genotyping in France, Burkina Faso, Madagascar, and Niger. 7 studies reported detection of B. For example, a survey in Vient City, Lao in 1998 found B. pseudi before human cases. This led to identifying B. pseud in clinical specimens, with the first case in 199, followed by 560 cases in 12 years.
Researchers have discovered a new way to stop the deng virus from entering cells by targeting a specific part of the virus called the fusion protein. This protein helps the virus merge with the cell membrane, allowing it to infect the cell. The team found peptides, short chains of amino acids, that bind to an intermediate stage of the fusion process. These peptides block the virus's ability to infect cells in a dose-dependent manner, meaning the more they bind, the less the virus can infect. This happens even if the peptides are removed from the virus before it enters the cell. The peptides bind to the virus before it reaches the cell and are carried inside with it, where the acid triggers the fusion process. This binding depends on movement, as there is no effect if the virus is kept at 4°C instead of 37°C. The researchers propose a two-step model for stopping the virus entry by targeting this pathway. Their findings support how the virus changes shape promotes fusion and suggest ways to block flavivirus entry.
Researchers have developed a new method to sequence the entire genome of Vibrio cholera, the bacteria that causes cholera, from dried stool samples on filter paper. This is significant because cholera is a major global health concern with 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually. Outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen remind us that cholera is still a threat. The new method is low-cost, safe, and sustainable, and can be used in resource-limited settings. It provides data on circulating cholera strains, which can inform public health policy on control and elimination. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) was used to sequence the V. cholera O genome from stool enriched alkaline peptone water (AP) and culture isolates on filter paper. The minimum amount of V. cholera DNA needed was 0.02 ng/μL. GS confirmed the presence or absence of genes of interest, including cholera toxin and pilus loci. It also identified co-infecting pathogens in the gut, which may impact disease severity. GS placed the strains in the global cholera phylogenetic tree, identifying them as the 7th pandemic El Tor. GS allowed mapping of reads from AP-enrich specimen and culture isolate filter papers provided valuable epidemiological information on V. cholera strains in remote settings. Results showed co-infecting pathogens and specific V cholera strains in endemic areas.
Researchers have identified a protein called Dyne that plays a crucial role in maintaining the structure and organization of epithelial cells, which are layers of cells that line organs and glands. Epithelial cells have distinct top and bottom sides, or apical and basolateral, that must be precisely organized for proper function. However, little was known about how individual proteins become localized to these areas. A genetic study in fruit flies found that Dyne is essential for apical-bas polarity. Dy acts through a protein called Stardust (Sdt) to target a transmembrane protein called Crumbs to the apical side. The researchers found that Stardust mRNA is localized to a specific part of the gene that is only present in early stages of epithelial development, but not in mature cells. This is the first demonstration that Dyne is required for epithelial polarity and suggests that mRNA localization may play a role in regulating ap-bas organization. The study also shows that alternative splicing, a process that creates different versions of a gene, is used to control mRNA localization during development.
Researchers have found evidence that the Leishmania parasite, which causes leishmaniasis, can exchange genetic material within its own cells, a process called intraclonal exchange. This contradicts previous belief that the parasite reproduces clonally. To test this, scientists created transgenic Leish lines that express green and red fluorescent markers, linked to drug resistance. They fed these lines to sand flies, Phlebotus periciosus, and found that the markers were exchanged within the fly's midgut, indicating genetic exchange. The hybrid offspring had triploid DNA content and was stable throughout the parasite's life cycle. Infections with the hybrid in mice showed reduced parasite loads in spleen and liver, similar to uninfected mice, and lower arginase activity. This suggests the hybrid is less virulent. The study confirms Leish can mate within its natural vector, the sand fly, and the hybrid is stable but less virulent.
Researchers studied Leishmania donani strains from patients in Ethiopia with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and HIV co-infections. They analyzed DNA from 63 strains using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS), cystine protease B (cp), and HASPB. The ITS and cp PCR identified the strains as Leishmania donani. However, the HAS PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic location. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia produced a 290bp product, while a minority gave 410 amplicons, all from HIV-VL co-infections. Southwestern strains produced 450 amplicons, with smaller products observed in three. Sudanese strains had amplicons identical to northwestern, while Kenyan gave larger products 500-650bp. High-resolution analysis distinguished different products. Sequence analysis showed the HAS repeat region in Leish donani comprised polymorphic 13-14 amino motifs. The 13 amino peptide, prevalent in Leish donani, is rare in Leishum. The order of repeats in Leishani varies between regions. The HAS region shows considerable polymorphism among Leish strains from East Africa. This should be considered when designing diagnostic and vaccine assays based on this antigen.
Researchers have identified specific regions in the HIV-1 genome where recombination is more likely to occur, contributing to the diversity of the virus. They developed a probabilistic model to predict where recombination happens based on local sequence identity and compared it to the distribution of breakpoints in the HIV-1 pandemic. The model accurately predicted the frequency of inter-subtype recombination across much of the genome, indicating that local sequence-dependent recombination is sufficient to explain breakpoint locations. However, some regions showed more or fewer breakpoints than expected, suggesting natural selection influences recombination patterns. The envelope gene had fewer breakpoints, indicating recombinants in this region are less likely to be successful. Breakpoints at higher than predicted were near the envelope, indicating selection for these recombinants due to this region's tendency to be recombined as a unit. The study found that only a minority of recombination events are significant to HIV-1 evolution, despite diverse recombinant forms in the population.
Researchers in neuroscience rely on computational modeling to understand brain function and behavior. However, previous methods have addressed two related problems separately: estimating individual parameters in a population and comparing models. These problems are interconnected because population parameters depend on which subjects express the model. A new framework, hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI), combines approaches for concurrent model comparison and parameter estimation at the population level. This framework has advantages for both estimation and model comparison theoretically and experimentally. Parameters estimated by H show smaller errors compared to other methods. Model comparison by H is robust against outliers and not biased towards simplistic models. The fully Bayesian approach enables researchers to make inference on group parameters by H-test.

 A novel method, hierarchical Bayesian inference, solves problems by addressing model and comparison within the same framework using variational techniques. The approach has consequences for parameter and model estimation. A fully Bayesian quantifying uncertainty at group enabled statistical tests about parameters and errors. Empirical Bayes play a role in modern statistics.

 The HBI framework is hierarchical, regularizing individual parameters across individuals, and Bayesian representing uncertainties at both levels. Evaluating a model for a subject precedes estimation of its values; previous research used separate tools. However, the questions are interconnected because parameters depend on subjects expressing the model. This work addresses from a Bayesian viewpoint. Issues of inference both parameters and models remained with previous methods. Notably, the best-fitting may vary subject to subject, hierarchical estimation assumed the model expressed all.
Researchers studied how the development of the auditory circuitry in the brainstem, specifically the part of the brain responsible for processing sound and hearing. They found that a group of cells called rhombomeres, which contribute to brainstem development, play a crucial role in forming sensory and motor components of the auditory system. These components include the ventral nucleus of the lemniscus, ventral cochlear nuclei, and olivochlear neurons. The assembly of these components is necessary for sound perception and depends on interactions between two specific genes, Hox1 and H2. In mice without these genes, transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is lost, leading to hearing impairments. On the other hand, H2 regulates axon guidance and controls contralateral projections from the ventral cochlear to the trapezoid nucleus, a circuit involved in sound localization. Each rhomere and its associated genes control distinct sub-circuits in the developing brainstem.
Scientists have sequenced the complete genome of a marine bacterium called Saccharagus deans strain 2-40, which is capable of breaking down complex carbohydrates. This bacterium is part of a newly discovered group of marine bacteria that recycle complex carbohydrates. The genome analysis shows that it has many enzymes that can break down complex carbohydrates, and some of these enzymes have unique structures. Researchers think these features help the bacterium break down complex carbohydrates in the ocean. This is the first time a marine bacterium's genome has been sequenced that can break down plant cell walls, a key part of the carbon cycle not well understood in the ocean.

The study found that the bacterium's enzymes are regulated in different ways, and more complex carbohydrates require more enzymes to break down. Glucose, a simple sugar, is a key to regulating the enzymes. The bacterium can grow on plants as its only food and break them down completely, a first time a marine bacterium has done so. The bacterium is related to others that break down cellulose, a plant material, and nitrogen-fixing bacteria that live with worms.

The study suggests the bacter has a key role in the ocean's carbon cycle, breaking down complex carbohydrates from plants and animals. It's an important, understudied system. The bacterium's genome has been fully sequenced and is available online.
Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes significant childhood neurological infections in Asia. Over the past 20 years, JEV genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI). The reason for this shift is unknown. Culex (Cx) mosquitoes are common in China and play a key role in JEV transmission. This study used Cx pipiens mosquitoes from China to explore if they played a role in JEV shift. Female Cx pip mosquitoes were exposed to GI or GIII JEV strains. Midgut, organs, and saliv glands of infected mosquitoes were collected at 7 and 14 days post-infection (dpi) to measure infection, replication, dissemination, and transmission of JEV. Cx pip mosquitoes were competent for both GI and GIII infection with similar rates and kinetics. Both genotypes disseminated to secondary organs at similar rates. GI-infected saliv glands were positive at 16.2% at 7dpi, while GIII was undetectable. However, 29.4% and 36.3% were positive at 14dpi. No difference in transmission rate between GI and G-infected was detected. Data showed GI and GIII have similar infectivity in Cx pip, suggesting C pip may not play a role in J shift.
A two-year review of dengue deaths in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014 was conducted to study demographics and clinical characteristics associated with deng deaths. A total of 322 deng deaths were reviewed, with a mean age of 40.7 years and 72.5% were adults. Diabetes and hypertension were common co-morbidities among adults and elderly. The most common symptoms were lethargy and vomiting, with lethargy being more common in children and abdominal pain in adults. 22.4% had no symptoms and 34% were suspected deng at initial presentation. Adults developed severe plasma leakage and more than half suffered multi-organ involvement. Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) contributed to 70% of deaths, followed by severe involvement 69% and bleeding 29.7%. In Malaysia, deng deaths primarily occurred in adults and SS was leading cause of death regardless of age. The study highlights the need for early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent deng deaths.
Researchers studied how female fruit flies, Drosophila melanogaster, choose their mates to maximize reproductive success. They found that insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway, affects female attractiveness. Insulin signaling in the body's fat and ovarian cells, called follicles, sends signals to pherom-producing cells called oocytes. These signals are crucial for female attractiveness. Manipulating insulin in these cells changed attractiveness, while manipulating in the body had opposite effects. This suggests a connection between insulin in the body and ovaries. Insulin signaling in follicles increased attractiveness, while in the body decreased it. This also affected fecundity, or ability to produce offspring, in the same direction. Cuticular hydrocarbons, chemical cues, responded differently to body and follicle manipulations, indicating separate pathways. Insulin signaling in body and follicles are linked to attractiveness and fecundity. The study found a system where attractiveness and fecity are connected, both influenced by insulin in body and follicles.
During the 2013-2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa, the virus spread unevenly affected the hardest-hit countries Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. To understand how the virus spread, researchers used a statistical approach to estimate the basic reproduction number (R) for each district and country, using weekly case numbers. They found R ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone. At the national level, R was estimated at 0.97 for Guinea, 1.26 for Liberia, and 1.66 for Sierra. The study suggests that urbanization, such as high population density and wealth, contributed to the spread of EVD.

The researchers used district-level data from the epidemic and a statistical model to calculate growth at country and district levels. They estimated the transmissibility of EVD as R for Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra, and their 53 districts. They explored the relationship between R and socio-demographic variables as drivers of E transmission at a population level.

The Ebola outbreak started in December 2013 in Guinea and became the largest EVD epidemic ever. Studies have discussed the geographical heterogeneity of transmission in West, but not considered it in analysis. The epidemic has a multi-level structure and national curves are an overlay of local outbreaks. Only 9% of districts had a functioning Ebola Treatment Unit in the first eight weeks of the wave.

The study used weekly E cases in each subunit of Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra, available at the World Health Organization website. Findings are compatible with disease drivers, but factors cannot be answered with this design and data. The mixed model is a strategy to quantify local growth during a large-scale epidemic and confirms geographical heterogeneity in E in West.
Researchers investigated the relationship between a protein's age and its rate of evolution. They used a large dataset of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins with mapped structures to study the interplay of age and structural properties as determinants of evolutionary rate. The study found that previously observed correlations between structural and evolutionary rates also held within age groups, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and rates. However, age also played a role in modulating the relationship between solvent and rate. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, tended to evolve faster than older ones. The researchers showed that reported relationships between age and rate could not be explained by structural biases among groups. They introduced a knowledge-based function to study stability of proteins through large computation and found that older proteins were more stable in their native structure and robust to mutations than younger ones. The study underscored that determinants, both intrinsic and historical, interact to determine protein evolution.
Polycomb-like 3 (P3) is a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) that promotes embryonic stem cell (ES) self-renewal by regulating gene expression. Researchers identified P3 as a binding partner of Suz12, a core component of PR2, using mass spectrometry and co-immunoprecipitation. Knocking down P3 in ES cells increases spontaneous differentiation, but not early differentiation, indicating P3 has a specific role in self-renew. Consistent with P3 promoting PR2 function, decreasing P3 reduces H3me27 levels, while overexpressing P3 increases H3me levels. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing (ChIP-q) show P3 co-localizes with Suz12 and depletion of P3 decreases Suz binding at 60% of PR2 targets. Mutation of conserved residues in the P Tudor domain of P3, implicated in recognizing methylated histones, compromises Hme formation, suggesting the Tud domain of P3 is essential. P3 and its paralog P2 exist in different PR complexes but bind many of the same PR targets, particularly Cp islands regulated by P3. P3 is critical for ESC selfnew, histone methylation, and PR2 recruitment to a subset of genomic sites.
Researchers have studied how the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans regulates its chemosensory behavior in response to changes in feeding state. They found that the expression of a chemoreceptor gene, sr-234, in the AD sensory neuron of C. elegans is regulated by the transcription factor MEF-2 and basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) factors. MEF-2 acts together with bHL factors to regulate sr-234 expression as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory M2 site is necessary for starvation-induced downregulation of sr-234, while an E-box binds bHL factors to drive sr- expression in AD. HL-2, HL-3, and HL-4 act in AD neurons to regulate sr-234. Expression of sr- in AD neurons is also regulated by MX-3 and HL-30 in the intestine, dependent on insulin signaling in AD neurons. Intestine-to-neuron regulation of sr- involves a subset of insulin peptides. These results suggest chemore gene expression is regulated by cell-autonomous and non-autonomous mechanisms mediated by MEF and bHL, allowing animals to fine-tune chemens responses to feeding changes.
Researchers investigated the link between mosquitoes and the risk of Buruli ulcer (BU), a destructive skin infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans, in southeastern Australia. Mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula, Victoria, from 2004 to 2009, and tested for M. ulcer using real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed BU cases in residents during the same period was tallied to determine the average incidence in each location. A strong correlation was found between the detection of M. ulcer in mosquitoes and the risk of disease (r = 0.99, 95% CI 0.92-0.99, p<0.001). The study suggests mosquitoes play a role in transmitting M. ulcer to humans in southeastern Australia, supporting public measures to minimize mosquito bites in residents and visitors in endemic areas. The study also raises questions whether mosquitoes are involved in transmission in other BU areas, such as Queensland and Africa, where most cases occur.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the MRS2 gene in rats that causes demyelination, a condition characterized by severe myelin breakdown in the central nervous system after normal myelination is complete. The mutation is a G-to-A transition 177 base pair downstream of exon 3 of the MRS2 gene, creating a novel splice site that inactivates the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type MRS2 DNA confirmed the findings. M2 encodes a component of the Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria of yeast and human cells. Rats with the mutation have major mitochondrial deficits, including elevated lactic acid in cerebrospinal fluid, 60% reduction in ATP, and swollen mitochondria in oligodendrocy cytoplasm. M2-GFP recombinant BAC transgenic rats show M2 is dominantly expressed in neurons, not oligodrocytes, and ultrastructurally observed in inner mitochondria membrane. Observations suggest dmy rats suffer mitochondrial disease and myelin maintenance mechanism different from production. Mg+ homeostasis in mitochondria essential for myelin maintenance.
Microarray-based gene expression signatures hold promise to improve disease diagnosis and prognosis, but current documentation standards hinder their application in clinical practice. Researchers analyzed eight publicly available clinical microarray studies and found that study-internal and study-external diagnoses often disagreed, with discrepancies as high as 30% in the worst-case and 18% in median scenarios. This is because documenting a signature is conceptually different from reporting a list of genes. The exact specification of a classification rule alone does not define a signature unambiguously. A proposed documentation strategy, which includes quantitative information, reduced the median discrepancy to 1%. The process of bringing microarray expression signatures to clinical practice can be improved and made more reliable with better documentation. 

A study of eight clinical microarray studies showed that current documentation has shortcomings: using documented information, a study-external might receive a different diagnosis from the original. To address this, guidelines and methodology for building unambiguous signatures were proposed. The approach reduced ambiguity to a minimum. Rawarray data is subject to noise, variation not due to signal but measurement or experimental error. Preprocessing is common prior to analysis. Consistency of diagnoses on gene signatures depends on documentation. Optimal was obtained using the proposed strategy. No strong evidence was found favoring one approach over the other. Micro signatures hold promise to improve diagnosis, but evaluation is difficult and subject to research. A signature needs to hold independent information to existing markers. Before impacting practice, they need to be communicated for evaluation and use in routine, requiring unambiguous documentation.
Researchers have studied the structure of a protein called curli, which is secreted by a type of bacteria called Enterobacteraceae. Curli helps the bacteria stick to surfaces and form communities called biofilms, making them more resistant to stress. The team found that curli's structure is similar to human amyloid, a protein linked to Alzheimer's disease. They tested peptides designed to stop Alzheimer's amyloid from forming, and found they also stopped curli from forming and reduced biofilm in Salmonella bacteria. This suggests that these peptides could be used to fight bacterial infections by targeting amyloid biofilms. The study also showed that cur can seed amyloid formation in other proteins, like Alzheimer's amyloid, supporting the idea that amyloids from different species can interact. The research provides insights into how curli forms and proposes a new way to stop amyloid biofilms. It also suggests that amyloids from bacteria could contribute to neurodegenerative diseases.
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is a significant cause of encephal in Asia, with high fatality rates and neurologic sequelae among survivors. In the Philippines, the epidemiology of JE is not well defined. A systematic review of literature and surveillance data from 2011-2014 was conducted to support consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule. The review identified 29 reports on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic, 18 clinical, and 8 animal studies. Clinical studies reported 257 laboratory-confirmed JE cases from 1972-2013, with JE virus as causative in 7-18% of meningitis and encephalitis and 16-40% encephal cases. Predominantly affected children under 15, with 6-7% resulting in death. Surveillance from 2011-2014 identified 73 laboratory-confirmed JE out of 497 tested. This review demonstrates endemicity and geographic range of JE in the Philippines, supporting vaccine use in the country. Continued surveillance and laboratory confirmation is needed to quantify burden, guide prioritization of high-risk areas, and age and schedule of vaccine introduction, and measure preventive measures against this public health threat.
Researchers investigated the origins of genetic robustness in bacteria, which is the ability of a species to withstand genetic perturbations. They studied the metabolic networks of hundreds of bacterial species in various simulated environments and found that variations in robustness reflect ecological adaptations. Robustness was decoupled into two components: environmental, responsible for 20% of non-essential reactions and associated with species' lifestyle, and environmental-independent, associated with intrinsic metabolic capacities. Species with high robustness were fast growers or producers of secondary metabolites. Reactions uniquely susceptible to perturbations in pathogens were identified as potential drug targets.

The study used a computational approach to analyze metabolic networks and found a significant association between robustness and metabolic capacities, supporting the idea that increased capacities drove the evolution of robustness. Robustness can be studied at various levels, from molecular to organismal, where it's considered robust if a mutation has insignificant effect on a trait. Environmental robust differs across species, some can grow in various habitats while others have specialized requirements.

The contribution of environmental robust to genetic was demonstrated by a new pathway allowing a species to use an external metabolite as alternative to an existing one, promoting robustness. Environmental robust also correlates with modularity of metabolic networks. The effect of environmental on genetic robust was studied in yeast, where half of non-essential genes were active under restricting conditions. However, environmental cannot fully explain dispensability, other hypotheses propose adaptive origin.
Researchers conducted a randomized trial to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni infection on antibody responses to measles catch-up immunization in pre-school children and the impact of prazantel treatment on this outcome. The study, called the Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunization (IMCI) study, took place in Enteb, Uganda and included 193 Schistoma-infected and 61 uninfected children aged 3-5 years. Infected children were randomly assigned to receive prantel 2 weeks before, at the time of, or 1 week after measles immunization. Plasma-meas Ig was measured at enrollment, 1 and 24 weeks after immunization. The primary outcomes were Ig levels and percentage of participants with protective levels against measles. Results showed that Schistoma-infected children had lower anti-meas Ig levels and percentage with protective levels compared to uninf children. However, those treated with prant before immun had higher anti-meas Ig levels than those not treated. At 24 weeks post-immun, Ig levels did not differ between groups, but tended to be lower in previously-inf children still positive for Schoma than those who became negative. The study suggests Schoma infection impairs antibody response to measles immunization and prant treatment improves it.
Researchers have developed new statistical tools to study the evolution of bacterial populations on a large scale. Traditional methods, such as phylogenetic analysis, are limited when dealing with extensive sampling and recombination. The new tools, implemented in software called BAPS, can detect recombination between populations and describe the shape of a population in sequence space. This is demonstrated with data from the Neisseria genus, where genetic tools are combined with phylogen analysis. BAPS can capture various biological signals in molecular data, but interpretation must be done with care using complementary methods and knowledge of the strains. A sample of 508 Neisseria strains is used to show the complexity of the methods. The population is assumed to have a common ancestor and local ancestors from a global ancestor, enabling a tree representation of relationships. Traditional genetic tools are not applicable to bacterial data due to lack of population conditions, while phylogen analysis may distort relationships with recombination. The new tools in BAPS enable analysis of population structures on an unprecedented scale, overcoming computational complexity of standard methods. The Neisser species are chosen for validation due to frequent recombination and horizontal gene flow between species.
Researchers have long believed that brain rhythms play a crucial role in cognitive abilities such as attention. Recent studies have shown that beta activity in the 20 Hz frequency band is linked to attention, with top-down beta rhythms generated in higher areas sending signals to sensory areas supporting attention gain. To understand the role of beta and its mechanisms, a model of cortical areas was built. The simulation showed that top beta can activate projections from layer 5 to 4 and 2/3, responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Inhibitory neurons were found to resonate at 20 Hz and modulate superficial activity in an attention-related manner. This provides a potential mechanism for cholinergic to support selective attention.

A model was used to explore the effect of top beta on layer 5 neurons. Results suggested mechanisms for selective attention: cells resonating to beta can modulate superficial activity by projecting to upper layers. Two types of projections from 5 to upper layers were found, associated with beta activity in superficial in line with neural modulation by attention. Top beta associated with attention can enhance gamma in 2/3, reduce beta in 2/3 and 3, and spiking of 2/3 cells. Excitatory interneuron connections gave rise to biased competition, consistent with lateral in the model. This is in line with models that top signals can bias, but adds that interamin interaction regulated by beta supports attention.

A model was used to address whether beta can bias competition and how it achieves this. Top beta was tested to reproduce physiological findings that stimulus generated gamma and spiking, and attention enhanced neural responses. Inputs simulated by 100 Hz trains of EPs were introduced to 4 and cells of columns.
Researchers have developed a new method called Multiple Shooting for Stochastic Systems (MSS) to calibrate and predict stochastic compartmental models of epidemics. These models are useful for studying the emergence of new pathogens when the number of infected individuals is small. However, current methods for estimating and predicting these models are limited. SS applies a linear approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the epidemic state using new observations. The method was tested on simulated outbreaks of a viral pathogen and showed accurate estimates of key parameters, such as duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff, and the number of unobserved individuals. It also accurately predicted future hospitalizations and attack rate. SS outperformed three benchmark methods: likelihood with Poisson assumption, particle filtering, and Kalman filter in most scenarios. This method may improve current approaches for calibrating and predicting stochastic epidemics.

The method uses data available during the early epidemic period, such as weekly new case counts, as a proxy for incidence. It addresses challenges in parameter estimation and prediction when the true state is partially observed and disease spread is stochastic. The posterior from previous observations can be used as prior for new data. The goal is to improve predictions about future epidemics. The method was tested with competing approaches in accuracy, estimating parameters, predicting behaviors, and inferring the current state. Performance was sensitive to noise and model misspecification. Estimating parameters is challenging during emergence due to stochastic dynamics and partially observable processes.
Researchers have discovered that human perception is influenced by two opposing forces: adaptation and past decisions. In a series of experiments, they used multilevel modeling and cross-validation to investigate how previous stimuli and decisions affect behavioral responses in forced-choice tasks. The results showed that perceptual reports are biased by a hierarchy of serial processes: low-level adaptation pushes perception away from previous stimuli, while decisional pulls towards the past. This hierarchy of dependence arises from decision templates, not low sensory processes. A two-process model suggests that decision persistence compensates for adaptation, leading to attractive biases in perception. A unified account proposes distinct mechanisms at different stages promote differentiation and integration of visual information over time.

The study used multile modeling and cross-validation to characterize serial dependence, concluding: two forces interact at any moment shaping perception, biasing appearance towards or away from past. Repulsive forces dominate low-level adaptation after stimuli require perception. The goal was to determine if dependence depends on past stimuli or previous response. Recent work showed past biases decisions about present input, but history may combine or outweigh stimuli. This result supports a hierarchical view and shows decision affects even with new stimuli.

The study provides a unified account of perceptual and decision processes, proposing a model of dependence where adaptation and decision interact shaping experience and reactions. Contrary to low continuity, dependence originates from response changes in early neurons, not later stages. However, results show two mechanisms: repulsive after sensory and attractive perceptual.
Researchers studied the role of a protein called CY in the circadian clock system of fruit flies (Drosophila). CY has a DNA-binding domain but lacks an activation domain, and most of its transcriptional activity comes from a glutamine-rich region of its partner protein CLK. To understand its role in circadian timekeeping, they created a CY-viral protein 16 (VP) fusion, adding a potent viral transcription activator to CY. This enhanced CLKCY-VP complex's transcriptional activity compared to the normal CLKCY complex. Flies expressing CY-VP had increased levels of CLKCY target mRNAs and a shorter period, suggesting circadian transcription contributes to period determination. Reporter gene expression in CYVP-expressing flies showed the short period was due to rapid transcription. Behavioral effects required the per promoter, indicating increased transcription, not just higher PER levels, caused the effects. This suggests timing of transcription, not activation, is key to behavioral changes in CYVP-express flies. The study indicates circadian transcription contributes to core function in Dophila.
Scientists have long believed that horizontally acquired genes, or genes passed from one species to another, can function independently and confer new traits. However, researchers found that existing proteins in an organism can limit the functionality of a horizontally acquired gene if it interacts with an ancestral pathway. They studied the horizontally acquired pmr gene in Salmonella, which activates the Pmr/PB system, but not in the closely related Escherichia coli. The pmr protein in Salmonella binds to phosphorylated Pmr, protecting it from dephosphorylation by mr, leading to transcription of mr-dependent genes, including polymyxin resistance. They found that E coli pmr can activate Pmr/PB in Salmonella, but not in E coli, suggesting a difference in controlling mr levels. E coli mr displays higher phosphatase activity towards mr than Salmon mr, and identified a mr domain responsible for this property. Replacing E coli mr with Salmon mr restored E coli resistance to polymin under mr-inducing conditions. This shows that differences in biochemical activities of ancestral proteins dictate horizontally acquired gene's ability to confer species-specific traits, and acquired genes can potentiate ancestral loci.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify genes involved in the early stages of cell differentiation, a process by which cells become more specialized. This method, called Differentiation-Test, analyzes gene expression data from a mixture of cells without separating them into different types. Previous methods often included genes that respond to differentiation, not regulate it. The team applied Different-Test to mouse embryonic stem cells and found Smad1, a new regulator of pluripotency and self-renew. They used short RNA to study two regulators detected by Different-Test, Smad1 and P2, and found lower expression in differentiated cells. The researchers separated regulators into two modules: upregulated during differentiation and downregulated pluripotency.
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze genetic data from next-generation sequencing studies, called unbiased clustering of gene variants with phenotypic-link network. This method helps identify functional relationships between genes and their roles in diseases, even when the function of many genes is unknown. Traditional methods use large-scale data, such as protein-protein interactions and gene-expression networks, but can be affected by bias, leading to false findings. The new method controls for bias in gene length, which can lead to exaggerated results. It uses over 100,000 human-mammalian genotype-phenotype relations and semantic similarity to enhance the network. The researchers tested the method with different data and networks and found that genes associated with the same disease cluster more in the integrated phenotyp-link network than other networks. This method can identify functional associations among mutated genes in the same disease, even after accounting for sequencing bias. It can also cluster genes underlying polygenic disorders. The method was compared to another network, NETAG, developed by Gil and colleagues, and found similar results. This approach is useful for rare disease studies, as case-control studies have limited power to associate variants with disease. Functional-enrich approaches, like this method, identify shared functions in mutated genes, becoming standard in variant interpretation.
Mexico implemented an 8% tax on non-essential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100g and a peso-per tax on sugar-sweetened beverages (SBs) in January 2014 to prevent obesity and diabetes. This study evaluated changes in volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases in the first year after the tax, stratified by socioeconomic status (SES). The study used data from 6,248 households in Nielsen's Mexico Consumer Panel (2012-2014) and analyzed volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases from 2012-2014. Results showed a 5.1% decrease in taxed food purchases beyond expected trends, with no change in untaxed purchases. Low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed food than expected, medium SES 5.8% less, and high SES no change. The study's limitations include inability to infer causality due to national implementation and lack of control group, sample only urban areas, and 2 years prior data. Household purchases of non-essential foods declined in the first year after the tax.
Researchers have proposed a new model to explain the behavior of collision-sensitive neurons in the brain, which are responsible for detecting objects approaching objects in the visual field. These neurons integrate information from a large area of the visual field and respond best to objects on a collision course. A previous model used a power law to scale inhibitory input, but this new model assumes noisy channels with a threshold. The result is an approximate power law from pooling these channels. This mechanism can predict characteristics of the Lobula Giant Detector Neuron (LG), a well-studied neuron in locust that responds to approaching objects. The model depends on noise in the inhibitory pathway but is robust to noise in the excitatory pathway.

 The new model, called "n-ψ", is biophysically plausible and based on a predecessor that used a power law for inhibitory input. It's not as detailed as other models but explains many characteristics of collision-sensitive neurons with a maximum response before collision. Noise plays a key role in approximating a power in the inhibitory pathway by smoothing. This is due to integrating many inhibitory inputs. A power alone doesn't suffice, as it distorts the LG's response to approaching objects. The model "noisy" or "n-ψ" is based on an equation describing the membrane potential of the LG neuron. It receives Θ and Θ as input and integrates by the dendritic tree. Conditions are noise across channels and a threshold.
Cameroon has been endemic for Buruli ulcer (BU) since 1969, but control efforts began in 2002. The National Buruli Ulcer Control Programme (NBPUC) aimed to detect cases early, confirm 70% by PCR, treat all according to guidelines, and heal 95% without joint limitation. From 2001-2014, 370 cases were reported, with a significant drop from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants. The number of endemic districts rose from 2 to 64, with 5 functional diagnostic and 2 planned for 2015. The health system was strengthened and research gained interest. Although control began 30 years after the first cases, progress was made in detection, management, system, and research. However, reduced resources led to a drop in performance since 2010.
Researchers investigated how people's confidence in their choices affects learning and decision-making in situations where outcomes are either gains or losses. They found that people are more confident in their choices when learning to gain compared to avoiding losses, despite equal performance in both contexts. A computational model showed that this bias is due to "context-value", an estimate of the average value of options, necessary for equal performance in both gain and loss domains. This bias is the first found in a reinforcement learning context and is domain-general, suggesting important implications. The study also showed that in uncertain environments, people's learning strategies differ when outcomes are framed as gains or losses, despite similar behavior. A previous study found that stakes can bias confidence in choices, with gains increasing and losses decreasing it. The researchers hypothesized that people would be less confident in choices to avoid losses compared to gains, and that this would be due to learned-value. They tested this in a task where outcomes were either gains or losses, and found people performed equally well in both. The study suggests confidence can be a meta-cognitive variable for comparing learning strategies and deciding whether to adjust them. Despite recent models of confidence in decision-making, how people estimate confidence in reinforcement learning is poorly understood.
Researchers have studied the role of a protein called ns3 in the replication of alphaviruses, a type of virus that causes diseases such as chikungunya and sindbis fever. Ns3 is part of the virus's replication complex and has a conserved amino-terminal domain that helps with RNA synthesis and a poorly conserved carbox-terminal region. They found that the carbox-terminal of ns3 has a proline-rich sequence that binds to a protein called amphiphin, which is found in host cells. This binding is important for the virus to replicate. The researchers tested this by mutating the proline sequence in ns3 and silencing amphin expression, which impaired virus replication in cells. They also infected mice with a virus that couldn't bind to amphin and saw decreased mortality. The study shows that ns3 binding to amphin is a key interaction that helps the virus replicate in host cells.
Researchers studied 123 strains of a disease-causing fungi in Brazil, known as chromoblastyc, to understand its diversity. They used DNA sequencing to identify the species. The fungi were divided into three groups, with Fonseea being the most common, followed by Rhinadiella and Cyellophora. Fonsea pedso was the most prevalent, found in 80% of cases, followed by 13% for monora, 3 for nica, and 1 pnius. Two new species, Rhinadi and Cyello, were also found, making up 3 and 1% of cases, respectively.

The study analyzed 123 clinical cases from different areas in Brazil. The fungi were polyphyletic, meaning they didn't form a single group, and were divided into three clades: jeansme, biana, and europaea. Fonica and pni were in jeansme-clade, Rhadi in europ-cl, and two new species were found. Fonsea pedso and monora are common in humid climates, while nica is in southern China. Four Fonsea species were found in Brazil, with pedso and nica associated with chromobycosis.

The Brazilian isolates were from humid zones, no Cladiophora was not found, as it's in arid conditions. 98% were Fonsea pedso, 13% monora, 3 nica, and 1 pni. Two new species, Rhadi and Cyello, were found causing chromyc infections. Three genera were recognized: Fonsea, Rhadi, and Cyello, no Cladi found due to climate.
Listeria monocytogenes, a type of bacteria, infects host cells by causing DNA damage, but how it affects the cell's response to this damage is not well understood. Researchers found that Lister monocogen induces DNA breaks in host cells, but surprisingly, the cell's response to these breaks is only moderately activated. They discovered that the bacterial toxin listerolysin O (LO) blocks the cell's response to DNA damage by degrading the sensor Mre protein. Knocking out or inactivating proteins involved in the response promotes bacterial replication, showing the importance of this mechanism in controlling infection. The study highlights that dampening the cell's response is crucial for successful infection.

The researchers also found that deleting or inhibiting proteins involved in the response leads to higher levels of infection, demonstrating that the response can be a negative regulator of bacterial infection. Other bacteria, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Neisseria gonorrhoe, have been shown to induce DNA damage, but this has not been studied in Lister infection. Listerol induces degradation of Mre, a major sensor of damage, through proteome degradation. Results show that dampening the response is important for infection as inhibiting proteins in this pathway increases bacterial. The study uncovers L monocogen's subversion of response during infection and role in blocking bacterial proliferation.

Infection with L monocogen induces DNA breaks and activates response in cells in vitro and in vivo. Strikingly, monocogen dampens activation of DNA-damage pathway through bacterial LO. The bacterium monocogen provokes breaks in host while controlling ensuing response. Wild type bacteria modestly induce response, but Δl mutant lacking LO does significantly. Further, LO dampens response through degradation of host Mre. Consistent results, extracellular Lister (infection with Δl mutant or pretreatment with cytochal prior infection wild type) shows same level γ2 as observed infection monoc able invade cells.
Researchers have identified a protein called bromodomain protein 4 (BRD4) as a key player in the infection of two common human viruses, HSV-1 and HSV-2. They found that blocking a specific part of the protein, called the BD domain, with a compound called JQ, increased the viruses' ability to infect cells. The team showed that JQ works by changing how BR4 interacts with other proteins to help the viruses replicate. BR4 helps the viruses by forming a complex with two other proteins, CDK and RNA polymerase II, and JQ promotes infection by directing this complex to the viruses' genetic material. Suppressing BR4 or blocking CDK activity reduced the viruses' ability to infect cells. The study suggests that JQ enhances infection by switching BR4's function to regulate viral gene expression by targeting the viruses' genetic material. This is the first time BR4 has been linked to viral infection and shows its essential role in the process.
Researchers studied the microbial communities in the mouths of children with a rare and devastating disease called noma cancrum, which causes severe facial disfigurement in over 140,000 malnourished children every year. The cause of noma is still unknown, but a mix of microbial infection, poor oral hygiene, and weakened immune system likely contribute to the development of oral lesions. These lesions are entry points for unidentified microorganisms that trigger gangrenous facial infections. To catalog bacteria in noma lesions and identify potential triggers, researchers analyzed 16S rRNA gene fragments from 60 samples of gingival fluid from 12 healthy children, 12 with noma lesions, and 12 with Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG) lesions and healthy sites. Compared to healthy individuals, samples from diseased mouths were enriched with Spirocha and depleted Proteobacteria. Samples from healthy sites of diseased had similar proportions of Spiro and Proteobacteria to controls. Samples from n mouths did not have higher Fusobacter abundance, casting doubt on its causative role. Microbial communities from n and AN lesions were dominated by Prevotella intermedia OT, less abundant in healthy sites. Multivariate analysis confirmed different bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites. Several OTUs in Erysotrichales, Cloidales, Boid, and Spirotales were identified as indicators of noma, suggesting one or more microbes in these orders associated with development.
Bacillus thuringis, a bacterium that infects insects, uses a communication system called quorum sensing to adapt to its environment and decide whether to form spores or commit to a necrotrophic lifestyle. Quorum sensing is a way bacteria talk to each other through signaling molecules. In Bacillus thuring, this system is regulated by a family of proteins called RNPP. One of these proteins, Npr, acts as a transcription factor when bound to its signaling molecule Npr, turning on genes for survival in the insect cadaver. However, researchers found that Npr also inhibits sporulation, the process of forming spores, in the absence of Npr. Npr prevents the phosphorylation of SpoF, a protein needed for spore formation, thus delaying the process. Npr's function is similar to Rap proteins, which don't bind DNA but control gene expression through protein interactions. Residues that interact with SpoF suggest common inhibition of spore formation. Npr's structure is flexible, like Rap. The study proposes that Npr has two functions: binding Npr switches it from inhibitor to activator of necrotrophic lifestyle. Npr coordinates sporulation and necrotism, ensuring bacteria survival and spread during infection.
Researchers have developed a new computational model to predict the effectiveness of HIV treatment with antiretroviral drugs. This model, called proteochem, combines information about the chemical properties of the drug and the target it interacts with, in addition to the genetic information of the virus. The model was trained on a large database of over 300,000 data points of drug-virus interactions, and was able to predict the effectiveness of drugs with an error rate of less than 0.5.5. When compared to previous models that only used genetic information, the new model performed better in predicting resistance and identifying new mutations that cause resistance. The model was also applied to a public database and correctly predicted resistance in 84% of cases, compared to 80% by previous models. The researchers conclude that protechem models can accurately predict resistance based on genetic information, even for new and mixed mutations. The model also informs the user about the reliability of predictions.
Researchers have proposed an alternative explanation for the mechanism of chemotaxis, the process by which cells move towards chemical attractants. The traditional view is that attractants cause actin polymerization, leading to pseudop formation and movement. However, this study suggests that pseudops are formed by a self-generated cycle, and attractants modulate this cycle rather than directly causing actin polymerization. A computational model of cell movement and chemotaxis based on pseudop autocatalysis was developed to test the explanatory and predictive powers of this mechanism. The model reproduces a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemotaxis, simulates cell polarization and persistence, and predicts pseudop bias in attractant gradients. It also predicts lateral pseudop initiation in high attractant gradients. To test the model's ability, a prediction was made that the angle between successive pseudops at the front of the cell would increase with the difference between the cell's direction and the attractant gradient. This was measured in Dictyostelium cells under different conditions and agreed with the model well. The model and data suggest that rapidly moving cells like Dictyostelium and neutrophils have an intrinsic pseudop cycle at the heart of motility, implying that chemotaxis relies on modification of pseudop behavior rather than generation or actin polymerization by attractants.
Researchers studied how fleas transmit the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which causes the plague, to rodents. They found that fleas can transmit the bacterium in two ways: early-phase transmission (EPT) and bio-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and rodent species. To understand the mechanism of E, they fed fleas bacteremic blood from mice, rats, guinea pigs, and gerbils. The location and characteristics of infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pest were assessed 1-3 days post-infection. Surprisingly, 10-28% of rodent fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea blood regurgitated a portion of the infected meal into the esophagus within 24 hours. This phenomenon is called post-infection esophageal reflux (PIER). In contrast, PIER was rare in fleas fed bacteremic mouse or gerbil blood. PIER correlated with accumulation of dense aggregates of Y. pest, red blood cells, and hemoglobin that filled the proventulus. At next feeding, fleas with P were 3-25 times more likely to be blocked with blood retained in the esagus than fleas without P. Three days after feeding on bacteremic blood, Oropsa montana transmitted significantly more CFU than groups using mouse blood, and this transmission was bio-dependent. Data support a model where E results from regurgitation of pest from obstructed foregut and E and B can sometimes overlap.
Researchers have found that positive correlations between the activity of neurons in the brain can actually improve the accuracy of coding, rather than hinder it. Contrary to previous studies, which suggested that correlations were detrimental or only marginally beneficial, this study shows that they can enhance performance by astronomical factors. The probability of error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude and the number of stimuli that can be encoded can be increased tenfold. These effects do not require unrealistic correlation values and can occur in populations with just a few neurons. The study also shows that heterogeneity in activity is beneficial and that both error suppression and enhancement depend on a specific pattern of correlation. Tuning one or several parameters can lead to perfect coding, where the pattern of positive correlation leads to a "locking" of response that eliminates variability for stimulus discrimination.

The study demonstrates that certain patterns of positive correlation can suppress errors in a two-alternative task. The idea that correlations can be favorable to coding was previously noted, but the degree of enhancement is extreme, several orders of magnitude rather than a few percent. While some patterns are forbidden, responses are still variable and correlation can have moderate values similar to those measured. If the population is close to the singular limit, fine-tuned, even coding is not perfect can obtain an enhancement of performance compared to independent neurons. The role of heterogeneity is a general feature of coding and has been shown in various approaches. The phenomenon where correlation suppresses errors and boosts capacity is called high-fidelity coding.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine against cholera, a severe diarrhea caused by Vibrio cholera bacteria. The vaccine combines a specific part of the bacteria's outer layer, called OSP, with a fragment of tetanus toxin. They tested the vaccine in mice, varying the amount of OSP, ratio of OSP to tetanus fragment, and adjuvant, and route of injection. Mice developed antibodies and immune cells against OSP and Vibrio, but not against tetanus. Intestinal immune response occurred with intradermal injection. Responses were similar across variations, but blunted at highest dose. No difference with or without adju. The vaccine protected 55% of mice from cholera challenge. The new vaccine induces memory and protection against cholera in mice. An effective cholera vaccine would be beneficial, especially for children who poorly respond to outer layer antigens.
A study was conducted to investigate the cross-reactivity of immunochromatographic test (ICT) cards in areas with contrasting endemicity of Loa loa and Mansonella perans in Cameroon. The study assessed the prevalence and intensity of Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Mansonella perans in 42 villages across three regions of the Cameroon rainforest. Blood samples were collected for detection of circulating filarial antigen by ICT and assessment of microfilaria using thick smear. Clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis were also assessed. Overall, 219 individuals participated in the study, with 24 testing positive by ICT, ranging from 0% in South-west to 2.1% in North. Lymphedema was diagnosed in 20 individuals, with majority in North, none tested positive by ICT. No microf W. bancfti found in blood of individuals with positive ICT or lymphedema. Positive ICT associated with high Loa microf intensity, 21 with over 8,000 Loa/ml (odds ratio 15.4; 95%CI 6.1-39.0; p<0.001). Strong association observed between Loa prevalence and ICT by area, 1% positive in areas with Loa above 15%. No association ICT and M perans prevalence (Spearman rho -0.200; p0.747) and M density (odds 1.8;95CI0.8-4.2; p0.192). The study confirmed association ICT and Lo intensity at individual level, and demonstrated strong association with Lo prevalence. Results suggest main confounding factor for ICT are high Lo levels. Findings indicate W bancft less prevalent in Central region than assumed, accurate re-mapping useful for shrinking LF map distribution.
Researchers have studied how the SARS-CoV virus replicates in host cells. They found that it uses a network of modified endoplasmic reticulum, a type of cell membrane, to replicate its RNA. This network is made up of convoluted membranes and double-membr vesicles (DMVs) that are 200-300 nanometers in diameter. The DMVs are not isolated vesicles, but part of a larger network. They contain viral replicase subunits and double-stranded RNA, where RNA synthesis occurs. However, it's unclear how DMVs form and where RNA synthesis happens. The virus reorganizes host cell membranes to create a network for replication and hide from antiviral defense. This study helps understand early stages of coronavirus life cycle and virus-host interactions.
Researchers have long understood that roots play a crucial role in absorbing water and nutrients from the soil, but the exact mechanism behind this process has been unclear. A new study on Arabidopsis thaliana, a plant species commonly used in scientific research, sheds light on the role of suberin, a chemical compound found in roots. The study found that suberin acts as a barrier in the root, limiting the movement of water and nutrients to the rest of the plant. Plants with higher levels of suberin, called es1 mutants, showed reduced water loss and increased water efficiency during growth. These changes in suberin and water transport were linked to changes in nutrient accumulation in the leaves, with decreases in calcium, manganese, and zinc, and increases in sodium, sulfur, selenium, and molybdenum. The study provides direct evidence that suberin plays a key role in controlling water and nutrient uptake to the leaves. The changes in leaves also suggest that a significant portion of calcium and manganese transport occurs outside the cell walls of the root.

Experiments on Arabidopsis without suberin resulted in reduced water loss, wilting, and changes in the nutrient balance, including increases in sodium, sulfur, selenium, and molybdenum, and decreases in calcium and manganese. Grafting experiments confirmed that these traits were due to elevated suberin, providing evidence that sub acts as a barrier to water and ion transport. Elevated suberin in es1 should enhance this barrier, reducing water movement to the shoot and loss from the root to soil. The study found that daytime water loss in es1 and es2 plants was 15% of wild-type plants. These findings support the model that suberin acts as a barrier to water and nutrient transport. The study suggests that increasing suberin may be a way to develop drought-resistant crops with improved water use efficiency.
Researchers investigated the kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation and its role in regulating the reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. They used a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CT) model based on the biochemistry of rhodin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model reproduced both wild-type (WT) and mutant responses with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites. The sources of variability were dissected into components: random number of turn-off steps, random sojourn time between steps, or both. Results showed that only randomness of soj times in phosphorylated states contributed to coefficient of variation (CV) of response, while randomness of number of turn steps had negligible effect. This contradicts the view that larger number of decay steps makes response more stable.

The biochemistry of rhodin deactivation was put into a stochastic framework, reproducing SPR in WT and mutant mice, and analyzing randomness of each phosphorylation state. This was interfaced with spatio-temp model, tracking diffusion of second messengers and geometrical changes on photoresponse. The prevailing view is that activation causes variability, deactivation suppresses, and more decay steps make response stable. However, analysis of mice with 0, 1, 2, 5, and 6 phosphorylation sites showed inconsistencies. Mechanistically, probability of light-activated rhodin dissociating without adding phosphate increases with phosphates, reaching 1 when all sites are phosphorylated, consistent with in vivo observations. Initial deactivation is attributable rhin phosphorylation, preserved in arrest knockout mice. Deactivation stops at peak suppression and remains steady. Mutant rhodins with fewer phosphorylation sites generate SPR of extended durations.
Researchers have developed a new mathematical framework to study the dynamics of reaction networks within cells that are influenced by factors outside the network, such as fluctuations in the number of ribosomes in a gene regulatory network. Current models that account for these external factors are difficult to analyze. The new approach, called "uncoupling," separates the network from its environment by incorporating the environment's effect into a new model. This is done by "marginalizing" fluctuating external components, such as chemicals, to obtain a decoupled model. The team derived process and master equations for this model and showed how simulations can be performed. Studies demonstrate the significance of this approach.

The goal is to create a "self-contained" model that summarizes all behaviors under possible external fluctuations. This model can be used for uncoupled analysis of a network with external noise. The provided answer is marginalizing the system with respect to external fluctuations. There is evidence that biochemical networks need to account for both intrinsic and extrinsic noise from the intracellular environment. Studies do this by extending the model's state with environmental species, whose dynamics are described with the system of interest.

The uncoupled dynamics provide a tool to study how stochasticity is propagated in reaction networks. Environmental noise splits into two terms: one suppressed and one sensed by the network. In Monte Carlo simulations, the decoupled process reduces computational effort, especially if the network is costly. This highlights the framework as a tool to split biochemical networks into parts that are easier to simulate.

The time-evolution of a reaction network is described by a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC) with species and channels. The state at time is and its path on intervals.
Researchers have developed a new brain-machine interface (BMI) system that allows people to control devices with their thoughts at a faster and more precise scale than current systems. The system uses two main components: an infinite-hor feedback model of the brain's behavior and a point model of neural spikes. The feedback model infers the user's motor intention and is used for training and adaptation. The point model enables processing and adaptation with every spike, unlike current decoders that adapt in batches. Experiments in a non-human primates showed improved performance with the new system compared to current methods. Spike-based adaptation was faster and more consistent than batch-based and robust to initial conditions. The system also controlled tasks beyond those used in training. This has implications for developing clinically viable neuroprosthetics.
Researchers studied how the retina responds to different types of visual stimuli, such as movies and white noise patterns, to understand how it processes information. They found that the retina doesn't completely eliminate redundancy in responses, but rather reduces it to a lower level, similar to responses to white noise. The amount of redundancy varies with the type of stimulus, but is less than predicted by a simple model of neural response. 

The retina maintains a moderate level of correlation across a range of stimuli, from white noise to movies with both spatial and temporal correlations. The amount of correlation changes between stimuli is less than predicted by a simple model. Experiments showed the retina doesn't fully decorrelate input, even with least correlated noise, some correlations remain between ganglion cell spike trains. Results are similar to previous studies on LGN and visual cortex, which differ in structure with natural versus random stimuli. Gain of ganglion cells responding to correlated stimuli changes with input contrast, i.e. standard deviation of nonlinearity in linear model. The retina may adjust coding strategy to represent new stimulus efficiently.
Researchers have developed a new approach to predict genetic interactions between genes, called synthetic lethality, which occurs when a combination of mutations results in a surprising effect. This is important for understanding how proteins work together in pathways and the causes of human diseases. The new method, called Multi-Network and MultiClassifier, improves upon existing approaches by using a large number of features from various data sources, including known interactions. These features are independent of known interactions, unlike previous methods. A non-parametric classifier is used to predict interactions, allowing multiple procedures to be combined. Experiments showed this approach outperformed the current method. Using this, the first yeast transcription factor genetic network was created, supported by literature. The approach was also used to predict interactions between non-essential genes in yeast. This method is expected to uncover new interactions in yeast and higher organisms like mouse and human, where few have been identified.
The BRCA Challenge is a long-term data-sharing project initiated by the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GAH) to aggregate BRCA1 and BRCA data to support collaborative research. Its goal is to generate a comprehensive understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk across the predisposition genes BR1 and BR2. The project integrates variants from public databases into a single site, www.brca.org, providing a reliable and accessible record of interpreted variants. Over 20,000 variants have been aggregated, three times the number in the next-largest database, with approximately 7,250 classifications. The data is based on information from clinical databases, such as the Breast Cancer Information Core (BIC), ClinVar, and Leiden Variation Database (LOV), as well as population databases linked to a single access point. The BR Challenge brought together the international Evidence Network for Interpretation of Genetic Mutant Alleles (ENIG) consortium, expert clinicians, diagnosticians, researchers, and providers to advance understanding BR1 and BR2 variation. Ongoing work includes contact with centers for BR1 and BR2 data, development of methods for genetic variation extraction, and engagement with communities to understand clinical significance.
Malaria, a disease caused by the Plasmodium parasite, remains a significant threat to human health, resulting in over one million deaths annually. The parasite's life cycle involves rapid multiplication in humans and mosquitoes, requiring adaptation to various environments. To cope with reactive oxygen species and maintain redox processes, Plmodium relies on adequate redox balance. Researchers have mapped the subcellular localization of major antioxidant and redox proteins in Plasium falcum, revealing the first complete redox compartment map. Two Plasium peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxal system are targeted to the apoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid. The compartmentation of thiorexin and glutaredin-like proteins is also described. Notably, Plium uses alternative translation initiation (ATI) to target two major antioxidant enzymes, glutathione reductase and thioreductase, to different locations. This dual localization by ATI may occur in other Apicomplex parasites, opening avenues for therapeutic intervention.

The study provides the first comprehensive subcellular compartment of red metabolism in malaria. The apoplast, a non-photosynthetic plast of Plasium, contains plant-like metabolic pathways, including fatty acid and heme biosynthesis. Until now, antioxidative capacity of the apoplast was unknown. Two major antioxidants, catalase and glutathione peroxidase, are absent in the parasite. This offers potential for chemotherapeutic agents disrupting Plas redox balance. Many redox enzymes contain targeting sequences, but localization has not been demonstrated due to parasite's rapid multiplication, intracellular digestion, and host immune system ROS. Plasium has two NAD-dependent red systems with broad antioxidant mechanisms. The study maps Plas red system, understanding cellular functions and interactions, and demonstrates ATI in Apicom parasites for protein localization.
Researchers studied the role of electrostatic interactions in the binding of a protein called PUM to its partner Mcl-1. PUM is an intrinsically disordered protein, meaning it doesn't have a fixed shape, and folds into an alpha helix when binding to M-1. The team used a computer model to simulate the binding process, taking into account electrostatic forces, and compared it to experimental data. They found that intramolecular electrostatic interactions have little effect on PUM's shape before binding. However, intermolecular electrostatic interactions, particularly non-native electrostatic, play a key role in forming the initial complex.
