The model revealed more about the binding process than experimental data alone, highlighting the importance of electrostatic interactions in IDP binding. This approach can be used to predict results of mutational studies.
Researchers studied the behavior of Polycomb (Pc) proteins, which play a crucial role in silencing gene expression during development, in fruit fly embryos. They found that these proteins form structures called Polycomb bodies, which contain silenced genes, and move within the nucleus. Using live imaging, they tracked the formation and movement of these bodies during embryogenesis, comparing them to condensed chromatin. Results show that Poly bodies correspond to 3D structures of genomic domains identified in genome-wide studies. During early development, Poly and Polyhomeotic (Ph) proteins accumulate in bodies, which form on euchromatin domains with histone H3-methylated K27. Time-lapse analysis revealed two types of motion: long-range movement of bodies and chromatin, and fast motion of individual bodies and chromatin. Both types move within smaller volumes than chromosome territories, limiting interaction with other nuclear structures. Fast motion decreases in late stages, suggesting chrom dynamics in gene silencing maintenance.
Researchers used ultra-deep sequencing to study mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations in mice to understand their role in aging. They found that mice with a proofreading-deficient mtDNA polymerase, called mt mutator, had 10 times more mutations than normal mice. These mice also had high levels of linear mtDNA fragments and low levels of circular deletions, which contradicts previous claims that deletions drive aging. Sequence analysis showed most mutations were inherited from mothers, not acquired during life. No increase in mutations or deletions were found in normal mice with age, questioning their role in aging. Oxidative damage was also not a major cause of mutations. The study suggests most mtDNA mutations occur during development, not due to damage later in life.
Researchers have discovered a new type of ATP synthase enzyme in the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum that uses sodium ions (Na+) to generate a transmembrane gradient. This enzyme, called F1-ATP synthase, has a novel Na+ recognition motif shared by other human pathogens. Molecular modeling and energy simulations of the enzyme's rotary element, the c-ring, indicate Na+ specificity in physiological settings. Consistently, activity measurements showed Na stimulation of the enzyme, either membrane-embedded or isolated, and ATP synthesis was sensitive to Na ionophoresin. Furthermore, Na has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting ion sites, both the ATPase and c-ring. Evidence of Na coupling is provided by two crystal structures of the c-ring solved by X-ray crystallography at 2.2 and 2.6 resolution at pH 5.3 and 8.7, respectively. Na ions occupy all sites, coordinated by four amino acids and a water. Intriguingly, two carboxylates mediate ion binding. Simulations and experiments demonstrate this implies a proton is bound to all sites, although Na alone drives the mechanism. The structure reveals a new mode of ion coupling in ATPases and provides a basis for drug efforts against opportunistic pathogen.
Researchers studied how T cells, a type of immune cells, recognize and respond to foreign substances on the surface of other cells called antigen-presenting cells. They found that in the body, T cells respond best to substances with moderate strength of recognition, not strong or weak. This is different from what happens in lab experiments, where strong recognition is thought to lead to best response. They tested this by giving T cells substances with different strengths of recognition and tracking their response. Contrary to expectations, cells responded best to substances with moderate strength, not strong or weak. Cells that responded to strong substances had problems with signaling, growth, and function over time. This shows that how cells work in body is different from lab experiments and highlights importance of considering how substances work in body when designing vaccines.
Researchers studied the genome of the fungus Nect haematocca, a member of the Fusarium solani complex, which includes over 50 species that can cause disease in plants and infect humans. They analyzed the most studied member, N haematocca mating population VI (MP), and found that genes controlling its ability to colonize specific habitats are on extra chromosomes. Optical mapping showed that this isolate has 17 chromosomes, ranging from 530 kb to 6.52 Mb, with a total genome size of 54.43 Mb and 15,707 predicted genes, the largest in ascomycetes. Two classes of genes contributed to expansion: those not found in other fungi, including its relative Fusarium gramineum, and those common in single copies in other fungi but multiple in N. haematocca MP. Some may be from duplication, others from horizontal transfer. Supernumerary chromosomes 14, 15, and 17 were confirmed by absence in pulsed gel electrophoresis, lacking isolate-specific sequences on their ends. They have more repeats, unique genes, and lower G+C content than others. The origin of extra genes and chromosomes is unknown, but expansion and size fit species' diverse habitats. Unique genes on supernary might explain isolates' different niches.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how herpesviruses, a type of virus, leave infected cells using live cell microscopy. They used a technique called total internal reflection fluorescence (TIR) to image the virus near the cell membrane and a pH-sensitive probe to track when the virus leaves the cell. The study focused on pseudorabies virus (PR), a type of herpesvirus, in non-polar epithelial cells. They found that individual virus particles travel to the membrane inside acidified secretory vesicles, which are regulated by Rab GTPases, Rab6, Rab8, and Rab11. These vesicles move quickly to the site of exocyt, often near patches of LLβ, a complex that anchors microtubules to the membrane. The vesicles dock and fuse with the membrane, releasing the virus. After exocyt, the virus remains on the cell surface.

The study contradicts a previous research on herpesvirus-1, which observed membrane invaginations with many particles but not individual exyt events. The new study found particles are confined to the membrane before and after exyt, and move sharply after pH change. They also identified Rab proteins associated with exyt and found no evidence for cytoskeleton-deocyt sites. The study proposes an integrated model of intracellular transport and exyt mechanisms for herpesvirus egress.
Researchers investigated the impact of Enterobius vermicularis infection and mebendazole treatment on the intestinal microbiota and immune response in 109 primary school children in Taiwan. The study found that Enterobias increased gut diversity, which peaked after mebendazole treatment. At the phylum level, pinworm and meendazole were associated with decreased Fusobacteria and increased Actinobacteria. The probiotic Bifobacterium abundance increased after enterobias and meend treatment. Intestinal SIg levels were lower in the pin-infected group, but elevated in the meend-treated group. A higher pre-treatment Salmonella proportion was linked to increased SIg after meend dewing. The study suggests that exposure to pin and meend is associated with increased bacterial diversity, Actinob, and probiotic Bifobacterium, and decreased Fusob. Intestinalg levels were lower in pin-inf, but increased in meend-treated. 

The study supports previous findings of increased diversity in helmin-infected microbiota. Further research is needed to determine if pin and meend alter commensal metabolism and host immune response. The change in microbial composition after meend in pin-inf children may be due to late effects of enterobias. More experiments, including animal studies, are required to understand relationships between pin, microbiota, and immune. The immunomodulatory effect of pin may depend on individual microbiota interaction.
Researchers studied the genetics of root length in Arabidopsis thalian, a plant species, and found that most of the genetic variation in root length was not due to individual genes acting alone, but rather to interactions between genes. This is known as epistasis, where two or more genes work together to affect a trait. They used a method called genome-wide association analysis to identify genes involved in root length and found four pairs of interacting genes that explained a large part of the variation in the population. These genes were not detected in a standard analysis that only looked at individual genes. The researchers estimated that half of these interactions were real, not false positives due to the small population size of the study. They found functional genes in three of the pairs that affect root development. The study shows that epasis can explain why some traits have low heritability, or genetic variation, and why some genes are not detected in standard analysis. It also highlights the importance of accounting for epasis in genetic studies.
Researchers analyzed 30,506 mitochondrial DNA (mt) sequences from around the world to understand how genetic background influences the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mt mutations. They found that the likelihood of having two or more disease-causing mutations was 6 times lower in certain mt haplogroups, suggesting that the background plays a role in acquiring or retaining these mutations. The study also showed that disease-causing mutations were more frequent in younger sequences and genomes, and that some mutations recurred within the same phylogenetic cluster. This implies that natural selection may have purified these mutations in older populations, explaining why they are less common in specific ethnic groups. The researchers also found that 43% of disease-causing mutations were associated with specific haplogroups, raising the possibility that some are not directly pathogenic. The study's dataset was representative of global populations and not enriched with rare variants or mutations from patients with mitochondrial diseases. The findings suggest that mt background is a general factor in disease-causing mutations, not limited to a few examples.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study how cells interact and move together in groups, a process called collective motility, which is crucial in cancer, embryonic development, and wound healing. To understand these interactions, scientists use microped substrates that restrict cell migration to one-dimensional paths, leading to frequent collisions between polarized cells with limited outcomes: reversing, sticking, or walking past each other. The model, including cell shape mechanics and contact inhibition of locomotion (CIL), reproduces all observed collision cases. A balance between cell polarization, IL, and adhesion governs the outcome. Parameters controlling transitions between outcomes are cell adhesion strength, propulsion, and IL rates. This suggests why different cell types behave differently and how interventions affect collisions. To replicate heterogeneity in neural cell collisions, parameters must be tuned or assume cell-to-cell variation in adhesion.

The model goes beyond generic mechanisms like flocking, alignment, or velocity, and highlights the importance of cell shape and adhesion in collective migration. A minimal model would expect adhesion to reduce walking, but our results are surprising. Combining shape and adhesion may lead to new effects. The model describes crawling and collision dynamics on microped substrates, applied to neural crest cells, reproducing four phenotypes observed in crest and metastatic epithelial cells. Simplified models would not capture these effects, emphasizing the need for biochemical interactions and contact dynamics. Results show coupling shape and biochemistry can lead to non-intuitive adhesion effects.

Collective migration, where cells move together, is vital in immune response, development, and cancer. Cell interactions create new dynamics not seen in isolated cells.
Researchers have been trying to understand how thioredoxin (Tr) breaks down its mixed disulfide complex for over 20 years. A key to this process is the interaction between Tr and its partner, arsenate reductase (Ars). In this complex, a disulfide is formed when Tr's cysteine attacks Ars's cysteine. To study this process, scientists used computer simulations, biochemical experiments, and mutant Tr variants. They found that changes in the disulfide's shape bring Tr's cysteine in contact with Tr's cyste, making it more reactive. Tr's cystine is more reactive than Ars's cystine, and it attacks Tr's cyst, not Ars's. This study provides new insights into how Tr breaks its disulfide with its partner. 

Tr converts oxidized Ars back to its original state by attacking Ars's cystine. Tr's cystine attacks Ars's cyst in the disulf, reducing Ars and forming a mixed disulf between Tr and Ars. In this complex, Tr's cystine attacks Tr's cyst in the disulf, forming a new disulf. Tr's cyst is more reactive than Ars's, leading to the release of Ars. A cycle, Tr's cyst attacks Tr's cyst in the disulf, releasing oxidized Tr and reduced Ars. The mechanism of Tr's cyst deprotonation has been debated for 20 years. In the Tr-Ars complex, Tr's cyst attacks Tr's cyst in the disulf. Both Tr's cyst and Ars's cyst can be thiol, but Tr's is favored. Tr's cyst must be thiol to attack Ars's disulf. In Tr's active site, alpha helix and hydrogen bond stabilize Tr cyst as thiol. With oxid Ars as substrate, Tr's cyst attacks Ars's cyst in the disulf. This explains why Tr's cyst attacks Ars's disulf. In this reaction, Tr's cyst is thiol, unlike Tr's.
People's preferences are not fixed and can be influenced by the preferences of others. Researchers hypothesized that people are uncertain about their own tastes and can learn about them by considering the preferences of others and updating their beliefs. A study of 14-24 year olds examined discounting behavior, including variability before and after observing another person's choices, found evidence for uncertainty and Bayesian updating. Participants' decision variability was better accounted for by a random taste model than a response noise model, and taste shifts were described by a Bayesian model taking into account uncertainty and social information. 

The study modelled subjects as uncertain about their own tastes, reflected in choices before learning others' preferences. The taste-uncertainty (K) model assumed subjects updated a distribution over own taste and sampled to make a choice on trial. The premise is subjects are uncertain about own taste, not beliefs given tastes. Uncertainty in absence of social influence is a basis for preference shift. 

The paradigm of discounting modelled learning from others' preferences to form one's own. Tested in a study of 700 young people, providing novel contributions. Evidence of social information Bayesian updates preferences, better fit of K model, dependence of preference-shift choice and decrease in uncertainty with age suggest variability reflects uncertain taste, not response noise. Uncertainty does not necessitate variability, people might estimate own taste by samples and act.
Scientists have been trying to understand how different signaling pathways in cells communicate with each other to produce a coordinated response. In yeast, multiple pathways regulate filamentous growth, a complex response that occurs under specific conditions. Researchers used a new approach called secretion profiling to measure the release of the extracellular domain of Ms2, a protein that functions at the head of the filamentous growth MAP pathway. They found that many pathways that regulate filament growth, such as R, R101, O1, and RT, were also required for MAP activation. This suggests that these pathways are connected in regulatory circuits, showing a systems-level coordination of this response.

The study identified four regulators of filament growth that are also required for MAP signaling. The connections between R101, O1, and RT pathways to MAP regulation are new. They found that the AS and other pathways converge on the promoter of the upstream regulator MS2 of MAP. Other regulators of MAP included components of AS and the inositol transcription factor O1, which has been tied to filament regulation. The discovery that many growth pathways impinge on MAP suggests systems coordination between pathways that regulate growth.

The researchers tested other filament regulatory proteins. It's unclear if these function together or independently to regulate growth, as many proteins have been implicated in the response. To identify new aspects of regulation, they developed a screening to identify regulators of MAP that controls growth. This allowed examination of genes in the background, where growth occurs in MAP-dependent manner. Approximately 390 genes influenced secretion when overexpressed.
Researchers studied how changes in gene expression contribute to the evolution of different body shapes in filamentous fungi. They grew five species of fungi, Sordomycetes, in a common environment and measured gene expression at five stages of development. By comparing gene expression, they found which genes increased the most across development. Knocking out these genes in two species showed altered fruiting body development. This approach found relevant genes more efficiently than studying whole genomes or gene families. Combining expression and knockout helped refine networks of genes controlling fruit body development, a complex process in multicellular organisms.

Fungal fruiting bodies have similar stages but different shapes. This makes them ideal for studying how common and different developmental sources of similar traits and how new traits arise despite existing networks. Researchers found key genes in Neurospora and Fusarium for development and reproduction. A systematic approach compared and contrasted gene programs across species. Mapping properties of developmental processes is key to understanding how evolution occurs.

Bayesian networks based on gene measurements are hypothetical until verified by specific studies. Combining with knockout helps understand relationships among genes in a process and how they evolved. Estimating expression in ancestral lineages identifies changes that may be key to morphological innovation. If complex traits depend on expression, changes should map to regulation.
Researchers have found a new way to introduce genetic material into the eggs of a parasitic flatworm called Schistosoma mansoni, which causes schistosomiasis in humans. They used a technique called electroporation to deliver genes and other molecules into the eggs. Electrop is a method that uses electrical pulses to make holes in the eggshell, allowing the material to enter. The researchers tested electrop with different types of genetic material, including a fluorescent dye, a gene that makes fireflies glow, and a virus that infects cells. They found that electrop was more effective than just soaking the eggs in the material. The virus was detected in the larvae that hatched from the eggs that were electroped, but not in those that were just soaked. The virus was also found in the germ cells of the larvae, which are the cells that will become adult worms. This suggests that electrop can be used to introduce genes into the germ cells of the worm. The researchers also found that electrop was more effective with a virus that was coated with a protein that helps it enter cells. The virus was detected in the larvae that hatched from eggs that were electroped with this virus, but not in those that were just soaked. The virus was also found in the germ cells of the larvae. This suggests that electrop can be used to introduce genes into the germ cells of the worm.
Researchers have developed a new approach called Perturbation Markovian Transmission (PM) to study the dynamic behavior of large molecular assemblies in cells. These assemblies are crucial for various biological processes and signaling between different parts of the machine are vital for cellular function. However, previous studies on topology and fluctuation dynamics of coarse-grained networks do not provide information on time-dependent behavior of these assemblies. The PM model monitors responses of over 8,000 residues across 6 decades from initial perturbation to equilibrium using Klov subspace projection, yielding rich information. Criteria of relaxation time, flow change, and oscillation identify key residues for movement, signaling, and binding. Analysis of the GroEL-Gro chaperone system showed 71-84% accuracy with experimental studies. This approach is general and can be applied to other machineries like virus and ribosomal complex.

The PM model probes the assembly with perturbation and assumes transmission by Markov processes through contacts between atoms and residues. It aims to study how parts respond to signal. The perturbation is given, and response can reveal biologically important information. The method monitors time-dependent responses simultaneously from perturbation until equilibrium. It can also study signal pathways by perturbing local regions like surfaces and is effective for large assemblies requiring small time.
Researchers studied the role of fungal lectins, a type of carbohydrate-binding proteins, in the defense of fungi against predators. They used the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans as a model organism and found that feeding it with a lectin from the mushroom Coprinus cinerea, CGL2, inhibited its development and ultimately killed it. The lectin's toxicity depends on its interaction with a specific sugar-containing glycojugate on the nematode's surface. A screen for resistant mutants identified the glycojugate as a Gal1,4Fuc1,6 modification of the nemode's N-gly core. Analysis of Nly structures in wild and resistant nemodes confirmed this finding and identified a novel glycosylase required for its biosynthesis. The crystal structure of the lectin and glycojugate complex revealed the basis of their interaction. The study suggests that fungal lectins play a role in defense against predators by binding specific glycojugates of these organisms.
A long-lived reservoir of latently infected CD4 T cells is a major barrier to curing HIV and has been extensively studied. However, the effect of these reservoirs on the evolutionary dynamics of the virus has received little attention. Researchers developed a within-host quasis model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir and nested it into an epidemiological model of HIV dynamics. For biologically plausible values, the presence of a reservoir severely delays evolutionary dynamics within a host, with longer delays associated with larger reservoir sizes and homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. These delays change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale. In particular, the delay within evolutionary can be sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate loads consistent with maximising transmission, as observed, not very high loads previous models predicted. This effect can be enhanced if viruses similar to those initiating infection are preferentially transmitted. Results depend on within characteristics such as reservoir size, with evolution observed only when dynamics are sufficiently delayed. The reservoir plays an underappreciated role in both within and between viral evolution.
Researchers studied how the Coxsackievirus B3 (CV3) virus affects the immune system's ability to detect and respond to it. They used special T cells, called CD4 and CD8 T cells, to see how the virus interacts with the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) pathway, which helps the immune system recognize infected cells. The study found that CV3 almost completely blocks the MHC I pathway, making it hard for CD8 T cells to detect the virus. In contrast, the virus doesn't affect the MHC II pathway as much, allowing CD4 T cells to still respond. The researchers also found that these CD4 cells can fight the virus and remember it for future infections. This has implications for how the immune system deals with Coackievirus infections.
Researchers conducted a study to compare the effectiveness of high-dose intravenous methylprednisone and oral prednisone versus intravenous saline and oral prednisone in treating leprosy Type 1 reactions and nerve function impairment. Forty-two individuals were randomly assigned to receive methylprednisone followed by predone or predone alone. The study found no significant differences in the rate of adverse events or improvement at the end of the study. However, those treated with methylprednis were less likely to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and 113. The study also showed that 50% of individuals with Type 1 reactions and nerve impairment required additional predone despite 16 weeks of corticosteroids. This supports the use of prolonged corticosteroid treatment for Type 1 reactions and investigation of factors for recurrence after corticoid treatment.
Researchers investigated how regulatory T cells (Treg) affect CD8 T cell responses in people with chronic HIV infection. They compared Treg from HIV-infected individuals (T/HIV+) to those from HIV-negative individuals (T/H-). Unlike T/H-, T/H+ did not suppress polyclonal autologous CD8 T function, suggesting a defect in suppressive capacity or lack of sensitivity of effector cells. However, T/H+ inhibited IFNγ expression of autologous CD8 cells stimulated with CMV/EBV/Flu (CEF) antigens, but not HIV-specific CD8 cells. In cross cultures, T/H- inhibited differentiation of CEF or HIV-specific CD8 cells from infected patients. PD-1 and PD-L expression was higher on HIV-specific CD8 cells compared to CEF CD8 cells, and did not change after T depletion or co-culture with T/H-, unlike C-specific CD8 cells. T/H+ showed defect in modulating differentiation and expression of PD-1/P-L on HIV CD8 cells. Results suggest this defect might contribute to exhaustion of HIV-specific T responses.

Treg from HIV+ donors with controlled viral load inhibited differentiation of naïve CD T into CCR- CDRA EM cells and favored accumulation of cells with CM CDRA+CCR+ phenotype. In chronic infection, T may exert subset-specific inhibitory effects on CD8 cells. Failure to contain HIV-associated activation is due to impairment of T function and responsiveness of effector clones, associated with high PD-1/P-L levels. In cross cultures, T/H- suppressed IFγ by G-specific CD8 better than patients' T (mean inhibition 53±12 vs 22; P 0.05).
Researchers investigated the potential of Wuchereria bancrofti glutathione-transferase (GST) as a vaccine candidate for lymphatic filariasis. They cloned the GST gene from the third larval stage of W. bancroft and expressed and purified the recombinant protein. Serum samples from individuals living in an endemic area showed significant levels of anti-GST antibodies compared to those who were microfilaric or had clinical symptoms. Isotype analysis revealed a predominance of IgG and Ig3 antibodies in endemic individuals. The recombinant GST retained enzymatic activity and antibodies from endemic sera inhibited this activity. Similar results were obtained with anti-G antibodies in a neutralization assay. Brugia mal GST and WGST showed significant similarity. To evaluate vaccine potential, B. mal was used as a challenge. Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity assay confirmed the role of human and mouse antibodies. Subsequent vaccination in a jird model showed 61% protection against B. mal infection. The study suggests WGST is a potential vaccine against lymphatic filariasis, with 61% protection in a j model. The protein retained enzymatic activity and this appears critical for parasite survival in host.
CRISPR-C9 technologies have revolutionized genome editing of experimental organisms and hold immense therapeutic potential. However, concerns remain about potential off-target effects. Recent studies used whole-genome sequencing of edited embryos to search for de novo mutations, which may represent changes introduced by poor editing. These studies used strain-matched but not pedigree-matched controls, making it difficult to distinguish generational or colony differences from true mutations. This study used a trio design and sequenced parents and 19 embryos, 10 of which were edited with well-characterized gRNAs targeting the coat color gene. Detailed analysis revealed that if CRIS mutagenesis caused SN or indel off-target mutations, the number was not distinguishable from background mutations due to other processes. This supports efforts to develop CRPR-C9 as a therapeutic tool.
Researchers have identified two proteins, Hypersensitive to Red 1 (HR1) and Phosphatase 7 (PP), that play a crucial role in controlling the opening and closing of stomatal pores on plant leaves. Stomatal pores regulate carbon dioxide uptake for photosynthesis and water loss through transpiration, affecting photosynthesis, water efficiency, and crop yields. Blue light is a key environmental signal that regulates stomatal opening, perceived by blue/UV light-absorbing cryptochromes phototropins. The researchers found that mutations in HR1 or PP lead to misregulation of stomatal aperture and reduced water loss under light. Both HR1 and PP are expressed in guard cells in response to light-dark or dark-light transition. HR1 interacts with PP through its N-terminal zinc finger motif and requires PP for stomatal response. HR1 is phosphorylated in vivo and PP dephosphylates HR1. In the dark, HR1 is dephosphylated in a 193kDa complex, while light increases to 285Da. In PP mutant, this shift is impaired and HR1 is predominantly phosphorylated. The study proposes that HR modification by PP under light is essential for proper conformation and assembly of functional HR complex.
A Mediator subunit MDT-15 plays a crucial role in adapting Caenorhabditis elegans to ingested materials, including nutrients and toxins. MDT-15 is part of the Mediator complex, a group of proteins that helps regulate gene expression by interacting with other proteins. In C. elegans, MDT-15 works with the hormone NHR-49 and sterol-binding protein SBP-1 to control fatty acid metabolism. Research shows MDT-15 is involved in detoxification, the process of removing toxins, and heavy metals. Worms without MDT-15 or a mutated mdt-15 gene are more sensitive to toxins. MDT-15 also affects stress responses related to eating, but not other stresses like heat. A previous study found MDT-15 and N-49 regulate fasting response. This suggests M-15 integrates multiple pathways to monitor ingested materials, including nutrients and toxins. 

 Studies show M-15 contributes to at least two detox pathways in C. elegans. M-15 interacts with N-49 and SB-1 to express metabolic genes. M-15 may also respond to environmental toxins and metals with different factors. A previous study found M-15 impacts fatty acid metabolism in N- and -dependent ways. M- conveys FA desaturases by SB-1, a protein that regulates FA and cholesterol. M- affects energy genes that respond to food and detox genes to contaminants. Several M- targets are affected by mutations that alter life span, and stress is linked to life extension in C. elegans. M- is part of a system that coordinates ingestion stress, ensuring health and longevity.
Researchers have long believed that the hippocampus, a brain region responsible for spatial navigation, encodes geometric information such as distances and angles. However, since the hippocampus is made up of patterns of spiking neurons, downstream regions must translate these patterns into accurate information about an animal's environment. The researchers hypothesized that the pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, is key to decoding spatial information and since coiring implies spatial overlap of place fields, a map by coiring will be based on connectivity and adjacency, a topological. They tested this hypothesis with a model of hippocampal activity, varying parameters firing rate, place size, and number of neurons in simulations of rat trajectories in topologically and geometrically distinct environments. Using computational tools from algebraic topology, they found that patterns of coiring convey topological information about environment in biologically realistic time. Simulations revealed a "learning" region where interplay between parameters produce hippocal states more or less adept at map formation. For example, lower number of neurons can be compensated by adjustments firing or place size, but beyond point formation fails. They propose this region provides a theoretical lens to view conditions impairing spatial by altering cell rates or specificity.
Researchers have investigated the process by which the hepatitis C virus (HCV) is secreted from infected cells. The current understanding of this process is incomplete, so they used a combination of RNA interference (RNA) analysis and live cell imaging to gain a detailed understanding of how HCV is released. The RNA analysis identified multiple components of the secretory pathway, including the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi, trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from the trans-Golgi network (TGN), VAMP vesicles and proteins, and recycling endosomes. The results support a model where HCV is enveloped at the ER and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. To further study this, a tagged HCV was created with a tetrystine (TC) insertion in the core (TC) to monitor the dynamics of HCV trafficking in association with cellular cofactors. Only trafficking events required for essential H assembly factor NS2 were quantified. TC trafficked to the periphery microtubules and movement was inhibited by nocodazole. Subpopulations TC localized to Gol and co-trafficked with recycling endosome components. Silencing recycling component Rab11 resulted in accumulation of H at Gol. Majority trafficked with apolipoprotein (Apo) and VAMP vesicles. This study identifies new cofactors of H egress and dynamic studies H trafficking in infected cells.
Research has identified a link between the loss of an imprinted gene, Grb10, and tumor formation in mice with a genetic mutation of the Neurofibromatosis tumor suppressor gene 1 (NF). Imprinted genes are expressed from one parent and loss of the expressed allele leads to complete loss of protein. Gr10 is an imprinted and analysis of cell lines and tumors shows the expressed allele is commonly lost in NF mutant tumors. Studies found that restoring Gr10 in NF mutant tumors decreases growth, proliferation, and downregulates Ras signaling. Conversely, silencing Gr10 in untransformed cells increases proliferation and Ras-G levels. Expression of a constitutively activated ME rescued cells from Gr10 reduction in colony formation. These studies show Gr10 loss can occur in tumorigenesis and promotes Ras hyperactivation, a feature of tumor development. In a NF mutant mouse model, this work identifies a role for an imprinted in tumenesis.

Gr10 is a negative regulator of Ras signaling and contributes to dysregulation in NF-mediated tumenesis. Findings demonstrate a previously undescribed role for imprinted in disease and suggest mutations in im genes should be considered by parental origin. Gr10 loss has implications for types of tumors that can arise after loss. A mouse model produced F mice inheriting mutant NF copy and loss Gr10 with NF from maternal chromosome 11 is equivalent to Gr10 null in non-NS tissues. Gr10 is lost in most tumors in NF mutant mouse model. Functional studies show Gr10 promotes oncogenic through Ras and MAPK signaling. Data suggest Gr10 functions as negative regulator of growth factor signaling and loss contributes to tumenesis.
Researchers investigated how humans learn to predict threats from environmental cues, a fundamental skill found in many species, through Pavlovian fear conditioning. This process involves associating neutral cues (conditioned stimuli) with aversive events (unconditioned stimuli). Despite many studies on neural mechanisms, computational understanding is fragmented, with different models giving opposing predictions for trial-by-trial dynamics of autonomic nervous system (ANS) responses. The team used a statistical framework for psychophysiological modeling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of ANS responses during Pavlov fear conditioning. They considered non-probabilistic, probabilistic, and non-learning models, as well as different functions to link models with AN activity. Across three experiments, skin conductance (SCR) and pupil size (PS) responses were measured. A probabilistic model best explained AN responses, with SCR tracking a mixture of expected outcome and uncertainty, and PS tracking expected outcome alone. By combining psychophysiological modeling with learning theory, the team provided evidence that Pavlov threat formation in humans relies on probabilistic inference and uncertainty estimation. This could inform neural implementation of aversive learning theories.
Researchers have identified a new regulator of fungal reproduction in the fungus Aspergillus nidulans, called Pom, which suppresses the septation and conidiation process. Septation is the process of cell division in fungi, while conidiation is the production of spores for reproduction. Without Pom, the fungus has defects in septation and coniation, but overexpressing Pom stops septation and coniation. Pom works by affecting the phosphorylation of a protein called HogA, which is part of the mitogen-activated protein (MAP) pathway. This pathway responds to stress and environmental factors. Under normal conditions, Sep, another regulator, positively phosphorylates HogA, while Pom negatively affects this process. However, under osmotic stress, the phosphorylated Hog can bypasses the need for Sep, a key player in early cytokinesis, but not Mob/Sid, the last in the septation kinase cascade. This shows interaction between the septation and MAP pathways. Pom and Sep regulate Hog phosphorylation through upstream kinases.
Researchers investigated the association between Leish RNA virus 1 (LRV1) and mucosal manifestations of tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) in 156 patients in Brazil. Tegary leishias is endemic in Latin America and causes approximately 20,000 cases per year, but its pathogenesis is not fully understood. Clinical manifestations range from cutaneous leishias (CL) to severe disseminated leishias (DL), mucosal leishias (ML), and diffuse cutaneous leish (DCL). The study found five Leish species: 77.6% were Leishmania Viannia braziliensis, 11.5% Leish V. guyensis, 1.8 Leish V laini, 1.3 Leish Leish amazonensis, and 1.3 Leish V shawi. LRV was detected in 54 Le brazili, 5 guy, 2 amazon, 1 lain, and 6 inconclusive samples. Patients with CL+ML and DCL were excluded from analysis. Association between LRV and disease outcome was tested in 147 patients (109 CL and 38 ML). 71.1% muc lesions were LRV+ and 28.9 LRV-, 36.7 cutaneous lesions were LRV+ and 63.3 LRV-. The ratio LRV+/LRV- was 2.93 (CI 1.57-5.46, p<0.001), indicating LRV is associated with muc leishias as in animal models and not the only factor in disease.
Type I interferon (IFN) plays a crucial role in protecting against pneumocococcal disease by inhibiting bacterial migration from the lung to the bloodstream. Research shows that mice lacking the type I interferon receptor (Ifnar−/−) or treated with a neutralizing antibody against type interferon exhibit enhanced development of bacteremia following intranasal pneumoc infection, while maintaining bacterial numbers in the lung. In contrast, treatment with IFβ or IF-inducing double-stranded RNA (poly(I:C) reduces development of bacteremia following intranasal infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. IFβ leads to upregulation of tight junction proteins and downregulation of pneumoccal receptor platelet activating factor (PAF receptor). In accordance with these findings, IF reduces pneumoccal invasion and migration across epithelial and endothelial layers, and Ifnar− mice show enhanced lung permeability. The study identifies IF as an important component of host defense that regulates mechanisms involved in pneumoc invasion, including PAF-mediated transcytosis and tight-dependent perellular migration, limiting progression from localized lung to invasive disease.
Researchers have developed a neural network with multiple layers that can learn a complex foraging task. The network uses two types of plasticity: one that changes based on reward and one that doesn't. This is different from previous networks that only used one type of plasticity. The new network has three layers: one for input, one hidden, and one for output. The hidden layer uses non-reward plasticity to recognize patterns and the output layer uses reward plastic to make decisions. This combination allows the network to learn without labeled data and distinguish between good and bad patterns. Synaptic noise helps the network try different strategies to solve the task. The study shows that a network with these properties can solve a complex foraging task involving pattern recognition and decision. 

The researchers built on a previous network with one layer that learned foraging in a virtual environment. The new network has two layers with plastic connections and uses both reward and non-reward plasticity. The connections go from input to hidden and from hidden to output. The new network can solve a more complex foraging task than the previous one-layer network. Plasticity has been used in models for pattern recognition and reward for overcoming problems. This study combines both in one model for high performance in discrimination and decision-making. The components have been studied separately, but this study links them together for complex solving. Synaptic plastic follows rules and reward plastic between layers and nonward between hidden and output.
A protein called ELF5 plays a key role in the development of a type of breast cancer called luminal breast cancer. In this cancer, ELF5 helps the cancer cells grow and spread to other parts of the body, such as the lungs. Researchers found that ELF recruits a type of immune cell called myeloid-derived suppressor cells to the tumor. These cells help the cancer grow and spread. When these cells were removed, the cancer did not spread as much. In people with luminal breast cancer that had high levels of ELF5, they had more immune cells in the tumor and less time to live without the cancer coming back. This suggests that ELF helps the cancer grow and spread by working with the immune system. This is important because ELF has also been linked to cancer becoming resistant to hormone therapy. The study found that in mice and people with luminal breast cancer that ELF5 helps the cancer grow and spread by working with the immune system.
Recent research has shown that the interaction between chromatin loops plays a crucial role in determining cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. Chromatin loops are characterized by three factors: connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication. To understand how these factors affect gene expression, a model was developed that maps interacting DNA loops into a 4-state model of transcription. The study found that nested loops enhance expression and reduce noise, while alternating loops have opposite effects. Comparing facilitated and direct looping, the former performs better in controlling expression and tuning noise, but this control is distance-dependent, with a limit where the difference between the two forms disappears. The results support the chromatin-looping hypothesis.
Researchers have developed a new approach to create riboregulators, which are RNA molecules that can control gene expression without the need for extra proteins. Traditional riboregulators rely on proteins like Hfq and CRISPR, which can be burdensome and unstable. The new approach, called translation inhibiting RNAs (tiRNAs), focuses on thermodynamic and structural features that affect translation initiation. From a library of 12 features, 6 were selected and used to design 18 ribgulators, which reduced protein expression by up to 60%. A model was created to link tiRNA properties to gene repression, showing both structural and thermodynamic features are important for efficient repression. This method enables reliable design of effective ribg, expanding the toolbox for gene modulation.
Researchers studied how groups of neurons in the brain's cortex communicate with each other to form memories and behaviors. They recorded electrical activity at multiple sites in the brain of awake monkeys and lab-grown brain tissue. They found that when a group of neurons' activity reaches a certain level, it sends a signal to other parts of the brain without delay. This signal, called a coherence potential, can last hundreds of milliseconds and carries information like a single neuron's action potential. However, it has a unique shape, allowing it to encode and identify specific associations. This behavior is similar to how ideas spread in social networks.

The researchers used existing methods to identify groups of neurons working together, such as synchronized activity and similar patterns. They also found waves spreading across brain areas, raising questions about how signals travel between regions and interact. In the study, signals were shown to organize like neuronal avalanches, suggesting preservation of underlying activity. The shape of the signal often predicts behaviors better than individual neurons, supporting the idea that coherence represents meaningful information transfer in the network. The researchers looked for preservation of the pattern associated with coherence, but only a small number of neurons near the electrode could be resolved, a small sample of the activity.
Scientists have long known that the size of a cell's nucleus is related to its overall size, but the exact mechanism behind this relationship is unclear. To investigate this, researchers conducted a genetic screen in yeast to identify essential factors involved in nuclear size control. The study found 25 factors that affect nuclear size and implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in this process. The research revealed a wide range of nuclear sizes, from small to large, and highlighted the importance of cellular processes and structural components for size control. 

The study used yeast to generate cells with varying volumes, observing a consistent nucleus-to-cell ratio. In small-scale experiments, nuclear size increased with cell volume during the cell cycle, maintaining a constant ratio. However, a sudden increase in size occurred during DNA replication. Yeast Schizoscharomyces pombe is genetically simple and undergoes closed mitosis, making it a useful for studying nuclear size control. A screen of non-essential mutants implicated nucleocytoplasmic transport and lipid biosynthesis in size. This suggests regulation of global processes, nucleoplasmic transcription and cytoplasm translation, and specific nuclear components are important for size.

In multicellular organisms, the nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio varies between cell types but is generally within a narrow range for each. Evidence suggests size is determined by volume or related to it, not directly by DNA. Size correlates with volume in both budding and fission yeasts across a wide range.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to predict the effects of deep brain stimulation (DB) on patients with neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease and essential tremor (ET). The model uses coupled oscillators to represent brain areas generating pathological oscillations. A reduced form of the Kuramoto model was used to analyze how patients respond to stimulation when oscillations have a given phase and amplitude. The study found that the best stimulation strategy should be phase-specific and have a greater effect when the amplitude of brain oscillations is lower. This prediction was compared with data from ET patients. A new hybrid strategy combining two closed-loop approaches, phase-locked and adaptive DB, was proposed.

The model's phase-dependent effects have been shown to generalize to other models and biologically realistic neural circuits. However, predictions have not been compared to experimental effects of closed DB. Two closed-loop approaches, adaptive and phase-locked DB, were focused on. Adaptive DB applies high stimulation when oscillations exceed a threshold, while phase-DB stimulates according to instantaneous phase, roughly matching ET's tremor frequency (5 Hz).

The model describes how neural oscillators give rise to oscillations like LFP and tremor. Classic oscillators correspond to individual neurons producing spikes. Some report the phase response curve (PRC), describing changes in oscillations as a function of stimulation phase. Coupled models have been used to describe DB effects at particular phases. Wilson and Moles found optimal intensity depends on phase of ongoing oscillations.
Researchers have developed a new diagnostic tool to detect Schistosoma mansoni, a parasite causing intestinal and liver disease, in Biomphalaria snails, its intermediate host. The tool, called Biom-LAMP, is a rapid, sensitive, and cost-effective loop-mediated isothermal amplification assay. It can detect 0.1 fg of S. mansoni DNA in 63 minutes at 63°C. BiomAMP was tested on snails exposed to miracidia at different times post-exposure: prepatent period, light infections, and pooled samples. DNA was extracted using a commercial kit or simple NaOH method. BiomAMP detected S mans DNA in all snail groups without complicated procedure. This assay is suitable for large-scale field surveys in schistosomiasis endemic areas with basic facilities. The development of inexpensive, field-applicable assays for snail screening is crucial for schosiasis elimination. No LAMP has been evaluated for S. mans before. This new assay can monitor infected snails in endemic areas, providing effective control measures.
In Sri Lanka, deng has been a reported as a public health problem since the 1960s and is a priority for public health authorities. The Ministry of Health is responsible for controlling deng and other outbreaks, and providing care to deng patients at secondary hospitals. The involvement of many public staff in deng control and free care at hospitals is a financial burden on the health sector. This study estimated the public costs of deng control and hospitalizations in Colombo, the most urban district in Sri Lanka, in 2012 from the Ministry's perspective. Costs were collected and analyzed using a combination of activity and costing approaches. The total deng control and hospitalization cost was $3.45 million ($1.50 per capita) in Colombo in 201. Personnel costs made up 79% of deng control and 46% hospitalization costs. The per capita cost of deng control was $0.42. Hospital costs ranged $216-609 for pediatric and $196-866 for adult cases by disease and treatment. This is the first assessment of deng burden on the public sector in Sri Lanka. The results suggest deng poses a major economic burden on the health in Sri Lanka.
A long-standing debate has surrounded the contribution of Paleolithic hunter-gatherers and Neolithic farmers from the Near East to modern European populations. Haplogroup Rb1b2 (R-M269) is the most common European Y-chromosome lineage, increasing in frequency from east to west and carried by 110 million European men. Previous studies suggested a Paleolithic origin, but new research shows the distribution of microsatellite diversity is best explained by spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic. This indicates most European Y-chromosomes originate from the Neolithic expansion. This pattern contrasts with maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA, suggesting a unique role for males in the transition.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between movement variability and the speed of motor learning. Contrary to previous suggestions that variability increases learning speed, computational modeling shows it can have both positive and negative effects. Experiments also found decelerating effects. A meta-analysis of published studies found no statistical relation between variability and learning rate across a range of experiments. Motor learning is complex and further research is needed to understand factors involved.

 Simulations showed variability does not typically increase learning and sometimes slows it down. This does not rule out a possible positive correlation between variability and learning. Factors can affect learning and variability in different ways, leading to positive, negative, or zero relations. Variability may be correlated with learning in a task-specific way, depending on which factor affects performance. To test this, computer simulations were run with an optimal learner model. Variability is a problem for movement control and has attention. Studies on variability and learning are sparse, except those show reduction is a characteristic of learning.

Simulations suggest relation between variability and learning varies in adaptation, depending on which factor dominates performance. Divergent results can be explained by uncertainty or noise. People converge to solutions where variability minimally impacts accuracy. A study showed initial variability can predict learning in tasks. It was the first to show a facilitatory effect for adaptation.
Researchers have studied the interaction between a protein called RelA and a co-activator called CB/p300, which plays a crucial role in the transcription of genes involved in immune response, inflammation, and cell survival. RelA binds to CB/p300 through two parts: the DNA-binding domain of Rel interacts with the K domain of CB/p300, and the transcription activation domain of Rel binds to the TAZ domain of CB300. Phosphorylation of a specific site on Rel is necessary for this interaction to occur. The researchers used NMR spectroscopy to determine the structure of the Rel:CB complex and found that the activation domain of Rel folds upon binding to TAZ through hydrophobic sites on its surface. They also created mutants that selectively disrupt the interaction and found that many Rel-activated genes are affected by this interaction, more than previously thought. The interaction controls the response of NF-κ through a negative feedback loop and CB/p300 is recruited to Rel target gene promoters, suggesting a role in Rel recruitment.
Researchers have developed a new method called Time-course Gene Set Analysis (TSA) to analyze gene expression data from repeated measurements over time. This method is an extension of gene set analysis, which considers groups of genes together in analysis. Unlike previous methods, TSA can use all available measurements, even if some are missing, and accounts for differences within gene sets. It identifies significant changes in gene expression over time and compares patterns between conditions. The method was tested on two real datasets: an HIV vaccine trial and a study on influenza and pneumocococcal vaccines. In the HIV trial, TSA found significant changes in 69 gene sets over time, while other methods failed to detect any pattern. In the influenza study, TSA identified 4 gene sets linked to the vaccine, but not previously associated with pneumococcal vaccine. Simulations showed TSA's good performance and increased power compared to other methods. The method is available as an R package for the community.
Researchers have created a detailed map of the global distribution of Plasmodium vivax, a type of malaria parasite that has been less studied than Plasium falciparum. They used data from 9,970 surveys from 1985 to 2010 and a statistical model to estimate the parasite rate in every 5x5 km square. The map shows that Plas viv is found in a narrow range of areas, mostly in the Americas, Africa, and parts of Asia. The Americas have 22% of the area at risk, but only 6% of the 2.5 billion people at risk. Africa has 3.5% of the risk, mostly in Madagascar and the Horn of Africa. Asia has 82% of the risk, with high areas in India and Myanmar. South Asia has the highest risk, in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. The map is meant to help plan control and eliminate Plas viv.

The researchers used a method called model-based geostat to create the map. This method uses data from nearby areas to estimate the parasite rate. They also used information on a gene that makes some people resistant to the parasite. The map is most certain in areas with low parasite rates, but less certain in areas with higher rates. The map does not measure how many people are infected, just how many have the parasite. The map is based on an assumption that some people are resistant to the parasite.

The researchers tested the map and found it was mostly accurate, with a small error of -0.41 in the Americas, -0.03 in Africa, -0.43 in Asia, and -0.43 in South Asia.
Staphylococcus aureus, a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections, expresses several cell-wall anchored proteins that help it stick to host cells and tissues and evade the immune system, making it more virulent. One of these proteins, clumping factor B (ClB), has been shown to help S. aureus colonize the nose by binding to a protein called loric in the nasal lining. However, its role in skin and soft tissue infections was unknown. This study found that ClB plays a key role in abscess formation and bacterial load early in infection, and works by binding to loric in the abs tissue. A vaccine targeting ClB induced both antibody and cellular responses, protecting against S. aureus skin infection. This study identifies ClB as a promising antigen for future skin infection vaccines.
To achieve the UNAIDS goal of reducing new HIV infections to 500,000 by 2020, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a key strategy. Currently, Truvada (emtricabirine-tenofovir) is the only approved EP medication, but it's costly and requires daily dosing. To improve EP, next-generation regimens, including long-acting formulations, are being investigated. However, preclinical testing often fails to translate to clinical efficacy, and quantifying prophylactic efficacy in the clinic is ethically problematic. To prioritize and design EP regimens, tools are needed that integrate pharmacological, viral, and host factors determining prophyl efficacy. A stochastic approach was developed to predict prophyl efficacy, using dolutegravir (DT) as an example. Combining DT's population pharmacokinetics with the framework, predicted plasma concentrations of 145.18 and 722.23nM prevent 50-90% and 90% sexual transmissions, respectively. Daily EP with 50mg DT prevented 99-100% and 85% of infections when 50% of dosing were missed. EP 'on' demand prevented 79-84 and 80% when initiated within 6 hours after exposure and continued. The framework can be adapted to other EP candidates, indicating oral 50 DT is inferior to Trada. Predicted 90% concentrations guide release kinetics of developed DT nano-formulations.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) uses autophagy to enhance its replication, but how it regulates the autophagy pathway is unclear. Researchers found that HCV induces the expression of Rubicon and UVR, which inhibit and stimulate the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. Rubicon is induced early, while UVR is delayed, leading to accumulation of autagosomes at early in infection. Rubicon inhibits maturation of autag in H-infected cells, confirmed by siRNA knockdown and overexpression. Rubicon enhances maturation of autag. Rub plays a positive role in H replication, suppressing its expression reduces replication and overexpression enhances. In contrast, overexpression of UVR facilitates maturation of autag and suppresses H replication. The H subgenomic RNA replicon, expressing nonstructural proteins, induces Rubicon and autag accumulation. Analysis shows NS4 protein induces Rubicon and autag. Results indicate H, by differentially inducing Rub and UVR, temporally regulates autagy to enhance replication.
Cyclin-like 1 (Cny1), a newly identified member of the cyclin family, is highly similar in protein sequence to Cyclin Y (Cny). However, its function is poorly characterized in any organism. Research found that Cny1 was most abundantly expressed in the testis of mice, seven times higher than the level of Cny. Male C1- mice were infertile, whereas male and female C- mice displayed normal fertility. This suggests C1, not C, is indispensable for fertility. Spermatoa from C- mice displayed impaired motility, thinned annulus, and bent head. Found protein, not mRNA level of cyclin-dependent kinase 16 (CD16) decreased in testis C- mice. Study demonstrated C1 interacted with CD, interaction increased stability, and kinase activity of CD. Observed alteration phosphorylation of CD in presence C1. Identified phosphorylation sites CD by mass spectrometry revealed several modifications N-terminal CD indispensable C1 binding and modulation CD kinase activity. Results reveal previously role C1 regulating spermatogenesis through interaction and modulation CD.

C1 and CD16 complex essential for spermatogenesis and male fertility in mouse. C1 specifically expressed in testis, C- mice sterile, healthy, normal testosterone, mating. C1 may molecule for male contraceptive, screening drugs inhibit C expression C1 or C/CD activity. Study showed C- mice reproduct normal, deletion C1 leads infertility male, not female, cooperating CD maintaining enzymatic C1CD complex plasma sperogenic cells. Unlike homologue C, uniform pattern C1 high in testis. Data defects impaired motility C- spermzo prevent entry oocytes, fertilization. Other uncharacterized defects might involved. C1 and C share similarity protein, examined compensatory effects mice. Spermzo C- displayed phenotype C- cells. However, reported C1 no interactions CD in vitro system, conflicting results. Evidence β-act levels C- sperm ascribed shedding cytoplasm contents rather cytoskeleton. Cycl always CD partners, testicular CD found highly expressed.
Enterohemorrhagic Escheria coli (EHE) strains cause diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome due to toxin-mediated vascular endothelial injury. HE hemolysin (HE-H), a member of the RTX repeats-toxin family, is an increasingly recognized E virulence factor. The toxin exists as free HE-H and HE-H associated with outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) released by HE during growth. While the free toxin is lytic to human endothelium, the effects of OM-associated HE-H on vascular endothelial and epithelial cells, major targets during HE infection, are unknown.

Using microscopic, biochemical, and flow cytometry analyses, human microvascular endothelial (HBMEC) and Caco-2 cells demonstrate OM-associated HE does not lyse cells but triggers apoptosis. OM-associated is internalized by HBME and C-2 via dyn-dependent endocytosis and trafficked into endosomal compartments. Upon acidification and pH drop, HE is separated from OM, escapes lysosomes, probably via pore-forming, and targets mitochondria. This decreases mitochondrial transmembrane potential and cytochrome translocation to cytos, indicating HE-mediated permeabilization. Subsequent caspase and casp-3 activation leads apoptotic death evidenced DNA fragmentation and chromatin condensation.

The ability OM-associated to trigger apoptotic pathway in humanvascular and epithelial cells indicates a mechanism HE involvement in pathogenesis HE diseases. OM-mediated intracellular delivery represents a recognized mechanism for bacterial to host target mitochondria.
Researchers have discovered a feedback loop between two proteins, P-TEbdk and histone H2 ubiquitylation, that regulates gene expression in yeast. PTEb is a protein that helps RNA polymerase II, an enzyme that reads DNA to make RNA, move along the DNA. Histone modifications, chemical changes to histone proteins, have roles in starting gene expression, but their functions during gene expression are not well understood. Histone H2 ubiquitylation, a type of histone modification, plays a role in coordinating other histone modifications and regulating gene expression.

In yeast, Schizoscharomyces pombe, researchers found that lowering PTEb activity or preventing its substrate phosphorylation reduces histone H2 ubiqulation. Conversely, mutations in histone ubiqulation pathway impair PTE recruitment to chromatin and decrease phosphorylation of its substrate. Surprisingly, mutation of histone ubiquitin-acceptor residue relaxes PTE activity and PTE mutations suppress cell morphology defects in histone-deficient strains. Genome-wide analysis shows opposing effects of PTE and histone ubiqulation on transcribing RNA polymerase II.

The study reveals a balance between PTE and histone ubiqulation is necessary for gene expression. Loss of hist ubiqulation disrupts this balance and leads to aberrant expression and cell morphologies. The research also suggests other pathways can modulate PTE and histone ubiqulation functions. The study strengthens the idea that PTE activity is required to overcome repressive histone modifications.
Yellow fever virus (YFV) is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in South America. Researchers analyzed the largest YF dataset to date, comprising 133 isolates from 22 countries over 76 years, to understand its evolutionary history. They found that current YV strains emerged in Africa 1,500 years ago and arrived in the Americas via the slave trade 300-400 years ago. These viruses spread across the continent and persist in South America's jungles. The study shows how genetic data can test viral dispersal and demographic hypotheses and human migration's role in disease spread.

The analysis included 71 additional sequences, making 133 isolates from 22 countries (14 African, 8 American). Phylogenetic analysis divided YV into two groups, with distinct lineages in Africa and Americas. West African outbreaks occur annually, with 5 cities facing epidemics since 2001. However, analysis found no difference in dynamics between African and American viruses, nor increased diversity expected in epidemics. The virus established a sylvatic cycle in Amazon, Orin river basins, vectored by mosquitoes. The slave trade introduction hypothesis has been repeated, but not rigorously tested with sequence data and phylogen techniques.

YF is a feared disease, causing large outbreaks in 15-19 centuries, shaping settlements and colonial powers. It's a Flivirus family member, with vector-borne pathogens like deng, encephalitis, and West viruses. Previous studies suggest YV originated in Africa, with deepest phylogen split between East and West isolates.
Researchers studied a virulent strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae, a leading bacterial pathogen, in an infant mouse model of colonization and disease transmission, with and without influenza A (IAV) co-infection. They aimed to identify vulnerable points in the steps involved in pneumocococcal pathogenesis. The study found that in the setting of IAV co-infection, the organism must pass through single bottlenecks during bloodstream invasion from the nasopharynx within the host and transmission between hosts. These bottlenecks were not associated with genetic adaptation of the pathogen. The bottleneck in transmission occurred between exit from one host and establishment in another, explaining the number of organisms in secretions is critical to overcome.

The researchers used an animal model to study the consequences of bacterial colonization, including localized disease and host-to-host transmission. They found IAV increased the burden of colonizing pneumocci, consistent with prior observations in mice. By targeting stages when bacterial size is restricted, there is less opportunity for selection among phenotypically and genetically diverse pneumocci. The study employed an infant model that recapitulates key pneumoccal path features. Regardless of IAV-infection, sampled at 12 days prior to onset, detection of pneumonia by lung homogen culture was unusual.

A type 6 clinical S pneumonia isolate was tested in an infant mouse model with intranasal challenge at 4 days. An advantage is that mice are susceptible to low colonizing. To examine IAV co-infection, mouse-adapt strain 31 was inoculated at 8. To understand mechanisms of protection, steps during pneumocci pass through bottlenecks were identified - a reduction in size due environmental constraints. Bottleneck would occur if only infecting organisms pass host or evade local defense.
Researchers have identified two proteins from the saliva of the sand fly Phlebotus orientalis that can be used to detect if people have been bitten by this fly. This fly is a vector of the parasite Leishmania donani, which causes a serious disease called visceral leishiasis in Eastern Africa. The researchers created copies of these proteins, called recombinant proteins, and used them to test the blood of people from Sudan and Ethiopia, where the disease is common. They found that 52% of people from Sudan and 34.5% from Ethiopia had antibodies against these proteins, showing they had been bitten by the fly. This is the first time using recombin proteins to detect antibodies against this fly bites. The two proteins, mY1 and m5, are good markers for exposure to the fly and can be used together to increase the accuracy of detection. These proteins are specific to this fly and do not react with other similar flies that do not transmit the disease. The study suggests that using these proteins can simplify detecting people bitten by the fly in areas where leishias is common.
Salmonella genomic island 1 (SGI) is a genetic element associated with multidrug-resistant clinical isolates of pathogenic Enterobacteraceae. It is mobilized by IncA and Inc plasmids, also known as A/C plids, after excision from the chromosome, triggered by the transcription activator ACD encoded by these plids. Although SGI is not self-transmissible, it carries genes tra, NS, traH, and traG, coding for homologs of the mating pore subunits Tra, Tra, Tra, and Tra, encoded by A plids. Researchers investigated the regulation of tra and tra and role in SGI transmissibility. They found that expression of these genes is inducible by ACD and essential for SGI mobilization. Tra and Tra are required for Inc plid transfer, but SGI can rescue mutants of each gene, showing Tra, Tra, and Tra are functional. Complementation of Tra and Tra mutants showed that Tra and Tra replace Tra and Tra in the pore encoded by plids, and Tra and Tra are required for SGI optimal transfer. Remodeling the Inc-encoded pore by SGI enhances transfer rate over the plid. Tra is crucial for DNA transfer between cells bearing Inc plids, suggesting SGI disables Inc-encoded exclusion mechanism. Tra facilitate invasion of SGI in populations bearing plids.
Researchers studied the role of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo kinase Cdc5 in the DNA damage checkpoint response. The checkpoint is a mechanism that prevents cell division when DNA damage is detected, allowing time for repair. However, when damage is persistent, cells can adapt and escape the checkpoint to continue division. The study found that Cdc is necessary for adaptation and its overexpression promotes it, indicating that high levels of C5 modulate the checkpoint's ability to inhibit the cell cycle. They pinpointed the step in the pathway where C5 acts by overexpressing it in damaged cells and examining individual steps of checkpoint activation. C5 overproduction had little effect on early steps leading to Rad53 activation, a key checkpoint protein, but significantly reduced its hyperphosphorylation, which is necessary for cell arrest. This suggests C5 attenuates the checkpoint through loss of hyperphosphorylated Rad53, allowing cells to adapt to damage. This mechanism is conserved in vertebrates, as polo kinase homologs inhibit checkpoint activation of downstream kinases. In yeast, cells unable to repair damage will eventually override the checkpoint and continue division, a process called adaptation. The timing of adaptation correlated with loss of Rad activity, suggesting it may be a consequence of C5-mediated inhibition. Studies in higher eukotes show polo can inhibit checkpoint response after damage. The study suggests C5 does not inhibit formation of the Rad-Rad complex but blocks ability of Mec-primed Rad molecules to produce hyperphosphorylated53 in vivo.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework, called the Kirchhoffern-Planck (KNP) framework, to study the movement of ions and electrical potential in the extracellular space (ECS) of the brain on a large spatial and temporal scale. This is important for understanding conditions such as seizures, stroke, and depression, which involve changes in ion concentrations in the ECS. Previous models were limited to small spatial and temporal scales or simplified processes. The KNP framework assumes electroneutrality, making it possible to run simulations on larger scales on a standard computer. It was used to simulate the dynamics of ions and electrical potential around a detailed pyramidal cell, showing the neuron's contribution to electrodiff effects and the framework's efficiency. The KNP can be applied to more complex biological systems to explore pathologies with large ECS variations.

A reliable estimate of electrodiff effects requires knowledge of all ion concentrations, which is currently unfeasible experimentally but achievable with computational models. Most models only partially or ignore ion dynamics. The 3D KNP model predicts ion concentrations in all directions and can be applied to various biological problems. It addresses diffusion due to concentration gradients on large scales. Models without ion dynamics are not applicable to pathologies and neglect diffusive effects on potentials.
A proposed budget cut to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) funding for mosquito-borne disease surveillance, such as deng and West Nile virus, could leave the country unprepared to handle emerging and existing diseases. To demonstrate the consequences, researchers evaluated the impact of delayed responses to deng epidemics in a developed urban environment. They used a mathematical model to simulate scenarios of delayed response to deng introduction in Cairns, Queensland, Australia, and coupled the results with surveillance and management costs to estimate cumulative costs. The study found that halting surveillance increased epidemic management costs by an order of magnitude compared to sustained surveillance and early detection. The total costs of preparedness through surveillance were lower than responding to vector-borne pathogens, even without considering human lives and well-being. The analysis provides a science-based justification for reassessing the CDC budget cut and emphasizes the need for sustainable vectororne surveillance systems.
Dengue is a significant infectious disease worldwide, and in Nicaragua's capital, Managua, suspected cases among children have been documented, but not among adults with undifferent fever. A study in semi-urban and rural Nicaragua found that 63.5% of 740 patients with acute febrile illness were seropositive for deng at enrollment. The seropreval increased with age, reaching 90% in those over 20 years. Acute deng serotypes 1 and 2 were identified in 5.1% of patients. Only 8.1% of confirmed cases were clinically suspected. Dengue is an important and largely unrecognized cause of fever in western Nicaragua. Since Zika virus is transmitted by the same vector and associated with severe congenital infections, the population is at risk of being devastated by the Zika epidemic that has reached Central America.

In a hospital cohort of children and adults with acute febr illness, deng was identified as etiologic responsible for 5.1% of febr illnesses. Testing confirmed by paired sera for IgM and Ig, 24.3 were confirmed by PCR. Serology limitations include cross-reactions between deng and other flaviviruses, but deng was the only flavivirus circulating in Nicaragua. 63.5% of patients were seropitive for deng Ig at enrollment. Seropreval was 22% in <5, 57 in 5-9, 77 in 10-14, 86 in 15-19, 91 in 20-24, 95 in 25-29, and 100 in ≥30. Patients with and without deng had similar clinical features to other febr illnesses.
Plant-parasitic nematodes are destructive pests that cause billions of dollars in losses annually. Effective defense against them relies on recognizing pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) by surface-localized receptors, leading to activation of PAMP-triggered immunity (PTI). Research has extensively characterized PT in various plant-pathogen interactions, but less is known about PT in roots and plant-nemat interactions. This study shows nemat-derived protein elicitors can induce PT in Arabidopsis, dependent on the immune receptor BAK. Consistent with BAK's role, a leucine-rich receptor-like kinase, NIL1 (NIL1), is regulated upon nemat infection. NIL1 is essential for PT responses to nematodes, and loss-of-function mutants are hypersusceptible to broad nematodes. NIL1 is the first immune receptor involved in basal immunity PT in plants or animals to nematodes. Manipulating NIL will provide options for nemode control in crops.
Researchers studied how the anti-cancer drug milteine affects Schistosoma mansoni, a parasite that causes schistosomiasis. They treated adult worms with miline in a lab dish and found that it exposed new antigens on the worm's surface. These antigens are normally hidden from the host's immune system during infection. The researchers used antibodies to identify the exposed antigens and found three proteins: fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase, alkaline phosphatase, and malate dehydrogenase. These proteins were also found on the surface of 3-hour schosula and caused the parasites to clump together, suggesting they may help the immune system fight the parasite. This is a new way miline works to kill schos. The study suggests that miline unmasks antigens the parasite normally hidden from the host, similar to another drug praziquel. These antigens could be targets for new treatments and antibodies against them may make miline more effective and help prevent re-infection.
Researchers have studied how the bacterium Bacillus cereus acquires iron from its host, a crucial for growth and virulence. Iron is hard to obtain due to its low solubility and bioavailability, so bacteria have developed systems to extract it from various sources like heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin. While iron acquisition from heme and hemoglobin is well understood, little is known about ferritin, a 24-mer protein storing thousands of iron atoms. IlsA, a surface protein in Bacillus cereus, binds heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin in vitro and is involved in virulence. This study shows Ils acts as a ferritin receptor, causing ferritin aggregation on the bacterial surface. Ils binds several types of ferritins through interaction with subunits, enhancing iron release from ferritin. Disrupting siderophore bacibactin production reduces Bacillus ability to use ferritin for growth and attenuates virulence in insects.
