African trypanosomes, a type of parasite that causes sleeping sickness in humans and animals, have enzymes called peroxides that protect their cells from damage. These enzymes, called Px, detoxify lipid hydroperox, a type of molecule that can harm cells. Without these enzymes, the parasite's cells die quickly. Researchers studied two types of Px, one in the cell's liquid (cytosol) and one in the mitochondria. They found that the cytos Px protects the lysosome, a part of the cell that breaks down waste, from damage. Without cytos Px, the lysosome breaks down and the cell dies. The researchers also found that the parasite gets iron from its host's transferrin, a protein that carries iron. Without iron, the lysosome breaks down and the cell dies. The study shows that the lysosome, not the mitochondria, is the main site of damage in African trypanosomes. The cytos Px enzymes protect the lysosome from iron damage. This is linked to how the parasite gets iron from its host.
Researchers have studied the role of a protein called PMEL in melanocytes, cells that produce the pigment melanin in skin, hair, and eyes. PMEL is a conserved across vertebrates and mutations in several species are linked to reduced melanin levels in skin and hair. However, it was unclear if these mutations were gain or loss-of-function, and no complete loss-of-function had been reported in mammals. A mouse line was created where the PM gene was inactivated (P−/−). The mice were viable, fertile, and showed no developmental defects. Melanosomes in P−/− melanocytes were spherical, unlike the elongated shape in wild-type. This was seen in skin and eye melanocytes. Inactivating PM had a mild effect on coat color in four genetic backgrounds, with the strongest effect in mice with the brown/Tp mutation. This is similar to the silver mutation in mice, suggesting other described alleles in vertebrates are dominant-negative. Despite mild effect on pigmentation, P− led to reduced melanin in hair, showing PM's role in maintaining epidermal pigmentation.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental methods for deng vector control. Nineteen studies were included, with sixteen contributing to the meta-analysis. The methods evaluated were: container covers with and without insecticides, waste management and clean-up, and elimination of breeding sites. Quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste management without direct collection and elimination of places. Both review and meta showed a weak effect on larval populations, with no differences between individual results. For meta, container without insect (BI: -7.9, DOE-5) and waste with garbage (BI: -8.83, DOE-6.2) achieved strongest reductions for BI, while P results were opposite with covers (P: -0.83, 0.09) and elimination (P: -0.95, -0.83). Each method showed effectiveness in reducing Aedes larval and pupal densities. However, high-quality studies are needed to strengthen evidence. A previous studies concluded environmental management was effective, and community-based interventions reduced deng risk. This study aimed to review and meta environmental methods. Searches were finished in 2017, but no further studies altered results. All methods showed effectiveness in reducing Aedes densities, partly due to study design issues and linking control and transmission.
Researchers have identified small molecules that can selectively stall protein synthesis by the ribosome, a key to developing new treatments for diseases. These compounds, like PF-06303, inhibit PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, reducing LDL in preclinical models. However, their impact on cell physiology and ribosome control pathways is unknown. A genome-wide CRISPR screen was used to identify proteins and pathways that modulate cell growth in the presence of high doses of PF-03. The most potent genetic modifiers of cell fitness in presence of PF03 were the ubiquitin binding protein ASC2 and helicase ASC3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of the compound. Surprisingly, translation control proteins Pelota and H1 sensitize cells to PF03 treatment. Genetic experiments showed ASC3 acts with ASC2 and downstream of H1. These results connect ribosome control pathways and provide insights into selectivity of compounds that stall translation, aiding development of next-generation compounds to treat diseases.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNA (mRNA) to evade the immune system and block host gene expression. The virus uses a protein called SO to induce this effect, but its mechanism was unknown. The study found that SO stimulates RNA turnover through a unique process called aberrant polyadenylation, where the addition of extra adenine nucleotides to the end of RNA. Cells expressing SO show longer poly A tails and faster RNA turnover. Inhibiting poly A tail formation blocks SO activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly A binding proteins are necessary for SO function, with the latter relocating to the nucleus when SO is present. This is a new mechanism of host shutdown and a model to study poly A tail-stimulated RNA turnover in mammalian cells.

The study links polyadenylation to RNA surveillance and turnover, as yeast mutants defective in RNA processing accumulate hyperadenylated transcripts. Analogous pathways may exist in higher eukaryotes, with polyadenylated precursors detected in mammalian cells. KSH SO-induced shutoff is linked to polyadenylation, a first example of enhanced turnover coupled to hyperylation in metazoans. The ribonuc responsible for mRNA destruction is unknown, but SO may alter RNA processing to make them targets of quality control machinery. Polyaden plays a role in SO-mediated turnover, as SO has no intrinsic ribonuclease activity and no homology to known ribonucleases.

Expression of SO from herpes simplex virus has DNase activity but no role in shutoff and no effect on reporter mobility. This modification correlates with RNA activity of SO responsible for shutoff. Polyadenylation alters message size, a way to regulate expression on individual and global scale.
Researchers studied the role of type III interferon (IFλ) in the immune response to bacterial infections in the lungs. They found that IFλ is produced in response to Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections and is essential for clearing the bacteria from the lungs. Mice lacking the IFλ receptor, IL-28, had reduced bacterial clearance and increased lung damage. IFλ inhibits the microRNA mi-21, leading to increased expression of PDC4, a protein that promotes inflammation. In mice lacking P4, bacterial clearance and lung damage were improved. The study suggests that IFλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting mi-21 regulation of PDC in bacterial infections. IFλ and P4 are key elements in the immune response to airway pathogens, but have different effects in inducing immunity. The expression of IL-28 is more abundant on epithelial cells than immune cells, which may contribute to specific cytokine responses to pathogens. The study shows that inhibiting IL-28 signaling reduces lung inflammation and improves bacterial clearance.
Researchers at the National Center for African Trypanosomiasis in the Democratic Republic of Congo studied mortality trends and risk factors in 781 patients with advanced stage-2 sleeping sickness between 1989 and 2012. The study found that 17.2% of patients died in the standard melarsol treatment group, 12.1% in the short melarsol group, 5.4 in the eflornine group, 9.1 in the NECT regimen, and 36% in the group given efline due to clinical status. After adjusting for treatment, the odds of death were higher for patients with severely impaired clinical status, high protach, parasites in cerebrospinal fluid, and cyach. Multivariate analysis showed clinical status and protach as predictors of death in some groups. The study's clinical assessment algorithm may serve as a basis for standardized tools in managing sleeping sickness and epidemiological reports.
Researchers have developed a new method to study the effects of isolation on social behavior in fruit flies, specifically Drosophila melanogaster. They created a system to track and analyze the behavior of many flies at once, and used it to examine how isolation affects their social interactions. The team found that isolation quickly changes the way flies interact with each other and their own behavior. They also looked at the genetic changes in the flies after isolation and found that many genes related to metabolism were affected. The flies had more lipids, a type of fat, after isolation. The study shows that isolation has a strong impact on social behavior, genes, and physiology in flies. This method can be used to study social behavior in other animals, including humans. 

The researchers used a new system to track and classify the behavior of many flies and analyze their social network. They found that isolation changes the way flies interact with each other and their own behavior. The team also looked at genetic changes in the flies after isolation and found that many genes related to metabolism were affected. The flies had more lipids, a type of fat, after isolation. The study shows that isolation has a strong impact on social behavior, genes, and physiology in flies. This method can be used to study social behavior in other animals, including humans. 

The team used a new system to track and classify the behavior of many flies and analyze their network. They found that isolation changes the way flies interact with each other and their behavior. The team looked at genetic changes in the flies after isolation and found many genes related to metabolism were affected. The flies had more lipids, a type of fat after. The study shows isolation has a strong impact on social behavior, genes, and physiology in flies. This can be used to study social in other animals, including humans.
Researchers conducted a pilot study in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization's (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines, including a modality for age-based weight estimation. The study took place in two hospitals that lacked scales, necessitating weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with 10-day post-discharge follow-up. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. A total of 841 patients were enrolled (325 pre-intervention, 516 intervention). During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at both hospitals (p < 0.001) with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. However, when IV fluids were prescribed, the volume adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the antibiotic azithromycin increased (p < 0.001; p= 0.035) with RR of 6.9 and 1.6, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased; zinc adherence increased. The study found that a smartphone tool can improve guideline adherence.
Scientists have long struggled to predict how host-parasite systems will respond to climate change due to the complexity of their interactions. A key factors such as host survival and parasite virulence may have different temperature dependencies that need to be included in disease models. Researchers used experimental data from Daphnia magna and a microidian parasite to develop a mechanistic model of within parasite dynamics. The model accounted for host mortality, parasite growth, and infection cost at different temperatures with fewer parameters than traditional models. The study shows that linking metabolic theory with a host-parite framework can predict parasite population responses at the within-host level.

The researchers analyzed data on host and parasite across a temperature range using a model to capture thermal dependencies of aging and virulence, growth, and abundance. They fitted a model to experimental data on Dnia and its parasite to examine temperature effects on traits, interactions, and dynamics. Over nine temperatures, they measured lifespan of exposed and unexposed and parasite abundance at death. Accurate predictions of climate change on host-parite and disease require models that integrate thermal dependencies of host and parasite traits. Development, survival, and movement can be described by formula from metabolic theory. These inform classical host-parite models to estimate temperature effects on prevalence and severity.

The study demonstrates the power of linking metabolic thermal relationships for host and parasite in mechanistic models to understand temperature impacts on disease. The framework is simple and general, providing a valuable approach to predict outcomes and consequences of infections under climate change.
Researchers have identified a network of three types of inhibitory neurons, called interneurons, that play a crucial role in controlling the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs) in the brain. These interneurons, expressing parvalbum (PV), somostatin (SOM), and vaso intestinal peptide (VIP), work together to shape how information is processed in the brain. The study suggests that PV and SOM interneurons control the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition onto PCs, while mutual inhibition between SOM and VIP interneurons translates inputs into changes in somatic dendritic inhibition of PCs. A computational model shows that the neuronal and synaptic properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. The SOM-VIP motif allows the circuit to switch between two processing modes, either integrating or cancelling top inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs. SOM-expressing neurons mainly target apical dendrites of PCs and inhibit other interneurons, while VIP-express mainly connects to dendrite-targeting SOM neurons, providing a disinhibitory circuit for distal dendrites of PCs.
Researchers have found that interactions between microbes in the microbiome can create false associations between specific microbes and host phenotypes, making it difficult to determine which microbes are directly linked to a disease. They developed a method, called Direct Association Analysis, to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. The method corrected inflated p-values in association tests and showed only a small subset of associations are directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate, and brain-gut axis as factors in inflammatory disease. The study suggests that realistic interactions produce many spurious associations between microbiome and phenotypes, which can be removed by a procedure based on maximum entropy models from statistical physics. Microbiome association studies have been carried out for various disorders, including diabetes, arthritis, cancer, and autism. However, non-causal relationships give rise to spurious associations in synthetic and real microbiome data. The study used parameters from a large case-control study on Crohn's disease and found traditional methods lost power to identify the link between phenotype and microbiota. The number of detections increased for real data, suggesting many reported associations between microbi and IBD could be indirect. The researchers estimated the contribution of indirect associations and isolated direct, showing interactions are strong enough to generate changes in abundance of microbes not linked to host.
Researchers compared two types of Wolbachia infection models in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes to block the spread of dengue and West Nile viruses. Wolia is a bacterium that infects mosquitoes and can affect how they transmit diseases. The study looked at two types of Wolia infection: stable and transient. Stable Wolia is when Wolia is permanently in the mosquito, while transient is when Wolia is only in the mosquito for a short time. The researchers tested how Wolia affects the replication and transmission of deng and West Nile viruses in mosquitoes. They found that Wolia blocked the viruses in both types of infection, but the effect was stronger in mosquitoes with stable Wolia. They also found no evidence that Wolia made the viruses spread faster in mosquitoes. This suggests that Wolia can be a safe and effective way to stop the spread of these viruses.
In the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, cilia are microtub-based organelles that mediate signal transduction and are organized into structurally and functionally distinct compartments: the basal body, the transition zone (TZ), and the cilia shaft. In vertebrates, the protein Invers localizes to a portion of the cilia adjacent to the TZ, a region termed the Invers compartment (Inv). The mechanisms that establish and maintain the Inv are unknown. In C. elegans, the cilia of amphid and phasm sensory cilia are subdivided into regions by different microtub ultrastructure: a proximal doublet region adjacent to the TZ and distal singlet region. Researchers explored the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the C eleg ciliary double region and Inv. They found that Inv is conserved and distinct from the double region. The genes n-2, the C eleg Invers hom, and double region ar-13, lp-11, and unc-119 are redundantly required for cili. Inv and double region can be sorted into modules n-2p-11 and ar-13-119, which are antagonized by hd-6 deacetyl. The genes modulate the sizes of N-2 Inv and A-13 double region. Glutlation, a tub-trans modification, is not required for ciliary of Inv and double components; rather, glut is modulated by-2, -13, and-119. The ciliary and localization of N-, A-, and UNC does not require TZ double region and Inv-associated genes N- requires its calcium EF domain for targeting Inv.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Scribble plays a crucial role in the development and regeneration of myelin, the fatty insulation that surrounds nerve fibers in the central nervous system. Myelin is formed by oligodendrocytes, specialized cells that undergo significant shape changes to create the myelin sheath. Scribble is present throughout oligodendrocy development and is upregulated in mature oligodrocytes, where it is found in both developing and mature myelin sheaths. When Scri expression is knocked down in cultured oligodrocy, myelination is disrupted, and when Scri is conditionally eliminated in myelinating glia of mice, myelination in the CNS is disrupted during development and after demyelination. Scri also regulates myelin thickness by suppressing the ERK/MAPK pathway and localizes to non-compact myelin at the node of Ranvier, where it is required for axo-glial adhesion. These findings demonstrate Scri's essential role in evolutionarily conserved intracellular polarity in myelination and remyelination.
Researchers have identified a new virulence factor, Listerin S, associated with a subset of Listeria monocytogen, a bacterium responsible for listeriosis outbreaks. Listerin S is a bacterioc-like hemolytic and cytotoxic protein that contributes to the pathogen's virulence. It is part of a family of modified virulence peptides (MVPs) produced by several Gram-positive pathogens, including Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium botulin. The Lister S cluster is found in a subset of lineage I strains, which cause most listeriosis outbreaks. Expression of Lister S results in hemolysis and cytotoxicity, contributing to the pathogen's virulence in murine and human polymorphonuclear neutrophil studies. The study reveals the genetic basis for enhanced virulence in a proportion of lineage L monocytogen.
Researchers studied the role of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma, a type of granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. Myetoma is characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains, surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. The study aimed to determine if IL-17 and MP-9 levels in myet lesions were related to disease severity and independent of causative agent. Biopsies from 100 patients with myet were analyzed for IL-17 and MP-9 expression using immunohistochemistry. Results showed IL-17 mainly in zones I and II, and less in III, while MP-9 mainly in II and III, and least in I. MP-9 was higher in Actinadura and Streptomyces biops compared to Madure myet biops. MP-9 levels were directly proportional to IL-17 (p=0.001). Only association between MP-9 and patients' characteristics was disease duration (p<0.001). No correlation between IL-17 and patients' characteristics.

IL-17 and MP-9 were present in myet granoma, but their functions unknown. Further studies needed to determine roles in granuloma formation and myet immunogenesis. Results indicate IL-17 more in larger lesions and longer disease duration, and positive correlation between IL-17 and MP-9 levels. Immunohistochemistry showed IL- and MP-9 presence, but not formation time. Future studies to determine IL- and MP functions in myet granoma.
Researchers studied how a type of protein called intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) interact with other molecules. IDPs are proteins that don't have a fixed shape and can change their structure when they bind to a target. Some IDPs stay disordered even when bound, a phenomenon called "fuzziness". The study focused on the transcription activation domain of the Ewing Sarcoma oncoprotein (E), an ID with many features of fuzziness. They hypothesized that E-target binding involves interactions between E's aromatic side chains and target's basic residues. Experiments with E variants of E supported the hypothesis. A coarse-grained E model and analytical model captured the trends. E-target binding is driven by balance between E conformation entropy and E-target cationπ contacts. This versatile recognition mode offers a framework for promiscuous target by polyent IDPs.
Researchers studied the functions of two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2, in the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease. This bacterium has a unique feature of having two putative ATP-dependent Lon homologs, unlike other bacteria. Previous work showed that Lon-1 is upregulated by blood exposure in vitro, while Lon-2 is not. The study aimed to clarify the roles of these proteases in B. burgorfer. Phylogenetic analysis revealed Lon-1 and Lon- cluster separately due to differences in substrate binding domains. Recombinant Lon-1 showed ATP-dependent chaperone-protease properties but did not complement E. coli mutant, while Lon-2 corrected Lon-mut phenotypes. The study concludes that B. burgor Lon-1 and-2 have distinct roles. Lon-2 functions like canonical Lon in cellular homeostasis, while Lon-1, induced by blood, may be important for host adaptation from arthropod to warm-blood host.
Researchers investigated the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in preventing HIV-1 infection. AD is a process where antibodies help cells engulf and internalize foreign particles. They tested the ability of HIV-specific antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-infected cells by phagocytes. Using a green-fluorescent protein-expressing HIV clone, they found minimal or no AD of virions with any antibodies. However, after coating virions with a specific protein, gp41, antibodies efficiently mediated phagytosis. A few hundred gp molecules were needed for successful phagytosis, similar to the number on influenza virus. Fluorescence spectroscopy showed a clear association between virus aggregation and AD. In contrast, vir-decorated cells were targets for AD orgocytosis in presence of HIV antibodies. Findings indicate AD of vir may not prevent infection due to paucity of trimers and inability of vir-bound antibody to cross FRs on phocytes. However, AD orocyt could clear infected cells on verge of infection.
Hookworm infection is a widespread in many countries around the world, but its global economic and health impact is not well understood. To determine how much time, money, and resources to invest in controlling the disease, researchers created a model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm in every country, region, and globally in 2016. From a societal perspective, globally, hookworm resulted in 2,126,280 Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) using 200 disability estimates and 4,087,803 DALs using 201 estimates (excluding cognitive outcomes). Including cognitive impairment did not increase DALs worldwide. Productivity losses varied depending on anemia and calculation method, from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually using Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage. Hook is classified as a neglected disease, but its burden exceeded estimates of diseases with more attention, such as rotavirus. Countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face significant hook burden.

The Global Burden of Disease (GBD) 2010 reported 3,230,800 DALs annually due to hook among all ages in 21 regions. This included disability weights for hook outcomes (wasting and abdominal problems) and anemia, but not cognitive. Large countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face considerable hook burden. Assuming median anemia, 200 estimates and NI, hook infections resulted in productivity losses $11.1 billion (95%:5.5-18.5) using Method 1, $87.9 (95:1.7-302.3) Method 2, and $23.1 (11-38.4) Method 3. Using minimum wage, global burden was $3.

The number of hook infections with health outcomes (heavy infection and anemia) and DALs for each region in 201 (excluding cognitive) using 200 estimates varied with anemia given. There is variation in countries due to productivity proxy (NI vs. wage), estimates (200 vs 201), and 201 estimates. China's 35,917,360 hook infections result $6.7 in losses NI, $1 using wage.
Researchers studied how oxygen deprivation, or hypoxia, affects the developing brain in vertebrates, such as zebraf fish. They found that hypox disrupts the pathfinding of brain neurons, leading to errors in axons failing to cross the midline. This is similar to what happens in in invertebrates, such as Caenorhabditis elegans, where hypia causes axon path errors in certain neurons and motorneurons. The researchers identified the hypia-inducible transcription factor (h1) pathway as the cause of the defects and showed that blocking its activation prevents the errors. They found that ephrin2, a protein, is a target of the h pathway and that mediates the errors. Knocking down eph2 rescued the defects and showed that the receptor eph4 is expressed in a pattern complementary to the misrouting axons. Magnesium, used to improve outcomes in preterm births, protects against errors by preventing upregulation of eph2. The study shows that conserved genetic pathways regulate changes in the CNS in response to hypia and supports a neuroprotective role for magnesium.
Researchers studied pulmonary abnormalities in mice with paracidiomycosis, a fungal disease caused by Paracidi brasiliensis, using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathology. Fifty mice were infected with the fungus and 50 were not. HRCT scans were done every four weeks to track lung damage and density. Three types of lesions were found: nodular, diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-tum. Lesions were mainly around the hilus and affected the left lung. At four weeks, 80% of infected mice had peri-bronial consolidations with increased lung density compared to controls. After eight and 12 weeks, consolidation spread to middle regions. Histology showed consolidation as confl granulomatous reaction and nodules as compact granomas. At 16 weeks, confl granomas formed pseudooral masses obstructing bronchi. Focal fibrosis was seen around granomas, but only by histology. This study shows HRCT is useful for evaluating and quantifying damage in experimental paridiomycosis. The design reduces animal sacrifice and allows monitoring treatment efficacy with a more rational approach to human lung disease.
Researchers have developed a new test to detect infection with Leishmania donovirus, a parasite causing visceral leishmaniasis in endemic areas. The test, called Interferon-gamma Release Assay (QuFERON), measures the body's immune response to the parasite. It uses five different Leish antigens: H2, H2-PS2, H-Le12, crude antigen, and soluble Leish antigen (SL). The test was evaluated on blood samples from 13 active VL patients, 15 cured patients, 11 non-endemic controls, and 19 healthy controls. The test using SL antigen had a sensitivity of 80% and specificity of 100. The results suggest that the whole-blood SL-based QuFER assay can measure the immune response to Leish infection. A surprising finding was that active VL patients produced interferon-gamma when stimulated with Leish antigen, contradicting previous findings of non-proliferative response in peripheral mononuclear cells.
Researchers have found that a toxin called CNFY plays a key role in making the bacteria Yersinia pseudotuberculosis persistent in the body. This bacterium causes gastrointestinal infections that can lead to relapsing enteritis and autoimmune disorders. To establish a persistent infection, the bacteria must navigate through the intestinal lining and colonize the underlying lymphatic tissues, but how they evade the immune response is not well understood. The study shows that CNFY toxin enhances the transfer of anti-inflammatory effectors, leading to tissue destruction and alteration of the microbiota and bacterial suppression. However, suppressing CNFY function increases interferon-mediated responses, non-inflammatory activities and tolerogenesis. This leads to a preprogramming of the pathogen's transcription towards persistence, giving the bacteria an advantage against host responses and establishing a commensal lifestyle.

The study demonstrates that removing a single virulence factor, CNFY, is sufficient to dampen inflammation and evade host defense, favoring Yers persistence. The mechanisms are unclear, but the impact suggests a set of immune responses, such as IL-6 levels, modulators, bactericidal activities, and anti-inflammatory factors, contributing to the process. The CNFY process is a double-edged sword. The toxin constitutively activates Rho GTPases deidation and Y translocation into host, enhancing inflammation and damage. Suppressing CN function shifts the balance towards immune suppression, promoting asymptomatic infection. Several enteric pathogens, including Yersiae, persist in the intestinal and lymphatic tissues, promoting arthritis and ileitis.
Researchers have identified a new gene, DES1, in the fungus Magnaporthe oryza, that helps the fungus evade the plant's defense system. To do this, DES1 breaks down a type of molecule called reactive oxygen species (ROS) that the plant produces to fight off the fungus. Without DES1, the fungus can't colonize the plant and causes a strong defense response in the plant. The researchers found that DES1 is responsible for breaking down ROS in the plant cells, which helps the fungus avoid the plant's defense. When DES1 is missing, the fungus can't grow well and the plant's defense is triggered. The researchers also found that DES1 is related to an enzyme called peroxidase, which breaks down ROS. When they treated the fungus with a chemical that stops ROS production, the plant's defense is reduced and the fungus grows normally. This suggests DES1 is a new gene that helps the fungus evade plant defense by breaking down ROS.
Researchers in Ghana evaluated the accuracy of a mathematical model used to predict the prevalence of schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection, in the country. They compared the model's predictions to actual infection rates found in 79 schools surveyed in 2010. The study found that using the model alone, 21 schools with high infection rates would have been undertreated and 20% would have been treated unnecessarily. This would have meant 28% of children were undertreated and 12% received treatment without need. The researchers suggest the model should not be used as a one-time tool, but rather an iterative process that incorporates actual data to refine predictions. This would help control programs make better decisions.

The model was based on data from 2008, but the researchers used new data from 201 to test its accuracy. Schistosoma haematium, the most common schistome infection in Ghana, was the focus. The study aimed to understand how to best use predictive maps to guide treatment decisions. The World Health Organization does not recommend treating at district level, but Ghana did so. The study found using the model alone was not accurate enough to guide the national program. Each school in endemic areas should be assessed, not just districts. The model should be a tool to help, not replace actual assessments.
Researchers have discovered that a mixture of prostaglandins, a type of hormone, guides sperm through the reproductive tract of Caenorhabditis elegans, a type of worm, to reach the egg for fertilization. They found that the worm's oocytes, or egg cells, synthesize prostagland from fatty acid precursors in yolk protein complexes. Using genetics and mass spectrometry, they identified prostland pathways and showed that omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids are converted into over 10 structurally related prostland, which collectively promote sperm guidance. Disrupting omega-3 fatty acid synthesis triggers compensatory upregulation of prostland from omega-6 fatty acids. The worm's prostland synthesis involves different mechanisms than mammalian cyclooxygen pathways, yet PG2 stereomers are still synthesized. A conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme regulates prostland synthesis, similar to its human homolog in Biet's Crystine dystrophy. The study supports model that multiple cyclooxygen-independent prostland function together promote sperm motility for fertilization.
Researchers have developed a new method to design biotherapeutic proteins that are less likely to trigger an immune response while maintaining their function. This approach, called Pareto optimization, balances two goals: reducing the number of immune-activating parts (epitopes) and preserving the protein's function. Analysis shows that there is no single best design, but a range of options that trade off between these two factors. The team created 18 such designs and tested them experimentally, finding a correlation between predicted and actual performance. This study is the first systematic evaluation of the trade-off between reduced immunogenicity and function in biotherapeutics. The method can quickly assess and design proteins with varying levels of immunogenicity and function, potentially speeding up and reducing the risk of deimmunization efforts. 

The team used a computational tool that integrates epitope prediction and in silico analysis of functional consequences of deimmizing mutations. This enabled global design and deimmization on a faster scale. Predictions matched experimental results, showing that deleting more epitopes led to increased loss of function. The study outlines a design-based approach to functional deimmization of biotherapeutic candidates. Next-generation deimm tools combine immunoinform epitope prediction with in silico analysis of functional consequences of deimm mutations, allowing global design and deimm on a compressed scale.
Researchers studied how temperature affects the process of meiosis in Arabidopsis thalian, a type of plant. Meiosis is a fundamental process in sexual reproduction that involves the exchange of DNA between chromosomes to ensure proper segregation. The frequency and distribution of these exchanges, called crossovers (CO), are regulated by internal and external factors, but more is known about the internal mechanisms than the external. The study found that elevated temperature increases meiotic recombination in Arabidopsis and used genetic analysis to show that the extra crossovers come from the Type I pathway, which is sensitive to interference. This pathway is different from Type II, which is not sensitive to interference. The study also found that temperature-induced crossovers are not caused by an increase in DNA breaks and the hyper-recombination phenotype is specific to heat stress, not a general stress response. The findings provide insight into how environmental cues modulate meiotic recombination and may have practical applications.
Researchers have developed a novel computational approach to navigate the vast and rapidly evolving landscape of biomedical literature, particularly in molecular medicine. The system, called Hanalyzer, combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods to facilitate analysis of experimental data. It extracts information from external resources, structured or unstructured data, and tracks provenance. Reasoning enriches the results by noting genes annotated to the same term or database, and combines sources into a network representing relationships between genes, calculating a reliability score. Reporting combines the network with congruent constructed from data and visualizes in a tool for knowledge-based analysis.

Hanalyzer was demonstrated on a large gene array dataset relevant to craniofacial development, identifying roles of four previously uncharacterized genes. Each hypothesis was validated by further work. A plugin, Coscape, allows tracing provenance links and accessing sources (Figure 2). This identified explanations by inferences not in individual sources. To present relevant knowledge, sub-networks are selected and presented in a comprehensible way, visualizing with fidials or generating sub-networks including them. A more effective method is creating a quantitative network from data and combining in various ways. Here, a network was constructed from expression experiment results.

Biomedical knowledge is expanding exponentially, with over 10 million PubMed indexed in 20 years, 4.8% annual growth. Combining knowledge with data highlights supported linkages, facilitating explanation, or unsupported linkages generating hypotheses. Both can be together, demonstrated.
Helminth parasites, such as Fasciola hepatica, secrete extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be internalized by host cells, modulating the host's immune response. While the cargo of EVs has been characterized in many parasites, little is known about the surface-exposed molecules that participate in ligand-receptor interactions with the cell to initiate vesicle docking and internalization. Researchers used a membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins on the outer surface of two EV populations (15 and 120 EV) released by adult F. hepatica, describing 380 proteins including virulence factors, membrane proteins, and molecules involved in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis showed the 120 EV have endosomal origin and may be released via the protonephial excretory system, while larger 15 EV are from gastrodermal epithelial cells lining the gut. A lectin microarray strategy profiled the surface oligosaccharides of intact fluorically labelled EVs as displayed to the host. Lectin profiles of 15 and 120 EV subpopulations are identical but distinct from parasite tegument, dominated by high mannose sugars. EVs were resistant to exo and endoglycosases, but glycosidase PNG remodelled surface oligosacides and blocked uptake by macrophages. Pre-treatment with antibodies from infected hosts or purified against EV surface proteins (DM-containing, CD63 and myferlin) significantly enhanced internalization.
Researchers have identified a protein called Arabidopsis CDF2 that plays a crucial role in regulating microRNA (miRNA) production in plants. miRNAs are small molecules that help control gene expression and are essential for plant development. CDF2 interacts with an enzyme called Dicer 1 that cuts miRNA precursors into mature miRNAs. C2 binds to the promoters of some miRNA genes, acting as an activator or repressor to control their expression. It also binds to miRNA precursors and affects their processing by Dicer 1. Genetically, C2 works in the same pathway as mi156 and mi172 to control flowering. C2 regulates a group of miRNAs at both transcription and post-transcription levels to maintain proper levels and control plant development.

 Studies found C2 regulates miRNA biogenesis at both transcription and post-trans levels to control flowering. By regulating transcription and processing of miRNA precursors, C2 precisely controls a population of miRNAs for proper plant development. C2 also regulates components involved in miRNA biogenesis, affecting biogenesis. A feedback network among components in mi biogenesis is of interest. C2-regulated miRNAs include156,160,167,172,165/166, and319, contributing to early flowering in c2 mutant. mi156 and172 were studied, widely known miRN. Results suggest C2 regulates biogenesis indirectly by regulating mi processing proteins, in addition to direct transcription and post-regulation of mi precursors. D1 level increased in h1-2 and se-1 mutants, and SE in h1 mutant. mi156 flowers earlier and mi172 later, consistent with c2 early flowering, mi156 decrease and SPL increase, whereas mi172 and AP2 in c2.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GG) plays a crucial role in the communication between oocytes and granulosa cells in the ovary. This communication is essential for the development of follicles, which provide eggs for reproduction. GG is involved in a process called protein geranylation, which helps cells talk to each other. The study found that GG levels increase in oocytes during early follicle development. Depleting GG from oocytes impaired granosa cell growth, primary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GG blocked a protein called Rho, which helps cells stick together, and another called Rab, which helps send materials from o to granosa cells. GG administration restored defects in GG-depleted mice. The study shows GG-mediated geranylation contributes to o-granosa communication and primary follicle transition, a key step in follicogenesis for female function.
Researchers have created a detailed model of an enzyme called RNA polymerase II, which is crucial for creating messenger RNA from DNA. Despite previous studies, it was unclear how a molecule called NTP (nucleoside triphosphate) reaches the enzyme's active site. Two possible routes, the "main" and "secondary" channels, were considered. To understand this, researchers built a model of RNA polymerase II with a full "transcription bubble" (unpaired and unpaired DNA) using existing data and computer simulations. They found that the secondary channel is the main route for NTP to enter the enzyme, but the main channel is still a possibility. This is because the unpaired DNA part of the transcription bubble overlaps with the main channel, making it hard to study. The researchers used computer simulations to see how NTP moves through both channels and found that the main channel is difficult due to electrostatic repulsion between N and negatively charged DNA. The study suggests the secondary channel is the main route for NTP during RNA synthesis.
Dengue is a significant public health problem in Thailand and Cambodia, particularly among children under 15 years old. Although deng is a reportable in both countries, the reported incidence underestimates the true burden of the disease. Researchers used data from laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases in prospective studies to estimate the magnitude of deng underrecognition and establish more accurate disease estimates. Two cohort studies were conducted among children under 15 in deng field sites over two deng seasons. Age-specific multiplication factors (MF) were calculated by comparing cohort data to national surveillance in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14,493 in one province in Cambodia. Annual incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand, and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated MF varied by age and year (0.4-29). Average age-specific MF were applied to country data, indicating in Thailand 229,886 (210,612-331,236) deng cases annually 2003-2007 and 111,178 (80,452,357,135) in Cambodia. Underrecognition of total inpatient deng was 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand, and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. In 2007, over 95,000 children in Thailand and 58,000 in Cambodia were estimated hospitalized due to deng. Calculating MF by comparing cohort to surveillance is one approach to assess burden. Data indicate deng reported in many countries underestimates true burden.
Researchers have discovered that natural killer (NK) cells play a crucial role in promoting early immune responses to cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. They found that NK cells help accelerate the development of CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that fights off the virus, by limiting the production of immunosuppressive cytokines. This is achieved by controlling CMV replication early on, which reduces the activation of plasmacyoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and preserves conventional dendritic cells (DC), leading to accelerated CD8 T cell responses. Conversely, administering interferon-alpha (IFN) in animals blocks DCs and delays CD8 cell activation when NK cells control viral replication. The study shows that NK cells' ability to respond early to CMV infection is critical in balancing innate immune responses, reducing immunopathology, and promoting adaptive immunity.
Researchers have studied the regulation of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes in Arabidopsis thalian, a plant species. These genes are arranged in arrays of hundreds to thousands of copies, but not all are transcribed under normal conditions. The team found four rRNA variants in Arabid thalian, with one induced and others repressed or unchanged in plants with a disrupted nucleolin protein, At-L. The most represented rRNA variant, inactive in normal plants, is reactivated in At-L mutants. They show that pre-rNAs originate from RNA I transcription and are processed. Disruption of At-L gene leads to loss of DNA methylation without affecting histone marks on r genes. The study reveals a mechanism for r gene regulation, with nucleolin controlling active and repressed r variants.
Researchers have identified a protein from the human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) called UL29 that interacts with a cellular complex called NuRD, which is involved in histone modification. This interaction is important for the accumulation of immediate-early RNA, a crucial for viral replication. The study used a method called immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry to identify proteins that interact with HD1, a component of Nu, and found multiple CM-coded proteins, including UL29 and UL38. The interaction between UL29 and UL38 and HD1 was confirmed. HD1 is part of the Nu complex, which remodels chromatin and deacetylates histones. UL and UL28 associated with the M2 component of Nu, and RNA knockdown of RBP and CH4, constituents of Nu, inhibited CM immediateearly and viral DNA accumulation. This suggests multiple Nu components are needed for efficient CM replication. The growth of UL28 or UL-deficient viruses could not be rescued by treating cells with a deetylase inhibitor, trichatin A. Transient expression of UL28 enhanced the CM majorearly promoter in a reporter assay, regardless of UL expression. Importantly, induction of the majorearly reporter by UL28 required Nu components, consistent with inhibition of RNA accumulation after knockdown RBP and CH4. The study proposes UL28 modifies Nu to stimulate accumulation of immediateearly RNAs.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in young children and adults. They used a technique called whole-genome-fragment display libraries (GFPDL) to identify the specific parts of the virus that the immune system recognizes, called epitopes. The study found that after infection, the immune system recognizes more parts of the virus attachment protein G, but not the fusion protein F. In young children, the immune system recognizes more parts of the fusion protein, but in adults it recognizes more of the attachment protein. The study also found that the immune response to the fusion protein changes over time, with more recognition of the pre-fusion form than the post-fusion form. In contrast, the immune response to the attachment protein is high in children but decreases in adults. The study suggests that the immune system evolves its response to the virus over time, which could help in developing effective countermeasures, such as vaccines. The findings could lead to better understanding of how to protect against RSV, a major cause of pneumonia in infants.
Emodeide, a veterinary drug used to treat nematode infections in cats and dogs, has been shown to have macrofidal effects on adult Brug mal, a parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis. Researchers studied how emide works on Brug mal and found it potently inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. They discovered that emide targets S-1 channels, a type of potassium channel, and that has different forms due to alternative splicing in the R1 region. The slo-1 isoform found in males is more sensitive to emide than the slo-1 isoform found in females. Knocking down the slo-1 isoform in females increased emide potency. Onchercavolus, another parasite that causes blindness, has two forms of slo-1 in females with different R1 domains. Modeling showed emide binds to the same R1 region in different species of filaria, affected by splicing variations. This study shows emide has potent macroidal effects and splicing in R1 affects potency. Evaluating sex-dependent effects of anthelmint compounds is important to prevent underdosing one gender of nematodes given to patients.
Researchers have identified the antigens from the Loa loa parasite that cause false-positive results in rapid diagnostic tests for lymphatic filariasis. These tests are used to determine where mass drug administration is needed and when it can stop. Loa antigens cross-react with tests for Wuchereria bancrofti, a different parasite, making it hard to eliminate Loa filariasis in areas. To understand this, researchers used an antibody to purify Loa antigens from people with Loa infection. Immunoblot and proteomic analysis found many Loa proteins, including secreted and somatic, that may come from dying adult worms or microfilar. Unlike W bancroft antigen, Loa antigens are only present in a subset of people with Loa. This difference can help differentiate between the two parasites and improve tests.

The Loa antigens are made differently than Wucher bancft's. The likely reason Loa cross-reacts with bancft tests is when Lo worms die and release antigens into the blood. The balance between release and clearance of these antigens makes them detectable in some Loa patients but not bancft-infected people. Samples from Loa patients without bancft infection were negative for Lo antigens. Proteomic analysis matched Loa antigens to the parasite's genome.

Loa cross-reactivity with bancft tests is a problem in Lo-endemic areas, where prevalence is 1% or higher needs mass drug administration. This study aimed to find Loa antigens causing false positives in tests. Unexpectedly, different Lo antigens were found compared to previous studies. Loa antigen is produced by adult worms, while previous studies found Lo antigens in blood and urine. This study focused on antig causing bancft cross-reactivity, so different Loa antigens were found.
Researchers used the nematode C. elegans to identify new genes associated with cilia, specialized structures on the surface of eukaryotic cells. Defects in cilia cause human disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bard-Bied syndrome (BBS), affecting many physiological and developmental processes. They used whole-organ RNA-Seq to discover a signature profile of ciliary transcripts, including known proteins FAM161, CC104, and RP1. From a list of 185 candidates, they found orthologs of MAP, YAP, CC149, and R28 as conserved ciliary components. C. elegans R-28, associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, is a small GTPase expressed in ciliated neurons, where it associates with intraflagellar transport (IFT) trains. Inactive R-28 shows no IFT and diffuse localization, but GTP-bound R-28 concentrates at the periciliary membrane in a BBS-dependent manner and undergoes bidirectional IFT. Overexpression of predicted or locked GTP variants of R-28 perturbs cilium and sensory morphogenesis. The study presents a new approach for identifying ciliary proteins and unveils R28, a GTP closely related to B protein R4/IFT, as IFT-associated with BBS-dependent cell and non-autonomous functions at the ciliary base.
Researchers have investigated how the brain represents the outside world using neural responses without direct access to external stimuli. They used hippocampal place cells as a model and found that knowing which groups of cells fire together can reveal a surprising amount of structure in the stimulus space. This enables the brain to construct its own internal representations. The study showed that knowing which groups of hippocal cells fire is enough to extract global features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate representation of physical space, including the animal's position. This is different from previous approaches that required knowing place fields or other neural responses related to position. The researchers found that simple knowledge of groups of hippocal cells can infer topological features of a two-dimensional environment and geometric reconstruction of space, including the animal's position, without needing actual place fields or prior measurements. This challenges the idea that place fields are necessary for reconstructing position from cell activity. The study suggests that coarse features of population spiking activity can provide a great deal of information about the environment.
Researchers studied the role of the NLR3 inflamome and IL-1β in viral fulminant hepatitis, a severe liver disease caused by excessive inflammation. They infected mice with a virus that causes fulmin hepatitis and found high levels of IL-1β in the liver and blood. Mice lacking IL-1 receptor or treated with IL-1 antagonist showed reduced virus replication, disease, and mortality. IL-1 receptor deficiency blocked the production of a protein by macrophages and neutrophils in the liver. The release of reactive oxygen species by macrophages activated the NLR3 inflamome. Mice lacking NADPH oxidase, which controls ROS production, had reduced NLR3 inflam activation and IL-1 secretion, making them resistant to the disease. Mice lacking NLR3 and caspase-1, components of the inflamome, also had reduced IL-1 and less severe disease. The study found that the ROS/NLR3/IL-1 axis is a key pathway that causes severe liver disease during viral infection. This sheds light on developing treatments for fulmin hepatitis and other inflammatory diseases.
Researchers conducted a study in Malawi to investigate the role of hookworm infections in severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. They used a new diagnostic tool, multiplex real-time PCR, to identify and measure the load of two types of hookworm species, Ancyoma duale and Necator american. The study found that 34.1% of severely anemic children and 27.0% non-severely anemic children had hookworm infections, while microscopy detected only 5.6%. The prevalence of A duale and american was 26.1% and 4.9 respectively. Moderate to high A duale infections were associated with severe anemia and iron deficiency, with odds ratios of 2.49 and 9.04 respectively. Iron deficiency was also associated with intensity of Aale infection, with odds of 3.63, 16.98, and 44.91 for low, moderate, and high load. This is the first study to assess hook load and species with anemia and bone iron deficiency. The results show a higher than expected prevalence of Aale and its association with severe anemia and iron in pre-school children in Malawi, highlighting the need for species-specific screening. Multiplex real PCR is a powerful tool to combat anemia and iron deficiency in resource settings.
Researchers have identified a protein called COM-1 that plays a crucial role in the process of meiosis, a type of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells. During meiosis, DNA is broken into pieces called double-strand breaks (DSBs), which can be repaired in two ways: homologous recombination (HR) or non-homous joining (NHE). HR is necessary for the formation of interchromosomal crossovers (COs) that allow for proper chromosome segregation. Without COM-1, cells repair DS via error-prone NHE, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal abnormalities, and near-complete embryonic lethality. Unlike its counterparts in yeast, COM1 is not required for Spo11 removal and initiation of meiotic DS repair, but instead promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting NHE complex. In fact, animals lacking both COM1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. COM acts parallel to nucleaseEX-1 to promote interolog HR at early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase, safeguarding CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD51 recruitment at late pachene stage when hom-independent pathways predominate, suggesting redundancy and regulation of DNA resection during meiotic prophase.
Researchers studied the immune response of goats to Burkholderia pseudallei, a bacterium that causes meloidosis, a severe pneumonia and sepsis in Southeast Asia and Australia. They used an aerosol infection model to mimic the disease in goats, which is more similar to human infection than previous mouse models. The study aimed to identify proteins that trigger an immune response, which could lead to new diagnostics and vaccines.

The researchers found that goats developed a strong immune response to the bacterium, with more antibodies increasing over time. They identified several proteins that triggered this response, including GroEL, EF-T, and Dna, which were present in all infected goats. The strongest response was to heat shock protein Gro1, which elicited antibodies in all goats. Most antigens showed peak IgM reactivity at day 14, while IgG reactivity increased as disease progressed.

The study compared goat and human immune responses, finding many common reactive proteins between the two species. The researchers used ELISA, 2D electrophores, and western blots to analyze antibodies in goat serum. They found a diverse and increasing antibody response over disease progression, with IgG and IgM antibodies reacting to multiple antigens.

The study suggests goats are a good model for human meloidosis, with similar immune response to the disease. The findings could lead to new diagnostics and vaccines for meloid.
Cyclin B–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk) plays a crucial role in initiating mitosis by triggering a positive feedback loop at the end of the G2 phase. However, its activation during mitosis has been poorly understood. Researchers used a novel approach to track the development of cyclin B–C1dk activity in single cells by quantifying dephosphorylation of Cdk and phosphorylation of its target anaphase-promoting/cycome 3. They found that cyclin B–Cdk continues to be activated after centros separation and can be maintained in the cytoplasm even when cyclin B translocates to the nucleus in prophase. This suggests that increasing cyclin B–dk activity after centros separation is essential for mitotic progression. The study reveals distinct thresholds for cyclin B–dk activity controlling successive mitotic events. Cyclin B–dk is activated in late G2 and gradually increases between centros separation and prometaph. Reducing C1 levels affects mitotic progression, with a threshold triggering autocatalyzing further cyclin Bdk activation and entry into mitosis. Cyclin B–dk contributes to centros separation in G and is initially detected on centros before they separate in G or pro.
Researchers studied the immune responses of 21 Kenyan women who were infected with HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D after being exposed to the virus from different partners. The women were infected for a median of 1.07 years before being exposed to the virus again, and their blood samples were taken 2.72 years after the second infection. The study focused on 4 main targets on the HIV-1 envelope: the CD4 binding site, V1/V glycan, N332 site in V3, and gp41 membrane. The results showed that the second infection did not lead to a dominant response to any of these targets in the women's blood. In fact, 20 out of 21 women's responses could not be linked to a single target with high confidence. This suggests that being exposed to multiple types of HIV may lead to a broader and more diverse immune response. The study supports the idea that a vaccine should aim to elicit a variety of antibodies to protect against different parts of the virus.
Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. CMV has been shown to dysregulate the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hairy Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) is a key regulator of NPC fate and brain development. Researchers found that CMV downregulates Hes protein levels in infected NPCs. The CM 72Da immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) is involved in H degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting H ubiquination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of H. A component of PML bodies, SpA, is also targeted by IE-mediated ubiquination. The C-terminal region of IE, spanning amino acids 451-475, is required for IE/H interaction and IE-mediated ubiquination but not for IE/SpA interaction. This study reveals a new mechanism linking H downregulation to neurodevelopmental disorders caused by CM infection. It also identifies IE as the first CM-encoded E ubiquitin ligase.
Researchers studied how changes in the binding of transcription factors to DNA affect gene expression in fruit fly embryos from four different species of the Drosophila genus. They compared the binding of four transcription factors involved in early development to gene expression and found that the levels of these factors are more conserved than individual binding events. However, changes in gene expression were not explained by changes in transcription factor binding, suggesting that many binding sites are weak or non-functional and not subject to selection. The study found that highly bound sites, regions bound by multiple factors and near genes are conserved more than other binding sites, indicating that a significant amount of transcription binding is not functional.

The researchers compared divergence of binding to divergence and found that only 3-7% of variance in binding between species is explained by divergence. They sequenced mRNA from embryos at the end of cellularization using high-throughput sequencing and found that mRNA levels are highly correlated between species, decaying with phylogenetic distance. Divergence of mRNA was lower than divergence of TF binding, measured along the Dophila tree. The study identified two sources of binding divergence: alterations of B, HB, GT, and KR motifs drive a portion of binding, and highly bound regions near genes are conserved more than other binding sites.

The researchers matched each gene to the region bound by the highest number of TFs and focused on 4,846 genes annotated in all species and expressed in at least one. They found that mRNA levels are highly correlated between species, decaying with phylogenetic distance, and divergence of mRNA was lower than divergence of TF binding along the Dila tree.
A large-scale epidemiological study was conducted in two primary health centers in Thanjav district, India, where eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis had been completed. The study aimed to assess the impact of MDA and identify potential "hotspots" of transmission. The study covered 70% of the 50,363 population and found a microfilaria (M) prevalence of 0.2% and intensity 0.004 per 60µl blood, and antigenemia (Ag) prevalence 2.3% and 17.3 units. The Ag prevalence ranged from 0.7 to 0.9% in children 2-10 years and 2.7 to 3.0 in adults. Despite M levels <1% and Ag <2 in sentinel sites, "residual" M prevalence ≥1 was found in 7% of children and "transmission" at least one Ag-positive child during M period hotspots were identified. Antigenemic persons were clustered at household and site levels. An Ag prevalence of 1% in children (0.4 community M prevalence) was suggested as a threshold for stopping MDA. The existence of hotspots and clustering indicate the need for surveillance strategies to detect hotspots, evidence-based sampling, and evaluation size for transmission assessment surveys.
A systematic review assessed the effectiveness of temeph, an organophosphate laricide, in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other methods. The review included 27 studies, 11 single intervention and 16 combined, and found that temos consistently reduced entom indices when used alone, but not when combined with other interventions. The effectiveness of tem was dependent on factors such as delivery quality, water turnover, type, and environmental conditions like debris, temperature, and sunlight. Timing of deployment and reapplication, application reluctance to drinking water, cost, supplies, time, and labor were limitations. When used as a single intervention, tem was effective in suppressing entom indices, but not when combined with other methods. There is no evidence that tem use reduces deng transmission. The review highlights the effectiveness of tem in controlling Aedes breeding sites, but not when combined with other interventions. No conclusive evidence shows the impact of tem on d transmission.
Researchers have studied how the cohesion complex, a protein that holds sister chromatids together during cell division, is established at the pericentere, the region surrounding the centromere. They found that two complexes, C19 and C3, play distinct roles in this process. The C19 complex ensures cohes is loaded onto the perentere before DNA replication, while C3 is crucial for cohes to hold sister chromatids together after replication. Without C19, cohes is reduced at the perere, leading to problems with chromosome segregation. Without C3, cohes is present but not functional, also causing segregation issues. Cells lacking both C19 and C3 show additive defects. Delaying replication rescues the defect in C19 but not C3. The study suggests C19 loads cohes at the centere before replication, ensuring its incorporation through a process requiring C3. Two C19 proteins, I3 and Ch4, direct cohes to the perere during mitosis and meiosis. Without I and Ch4, cohes at the perere is reduced, affecting sister chromatid cohesion. This pathway is essential for cohes to be in place before replication. C3 ensures the integrity of the replisome and its association with cohes as it traverses the centrom. The study found I and Ch4 localized at the centere, despite influencing cohes in the perere. The C19 complex plays a similar role in perenteric cohesion during mitosis and meiosis. C19 and C3 are conserved, raising questions about whether this mechanism operates in other organisms with perent heterochrom.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a widespread arbovirus that infects an estimated 100 million people annually, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. Dengue fever (DF) and deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF) are major public health concerns. To understand the underlying mechanisms of deng pathogenesis, researchers analyzed the serum metabolome and lipidome of adult patients at three stages of infection: early fever, defervescence, and convalescence. Using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry, they identified 60 differential metabolites, mainly fatty acids, acylcarnines, phospholids, and amino acids. Perturbed pathways included fatty biosynthesis, β-oxidation, phosphid catabolism, and steroid. These changes suggest a multifactorial host response. Analysis of phosphids and sphingids revealed trends associated with lymphocytes and platelets, which normalized at convalescent stage. These metabolites may be prognostic markers. DENV causes distinct serumome and lipidome changes, with many involved in inflammatory responses. The study reveals anti-inflammatory responses modulate early pro-inflammatory processes, preventing pathologies. This is the first omic approach to host responses, offering physiological insights into DF self-limiting.
Research on neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) has increased in recent years, but significant gaps in diagnostic and treatment remain. Analyzing bibliometric data from research is a powerful method to reveal research efforts and partnerships. This study aimed to map NTD research in Germany and its partners to enable informed and transparent evaluation of German contributions. A Scopus database search for articles with German affiliations published between 2002-2012 was conducted for kinoplast and helminth diseases. Open tools were used to clean and analyze data (OpenRefine), geocode (OpenMaps) and create (TableNet) visualize and co-author networks (Gephi). From 26,833 publications worldwide, 1,187 (4.4%) had at least one German affiliation, and 972 were processed for five most published diseases. 4,007 authors and 863 institutions were extracted to construct co-author networks. Most co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries, Brazil. Collaborations with Africa remained scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. Strong performers were identified on individual level using parameters (publications, h-index) and network (between centrality). Network varied between diseases. Share of NTD publications with German affiliations was half of other medical fields. This underlines need to identify and expand Germany's strong research towards NTD. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad can support decisions to strengthen capacity, particularly low-middle countries less involved than high. Identifying knowledge within researcher complements traditional indicators opportunities for collaboration.
In Haiti, a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helmin (STH) has been implemented since 2000 by the Ministry of Health and its international partners. By 2012, the program had reached national scale with high epidemiological coverage, allowing treatment for almost all of the country. Key elements of success included community awareness through multi-channel education, voluntary distributors, community trust through training and supervision, directly observed treatment, easy access, and data-driven strategies. High coverage (100% in 2012) and significant reduction in infection (45 communes reached LF threshold) demonstrate effectiveness. Haiti's campaign, with international support, achieved progress toward elimination and a strong foundation for STH control. Strategies, described, establish global best practices for NTD control and address future challenges: maintaining STH control after LF treatment and morbidity management for lymphatic disease.

The likelihood of taking treatment was associated with knowledge, disease understanding, transmission, strategy, risk, and side effects in studies. However, in Haiti, knowledge was low and not associated with MDA participation. In Grand'Anse, with 72% prevalence in 2001, decline was less pronounced, remaining 55. Results show progress addressing STH, but highlight continued support after MDA ceases. A successful campaign was launched in 200 with high rates, progress toward elimination (more rounds in high prevalence, fewer in low). A foundation for STH control was established. Factors determining treatment were (1) knowing MDA and (2) ease of access. Direct observation increased participation in other settings.

Haiti now focuses on morbidity efforts, building on hydro surgery and lymphema support groups.
Researchers studied the role of the master regulator Ctr in controlling the cell cycle of Sinorhizob meli, an alphrote bacterium that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume hosts. The cell cycle is crucial for genome replication, segregation, and division in some bacteria, also for morphological and functional differentiation. In symbiosis with legume, S meli undergoes cellular differentiation, resulting in genome amplification, branching, elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The researchers found that depletion of Ctr causes elongation, branching, and genome amplification, similar to nitrogen-fixing bacteroids. They also showed that cell cycle regulated proteolytic degradation oftr is essential in S meli, suggesting a mechanism oftr depletion in differentiated bacteroids. Using ChIP-Seq and gene microarray analysis, they found that S meltr regulates similar processes as Ctr, but through different genes. For example, tr does not control expression of F complex to timing cell division, but negatively regulates sept-inhibiting Min system. This study provides insight into how conserved networks evolve to fit diverse lifestyles of bacteria. The model oftr cell regulation in mel will help elucidate how bacterial cycle is modulated by plant during symbiosis.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes the zoonotic disease tularemia. To survive and multiply inside host cells, it needs to evade the immune system. Researchers studied a library of mutants of the F. tularens vaccine strain LVS to find a gene responsible for intracellular growth. They found a gene called ggt, which encodes a glutamyl transpeptase, an enzyme that breaks down glutathione (GSH) and glutylcysteine. The ggt mutant had impaired intracellular growth and was less virulent in mice. The study shows that F. tulns uses SH and glutylcystine as cystine sources for intracellular growth. SH is the most abundant cystine in the host cytos. This is the first demonstration of a nutrient system essential for F. tulns intracellular multiplication. F. tulns has adapted to use SH as a cystine source in the host cytos, an example of bacteria-host adaptation.
Researchers studied how two types of Leishmania parasites, Leishmania amazonensis and Leish major, interact inside host cells. These parasites alternate between two forms: flagellated promastigotes in insects and round amastigotes in host cells. Leish amazonensis amastotes occupy large vacuoles with many parasites, while Leish major amastotes are in small, tight vacuoles that divide. To see if these vacoles can fuse, scientists infected mouse cells with non-fluorescent Leish amazon amastotes and 48 hours later added fluorescent Leish majorast or promastigotes. They used time-lapse imaging and found that Le major promastotes fused with pre-existing Leish amazon vacoles. In these chimeric vacoles, majorast remained motile and multiplied but didn't turn into amastotes. In contrast, infected cells with separate vacoles, Leish major promast were destroyed or differentiated into amastotes. The study shows that Leish vacoles, made by majorast or promast, differ in their ability to fuse with Leish amazon vacoles. A species-specific mechanism is required for Le majorast differentiation, which is unknown. This research will help understand interactions between Leish vacoles and mechanisms of recognition and fusion.
Researchers have been working to develop a vaccine that can elicit broad neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) against HIV-1, a type of antibody that can block the virus from infecting cells. To achieve this, they investigated the ability of native, membrane-expressed HIV Env trimers to elicit nAbs. In a study, two groups of rabbits were immunized with virus-like particles (VLP) expressing trimers (trimer V) and one group with DNA expressing Env trimer followed by protein (DNA). The results showed that both groups developed potent n titers that neutralized quatern epitopes, exploiting gaps in the glycan shield of the conserved region of JRFL gp120. Specifically, trimer V took advantage of the absence of a glycan residue at position 197, present in 98.7% of Envs. Removing this glycan made 50-67% of clade 2 isolates sensitive to trimer V sera, showing neutralization masked by the glycan. Neutral sera targeted epitopes overlap the CD binding site, suggesting the glycan acts as a "fence" limiting access. Bioinformatics analysis showed features of one trimer V sera similar to monoclonal PG9. The DNA trimer took advantage of absence of gly at 230, proximal to CD site, similar to monoclonal 8, albeit lacking breadth. The study shows strain-specific holes in gly shield can elicit nAbs to native spikes, and cross-neutralization can occur without gly. These findings inform future development of nAb vaccine.
Researchers have investigated the healing process of Buruli ulcers (BU) in patients treated with antibiotics using immunohistochemistry to identify markers that can monitor wound progression. Traditionally, surgery has been the main treatment for BU, but a combination of oral rifampicin and intramus streptomycin has improved outcomes and reduced recurrence rates. However, managing extensive lesions after treatment remains a challenge, particularly in African countries where the disease is most prevalent. The study analyzed tissue specimens from eight patients with BU lesions before and after treatment for the presence of markers associated with connective tissue formation, remodeling, and epidermal activation. Several proteins were found to be suitable for monitoring healing. α-smooth muscle actin positive myofiblasts were not present in untreated lesions but emerged during healing, producing extracellular matrix proteins like pro-collagen and tenascin. After treatment, cells including myoflasts showed an activated phenotype with ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a marker for translation. Healing wounds also showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 in the epidermis. The study identified a set of markers to monitor healing in treated BU lesions by immunohchemistry, which may help understand delays in some patients.
Researchers studied how mitochondria, the energy-producing structures within cells, move along axons, the long extensions of nerve cells, in living mice. They used a special imaging technique to track mitochondria movement in saphous nerves, a type of nerve, in anesthetized mice. The goal was to understand how mitochondria respond to electrical activity in axons, which can be far from the cell body and have high energy needs.

The study found that low-level electrical activity increased mitochondria movement in both forward and backward directions. Higher activity, within a normal range, increased forward movement but not backward. This was due to more mitochondria becoming mobile and moving faster.
