Capsaicin, a substance, applied to skin innervated by saph nerve, increased mitochondria movement in both types of axons. Additionally, mitochondria in active axons became shorter, suggesting they divided to supply more to the moving population.

Mitochondria did not accumulate at nodes, areas of high activity, but continued moving forward. This suggests sensory axon terminals have high metabolic needs during high activity. Most mitochond are made in the cell body, so increased forward movement may ensure uniform density along axons during high load, supporting increased demand.

The study showed a relationship between activity and mitochondria movement in normal, myelinated and unmyinated mammalian axons in vivo. No difference was found in membrane potential between forward and backward moving mitochond. Increased forward movement with stimulation suggests mitochond may accumulate in distal axons.
Researchers studied a genetic disorder called spondylocarparsal synostosis (SCT), which causes progressive vertebral fusions due to a loss of function in a protein called Filamin B (FLNB). FLNB acts as a scaffold, linking the actin cytoskeleton to signaling systems, but the disease mechanisms are unclear. Using a mouse model without FLNB, they found that intervertebral discs (IVD) undergo rapid degeneration during development due to abnormal cell changes in the annulus fibros (AF). AF cells lose their fibroblast characteristics and become hypertrophic chondrocy, with hallmarks of endochondral ossification, including collagen changes, apoptosis, and ossification. This is due to increased TGFβ and BMP signaling via Smad2/3 and p38, and activation of canonical and non-canonical genes p21 and Ctg. FLNB is involved in attenuating TGF/BMP signaling, influencing AF fate. The study shows IVD disruptions resemble degenerative discs, revealing molecular causes of vertebral fusions and degeneration.

In the absence of FL, Tβ and BMP signaling is increased in vitro and in vivo, demonstrating FL is required for attenuation of T/B signaling. The AF undergoes ectopic differentiation to chrogenic lineage in IVD, leading to abnormalochond ossification. Phenotyp findings resemble aging degeneration, providing a model for degenerative disease. Previous studies interpreted increased T/B within deg discs as repair effort extracellular matrix. Elevated p-Smad and 3 in chrocy before IVD degeneration suggest increased T and BMP as consequence of FL loss initiates cell changes, degeneration and fusions.

Loss of FL in mice produces AF from fibrous to cartilaginous fate, disrupting nucleus, leading degeneration, collapse, and vertebral fusion. This results from upregulation of T canonical and non-canonical pathways. FL interacts with Sm2 and 3, mediators of T and BMP, respectively. FL is expressed in cartilage and cartilagons developing vertebra.
Researchers have discovered a new way in which a virus can evade the immune system. The virus, called Thog virus, targets a protein called TFI, which is important for the immune response. By moving TFI out of the cell's nucleus, the virus reduces the immune system's ability to fight off the infection. However, this doesn't stop all gene expression in the cell. Only certain genes that need TFI to start producing proteins are affected. These genes include those that help fight the virus and cause inflammation.

The immune system is made up of many parts that work together to fight infection. The researchers found a way to target just one part, TFI, without affecting the rest of the cell's functions. This is useful for the virus because it can stop the immune from fighting while keeping the rest of the cell working. This could be a way to treat unwanted inflammation.

The virus targets TFI by using a part of itself, called ML. This stops certain genes that need TFI to start from making proteins from being made. These are genes that help fight the virus and cause inflammation. Other genes that don't need TFI to start can still be made. Genes that need TFI to start are mostly those that help fight the virus and cause inflammation.

Another virus, Thog virus, also targets TFI. But it doesn't stop all gene expression. Instead, it stops genes that help fight the virus from being made. This is different from another virus that also targets TFI, which stops all gene expression.
Parvovirus B19 (B19) infection of human erythroid progenitor cells (EPCs) causes cell cycle arrest at both late S-phase and G2, containing 4 DNA. The virus induces a DNA damage response (DDR) that facilitates viral replication but is not necessary for G2 arrest. A putative terminal activation domain (TAD) within NS1 is responsible for G arrest. To understand the mechanism of B19 NS-induced G2 arrest, researchers created doxycine-inducible B19-permissive UT/E-S cell lines expressing NS or NSmT2 and examined the function of T2 during G arrest. Results confirm NS T2 plays a role in G arrest Mechanistically, NS activated gene expression through T, responsible for ATR (ataxia-telated and Rad-related) activation. Activated A phosphorylated CDC25 at serine, inactivating cyclin B/CD1 complex without affecting nuclear import. Importantly, ATR-CHK-CDC25-CD1 pathway is activated during B19 infection EPC, and A plays a role in G arrest. 

B19 infection induces DDR essential for replication, but has no effect on G arrest. The mechanism of B NS-induced G arrest is crucial, particularly the role of T2 in cell cycle dysregulation. Previously, B19 NS protein disrupts cycle via T and viral replication is not necessary for arrest. B-infected cells arrest at S and G contain 4 DNA. Results show ATR plays role in G arrest mediated by T, and ATR-CHK-C25-CD1 pathway is activated in G. During B infection, viral replication contributes minimally to BrU incorporation. Expression of NS alone induces G arrest, characterized 4 DNA without BrU.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes a range of diseases from mild to life-threatening, characterized by endothelial dysfunction and vascular leakage. The virus's non-structural protein 1 (NS1) has been shown to induce endothelial hyperperability in mice and human endothelial cells by disrupting the endothelial glycocalyx layer. Researchers investigated the role of inflammatory mediators and endothelial-intrinsic pathways in this process. They found that DENV NS, but not a related West Nile virus NS, triggers vascular leak in the dermis of wild-type mice. In vitro, human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV NS did not produce inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8), and blocking these cytokines did not affect DENV-induced endothelial hyperability. Further, DENV induced leak in TLR- or TN- receptor-deficient mice at similar to wild-type levels. Blocking DENV-induced leak in vivo using glycocal disruption inhibitors was also effective. These results indicate D NS-induced endothelial vascular leak is independent of inflammatory cytokines but dependent on glycocal components. This suggests potential targets for therapeutics that inhibit glycocal degradation for severe deng treatment.
In budding yeast, the formation of a septin ring at the site of bud emergence is crucial for proper cytokinesis, spindle positioning, and the spindle position (SPO) checkpoint. The PO checkpoint delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis if the anaphase spindle does not align with the division axis. Researchers found that two ubiquitin ligases, Dma1 and D2, control septin dynamics and PO by promoting the recruitment of Elm1 kinase to the bud. Cells lacking Dma and D2 showed reduced Elm levels at the bud and Elm-dependent Kin4 activation. Artificially recruiting Elm to the bud restored normal septin ring, spindle positioning, and PO in Dma D2 cells. This indicates that septin dynamics and PO function are linked and the integrity of the bud is crucial for PO signalling.
Humans have adapted to live in a wide range of environments, and natural selection has likely played a key role in their ability to survive and thrive in extreme climates. Researchers scanned the human genome for signs of selection by looking at single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that are strongly linked to climate across 61 populations worldwide. They found a higher number of SNPs that affect gene function compared to those that don't in SNPs that are strongly linked to climate. Some of the strongest signals match those found in genetic studies of diseases, including pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. The researchers also found strong signals in genes related to UV radiation, infection, and cancer. This suggests that climate has shaped the distribution of human variation.

The study looked for evidence of selection in response to climate variation. Climate affects the spread of diseases, so many signals match SNPs associated with immune response in genetic studies. This suggests the analysis detects pressures due to climate or mediated by climate. The study found selection at individual SNPs identified in genetic studies, sets of genes in cardiovascular and immune diseases, and sets of response to chemical and genetic changes. Common themes are genes and variants in pigmentation, UV, immune, autoimmune, and cancer.

A subset of SN with strong signals for climate were also associated with traits in genetic studies. Some are implicated in pigmentation and autoimmune. The study used allele data to test adaptations to climate at the genome level and identified loci that underlie adaptations. Several genome scans have been conducted in humans, but only two used environment to detect selection on a scale. The strongest signals for climate in subsets show patterns in specific regions. Despite fewer populations, a significant enrichment of functional SN with climate compared to non-functional in all subsets was found.
Researchers have studied the genetic condition known as short QT syndrome (SQTS), which is characterized by a shortened QT interval in the heart's electrical cycle and increased risk of abnormal heart rhythms and sudden death. They focused on the SQ1 variant linked to a mutation in the delayed rectifier potassium current (IK) channel, encoded by the KCNH2 gene. Using computer models, they simulated the effects of this mutation on the heart's electrical activity and found that it increased the risk of abnormal heart rhythms. In single-cell models, the mutation shortened the time it took for the heart cells to repolarize and reduced the differences in electrical activity across the heart muscle. However, in a more complex model of the heart tissue, the mutation increased the risk of abnormal rhythms due to uneven distribution of electrical activity. The study found that the mutation facilitated the formation and maintenance of abnormal electrical waves in the heart, making it more susceptible to arrhythmias. This is the first study to show the link between the mutation and increased risk of abnormal heart rhythms in SQ1.
Researchers have developed a new model using deep networks to study the collective behavior of zebraf, a type of small fish. The model is both predictive and insightful, meaning it can accurately describe the motion of individual fish in a group and the interactions between them. The model uses two parts: a pair-interaction network, which describes the interaction of one fish with its neighbors, and an aggregation network which combines these interactions. The pair network takes 6 inputs and produces 128 outputs, while the aggregation network combines these to a single number. The model was tested on simulated and real data of 60-100 zebraf and found that interactions can be repulsive, attractive, or aligning, but only when moving slowly. At high speeds, interactions are alignment or repulsion at close distances. The model also found that each fish decides where to move by averaging information from neighbors, with more weight given to those close, in collision, or moving in front or laterally. The number of interacting individuals is dynamic, typically 8-22, with 1-10 most important. This suggests each fish selects information from the collective.
Researchers have developed a new method to measure the impact of HIV drug resistance mutations on the virus's ability to spread from person to person. This is important because drug-resistant HIV is a major threat to long-term success of antiretroviral treatment. About 10% of new HIV patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant HIV-1. The study used data from the Swiss HIV cohort and drug resistance database to model the spread of resistant and sensitive strains. They found that one mutation in the protease gene made the virus more infectious, while six mutations in the reverse transcriptase made it less infectious. The other mutations had no significant effect on the virus's ability to spread. This method can help assess the risk of drug resistance in areas with limited resources.
Researchers have found that a protein complex called Elong, which includes histone acetylase Sin3/El3, plays a crucial role in modifying transfer RNAs (tRNAs) to regulate translation efficiency. In yeast cells lacking Elong subunits, transcription is defective. However, Elong also mediates the modification of some tRNAs, modulating translation efficiency. The study shows that fission yeast Sin/3El3 is important for oxidative stress survival. The transcription program governed by Sty1-Atf1-P1 pathway is affected in mutant cells, but not severely. Cells lacking Sin3/3 cannot modify uridine wobble nucleotide of tRNAs and other tRNA activities such as Ctu-C2 are essential for normal tolerance to H2O. A plasm overexpressing tRNALUU complements stress-related phenotypes of Sin3El3 mutant. Main H2O-dependent genes, including transcription factors At1 and P1, are highly expressed mRNAs with biased lysine codons. These mRNAs are poorly translated in stress cells lacking Sin3 or C2, whereas mutated At1 with AAG codons is efficiently translated in all backgrounds. The study shows that lack of functional Elong results in stress due to tRNA modification and translation inefficiency of stress-induced mRN.
Researchers have discovered a new function of the HIV protein Nef, which makes the virus less sensitive to certain antibodies that target the membrane-proxternal region of the Env protein gp41. This region is crucial for the virus to infect cells and cause AIDS. The study found that Nef makes the virus 50 times less sensitive to two potent antibodies, 2F and 4, that target this region. In contrast, it had no effect on other antibodies that target different parts of Env. This effect was seen in various HIV-1 and SIV isolates, including viruses that infect different types of cells. Analysis of N mutants showed that this activity requires Nef to be attached to the membrane, but is separate from other functions like increasing infectivity and downregulating CD4. Glycosyl-G, a protein from a different virus, substituted for Nef and had the same effect, indicating this is conserved in viruses without N. The study suggests N alters Env recognition in the virus membrane, making it harder for antibodies to bind. N and Glyyl-G decreased efficiency of virus capture by 2 and 4, but not other antibodies. This new function of N has implications for HIV immunity and AIDS progression.
Researchers studied the genetic changes that occur in a snail hosts when infected with the liver fluke parasite Opisthorchis vivini, which causes cholangiocarcinoma in the Mekong region of Thailand. The snail, Bythia siam gomphos, is the intermediate host of the parasite. The study used high-throughput sequencing and bioinformatics to compare gene expression in infected and uninfected snails. They found 7,655 differentially expressed genes associated with 43 biological pathways, including immune response to parasites. Genes encoding proteases were downregulated in infected snails, while heat shock proteins and actins were upregulated. The study lays groundwork for understanding how the parasite colonizes the snail host. The dataset is a resource for studying susceptibility and resistance mechanisms of the snail to the parasite.
Researchers investigated the role of complement receptor 1 (CR1, also known as CD35) in the susceptibility to leprosy, a public health issue in Brazil. They studied CR1 polymorphisms, gene expression, and soluble CR levels in a case-control study with 213 lepro patients (47% multibillary) and 297 controls. The most common haplotype harboring rs926*T in intron 21 and rs700*T in exon 26 presented twice higher susceptibility to lepro (OR=2.43, p=0.017). Paibillary patients with these variants had lower CR levels, reducing anti-inflammatory response (p=0.040 and p=0.046). The most haplotype increased susceptibility to multib clinical form (OR=3.04, p=0.01) and presented intronic rs343*G allele, associated higher gene expression (p=0.043), probably increasing parasite internalization. There was an inverse correlation between CR and mannose-binding lectin (initiator of lectin pathway, recognized by CR) (R=-0.52, p=0.007). The study suggests a regulatory role for CR1 polymorph on mRNA and CR levels, haplotype effects increasing lepro, probably enhancing phagocytosis and inflammation.
Researchers have used a comprehensive approach combining metabolomics and genomics to investigate how genetic variations affect biological processes at the molecular level. They analyzed data from over 3,300 individuals and found significant differences in serum metabolite concentrations between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites. The study also identified genetic differences in the CPS1 locus, a gene related to carbonyl-phosphate synthase, for glycine. The results show that metabolite profiles of males and females are distinct, and specific genetic variants in metabolism-related genes contribute to these differences. This study highlights the importance of considering sex-specific effects in research design and interpretation. 

The researchers assessed the effect of sex on serum metabolites in a large cohort and investigated sex-specific genetic determination of metabotypes. Their findings provide insights into the sex-specific architecture of the human metabolome and potential mechanisms explaining differences in disease susceptibility and progression between males and females. A meta-analysis revealed 113 metabolites with significant sex effects. The study also examined correlations between metabolites and how sex effects propagate through the metabolic network. To identify genetically determined metabotypes, researchers used a subset of participants and replicated in independent cohorts. Genome-wide association analysis adjusted for age and BMI showed significant sex effects in 102 metabolites, including amino acids, acylcarnines, phosphatidolines, and sphingomyins.
Researchers have been using genome-scale metabolic networks to model the relationship between a cell's genetic makeup (genotype) and its function (phenotype) through simulations. However, the large solution space of possible metabolic states makes optimization necessary to predict the active state under specific conditions. The objective function used in optimization is linked to the biological model's underlying hypothesis, making it a crucial parameter for successful modeling. Current methods use a combination of fluxes to formulate the objective, but show sensitivity to stoichiometry representation of the network, leading to different results with numerically equivalent but biochemically representations. This makes interpretation subjective and ambiguous. A new method, Minimization of Metabolites (MiBl), decouples stoichiometry from objective formulation by using metabolite turnovers instead of flux. Simulations demonstrate stoichi representation independence for unambiguously linking results with biological interpretation. For example, Mi allowed expanding metabolic modeling of genetic interactions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the distribution of plague, a highly virulent and re-emerging disease, and the genetic structure of the black rat population, Rattus rattus, the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. They conducted a comparative study of seroprevalence and genetic (microsatellite markers) in rat populations from four geographic areas differing in topology, covering 150-200 km within the Madagas plague focus. The results showed that serreval levels in rat populations mimicked those reported for humans, and populations displayed more genetic structure with increasing relief. However, the relationship between serval data and genetic differed between areas, suggesting plague distribution not solely related to rat dispersal. Genetic estimates suggested plague epizotics had weak impact on population sizes. In highlands Madagascar, plague cannot be accounted for solely by dispersal of reservoir. Human activities may be involved in spreading disease in rat and human populations.
Researchers investigated the Schistosoma mansoni Ly6 (Sm6) family, a group of proteins on the parasite's surface that helps it stay inside the host for a long time. They found 11 members of this family, including 3 new ones, and confirmed that one of the previously known proteins, Sm29, has a unique structure. These proteins are likely attached to the parasite's surface. To see if they trigger an immune response in humans, the researchers looked at IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies in a group of infected Ugandan men before and after treatment with praziquel. Before treatment, 7.4% and 25.3% of the group had IgG against Sm6A and SmB, respectively, higher than 2.7% against another surface antigen SmAL. After treatment, IgG against SmA and SmB dropped, while Ig against SmAL rose. This study expands the number of Sm6 proteins and shows that SmA and SmB trigger an immune response in infected communities.
Researchers have created a computer simulation to study how cells in the fruit fly retina develop their shape during tissue formation. They found that a protein called cadherin, which helps cells stick together, plays a crucial role in determining the details of their shape. The simulation can explain data from normal and mutant cells that lack or have too much of this protein. The model shows that cadher's timing and how it changes in cell connections between cells are important for shape. It also suggests that cadher is moved from inactive to active areas, changing how strongly cells stick together.

The study confirms that cell adhesion is key in sorting and shaping tissues, as seen in previous research. The simulation specifically looks at the fly retina, where cadher's role goes beyond just sorting and affects geometry. The model reproduces shapes of normal and mutant cells and highlights cadher dynamics, showing its importance in adhesion and timing.

The model includes features like cadher recycling, expression, and cell contact changes without extra parameters. To understand how cadher controls shape, consider its distribution and dynamics. The researchers applied this to their model and tested with data from mutants with altered cadher levels. Cells in the retina have two adhesion molecules: E-cadher and N-cadher. All have Ead, but only cone cells have N. Cadher is in a band on the cell membrane where cells stick, the adherens junction.

The simulation shows that cadher's distribution and dynamics control geometry.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the role of a protein called MT-MT-M in the degradation of the extracellular matrix (ECM) by cancer cells. MT-M is a potent protease that helps cancer cells invade by breaking down the ECM. Previous studies suggested that a continuous supply of MT-M is necessary for this process, but the rate of MT-M turnover and its contribution to ECM degradation were unclear. The researchers used a technique called FRAP (Fluorescence Recovery After Photobleaching) to study MT-M on single invadopodia, membrane protrusions where MT localizes. They found rapid recovery of MT-M, approximated by double-exponential plots with time constants 26 and 259 seconds. This recovery depended on vesicle transport, not lateral diffusion. A computational model was built based on these kinetics and reproduced the FRAP results. Inhibiting vesicle transport blocked ECM degradation in experiments and simulations. The degree of reduction in ECM degradation depended on the degree of reduction in MT-M turnover. The study established the role of rapid MT-M turnover in ECM degradation and suggested synergy between proteolytic activity and MT-M turnover. A computational tool was developed to design intervention strategies for cancer invasion.
Researchers studied how the spread of drug-resistant HIV-1 within an infected individual by analyzing viral sequences from four macaques with a simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) containing HIV-1 reverse transcriptase. The macques were treated with inhibitors, and viral DNA and RNA were isolated from blood, lymph nodes, gut, and vagina at four time points. Single-genome sequencing revealed a dynamic process where the virus rapidly acquires resistance across compartments through multiple mutations. The blood and lymph nodes were compartmentalized, while the blood and lymph were more different from mucosal tissues. This suggests that blood sampling may not capture viral dynamics in other parts of the body, especially the gut, where RNA turnover was faster and DNA retained wild-type viruses. The study's findings of compartmentalization across tissues may explain previous conflicting results in HIV-1 compartmentalization studies.
Researchers have investigated the role of feedback in tissue morphogenesis, the process by which tissues grow and develop shape. They used mathematical modeling to show that a specific type of feedback, where both positive and negative signals act on stem and progenitor cells, leads to unique behaviors such as bistable growth, ultrasensitivity to external cues, growth, and self-organization in the form of lamellar fingers. These behaviors arise not through cell cycle regulation, but through control of stem and progenitor self-renewal. The patterns that emerge are a result of interactions between diffusible factors with opposing effects, but morphogenesis is not due to Turing instabilities.

The study found that feedback of stem and progenitor selfnew can lead to bistability and ultras, with switching between high and low or zero growth states. A necessary condition for this behavior is the presence of both positive and negative feedback. Several in vivo phenomena, such as growth bistability, ultras, and feedback-regulated morph, support this view.

The researchers showed that simultaneous positive and negative regulation of renewal by diffus signals leads to emergence of spatial dynamic behaviors, manifesting as localized growth differences. They mathematically defined conditions for phenomena like bistability, ultras, and selforganization to arise in such systems, and how they drive formation of induced or spontaneous bulges and fingers. These are basic building blocks of many morphogenesis. Although patterns arise from opposing diff factors, they are not Turing patterns.

Tissue morph often occurs quickly, relative to cell lifespan, final models may represent lineage dynamics during morph, even in selfnew tissues. The study explored effects of feedback in final systems.
Researchers conducted the largest genome-wide study to date on myopia, a common eye disorder characterized by nearsightedness, in 45,771 Europeans. They analyzed data on age of onset and identified 22 significant associations, 10 of which were novel, and replicated in a separate cohort of 8,323 participants who developed myopia before age 10. These associations explain 2.9% of variance in myopia onset and suggest multiple mechanisms behind its development. One gene, PRSS, linked to abnormally small eyes, and another, LAMA, part of extracellular matrix, were found. Two genes, RGR and RDH, involved in regeneration of 11-cis-retinal, and two, ZIC and SP1, in growth of retinal ganglion cells, were also identified. Five genes involved neuronal development and signaling were found. The study points to complex interactions between extracellular remodeling, neuronal, and visual signals from retina in myopia development in humans.
Researchers studied the role of feedback in the swimming dynamics of lampreys, a type of eel-like fish, to understand how it affects their movement and energy use. The lamprey has a central pattern generator (CPG) circuit that controls movement and adjusts to sensory inputs from the environment. Feedback is crucial for responding to unexpected changes, but also active during steady swimming and influences the pattern. The study investigated different forms of body-based feedback and their effects on swimming energy and movement. The CP was modeled as a chain of oscillators, with pairs representing left and right body segments, activating muscles to move the lamprey through a simulated fluid. The body's curvature serves as input to the oscillators, closing the loop. Two forms of feedback were considered, consistent with experimental results on lamprey sensory receptors. Directional feedback excites or inhibits oscillators on the same side, opposite on the other side. It doesn't affect frequency but changes muscle duration. Magnitude feedback provides a symmetric effect on both sides, increasing frequency and reducing energy when gain is high. Both types have similar curvature magnitude. Results show that same curvature-based feedback with different forms can cause distinct swimming differences.
Researchers studied how the spread of HIV in different populations and found that the first strain to colonize a population has an advantage over new strains. This slows down the spread of new strains and diversification of the epidemic. They developed a model to simulate HIV epidemics on contact networks and tested scenarios with varying prevalence levels. The second strain spreads slower than the first, even with equal transmission efficiency, and needs a 25% advantage to become dominant in decades. Inhibition is weaker if introduced during the first strain's growth phase. Interference mechanisms like superinfection, hub depletion, and peak infectiousness contribute to the effect. The first strain has a strong advantage in competition, explaining the virus's global geography and influencing the pandemic's evolution. 

A model showed that the most transmissible strain drives out less efficient ones, and epidemics expand as original strains are replaced by "fitter" lineages. The pace of this process needs to be characterized. A model of sexually transmitted HIV epidemics allowed monitoring competition of strains with varying transmission rates. Without conditions, the highest transmission strain in a population drives others extinct, a principle from simple to complex models. The model was based on heterosexual epidemics in Africa, adaptable to other routes and concentrated epidemics. Mechanisms can slow invasion, but the pandemic shifts between lineages occur. The expansion of HIV-1 at expense of D in Eastern Africa is an example, and data from Uganda estimated the required advantage for expansion. A stochastic model tracked HIV spread on a dynamic network of heterosexual contacts. The network consisted of males, females, and sex workers. HIV is transmitted over a limited subset of contacts, far from "free" mixing. To detect network effects, an individual simulation tracked contacts and transmission along links.
Researchers have studied how muscle cells organize their internal structure and function at different scales, from the smallest units called sarcomeres to the entire muscle bundle. To understand this complex process, they looked at how cells interact with their surroundings, specifically the space outside of the cell. They hypothesized that conditions in this space help organize the cell's internal framework, called the cytoskeleton, to form sareres. A model was created to see how the cytoskeleton of rat heart muscle cells organizes with cues from the outside space. Results showed that the cytoskeleton forms through two processes: actin fibers, myofibrils, and focal adhesions, and myofils aligning and bundling. This suggests a hierarchy of mechanisms regulates the contractile cytoskeleton, and a feedback loop from outside conditions polarizes the contractile cytos.

A model was made to mimic the assembly of sareres, where proteins assemble along actin fibers. Other models of cykeleton assembly have been reported, but this one is compared to others. Myofils mature with force, suggesting cell contractility plays a role in polarizing the network. This has been seen in non-muscle cells where cytos architecture becomes polarized with traction forces. A model was created to show how myil patterning is sensitive to outside space, to understand assembly and organization of the contract apparatus in heart cells.

Muscle cells depend on outside cues to organize myils and function. As cells mature, myils change from irregular to organized bundles. This suggests cells use outside cues to efficiently organize myils and contraction. A hierarchy of mechanisms may be responsible for myil organization. A model was used to determine which feature, fiber-force or parallel fibers, is dominant in myil architecture.
Researchers investigated the potential of Wolbachia, a symbiotic bacterium being trialed as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission, to invade and spread in wild mosquito populations. To do so, it requires high maternal transmission rates, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, and low fitness costs in the host. However, differences in climate, field protocols, urbanization, and human density amongst deployment sites have limited comparison of Wolia's invasive potential. The study examined the phenotypic effects of Wolia strain in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes with Brazilian background to characterize its invasive potential. Results showed strong cytoplasm incompatibility, high maternal transmission rates, and no detrimental effects on host fecundity or fertility. To understand urban landscape effects on mosquito survival, mark-release experiments were performed using Wolia-infected Brazilian mosquitoes in Rio de Janeiro areas where Wolia will be deployed. Mosquito populations were characterized in relation to socio-demographic conditions at sites and future release areas. Mathematical models were constructed using laboratory and field data to describe urban conditions' influence on Wolia frequency reaching 100% following release. Predicted successful invasion at five sites, but conditions vary greatly between sites, influenced by local mosquito population size. Laboratory and field data showed Melia strain Wolia possesses characteristics to spread in urban-demographic environments in Rio Janeiro, including Eliminate Program sites.
Researchers have identified a protein called JMJ703 that removes a type of epigenetic modification called histone lysine methylation from histone H3 (H3) in rice plants. This modification, known as H3me, plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression and plant development. The study found that JMJ is a histone demethylase that specifically removes all three forms of H3me: mono-, di-, and tri-methylated. Without J, rice plants have stunted growth and elongation, possibly due to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase genes. The researchers analyzed the structure of JMJ's catalytic core and found similarities with mammalian and yeast proteins that demethylate H3 and H3, but also unique features that interact with cofactors and methylated H3 peptide. Key residues are conserved in other H4 demethylases, suggesting specificity for H4 demylation. J is essential for plant cell division and stem elongation, and demethylates all three forms of Hme in vivo and in vitro. Demethylation implies J is important for gene expression in rice. Phenotype caused by T-DNA insertion and RNAi and increased CK genes suggest J regulates growth hormone metabolism in rice, distinct from J14 that functions in floral transition, DNA methylation, and silencing in Arabidopsis.
Researchers have studied the structure of the HIV-1 capsid, a protein involved in the virus's life cycle from reverse transcription to integration, and found that it interacts with multiple host and pharmacologic ligands. However, previous studies have focused on individual capsid monomers, and the mechanism of how these ligands influence infection was unclear. The team discovered that a multi-unit interface within hexamers, a form of the capsid, mediates binding to cellular cofactors NUP and CPS6 and antiviral compounds PF and BI-2. Each ligand anchors to a phenylalanine-glyine motif in the N-terminal domain of one monomer, with BI-2 also interacting across the N-terminal: C-terminal interface of a second monomer. Dissociation of hexamer into monomers prevents high affinity with CPS6 and PF, and abolishes NUP binding. The interface is conformationally dynamic, but NUP or CPS6 binding is accommodated by one conformation. N and CPS6 have overlapping sites, but unique interactions when mutated, perturb cofactor dependency.
Researchers have improved the assembly of the genome of the mosquito Aedes aegypt, which transmits diseases such as dengue fever and chikunya viruses. The mosquito has a large genome with many repetitive sequences, making it difficult to assemble. The previous assembly had 4,758 scaffolds, few of which were assigned to chromosomes. To map genes affecting disease transmission, researchers scored many single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in offspring from a cross between two strains of Ae. aegypt and generated a genetic map. This revealed a high rate of misassemblies in the genome, where sequences from different chromosomes were on the same scaffold. Once corrected, 60% of the genome was assigned to chromosomes and scaffolds ordered along chromosomes. Large regions of suppressed recombination were found around centromeres, extending up to 47% of chromosome. A gene making Ae.egi resistant to the parasite Brugia mal was mapped, and a list of candidate genes affecting the trait was generated.
Aedes aegypt, a mosquito vector of deng and yellow fever viruses, is a key target for control programs in tropical countries. Most surveillance relies on traditional larval surveys, but new devices are available. A multicenter study compared four traps (BG-Sent, Adul, MosquiAP, and ovit) with larval surveys in five cities with varying climates. Traps were used in 1km areas, simultaneously with larval surveys. Positivity and density indices were calculated and regressed against meteorological variables to characterize seasonal patterns. The House index was low in most cities, with median 0, while traps produced indices, indicating greater sensitivity to Ae. aegyti presence. Indices plateaued at high densities, but agreed on seasonality in all cities. Mosquito seasonality was associated with temperature, not precipitation, even in areas with small temperature variation. All traps outperformed the House in measuring seasonal variation and should be considered complements or alternatives to lar surveys. Choice depends on cost and ease-of-use.

A two-year study compared larval and four traps in a routine Ae. aegti surveillance program. Traps were valuable and could be combined with control strategies to improve response to deng and other diseases. Household surveys and trap systems are not interchangeable. Traps' properties (sensitivity, specificity) should be invariant and consistent under low and high abundances. Five cities with distinct climates were monitored by different traps. Temporal consist of entom indices were compared. Sensitivity to density is important for trap surveillance. CG was the best scenario to test, with strong seasonal variation. Ovaps, Adtraps and Sentels detected large variations, consistently. Household surveys identify breeding sites for control, while traps monitor infestation and impact. Together, they optimize surveillance and prevention. Future studies should assess cost-benefit of integrated strategies.
Researchers have studied the protein APOBECG3, a potent inhibitor of retroviruses and transposable elements, to understand how it restricts HIV-1. APOECG3 contains two cytidine deaminase domains, one of which is known to mediate cytidine deamination. By analyzing the structure of a related protein, APOEC2, they identified residues in APOG that could mediate oligomerization. Using yeast two-hybrid, coimmunprecipitation, and crosslinking assays, they found tyrosine and tryptan in the enzymatically inactive N-terminal domain mediate APOG oligomer and its packaging into HIV-1 virions. Oligomerization is also shown to be RNA-dependent. Modeling APO onto the A2 structure indicates a positive charge accumulation in a putative dimer interface. Substituting arginine at positions 24, 30, and 136 in this pocket reduced virus, virion, and oligomer. Consistent with RNA's central role, oligomer-deficient APO associated less with cellular molecules. They propose that RNA occupies the charged pocket, promoting oligomer, packaging, and antiviral function.
Researchers have identified the genetic variations that contribute to a significant trait in fruit flies, Drosoph melanogaster. This trait, called bric-br, affects cuticular pigmentation, or the color and texture of the fly's outer layer. The team used the fly's high genetic variation and low linkage disequilibrium to pinpoint the specific variations responsible for the trait. They found that multiple polymorphisms, or variations in the DNA sequence, in three regions near the bric gene contribute to its effect. These regions include a promoter, a tissue-specific enhancer, and a Polycomb response element, which regulate gene expression. The researchers confirmed that these variations affect transcription, or the process of turning genes on and off, at the bric locus. This study shows that a single quantitative trait locus, or QTL, can be influenced by multiple mechanisms and that variations in nearby functional elements can significantly impact gene activity and phenotype. The findings have implications for understanding genetics and genomics in both basic and medical research. 

The team sequenced the 148 kilobase region of the bric br gene in 94 inbred lines of D. melanogaster. They found that multiple polymorphisms in a single regulatory element of the ebony gene contribute to pigmentation differences between populations. Other studies have shown that multiple polymorph contribute to protein function. This suggests that accumulation of mutations at a locus may be a common mechanism for micro and macroevolutionary change. The br locus is composed of two duplicated genes, bab1 and bab, involved in patterning the abdomen, legs, and ovaries. Bab expression in the pupal epidermis is responsible for sex-specific pigmentation and changes in regulation have played a role in the diversification of D melanaster color patterns. This is in contrast to cases where large Qs are due to single or regulatory mutations with major effects. Detailed analysis of a gene responsible for 100 of a difference between D melan and D simul revealed contributions from independent regions.
Streptococcus pneumonia (pneumococcus) is a persistent cause of invasive and mucosal disease in humans, despite widespread use of antibiotics and vaccines. Its resilience is due to its ability to adapt through uptake and incorporation of new genetic material from surrounding microbial community. A tightly regulated quorum sensing system, triggered by extracellular accumulation of competence peptide (CSP), controls DNA uptake and recombination. This study shows CSP stimulates production of diverse bacteriocins through increased production and secretion of bacteriophage BlC (BlC) and requires functional competence system. A conserved motif in promoter of operon encoding BlC and its transporter mediates upregulation by CSP. Accumulation of BlC results in activation of Bl locus. Using biofilm organisms as model for competition and genetic exchange on mucosal surface, DNA exchange is enhanced by bacterin secretion, suggesting co-stimulation of bacterins with competence provides adaptive advantage. Bl and regulatory pathways are believed to have diverged in remote pneumoccus ancestor, yet maintained connection promotes competition and adaptation by targeting wide array of competitors while providing incorporation DNA.
Researchers have studied how the poliovirus, a virus that causes polio, infects cells and takes over the cell's translation machinery to replicate. They focused on two proteins, PC2 and SR20, which work together to recruit ribosomes to the viral RNA for translation. The study found that SR20 moves from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of infected cells and partially co-localizes with PC2 in the cytoplasm. They also showed that SR20 is associated with PC2 bound to polirus RNA, indicating this interaction occurs on the viral RNA. A mutated version of SR20 lacking a recognition motif was created and expressed in cells, resulting in a 100-fold decrease in virus yield compared to wild-type SR20. This suggests SR20 interacts with PC2 on viral RNA to recruit ribosomes for translation. The study supports a model where PC2, bound to viral RNA, interacts with SR20 to recruit the translation complex to viral RNA. The localization of SR20 changes during infection allows it to be available for viral translation. The study suggests a role for SR in linking splicing and translation in eukaryotic cells and provides evidence for SR in cap-dependent and cap-independent translation of certain RNAs.
Researchers used a genetic screen to identify genes involved in the development of neural crest (NC), a group of cells that gives rise to various cell types, including nerve cells and skin cells. They used a mouse model with a mutation in the Sox10 gene, which is important for NC development, and exposed it to a chemical that causes random mutations. Out of 71 lines analyzed, four mutations were found that altered NC patterning. One mutation, called m1, was studied further and found to be a new version of the ErbB3 gene, which is a receptor tyrosine kinase. The mutation changed a single amino acid in the protein, but did not affect its expression. However, it impaired the protein's ability to signal, leading to defects similar to those seen in Erb3 null mice. Biochemical analysis showed the protein was on the cell surface but had reduced ligand-induced phosphorylation. This highlights the importance of the mutated residue for Erb3 function.
Researchers conducted a study in a Ugandan community to understand factors influencing Schistosoma mansoni infection, a parasitic worm causing intestinal disease. They investigated how age, sex, ethnicity, and IgE (a type of immune response) affect reinfection after anti-parasite treatment. To control for environmental and behavioral differences, they used individual cercarial exposure scores and statistical methods. They found ethnic and sex variations in reinfection due to cercarial exposure, not biological differences in susceptibility. Age-related reinfection not explained by exposure, but linked to IgE and IgG responses to a specific antigen. This study highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in complex settings to understand population ecology and draw robust conclusions.

The study used data from a multi-disciplinary reinfection study in a Ugandan fishing community to investigate S. mansoni reinfection. To account for complex, ethnically-influenced exposure patterns, they used individual cercarial exposure scores to adjust for variations. This is supported by epidemiological studies on exposure and rein in schosmic communities, identifying individuals resistant or predisposed to infection. Genetic studies also identified genes associated with susceptibility or immunity. Small studies on risk factors for Schos infection are limited by lack of cerc exposure data, but using proxy markers like distance to infect water may not be accurate. This study derives exposure indices to reflect exposure accurately. Age profiles were typical of schos-endemic communities: infection greatest in children, lower in adults. Exposure scores investigated roles of age and sex in susceptibility, and whether Alur ethnic group is more susceptible. Schosome Ig or Ig4 responses account for remaining susceptibility variation.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the number of eggs per gram of feces (EPG) and the actual worm burden of Clonorchis sinensis in humans. A total of 60 residents, 50 egg-positive and 10-negative, in Sanche-gun, Korea, participated in the study from 2006-2009. They were diagnosed by egg positivity in feces using the Kato-K method. After administration of prazantel, they were purged with cathartics the next day, and adult worms were collected from feces. EP ranged from 0 to 65,544. Adult C. sin were collected from 17-positive, and number ranged from 1 to 114 each. A correlation between EP and numbers was demonstrated (r= 0.681, P<0.001). Recovery rates were 9.7% in EP 1-1,000 and 73.7% in EP over 1,000. No worms detected from egg-negative. Maximum count per worm per day estimated 3,770 in subject EP 2,664 and collected. Numbers correlated with egg in Cloniasis. Estimated 110 worms in body with EP around 3,000 and productivity per day around 4,000.
Researchers have developed a new approach to combat the growing problem of antifungal drug resistance by identifying genetic interactions that can be targeted to prevent resistance. They used a yeast model organism, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, to screen for genes that interact with a gene responsible for fluconazole resistance in the human pathogen Candida glata. Eighteen synthetically lethal interactions were found, one of which was a histone acetylase called G5. Deleting or inhibiting G5 made Candida cells expressing the fluazole resistant allele inviable and prevented the emergence of resistant isolates. The study shows that targeting synthetically lethal interactions can be a new way to treat drug-resistant infections. Candida strains with fluazole resistance mutations are more virulent and may adapt to antifungals, making them more disease-causing. The researchers used a combination of genome-wide screens and mutant construction to identify synthetically lethal partners of the fluazole resistant allele in Candida. Chemical inhibition of G5 prevented growth of yeast and Candida strains with the fluazole resistant allele. This proof-of-concept study demonstrates that identifying synthetically lethal interactions that confer antifungal drug resistance can identify pathways to prevent the emergence of resistance.
Researchers have studied how the poliovirus (PV) multiplies within cells, focusing on the role of phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PIP) in the process. PIP is a type of molecule found in cell membranes that changes during PV infection. The study used two PV mutants, EG and GG, which have problems processing the P3 protein, delaying genome replication and assembly. PIP changes were observed as early as 30 minutes post-infection, even in the presence of a replication inhibitor. Membrane tubules formed throughout the cytoplasm, and vesicular clusters appeared in the perinuclear region at 3 hours post-infection. The delays in replication for EG and GG were similar to PIP remodeling, suggesting PIP is a marker for the genome replication organel. GG failed to convert tubules to vesicles, resulting in nearly 5-log reduction in virus production. The study suggests PV induces distinct membrous structures for replication (tubules) and assembly (vesicles). The pace, spatiemporal dynamics, and efficiency of replication-to-assembly conversion may be set by P3 processing rate and capacity to yield 3 and 3 proteins.
Researchers used a multi-step strategy to find new compounds that can kill the parasite causing Chagas disease, a major health problem in Latin America. They searched a large database of available compounds and selected 23 to test for activity against the parasite's enzyme cruzain. 12 compounds showed strong binding to cruzain, with values in the low micromolar range, acting through a competitive mechanism. The binding mode of one of these compounds was confirmed by X-ray crystallography. Cruzain is a target for new chemotherapy for Chagas and is similar to a mammalian enzyme cathepsin, which is linked to cancer. The researchers tested cruzain inhibitors against catheps and found similar values, raising the possibility of using them for cancer treatment. To find the most effective compounds, they tested them against infected cells. Two showed trypanidal activity. One compound, Neimed42, was used to study the relationship between structure and activity. The 2-acamidothiophene-3box group was found essential for both enzyme and parasite inhibition. The compound Ne42 had a low value of 10.6±0.1 µM against the parasite form of the Tulah lac strain, better than the current drug benznidazole. A smaller version of Ne42, Ne176, was identified as a non-peptide, nonvalent cruzain inhibitor with potential for optimization.
Researchers have developed a new DNA-based vaccine against yellow fever (YF) virus, which is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical areas worldwide. The current attenuated YF vaccine generates long-lasting antibodies and T-cell responses, but can have rare fatal side effects. The new vaccine consists of two DNA formulations encoding the full-length envelope protein (pFE) or full-length protein fused to lysosomal membrane protein LAMP-1 (LFE), aiming to divert antigen presentation through major histocompatibility complex compartments. The formulations were tested in C57/6 and BAL/c mice, corresponding to C57/6 and BAL/c strains, respectively. Both induced strong T-cell responses against all epitopes generated by YF17 vaccine, with LFE performing best. Additionally, LFE stimulated high anti-Y neutralizing antibodies comparable to 17 vaccine levels. Importantly, LFE provided 100% protection against intracereally challenged mice. These results indicate LFE is an excellent candidate for further studies.
Researchers have identified a new role for the nucleoid protein SlmA in the cholera pathogen Vibrio cholera. SlmA is a transcription activator of the chb operon, which encodes genes for chitin utilization. Chitin is essential for Vibrio cholera's persistence and horizontal gene transfer in the marine environment. The sensor kinase ChiS regulates the ch operon, but the mechanism of Chi activation was unclear. An unbiased transposon screen revealed SlmA as a regulator of chb. SlmA is a member of the TetR family, typically transcriptional repressors. In vitro, SlmA binds to the ch oper promoter, and in vivo, this interaction is required for transcription and chitin utilization. Mutations show DNA-binding, not nucleoidation, is critical for activation. This study reveals a novel role for SlmA in Vibrio cholera, in addition to its established cell division function.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework for solving complex problems that arise in modeling biological systems. These problems are challenging because they involve highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations, as well as many experimental data points and parameters. The framework uses cutting-edge tools that are efficient, robust, and easy to use. It employs a time-discretization approach that avoids repetitive model simulations, enables algebraic computation of derivatives, and uses efficient solvers that exploit linear techniques.

The framework was tested on a human gut microbiome model with 156 parameters, 144 equations, and 1,704 data points. It solved the problem in under 3 minutes, while an off-the-shelf solution took over 7 hours. Large instances showed the framework's scalability, solving problems with 2,352 parameters, 2,304 equations, and 20,352 points in under 15 minutes. The framework is flexible and can be applied to various biological models, enabling tasks such as uncertainty quantification, observability analysis, model selection, and outlier handling.

Dynamic modeling is crucial for understanding biological systems like microbial communities, gene networks, and pathways. A key task in modeling is validating against data using parameter estimation. This is challenging due to solving optimization problems with differential equations. The new framework combines modern tools to create scalable, robust, easy-to-use, and flexible solutions. It was demonstrated on microbial models, enabling higher tasks like observability analysis and uncertainty quantification.

The framework's efficiency enables modeling complex systems from biomolecular to high-dimensional communities. It can construct high-fidelity models of whole-cells or microbiomes. Challenges arise from dimensionality, nonlinearity, stiffness, incomplete states, many parameters, and large data. Research has been reported on solving differential problems in biology.
Researchers used a high-throughput gene expression system called nCounter to study the inflammatory response in mice infected with West Nile virus (WNV) in the Swiss Webster (SW) mouse model. The goal was to understand how the virus spreads and how the body reacts to it. The system analyzed 179 inflammation-related genes in multiple tissues over nine days after infection. Protein levels of some cytokine/chemokine genes were also measured using a multiplex detection system. Results showed that Ccl and Ilb were differently expressed in all tested tissues except kidney. Stratification of infected versus non-infected tissues allowed differentiation of systemic response from tissue-specific responses. Significant decrease in C1 was found in non-infected spleen, while Il was upregulated, Il was downregulated in non-inf lung, and M2 were downregulated in non-liver. In-inf livers, Stat, T2, chemines Ccl, C, C, C, C, cytok, Il, Il, and Il were upregulated. In non-brain, C and C were upregulated. Gene and protein kinetics for C, C, C, C, and C correlated with virus presence. The study demonstrated the utility of nCounter for rapid identification of gene changes in mice with NV infection.
An outbreak of rabies occurred in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique in 2014, prompting an investigation into the epidemiology, clinical features, and risk factors of human and animal bites in the two cities. From April to July 2014, 14 cases of human rabies were detected in Maputo (n=10), Matola (n=3), and neighboring Boane (n=1), all with a history of recent dog bites. Only one of the 14 rabid dogs was immunized. A total of 819 animal bites were registered, with 64.6% (529) from Maputo City, with dogs responsible for 97.8% (801) of bites, but only 27% (126) were immunized. Factors associated with human rabies were age <15 (p=0.05), bite by stray dog (p=0.002), deep wound (p=0.02), bite to the head (p=0.001), by unimmun dog (p=0.01), no soap and water (p=0.001), and no post-exposure prophylaxis (p=0.01). Control measures for rabies are poor in Maputo and Matola, with cases strongly associated with stray and unvaccinated dogs and irregular post-exposure measures. The study aimed to determine clinical and epidemiological features of human rab cases, risk for developing rab, and animal bites in Map and Matola, contributing to formulating recommendations for rab control in Mozambique. This is the first investigation of rab outbreak and epidemi profile bites in Mozambique, where procedures are irregular, resulting in frequent rabies cases.
Researchers have identified a new gene, SCN9, as a potential cause of febrile seizures (FS) in a large family with significant linkage to chromosome 2q. The gene encodes the Nav1.7 subunit of the sodium channel. In 21 affected family members, a mutation was found in a highly conserved amino acid, p.N641, in the cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II, absent in ethnically matched control chromosomes. To confirm the mutation's role in seizure susceptibility, the mutation was introduced into the murine Sc9 ortholog using targeted homologous recombination. Compared to wild-type mice, homozygous Sc9/N mice exhibited reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures and increased kindling rates. These data support SCN9 as disease-causing in this family. To confirm SCN's role in FS, a collection of 92 unrelated patients were analyzed and additional conserved Nav.7 missense variants were found in 5%. One child with FS later developed Drav syndrome, severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy, and SCN was sequenced, identifying a heterozygous frameshift. Analysis of 109 Drav patients yielded 9% with Nav.7 missense variants, all in conserved amino acids. Six Drav patients with SCN miss variants had either miss or site SCN mutations or no SCN mutations. This study provides evidence for SCN's role in human epileps, both as cause and partner SCN mutations.
Researchers have long sought to understand how complex tissue shapes arise through growth, particularly when growth occurs preferentially along certain orientations, raising the question of how these orientations are specified. Two possibilities exist: orientations are specified through stresses in the tissue (axiality system) or independently through molecular signalling (polarity system). The axial system has been explored through computational modelling, while the polarity system is less understood. This study develops a polarity-based framework, called Growing Polarised Tissue (GPT), treating tissue as a continuous material with regionally expressed factors under genetic control interacting and propagating polarity established by signals anchored in tissue organisers under genetic control. Growth rates parallel or perpendicular to polarity are specified through a regulatory network. Resulting growth depends on specified patterns within tissue constraints, leading to features like curvature not directly specified by networks. Growth feeds back influencing spatial orientations and tissue, allowing complex shapes from simple rules. Asymmetries emerge through polarity interactions. The PT framework is applied to a growing Snapdragon, illustrating hypotheses testable by simulation. Combinatorial interactions between orientations and growth, key in polarity systems, have generated observed shapes.
Researchers investigated how multiple CD8 T cell responses during early HIV infection affect the emergence of mutations that help the virus evade the immune system. These responses put pressure on different parts of the virus's genome, leading to mutations that are beneficial for the virus. Some studies found that as these mutations emerge, they become less common over time, a pattern known as the "escape rate decrease" (ER). This pattern can occur due to different mechanisms, including interference between mutations in large populations with high mutation rates. In this study, the researchers looked at how interference between concurrent mutations affects escape rates in multiple parts of the virus and if it's a source of ER. They developed a model of HIV dynamics with selection, mutation, and recombination, and found that interference between equally beneficial mutations can generate ER. The number of locations and recombination rates affect ER, which can be explained by the decline of escape rates over time. The observed ER pattern in infected individuals is consistent with both interference-free and interference effects. Interference should be considered when analyzing HIV mutations, as current methods can't account for competition between mutations.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to predict the effectiveness of chemotherapy in treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) patients. The model takes into account various factors such as cancer cell growth, heterogeneity, hypoxia, and treatment resistance. It uses data from two points in time, before and during treatment, to estimate the effect of the tumor environment and cell repopulation on treatment outcome. The model was tested on 13 patients with NSCL who received cisplatin with gemcitab, vinlb, or docax in neoadjuvant context. The input values were guided by literature on cancer proliferation kinetics and patient-specific uncertainties were compensated with latin hyper sampling. The model estimated the cell killing ability of various chemotherapies, which could be used for personalized predictions based on patient molecular profiles.
Researchers studied how bacteria in biofilms develop resistance to antibiotics. Biofilms are communities of bacteria that stick to surfaces and are hard to kill with antibiotics. They found that some biofilms are more resistant to the antibiotic ofloxacin because they are starved of nutrients. This means they don't have enough amino acids and carbon to grow. The researchers used a technique called random mutagenesis to find mutants that were more resistant toloxacin. They found that these mutants were more resistant because they were starved of amino acids. They also found that the SOS response, a stress response to DNA damage, was key to this resistance. The SOS response helps bacteria survive when they are starved of nutrients. The researchers also found that the SOS response was necessary for resistance tolox when bacteria were starved of amino and carbon. However, it was not necessary when they were starved of leucine, another amino acid. Biofilms get more resistant tolox as they age, and this is also due to the SOS response. The study shows that SOS in starved biofilms is a key to their resistance toloxacin.
Researchers have identified a key regulator that helps Plasium falcumeroites invade human red blood cells. The regulator, called cAMP, triggers the release of proteins on the parasite's surface that allow it to attach to and enter the cell. The team found that when the parasite is exposed to the low potassium levels found in blood, it activates an enzyme that raises c levels and activates a protein that controls the release of these proteins. They also discovered that c regulates the parasite's calcium levels, which is essential for the release of these proteins. This discovery provides new targets to stop the parasite's growth and prevent malaria.

The study focused on the parasite's invasion of red blood cells, which causes all symptoms of malaria. The parasite multi-step process involves specific interactions between cell receptors and parasite proteins on the parasite's surface. Proteins on the parasite's apical organelles, called micronemes, are crucial for invasion. The team used pharmacological inhibitors to explore the role of a specific enzyme, Pfβ, and other players in signaling pathways that control micron secretion. They found that low potassium in blood activates Pfβ, raising c levels and activating a protein that regulates micron secretion.

The parasite has alternative mechanisms to trigger release micron release, as seen in parasites without a specific protein. Other proteins in the Pf family may also mediate calcium and micron release, but this is unknown. The study provides new targets to stop the parasite's growth and prevent malaria.
Strongyloides stercis, a soil-transmitted threadworm, is one of the most neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). A review of 20 years of studies on its global prevalence in populations and risk groups was conducted. A literature search of PubMed articles from 1989 to 2011 was performed, including those with information on infection prevalence. A Bayesian analysis was done to get country-specific estimates and compare odds in risk groups, accounting for diagnostic sensitivities. 354 studies from 78 countries were included, 62.4% community-based, 34.2% hospital, and 11% refugee/immigrant. World maps with data are provided. Many African, Asian, and South American poor countries lack S.ercis information. Meta-analysis showed association with HIV/alcoholism and Sercis (OR 2.17, CI 1.18-4.01, OR 6.69 CI 1.47-3.8). High prevalence in selected countries and regions. Sercis prominent in risk groups. Information lacking in many countries, but shows Serc must not be neglected. Further socio-economic and ecological assessments and global health integration are needed.

The study aimed to get country-wide Sercis risk and assess association with risk groups. High rates in South Asia, refugees, and immigrants reported. In developed countries, strongyias an issue for immigrants, tourists, and military returning from endemic areas. This has implications for medical services and screening before immunosuppressive treatment. Serc rates are patchy, incidence non-existent. Strongloides stercis a soil-trans nematode, one of most helth NTDs, world-wide, excluding north and south. Estimates are often guesses. Data needed for countries, socio-cultural settings. Large surveys and sensitive methods would narrow gap.
Researchers have long known that stochastic noise, or random fluctuations, plays a crucial role in circadian rhythms, influencing how groups of cells synchronize with external cues and generating internal rhythms. However, few studies have investigated how perturbations affect stochastic noise, mainly due to the difficulty in measuring it directly. This study shows that the rate of population-level bioluminescence can serve as an accurate measure of overall stochastic noise, applicable to high-throughput circadian screens. Using fibroblast data, researchers found that higher single-cell noise results in faster population damping. They also demonstrated that damping can be changed by small molecule modulators in a dose-dependent manner, and explained by single-cell noise using a mathematical model. The method was applied to a genome-wide siRNA screen, revealing stochastic altered independently of period and phase. The study suggests the unperturbed clock is optimized for robust rhythms, with few perturbations capable of increasing amplitude and lowering noise. This highlights the importance of considering circadian perturbations on stochastic, particularly in developing small-molecule circadian therapeutics.
Researchers have identified a protein called FZ as a promising target for developing new antibiotics to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria. FZ is essential for bacterial cell division, and a small molecule called PC723 has shown in vitro and in vivo activity against Staphylococcus aureus. However, its mechanism of action and effect on other bacterial species is unclear. To understand how PC723 binds to FZ, the researchers used a method called Pocket to analyze the 3D structure of the binding site and molecular dynamics simulations. They found that species and nucleotide state significantly impact the site's properties, with different environments for non-Staphlococcus bacteria. PC723 prefers to bind Stylococcus FZ in the nucleotide state, and simulations suggest polymerization enhances binding. These results show that the binding pocket can vary across species, genetic variations, and polymer states, informing the development of FZ inhibitors.
Researchers have determined the crystal structure of the N-terminal and catalytic core domains of HIV-1 integrase (IN) in complex with the binding domain of lens epithelium-derived growth factor (LEDGF), a protein that lentiviruses rely on for efficient replication. The structure reveals key interactions between the two proteins, including a constellation of acidic residues on IN and positively charged on LEDGF. These contacts are crucial for stimulating lentiviral DNA integration in vitro and during early HIV-1 replication. The findings also enabled the creation of a mutant HIV-1 integrase that only functions with a modified LEDGF. The study provides a basis for understanding the high-affinity interaction between lentiviral IN and LED and paves the way for developing LED-targeting technologies for gene therapy.
Researchers studied how cancer cells in different organs change over time and how these changes affect tumor growth. They found that cancer cells inherit traits from their original cells that determine how they behave and grow. Genetic and epigenetic changes can alter these traits, making some cells more fit and growing faster. The study used a computer model to track cancer stem cells, which can start and sustain tumors, and looked at traits like migration, death, division, and telomere length. They found that cell proliferation, or growth, is the strongest factor in tumor growth. More growth leads to more non-stem cells that compete with stem cells, while less growth allows stem cells to divide more. The stem cell population becomes diverse, with some dormant and aggressive. A single tumor sample only shows a small part of total phenotypes. 

The study looked at traits like migration, death, death, division, and telomere length. Proliferation and death modulate growth, while migration and division speed up growth. Increased death counters stem confinement and promotes expansion. This supports previous findings that death slows stem and promotes growth. Evolution leads to uneven cell distribution with varying aggressiveness. Some areas are dominated by old, while new clones are small but fit. The interplay of dynamics requires investigating combinations that yield aggressive clones. While fast growth can be pushed to slow or dormancy by mutations. Proliferation is the strongest modulator of growth.
Researchers studied the emergence of novel infectious diseases that jump from animals to humans, such as influenza A (H1N1). They used mathematical models to explore how adaptation plays a key role in establishing human-to-human transmission. The study focused on spatial heterogeneity within the human population, or how people are connected to each other. They found that for typical connections between communities, spatial heterogeneity has a weak effect on outbreak size and emergence risk. For example, a village connected to a city by 10 commuters a day is effectively part of the city for emergence and outbreak distribution. Data showed most communities are at least this interconnected. For plausible ranges, effects of heterogeneity are dominated by pathogen biology. The study suggests only remote communities are subject to epidemiological isolation. Other factors like human patterns and host heterogeneity also shape risk and speed of emergence. The study focused on spatial host population structure, which has received little attention in adapting pathogens. They modeled communities with varying connections, like a village and city. The biology of the pathogen determines emergence and outbreak size based on average reproductive number. A threshold exists where heterogeneity doesn't matter. Previous research showed heterogeneity in structured models depends on connectivity allowing spread between communities. This approach provides new insights without specifying infectious hosts migrating. The study calculated epidemiological parameters of a disease adapting to humans, exploring host structure and validating with simulations of village-city models.
Researchers studied the migration patterns of the influenza A virus in wild birds in North America over a 34-year period. They analyzed 287 sequenced avian influenza virus samples from migratory birds in Alberta, Canada and Delaware, USA. The goal was to understand how the virus spreads between different bird populations and how it affects humans and livestock. 

The study found that birds in Alberta, which is a key stopover point for four migratory flyways, has most of the genetic diversity of the American influenza virus. This is because birds in this area mix and spread the virus, creating new genetic variations. The Delaware, where thousands of birds stop to feed, is a hotspot for the virus, but does not contribute much to the virus diversity. 

The researchers also found that the virus can spread between bird populations over long distances, not just within flyways. This is important for predicting and preparing for pandemics and protecting livestock. The study used a new method to analyze large-scale patterns of viral movement between bird populations. It identified 20 areas in North America where viruses were collected from wild birds to see if populations were structured by flyways and gene flow. 

The results show that long-term persistence of the virus in wild birds is independent of flyways. This means the virus can spread between populations over time, not just within a short period. The study used 30 years of data to understand dynamics and patterns of the virus in natural hosts.
Researchers have developed a new monoclonal antibody, MAb S/1391, that targets a specific site on the hemagglutinin (HA) protein of influenza A viruses. This antibody is unique because it can neutralize multiple subtypes of the virus, including H1, 2, 3, 5, 9, and 13. In experiments showed that MAb S/1 blocked the virus's ability to attach to cells, which is a key step in the infection process. The antibody was tested on mice and provided protection against different subtypes of the virus. This suggests that MAb/1 binds to a common site on the HA protein that is shared among various subtypes. The study supports the idea that cross-reactive antibodies can play a role in protecting against influenza infection and highlights the potential of using cross-reactive antibodies as a treatment.
Researchers conducted a three-year study to assess the effectiveness of ivermectin in controlling Strongyloides steralis infection in an Australian Aboriginal population. The study involved 259 adults living in a remote community in northern Australia, where the infection prevalence was initially 35.3%. Participants were treated with iverectin and followed up at six months and three years later. The results showed a significant decrease in infection prevalence, from 35.3% to 5.8%, indicating ivermect's effectiveness. Using a lower ELISA threshold for diagnosis was also validated in this setting. However, a small group of individuals remained positive despite treatment. After three years, the infection rate fell to 1.4%, confirming the treatment's success. The study suggests that controlling Strongloides steral infection in Aboriginal adults can be achieved through case-finding and treatment, following current guidelines. The communities in northern Australia have high infection rates, up to 40%.ivermect is the accepted treatment, but there's debate on widespread testing and elimination. The study took place in three communities in Western Australia's Kimberley region, isolated from medical services. Prior to the study, systematic testing and treatment didn't occur. Diagnosis relied on serology due to logistical issues with parasitological methods. ELISA testing was done at a reference lab using a commercial kit. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a "find and treat" approach. No data on symptoms or health improvements were collected.
Researchers studied how different strains of prion, a misfolded protein that causes prion diseases, interact with each other. They hypothesized that long-incubation strains, which take a long time to develop, can block short-incation strains, which develop quickly. However, they found that co-infecting animals with combinations of long-incation strains did not show evidence of interference.
