They created a recombinant, chimeric virus (rMAC/Cd1-G) that expresses the glycoprotein from the Candid1 (Cd1) strain of JUN and found it to be completely attenuated in a murine model and protected animals from lethal challenge with MAC. However, a single mutation in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of the glycoprotein, equivalent to the attenuating mutation in Cd1, was not sufficient to fully attenuate JUN. To investigate the role of different domains of Cd1 glycoprotein in attenuation, they created several rMACs expressing the ectomain of Cd1 glyprotein alone (MC1), with the TMD substitution (MC2), or the T of Cd1 (3). All rMAC exhibited similar growth in cultured cells. In mice, MC1 showed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMAC. MC was detected in brains and spleens of MC-infected mice and associated with inflammation. On the other hand, all survived MC2 and MC3 infection without detectable virus in organs while producing neutralizing antibodies against Cd1. The study suggests the indispensable role of each glycoprotein domain in full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMAC/C1-G.
Researchers studied a protein called centromere histone 3 (CH3) that helps separate chromosomes during cell division in plants. To understand how CH3 works, they created mutant versions of the protein with single amino acid changes in its structure. Some of these mutant plants looked normal and fertile when self-poll, but produced abnormal offspring when crossed with normal plants. This is called postzygotic incompatibility and uniparent inheritance. The researchers found that a single mutation in the CH3 structure can cause this problem, similar to what happens when CH from different species are combined. They also found that a single mutation can create a haploid inducer, which is a plant that produces offspring with only one set of chromosomes. This is useful for identifying haploid inducers in crop species. They tested this by finding a mutation in CH3 in a plant and found it produced haploids when crossed with normal plants.
Researchers have explored the role of alternative splicing in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. They modified the H9 hESC line to select for pluripotent cells with neomycin resistance and cardiac progenitors with puromycin resistance. By analyzing microarray data from undifferentiated hES and cardiac precursors, they identified spliceforms with cardiac-restricted or common/neural expression patterns. These events corresponded to pathways of cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle control, as well as genes with ser/threon kinase and helicase activity. A new program, AltAnalyze, predicted changes in protein and microRNA site architecture that affect function and expression, including isoforms opposing cell arrest in hES and promoting cardiac development in prec. Genome-wide predictions combined with functional annotations suggest mechanisms influencing commitment and maintenance at the level of specific isoforms and microregulation.
Researchers have identified a potential target for developing new treatments against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium that causes tuberculosis, by studying its trehalose biosynthesis pathway. Trehalose is a sugar molecule essential for the bacterium's growth and survival. Two enzymes, T6-phosphate synthase A and T-phosphatase B, produce trehal from ADP-glucose and glucose-6-phosphate. To test the potential of Tphatase B as a target, scientists created a mutant of M. tuberculosis that can turn off the Tphat B gene. They found that Tph B is essential for the bacterium's growth in a lab and in mice, but not in chronic infections in mice. This suggests that the bacterium changes its trehal metabolism during infection. Blocking Tph resulted in the buildup of its substrate, T, which is toxic to the bacterium, leading to cell death. Blocking T production in a mutant without Tphase made Tph non-essential. The buildup of T led to the upregulation of over 800 genes, possibly due to increased RNA stability and toxin neutralization. Surprisingly, buildup of another toxic molecule, maltose-phosphate, had minimal effect. A search for genes that interact with Tase identified potential targets for combination therapies to prevent resistance to Tase inhibitors.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, affects 11-18 million people worldwide. Current treatments have poor efficacy and safety profiles. Research has identified trypanosoma cruzi proline racemase (TPR) as a potential target for improved therapy. Conformation changes associated with substrate binding to TPR expose residues that trigger a host immune response, contributing to parasite persistence and immune evasion. Characterizing TPR conformation states requires long-time motions inaccessible by standard simulations. We used accelerated dynamics to extend simulation time and capture large motions. Conservation and fragment analyses identified conformation epitopes near transient binding pockets. Newly open TPR conformations revealed by this study, along with closed-open conversion mechanism, advance understanding of TPR function. This work is a step toward rationalizing the molecular basis of TPR's mitogenic response and providing insights for structure-based drug discovery.

A crystal structure of TPR with pyr-carboxylic acid was used to build our model. Initial apo TPR coordinates were obtained by removing inhibitors. Residues like Arg and Lys were protonated, acidic like Asp and Glu deprotonated. This provides evidence that TPR is a promising target for therapies to combat Chagas. Crystallography and mutagenesis indicate ligand conformation changes in TPR modulate exposure of critical residues. Two TPR structures are available. Accelerated dynamics extended simulation time, combined with sequence and fragment analysis, indicate mitogenic properties of TPR are associated with conserved conformation epitopes around unidentified pockets. We show a model of open TPR through state-of-the-art simulation, indicating mitogenic properties may be associated with conformation epitopes around newly identified pockets.
Researchers have developed a new method to turn genes on and off at will in mice, called the inducible knockout (iKO) system. This system uses two genetically modified mice lines: one with a gene turned off and the other with a gene that can be turned on by treating with doxycycline. The gene can be inserted into a specific location in the genome using a technique called recombinase-mediated insertion. This method is efficient, cost-effective, and can be used for many genes. As a test, the system was used to turn on and off the apolipoprotein E (ApoE) gene, which affects cholesterol levels and atherosclerosis. Results showed reversible switching of AE expression, cholesterol levels, and atherosclerosis progression. The iKO system is a versatile and can be used with other techniques for various applications.

The iKO system is a binary approach based on Tet-dependent technology. It complements existing methods, such as tamoxifen-dependent CreERT, but is reversible and efficient throughout the body. The design allows for streamlined production of both KO and TRE mice, making it possible to generate iKOs for many genes in a cost-effective manner. The KO and TRE lines can be engineered independently and combined, making a range of applications possible. Two genetically modified strains are created: one with a Tet-dependent transactivator inserted into the gene, inactivating it, and the other with gene that can be turned on by doxycine. The system was tested by generating Apo iKO mice by creating Apo KO and Ap TRE lines and breeding them together, modeling human conditions like hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis.
Researchers studied the genetic response of the placenta to infection by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease. They infected mice with two different strains of the parasite, K and V, and analyzed the genetic changes in the placenta. The study found that the placenta responded differently to each strain, with some genes up-regulated and others down-regulated. The "Innate Immune Response" and "Response Interferon-gamma" pathways were upregulated in V infection, but not in K. Metabolic processes and macromolecular transport were downregulated in infected placentas. The V strain had a stronger tropism to the placenta, with parasite DNA and RNA detected. The study suggests a strong immune response, parasite-dependent to the detriment of cellular metabolism, which may prevent congenital transmission.
Sindbis virus (SINV) polyarthritis, also known as Ockbo disease in Sweden and Pog disease in Finland, has been recognized in northern Europe for about 50 years. This mosquito-borne virus is mainly found in tropical and subtropical countries, but in Europe it causes recurring outbreaks. A seven-year cycle of SINV outbreaks has been reported, but only based on human cases. To find a more objective signal, mosquito and SINV prevalence in vectors from an endemic area in Sweden were studied. Mosquitoes from the Riveräl floodplains were collected in 2000, 2001, and 2003 and assayed for virus on cell culture. Obtained isolates were sequenced and nucleotide sequences analyzed. Only SINV was found in 2001, 4 in 200, and 15 in 200, with increased rates in both enzoot and bridge vectors in 200. Maximum likelihood infection rates were 1.0/1000 in enz Cx torrentipiens and 0.62/100 in bridge Aedes in 200, compared to 0.9/100 and 0/100 in 1 and 0/100 and 0.32 in 3. Sequence analysis showed all isolates belonged to SINV I (S-I). Genetic analysis revealed four S-I clades in Riveräl floodplains over years. Increased S-I in vectors constitutes a valuable marker for scrutinizing hypothesized S-I outbreaks and mechanisms.
Researchers studied how the locust's sense of smell works, specifically how the brain processes information from the antennae to the mushroom body, a region linked to memory. They found that only a few neurons in the mushroom body responded to a specific smells, while different smells triggered different neurons. To understand this, they created a model to see if changes in connections between brain cells could control which neurons respond to familiar smells. The model showed that changes in connections between the antennal lobe and mushroom body efficiently filtered out strong signals and condensed them into a sparse representation in the mushroom. This led to specific, reliable, and long-lasting smell representations, suggesting changes in connections play a role in processing information. 

The study focused on Kenyon cells in the mushroom body, which receive information from antennal lobe neurons. These cells are crucial for smell processing and memory. Recordings in locusts showed individual Kenyon cells responded to specific smells, but not all responded to the same smell. The model explored if changes in connections between antennal lobe and Kenyon cells could tune responses to familiar smells. Results showed changes in connections efficiently filtered and condensed signals, leading to specific, reliable, and long-lasting smell representations. This is consistent with previous findings that changes between Kenyon cells and mushroom neurons are critical in smell memory.
Researchers conducted the Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene (ST) study to identify genes associated with the development of coronary artery disease (CAD). They analyzed transcription profiles of liver, muscle, fat, and atherosclerotic and unaffected arterial tissues from 278 patients undergoing coronary bypass surgery. The analysis resulted in 60 clusters of genes, with two of which were associated with the extent of stenosis in atherosclerotic arterial and visceral fat. These clusters were validated by analyzing carotid atheros expression profiles. One cluster related to carot stenosis and 27 genes to coronary stenosis were confirmed. Genes in the transendothelial migration of leukocytes (TE) pathway were overrepresented in all clusters, referred to as the atherosclerosis module (A). The A-module was found to be enriched with CAD risk by 1.8-fold. Transcription-factor LIM binding 2 (L2) was identified as a potential regulator of A, supported by subnetwork analysis and expression of 13 TE genes in L2-deficient arterial. The A-module appears to be important for atherosclerosis and L2 merits attention in CAD research.
Researchers have studied the molecular mechanisms behind the circadian clock in cyanobacteria, specifically the Synechoccus. They found that the Kai protein, a central to the circadian clock, is involved in both activating and repressing its own transcription. Over 24 hours, Kai goes through different phospho-states during the day. It was unclear which phospho-state of Kai promotes or opposes transcription activation. A new model, TT/PT, was created to analyze combinations of positive and negative transcription regulation. Only one two-loop mechanism out of 32 tested could reproduce existing observations, including effects of knocking out or overexpressing Kai genes. Phosphorylated KaiC activates and unphosphorylated Kai suppresses Kai transcription. The model suggests the ratio of positive and negative components of Kai expression is key to how two-loop models respond to removal or overexpression of genes. This model could help reveal how the circadian pathways allow Kai to control rhythmically regulate genes in the cyanobacterial genome.
Researchers studied HIV-2 infection in people with slow or no disease progression to understand why it is less severe than HIV-1. They found that HIV-2 mainly infects a specific type of immune cell called transitional-memory CD4 T cells, not central-memory CD T cells like HIV-1 does. This is linked to lower expression of a co-receptor called CXCR6 and higher expression of a restriction factor TR5. HIV-2 was not found in monocytes and only in a few central-memory CD T cells, but in many transitional CD cells. This is different from HIV-1, which infects monocytes and central-memory T cells. The study suggests HIV-2 is less adapted to infect central-memory cells and more to transitional cells. This is similar to other models of attenuated HIV/SIV infections. The researchers also found that HIV-2 is poorly adapted to the myeloid compartment, the part of the immune system where monocytes are found. The study provides new insights into why HIV-2 is less severe and how it differs from HIV-1.
Researchers have developed a new model called the Attention Routing Circuit (ARC) that explains how the brain processes selective attention in the visual cortex. This model is different from previous models because it provides a single mechanism that unifies various effects of attention, is based on individual spiking neurons, and matches physiological data, and makes testable predictions. 

The ARC model shows that attention affects how neurons respond to spatial information, but not other features like color or shape. It also suggests that different forms of attention are consequences of a single mechanism for selective attention routing. The model predicts that more neurons in higher areas of the brain will show attention modulation as they switch from default to selective state during demanding tasks. The magnitude of modulation will increase in higher areas. 

The model was tested on macaque studies and matched several forms of attention modulation. It demonstrated that shifts of attention cause shrinking of receptive fields, increased responses without changes in selectivity for non-spatial features, and that effect on contrast functions is better explained as response-gain than contrast-gain. This model overcomes limitations of past models by providing a unified explanation of attention effects, being implemented in spiking, defining attention modulation across areas, comparing to data, and making predictions.
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common and debilitating arrhythm that affects millions of people worldwide. While many genes have been linked to AF, most were identified in small studies, and their contribution to the condition is not well understood. Researchers analyzed whole-exome data from 1,734 individuals with AF and 9,423 without AF from three large studies: Framingham, Atherosclerosis Risk Communities, and NHLBI Exome Sequencing. They looked for genetic variations in 37 suspected AF genes and 99,404 common variants. None were significantly associated with AF after adjusting for testing. A common variant in SYN2 was associated with AF, but its role is unclear. Rare variants in AF genes were not significant. Individuals with AF did not have more common or rare variations in implicated genes. The study suggests that large-effect coding variation is not the main cause of AF. A variant in SYN2 needs further study to determine if it causes AF. To find meaningful genetic variations, large samples or populations with large effects are needed.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 cases of alveolar echoccosis (AE) were diagnosed in Poland, with 83.6% classified as confirmed, 16 as probable, and 22 as possible. The number of cases increased over the two decades. The average age at diagnosis was 47.7 years, with a male to female ratio of 0.86:1. The disease was fatal in 19% of patients, with an average age at death of 54.1 years. Aggregation of AE was found in 4 foci involving 9 patients, and 76 cases were diagnosed in an advanced stage. The liver was the primary location in all cases, with 24.8% showing spread to other organs. 94 patients were treated with albendazole and 73 underwent surgery, including 15 liver transplants. Studies show AE is an emerging disease in Poland, the 4th in Europe with over 120 cases. Results indicate a need for a national screening program in high-risk areas (northern Poland) and public awareness of E. multular and training primary physicians for early detection.
Researchers studied how the zinc-sensing protein Zur in E. coli responds to changes in zinc availability at the molecular level. They solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PnuABC promoter and found that it represses gene expression by binding cooperatively to two dimers around the core of regulated promoters. Cooperativity requires a pair of salt bridges between Arg and Asp that connect independent dimers. Analysis led to the discovery of a new regulon, pliG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-dependent manner. The plG forms complexes with one or two dimers with less cooperativity than other regulon promoters. Comparison of Zur-DNA binding at four regulon promoters shows a 10,000-fold variation in binding constants. The degree of repression in vivo matches this trend, with a 100-fold difference in transcript copy number between wild-type and Δzur strains. This suggests that the number of Fur dimers that bind varies and the thermodynamics of Zur-D interactions correlates with response at different promoters.

The study supports the idea that thermodynamics of protein-DNA interactions control gene regulation. The findings open how zinc and metal occupancy at a subset of sites in the repressor can fine-tune stress expression across promoters. Mutant proteins were expressed, isolated, and evaluated in metal, DNA, and dimer assays. Analysis by ICPMS shows they can be loaded with zinc, but less than wild-type Zur. A test of zinc activity showed E. coli switches off with Zn+ in the sub-molar range, corresponding to one zinc atom per cell. This suggests bacteria are intolerant of free zinc under normal conditions. Previous studies suggest subtle modulation of Zur-D affinities at promoters in response to zinc and implicate zinc sites in Scur. Our results reveal a layer of tuning based on affinities of saturated dimers for various regulons.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a zoonotic disease that affects livestock, causing high morbidity and mortality. In 2008-2009, a RV outbreak occurred in Madagascar, including the Anjoabe district in the highlands. An entomological surveys found no Aedes mosquitoes, the RV virus vector, and low mosquito abundance due to unfavorable climate conditions. No serological or virological signs of infection were found in wild mammals, suggesting no RV virus reservoir. However, three serological and virological follow-up in cattle showed RV circulation. To understand this, a spatial deterministic metapulation model combined with cattle trade network was designed to reproduce local conditions. Three scenarios explained RV circulation: i) RV overwintering due to direct transmission between vemic cows, ii) low vector circulation due to residual population, iii) combination. Multi-inference resulted in low vector-borne transmission and direct between animals. Predictions matched 84% vector-borne, 16% direct. Sensitivity analysis confirmed results. Interactions between agriculture, vector seasonality, and cattle practices are key to RV circulation in Madagascar highlands.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is an invasive and aggressive daytime-biting species that poses a significant public health threat in its expanding range. To understand its historical and contemporary movements in the Indo-Pacific region, researchers analyzed 13 microsatellite loci from 911 individuals and mitochondrial COI sequences. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was used to test competing invasion routes of Ae. albict in the Southeast Asian-Australian region. Results show Ae. albict was likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland Asia, colonizing the Solomon Islands via Papua New Guinea or Asia, and the recent incursion into northern Australia's Torres Strait was seeded from Indonesia. A colonized population in the Torres Islands has undergone rapid genetic changes, possibly due to genetic drift or a secondary invasion from an unknown source. High genetic structure and gene flow exist between geographically distant populations, driven by human dispersal. This study provides a broader distribution of the species' range, revealing more spatial structure than previously shown, and a probable invasion history in the Australasian region using ABC analysis.
A study investigated the effect of Schistosoma mansoni infection on the quality of life and physical fitness of 572 children aged 7-8 in Mwan Region, North-West Tanzania. The prevalence of S. mansoni infection was 58.7% with an average of 207.3 eggs per gram of feces. Most infections were light, while 16.4% had heavy infections. Girls had higher intensities than boys. 30.1% were anemic with no sex difference. Stunting and wasting were less than 10%. There was no association between S mans prevalence or intensities and anthropometry, anemia, or spleen pathology. However, infected children had lower emotional quality of life scores than uninfected and higher VO2 max. In multivar regression, age, S mans infection, hemoglobin, and VO max were predictors of emotional quality life, while predictors of VO max were physical quality, height, age, and hemoglobin. S mans infection was not retained in regression on VO max. The study suggests S mans infection affects emotional quality of life, not physical fitness.
Researchers studied how Leptira, a zoonosis caused by spirochete, infects rats. They compared three routes of infection: intraperitoneal, mucosal, and subcutaneous. The goal was to understand how Leptira colonizes rats naturally, like it does in the wild. Infection was asymptomatic in all three routes, with similar antibody production. Renal colonization rates were 8/8, 5/8, and 1/8 for intraper, muc, and subcut routes respectively. Mucosal inoculation was more efficient for urinary excretion than subcut, and slower than intraper. This study helps understand Lept infection in rats, unlike previous studies in wild rats. Future studies on natural routes will increase knowledge of rat-rat transmission and infection kinetics.
Researchers have identified a new role for Annexin A2 (AnxA) in regulating the body's response to sepsis, a life-threatening condition characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue damage, and organ dysfunction. Seps is difficult to treat, and understanding its molecular mechanisms may lead to effective treatments. AnxA is a multi-functional protein that inhibits inflammation by controlling reactive oxygen species (ROS) and interleukin-17 (IL-17) signaling during seps. In seps models, mice lacking AnxA showed increased inflammatory cytokines, neutrophils, and decreased bacterial clearance, and survival. AnxA deficiency also led to increased ROS and IL-17 levels. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed cysteine 9 of AnxA is crucial for regulating ROS levels, which in turn affects IL-17 and inflammation. Depleting IL-17 via CRISPR/C9 strategy reduced inflammation and protected AnxA- mice from seps. The study reveals AnxA's previously unknown function in seps via AnxA-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing insight into seps pathophysiology. AnxA may mitigate se severity by modulating ROS and IL-17 levels. Targeting neutils in seps may be therapeutic. AnxA-induced neutil infiltration contributes to severe and distant injury and mortality in seps mice. IL-17 is regulated by ROS, and reduced after IL-17 knockdown. Increased IL-17 correlates with ROS in An- mice, and IL-17 knockdown inhibits seps inflammation. AnxA, an intracellular protein, is involved in cellular processes, including immunity, endosome function, and inflammation. Overall, AnxA plays a critical role in inhibiting inflammatory response by regulating ROS and IL-17 in seps.
Researchers studied how polyinos-polycidylic acid (poly I:C) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS) affect HIV-1 infection in macrophages. These compounds activate Toll-like receptors (TLR) 3 and TLR4, respectively, and have been shown to decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs). However, the mechanisms were not fully understood. The study found that poly(I:C) and L-stimulation of MDMs reduced infection by CCR5-using macrophage-tropic HIV-1 and vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudyped HIV-1 virions, while TLR2, TLR or T9 agonists only partially reduced infection to varying extent. Suppression of infection did not correlate with effects on CD4 or CCR expression, type interferon induction, or pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Integrated viruses were detected in unstimulated TLR and T9-stimulated cells, but not TLR or T4-stim MDM, suggesting alteration of post-entry preintegration events. Microarray and RT-PCR analysis found increased microRNA mi-155 in MDM upon TLR4 but not T7 stimulation, and mi-155 inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly I-stimulated MDM. Ectopic mi-155 expression diminished HIV-1 in primary MDM and cell lines. Poly I-stimulation and ectopic mi-155 resulted in accumulation of late RT products and undetectable or low integrated viruses 2-L circles. Reduced mRNA and protein of HIV-1 factors involved in trafficking and import preintegration (AD10, TN3, N153, LED/p75) were in poly I-stim and mi-trans M, and reporter suggested authentic mi-155 targets.
Plants use daily light and dark cycles to control various physiological processes, including growth. In Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings, hypocotyl growth rates are highest at different times of the day depending on external light and internal circadian rhythms. However, the interactions between light, circadian clock, and growth-promoting hormone pathways are not well understood. Researchers analyzed the Arabidopsis seedling transcriptome under multiple growth conditions and mutant backgrounds using DNA microarrays to determine the transcriptional component of rhythmic growth. A group of hormone-associated genes are co-expressed when hypocotyl growth is maximal. This correlates with overrepresentation of a cis-element (CAT) in hormone gene promoters, which confers diurnal and circadian patterns in vivo. Circadian and light mutants show that internal hormone signaling and external darkness are required for wild-type growth. The circadian clock indirectly controls growth by gating hormone levels to proper time. This integration of pathways allows plants to fine-tune hormone responses for seasonal growth.

The circadian clock changes chromatin modifications, suggesting developmental states are reflected in modifications. The gated model provides a framework for the relationship between circadian, light, and hormone-regulated growth. IAA signaling plays a role in IAA growth. A time-day atlas showed photocycles, thermocycles, and circadian control 90% Arabid genes. The implication is that many pathways are coordinated at specific times. A transcription module is associated with growth, regulated by internal and external coincidence. The circadian acts upstream light to gate hormone expression in the evening. Since growth is time-specific, a temporal component of hormone pathways could be part of specificity. The circadian and light interact to coordinate biosynthetic, catabolic, receptor, and genes from multiple hormone pathways.
Researchers have developed a new method to control Chagas disease vectors, such as Rhodnius prolix, by modifying the insect's gut microbiota. They used a technology called RNA interference (RNAi) to deliver molecules to the insect's gut. The goal is to reduce the insect's ability to spread the disease. The researchers used two types of bacteria, Escherichia coli and Rhodoccus rhnii, to deliver RNA to the insect. The RNA targeted two proteins: Rhodni heme-binding protein (RH) and catalase (CAT). These proteins are important for the insect's development and reproduction. The researchers fed the bacteria to nymphs and adult stages of the insect. The results showed that the RNA interference was effective and spread throughout the insect's body. Concentrations of bacteria above 3.35 × 10^7 CFU/mL produced significant knockdown of RH and CAT genes in nymphs and adults. RH expression in the body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal 10 days after. CAT expression was reduced 99% and 96 in ovary and midgut, respectively, five days after. Mortality increased 24-30% in first instars fed RH and CAT. Molting rates reduced 100% in first and 80 in third fed bacteria RH or CAT. Oviposition reduced 43% RH and 84 CAT. Embogenesis arrested 16 RH and 20 of eggs. The researchers also used the natural symbiont, Rhodoccus rhn, to express RH-specific RNA, reducing RH expression by 89 and oviposition.
Fever in pregnancy is a significant risk for both the mother and the fetus. In the 1980s, malaria was the leading cause of death in pregnant women in refugee camps on the Thai-Burma border. However, artemisinin therapy has reduced the incidence of malaria in the population. The causes of fever in pregnancy are not well-documented. Pregnant women attending antenatal care, where screening for malaria is routine, were invited to have a comprehensive clinical and laboratory screening if they had fever. Women were admitted, treated, and followed up until delivery. Convalescent serum was collected on day 21. Outcomes were recorded.

Fever episodes occurred in 5.0% (409/8,117) of women attending anten clinics from January 2004 to May 2006. The main cause was malaria in 55.5% (227/409). A cohort of 203 (49.6%409) had fever investigations and follow-up. Arthrop-borne, malaria, ricketial, and deng, and zoon disease leptospi accounted for nearly half all febr illnesses, 47.3 (96). Coinfection was observed 3.9 (8) of women, mostly malaria and ricket. Pyonephritis 19.7 (40) was also a cause of fever. Once malaria, pyoneph and respiratory are excluded, one-third of remaining febr infections were caused by ricket or leptpi. Scr and murine typhus were associated with poor outcomes, including stillbirth and low birth. One woman died with no laboratory tests.

Malaria remains the leading cause of fever in pregnancy on Thaiurma. Scr and murine typh were important causes of fever with poor outcomes. Pregnant women on Thaiurma without malaria, pyone or respiratory infection should be treated with azithromycin for typh and leptpi.
Researchers investigated the relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans by analyzing over 600,000 genotyped markers in 69 French-Canadian families. They found a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, driven by chromosome-specific effects, particularly in the middle sections of chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions. This suggests that recombination's protective effect against non-disjunction becomes less efficient with age, contributing to higher aneuploidy rates in older women. The study proposes a model reconciling findings with associations between maternal age and recombination in trisomies. To further investigate, they genotyped individuals from 68 French-Canadian families and localized recombination events at high resolution, observing a genome-wide decrease in rate with maternal age. Chromosome effects may vary among populations due to genetic differences in regulating recombination machinery, supported by significant decay on nine chromosomes in the French-Canadian cohort and two in Hutter. Maternal age is a major factor in chromosomal anupidy, but little is known about age-related non-disjunction. Recombination initiated during fetal development can still be influenced by age. Not all trisomies are affected equally by maternal age, and mechanisms may not apply to anup conceptions. The study highlights distinct selective constraints on chromosomes influencing recombination over generations.
Researchers have found a new way to boost the immune system's first line of defense, macrophages, to fight off opportunistic infections in people with weakened immune systems. They used a strategy to "train" macrophages in the body to remember a specific pathogen, Cryptococcus neoformans, and stay protected for at least 70 days without the help from the rest of the immune system. This is different from current vaccines that rely on the second line of defense, the adaptive immune system, which can be weak in people with compromised immune systems. The team found that macroages that were "trained" with interferon-gamma (IF-γ) had a rapid response to the pathogen and stayed in a protective state for weeks. This was due to increased binding of a protein, STAT1, to genes that help fight fungal infections. The study suggests a new way to make vaccines more effective in people with weakened immune systems by inducing a memory-like response in macroages.
Researchers studied how a group of proteins called Polycomb repressive complexes (PCs) regulate gene expression and development in plants. These complexes are crucial for growth and development in both plants and animals, but how they target specific genes is not fully understood. They found that a protein called CURLY LEAF (CL), a key part of PC2, works with other PC members to suppress different developmental programs in plants. Specifically, it represses flower development in seedlings by working with LIKE HETCHROMIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). In contrast, embryo development is repressed by PC core units AtBMI and AtRING with PC enzyme CL or SWINGER (SW). The role of CL corresponds with changes in H3me3 profiles and is associated with binding of transcription factors, including MADS and ABA. Different PC combinations regulate different programs and specificity is modulated by transcription factors.
Researchers have created a detailed map of the "trigger" region of the RNA polymerase II enzyme, a crucial for transcription in yeast cells. This region, called the trigger loop (TL), plays a key role in selecting the right substrates, catalyzing reactions, and moving along the DNA. To understand its function, the researchers created nearly all possible single-residue variations of the TL in yeast RNA polymerase II and studied their effects. They found three classes of mutations linked to defects in transcription or stress, with distinct residue distributions. Disrupting a hydrophobic pocket in TL, thought to destabilize a catalytically inactive state, showed consistent with increased catalysis. Interactions among TL and nearby residues support the role of funnel and bridge helices in TL dynamics. This study combines genetic and structural data for high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and evolution, applicable to other essential yeast proteins.

The study reveals functional contributions of TL residues to its dynamics, catalysis, and sequence constraints. The approach expands existing mutational studies and can be applied to most yeast proteins. The researchers dissected Pol II mechanisms using this framework, assessing TL residues in S. cerevisiae under multiple conditions. Intra-T interactions and TL with nearby domains are critical for function. Genetic and structural studies support a multi-step folding model for catalysis. Many gain-of-function and loss-of-function variants were identified, some with predicted epistatic interactions. The TL's ability to fold into multiple states and convert between them is critical for its functions. Previous studies show TL is delicately balanced, perturbations result in increased or decreased activity and altered dynamics.
Researchers studied how the rabies virus (RV) spreads to the brain after entering the body through a bite or scratch. They wanted to know if the virus can also spread through the bloodstream to the brain. To find out, they infected mice with two types of RV: one from dogs (DOG) and one from silver-haired bats (SB). They gave the virus to mice either under the skin (intramuscularly) or through a vein (intravenously). The mice that got the virus under the skin got sick and died from rabies. But the ones that got it through the vein only got sick if it was from the bat virus. The researchers looked at how the virus spread in the brain and found that the bat virus went straight to the hypothalamus, a part of the brain connected to the pituitary gland. This is a new way the virus can spread to the brain. This has implications for how to prevent rabies, especially from the bat virus.
Researchers studied the evolutionary history of the H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus, which has caused significant illness and death in humans since the 1918 pandemic. They analyzed 71 complete genome sequences from 1918 to 2006 and found that segment reassortment, a process where genetic material is exchanged between viruses, played a key role in the virus's evolution. Specifically, they found that an H1 virus from 1947 acquired new genes through reassort, which may explain its sudden change in severity. Similarly, the 195 epidemic may have been caused by reassorted H1 viruses. The study suggests reassort is more important in H1's evolution than thought. Reassort between different species can create pandemic viruses, like H2 and H3 in 1957 and 196. The H1's eight segments generally evolved together, but some reassort events affected specific segments. The researchers analyzed 71 whole-genome sequences from 191 to 200, representing 17 countries and five continents. Few studies have looked at reassort in H1 viruses. H1 is thought to evolve slower than H2, needing less frequent vaccine updates. H1 circulated 191 195, then 197, had significant impact. The study's main question is how H1 became so severe in 191, killing 20 million in the pandemic.
Researchers investigated how nicotine affects the brain's ventral tegmental area (VTA), a key region involved in reward and motivation, to understand its addictive properties. They developed a computational model of the VTA's circuitry and nicotinic acetylcholine (nACh) receptors to clarify how nicotine's action. The model showed that αβ2-containing ACh receptors on dopamine or GABA cells can mediate nicotine's effects, consistent with both in vitro and in vivo data. The rate of endogenous acetylcholine input is crucial for the evoked dopamine response, either through direct stimulation or inhibition. Results suggest that low cholinergic input is necessary for direct stimulation, while high cholinergic input is crucial for inhibition to observe dopamine increase. This is due to known activation and desensitization properties of αβ2 ACh receptors. Experimental data support the role of GABA cells in nicotine's action. The model captures in vitro modulation of excitatory and inhibitory inputs to DA neurons and in vivo activation of β-containing ACh receptors on DA neurons. The study clarifies mechanisms of nicotine's action in V, suggesting acetylcholine dependence for reinforcement.
Researchers conducted a two-armed, randomized, double-blinded phase II trial in Kabul, Afghanistan to study a novel treatment for cutaneous leishmanias (CL) caused by Leishmania (L) trop infection. The treatment involved high-frequency electrocauterization (EC) followed by moist-wound treatment (MWT) with polyacrylate hydrogel with or without sodium chlorite (DAC-055). The primary outcome was the time for complete lesion epithelialization. Biops were taken before, after wound closure, and 6 months later. The mean time for wound closure was similar in both groups, 59.1 days and 54.2 days. DAC-055 caused faster wound healing in patients with Leish-positive biops, 37.2 days vs 58.3 days. Superfections occurred at the same rate in both groups, 8.8%. Relapses were higher in patients with persistent parasite loads, 10.2% vs 18.5%. DAC-055 showed lemanicidal effect on amastigotes. The EC plus M protocol led to rapid closure and lower relapse rate compared to intraional injections.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosila cells to identify factors that regulate the RAS-MAP signaling pathway. They found 101 validated hits, most of which were previously known to be associated with the pathway. Epist experiments determined the position of individual candidates relative to core components, revealing new factors acting at different steps, including a protein modulating RAF activation. Unexpectedly, most hits worked downstream of ME and influenced MAP expression, mainly through constitutive splicing. Two members of this group were characterized and found to regulate MAP alternative splicing. This study provides a comprehensive view of factors modulating R-MAP signaling in Dila and suggests that pathway output is not solely reliant on classical events like RAF activation, but also on MAP regulation. Core splicing can also impact alternative splicing.

The screen involved three steps: primary RNAi, validation, and secondary screens to establish regulatory position relative to known components. G-loaded R triggers sequential activation of RAF, ME, and MAP; RAF phosphorylates and activates ME, which phosphorylates and activates MAP. Unlike RAF and ME, MAP has various substrates including transcription factors. Two candidates, P1-87 and Sur-8, clustered with known factors in R-RA. Validated hits were submitted to secondary assays to position regulatory with core kinases, identifying new factors at different steps, including upstream of RAF.
Researchers in Thailand studied 498 isolates of the Cryptococcus neoformans and C gatt species to better understand cryptococcosis in the country. They found 386 isolates from clinical and 112 from environmental and veterinary sources. Most isolates were from males, aged 37.97 years, with 88.5% of C neoans and 37.5 of gatt from HIV patients. Molecular analysis showed most isolates were C neoans type V, regardless of source, with 94.8% clinical, 98.8 environmental, and 86.2 veterinary. Types II, IV, I, and II were less common. Multilocus Sequence Type (ML) analysis identified 20 types in Thailand, with some unique to the country. Most gatt isolates were ST7, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak strain, indicating a global spread. The study found greater diversity and range of molecular types in Thai isolates than previously reported.
Researchers studied the evolution of a large group of proteins called C2-H2 zinc finger transcription factors (TFs) in 12 species of fruit flies over 45 million years. They found that a significant number of these TFs have variations that affect their ability to bind to DNA. In addition to losing or gaining C2-Z domains, they also found changes in DNA-contacting residues in 44% of shared domains between species. These changes were conserved in 70% of Drosophila TFs and 26% of all annotated TFs, suggesting they are functional. They were rarely found as polymorphisms in a population of D melanogaster flies, indicating rapid fixation. Specificities of these domains changed across phylogenetic distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Proteins with conserved C-Z domains were enriched in developmental functions, while varying domains showed no enrichments. The study suggests a subset of dynamic and understudied TFs are a source of variation in Dophila and other metazoa.
Researchers have developed a new PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test to identify two types of bacteria that cause typhoid and paratyoid fevers, Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paraty A. These bacteria can be difficult to diagnose, especially in areas where typing sera is not available or culture is not possible. The new test uses a repeated DNA sequence called CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindromic repeats) that is specific to each serotype. The researchers tested the test on 188 Typhi and 74 Paraty A strains from different places and times, and 70 other bacteria that can cause similar symptoms. The test was 100% sensitive and specific, meaning it correctly identified all Typhi and Paraty A and not other bacteria. This test can be used in many laboratories with PCR technology to quickly and accurately identify these serotypes. The test was developed for cultured isolates, but can be modified for clinical samples.
Researchers investigated the role of Notch signaling in the immune response to Leishmania major infection, a protozoan parasite that causes leishmaniasis. They found that Notch receptors Not1 and Not2 are necessary for the differentiation of IFγ-secre CD+ T helper 1 cells, which are crucial for fighting the infection. Mice with cell-specific deletion of both Not1 and Not2 developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia due to impaired IFγ secretion by CD+ T cells and increased IL-5 and IL-13 cytokines. In contrast, mice with single inactivation of Not1 or Not were resistant to infection and developed a protective Th1 response. The study also showed that Not signaling is required for IFγ secretion by Th cells, independent of CSL/RBP-J, a major effector of Not receptors. Mice with R-J deletion in T cells were able to develop IFγ-secre Th cells, kill parasites and heal lesions.
Researchers investigated whether infection with the parasitic worm Schistosoma mansoni increases susceptibility to HIV infection in rhes macaques. The study found that animals infected with the worm were more likely to become infected with the AIDS virus after exposure, even at lower doses that were not enough to infect uninfected animals. In fact, the dose needed to establish infection was 17 times lower in infected animals compared to controls. Infected animals also had higher levels of the virus in their blood and increased viral replication in immune cells. This is the first direct evidence that schistomiasis increases the risk of new HIV infection. The study suggests that controlling parasitic infections may help reduce the spread of HIV in areas where both are common.
Researchers have created a computer model to study how the brain chemical acetylcholine (ACh) affects brain activity during sleep and wakefulness. ACh is a key regulator of brain excitability and plays a role in sleep. The model shows how changes in brain excitability and structure create three distinct activity patterns: localized, traveling, asynchronous, and synchronous. These patterns match what is seen in the brain during slow wave sleep, REM, and waking states. During slow wave sleep, traveling patterns occur in the brain, while in other states, stationary patterns do. The model is made of neurons with a current regulated by ACh. ACh level can cause changes between patterns. Reducing this current recreates reduction in spike frequency adaptation and shift in response curve seen with ACh. When frequency is low, activity is localized and pinned by network inhomogeneities. When frequency is present, traveling waves arise. Further decrease in A leads to high synchrony within waves. ACh also determines how sensitive activity is to heterogeneity. These patterns may be important as stationary may encode input and traveling could lead to regularization.
Researchers investigated the role of the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway in the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), a type of cancer linked to an inflammatory environment with reduced microbial diversity. They found that non-synonymous mutations affected the TLR pathway in 14.6% of 171 EAC tumors, with TLR4 being the most frequently mutated gene with 5.8% of tumors. These mutations were associated with more proximal and metastatic disease, suggesting clinical significance. TLR mutants had impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide, a key component of the immune response. The study also found TLR mutations in other solid tumors exposed to microbiomes, including uterine endrioid carcinoma, cutaneous melanoma, colorectal adenocarcin, and stomachocarcin. The findings suggest that TLR genes are recurrently mutated in EAC and T4 mutations may play a role in disease pathogenesis in a subset of patients.
Researchers investigated the development of taste cells in mice using a combination of in silico and in vivo analyses. They found that taste receptor molecules (TRMs) colocalized in the developing circumvallate papillae (CVP) and used computational analysis to identify a common regulatory network for TRM transcription. Hes was identified as a likely regulatory factor and its function examined in vivo. Expression analyses showed that decreased nuclear H1 correlated with type II taste cell markers. After E18, CVP of H1-/- mutants had 5-fold more TRM-immunactive cells than wild-type littermates. The study suggests H1 plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing buds.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling root development. Unlike the dicotyledonous plant Arabidopsis, the role of ethylene and auxin in monocotyledonous rice is unclear. They found that the activation of OsIL on the expression of Y8RE7 and indole-3-pyric acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using an inhibitor of Y activity, which regulates auxin biosynthesis via conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), they showed eth-inhibited primary root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. A rice mutant, rein-1, insensitive to ethylene, was identified with YRE7 truncated at its C-terminus. Mutation in Y7 reduced auxin biosynthesis in rice, while overexpression of Y enhanced eth sensitivity in roots. Y catalyzed the conversion of IPA to IAA, truncated at C-terminal of Y resulted in significant reduction of enzymatic activity, indicating Y is required for IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis and eth-inhibited elong in early seedlings. Investigations showed eth induced Y expression and promoted aux accumulation in roots. Addition of low IAA rescued eth response in rein-1, demonstrating eth-in elong depends on IPA-dependent biosynthesis. Genetic studies revealed Y-mediated auxin function downstream of OsIL, which activated expression of Y7.
A nationwide study in Saudi Arabia has revealed the challenges of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NT) diseases, which are increasing globally. The study, the first of its kind in the country, collected 527 isolates of NT with clinical and demographical data over 24 months. Primary identification was done by probe assays and 16S rRNA, 16-23 ITS, rpo, and h65 gene sequencing. Results showed 75.1% of isolates were pulmonary with 44.7% clinical significance. 34 species, including 17 rare, were identified, with M. simiae 22.6%, M. fortuit 18.1, and M. absus 17.8 predominant. M. riyense, a rare species, was found in 27 cases. Diabetes and previous tuberculosis history were risk factors for NT diseases. The study found rare events like mycobemia, abscess, peritonitis, and ascites caused by M wolii, hatic, duii, and monence respectively. NT disease and pathogen diversity is a challenge in Saudi Arabia, requiring immediate diagnostic and management plans.
Researchers studied how yeast cells prepare for a state of dormancy called quiescence in response to starvation. They found that three kinases, Yak1, Mck, and Rim15, play a crucial role in this process. These kinases help cells accumulate carbohydrates, specifically trehalose and glycogen, which are energy stores that allow cells to survive for a long time. When these kinases are missing, cells can't accumulate these stores and their lifespan is shorter. The researchers also found that levels of reactive oxygen species, which can damage cells, are controlled by Yak, Rim, and Mck kinases. They suggest that these kinases help cells prepare for quies by storing energy and protecting themselves from damage. The study supports the idea that cells reprogram their metabolism to store energy and protect themselves from damage to live longer.
Researchers have found that the influenza A virus's hemagglutinin (HA) protein can be modified with sugar molecules called glycans to compensate for the loss of fitness that occurs when the virus mutates to evade the immune system's antibodies. This process, called antigenic evolution, allows the virus to persist in human populations despite widespread immunity. The study used a method called primer error-correct viral sequencing to reveal this unexpected role of glycosylation. The results show that adding glycans to the HA protein's globular domain can increase the virus's ability to bind to receptors, even if it has mutated to evade antibodies. This finding expands understanding of viral mechanisms that maintain fitness during antigen evolution and highlights the power of high-definition virus sequencing to reveal new adaptive mechanisms. The study suggests that glycosylation can play a role in the virus's ability to combine antigen novelty with fitness and transmissibility. It also shows that glycosylation can increase the fitness of antigen escape variants by restoring optimal receptor interactions, even without antibody pressure. This raises the possibility that both mechanisms contribute to the accumulation of glycans in the globular domain during H1 and H3 virus circulation. The study demonstrates glycos can compensate for fitness costs imposed by escape substitutions on HA, increasing viability and emergence of antibody-escape variants.
Researchers analyzed 13 models of ventricular myocytes to understand why some antiarrhythmic drugs are less effective at slow heart rates and more effective at fast rates. These drugs, called reverse dependent, prolong the cardiac action potential (AP) more at slow rates, increasing arrhythmia risk and reducing suppression at fast rates. The opposite, forward dependence, would solve this problem, but forward dependent drugs are rare. The study found that reverse dependence is not a property of the AP itself, but of ionic perturbations that affect it. By simulating myocytes with varying properties and analyzing results, they predicted rate-dependent changes in 40 parameters, testing AP at slow and fast rates. They identified ionic perturbations that produce forward dependence, such as increased L-type calcium current with indirect changes in delayed rectifier potassium. Inward rectifier potassium and sodium-potassium pump were most likely to produce forward prolongation. Models with minimal AP shape changes have little forward potential, while those with large changes have considerable. This study provides insights into AP duration dependence and a strategy for beneficial antiarrhythmic design.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how genetic variations in people's genes affect their traits and diseases. They used this method, called Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PAS), to look at how thiopurine-methyltransferase (TPM) activity affects patients treated with thiopine drugs. TP is an enzyme that helps break down thiopine, a medication used to treat certain diseases. The study used data from 442 patients at a French hospital between 2010 and 2013. They analyzed ICD-10 codes, which classify diseases, and biological test results, like blood work, to see if there was a link between TP activity and disease. Two methods were used: ICD-10 hierarchy and mapping to existing ICD-9 codes. Biological results were also analyzed to validate the findings. Two diseases, iron-deficiency anemia and diabetes, were associated with high TP activity. This is the first study to use I-10 codes and biological results for P. The method can help identify patients who need personalized treatment.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of animal studies on stem cell transplantation in spinal cord injury found that allogenic stem cells improved motor function by 27.2% and sensory function by 26.3% compared to controls. The analysis included 156 publications and 45 different stem cell preparations, with only one using autologous cells. Allogenic cell treatment showed significant improvement in both motor and sensory outcomes, but heterogeneity between experiments was mainly due to stem cell biology. Differentiation, implantation route, and delivery method favored better outcomes. Stem implantation did not improve sensory outcomes in females and was enhanced by isoflurane anesthesia. A dose-response relationship supported biological plausibility. Motor outcomes were influenced by experimental design, injury location, and immunosuppression. Reporting bias was higher than in neuroscience but still suboptimal, with motor studies not reporting blinded assessment giving inflated efficacy. The review suggests stem-cell therapies may offer promise, but internal validity and publication bias likely lower efficacy.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of 154 studies on soil-transmitted helmin (STH) infections, including Ascaris lumbricoid, hookworm, and Trichuris trura, found that reinfection occurs rapidly after treatment. At 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, Ascaris lumic prevalence reached 26%, 68%, and 94% of pretreatment levels, respectively. Trichis trura reinfection prevalence were 36%, 67, and 82, and hookworm 30, 55, and 57. Prevalence and intensity of reinfection were correlated with pretreatment status. The study suggests frequent anthelmint drug administrations are needed to maximize benefit of preventive chemotherapy. Integrated approaches emphasizing health and sanitation are required to interrupt transmission. The analysis used pooled risk ratios from random-effects models to assess risk of STH reinfection after treatment. 51 studies provided STH rates pre and post-treatment, and 42 reported determinants of predisposition to reinfection.
Researchers have developed a new method called Minimum Enrichment Analysis (MiA) to study nonalcoholic liver disease (NAFL) by analyzing metabolic processes at the molecular level. NAFL is a spectrum of diseases from simple fat buildup in the liver to more severe inflammation. Current methods use predefined maps of metabolic processes, but these can be biased and miss complex interactions. MiA generates minimal networks of reactions that can produce a target metabolite and applies to genome-scale metabolic networks. The team applied MiA to human and mouse data to identify deregulated processes in fatty liver and inflammation. They found key changes in cholesterol and hexadecate synthesis and regulators of hydrogen peroxide synthesis differed between humans and mice. MiA can study metabolism for any disease or organism, making it a flexible tool for research. 

The method, MiA, compares conditions using transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics to identify minimal networks of reactions that synthesize a metabolite. Current methods use predefined maps that are limited and differ depending on database, missing complex interactions. MiA formulates metabolic tasks to mimic NAFL phenotypes, such as lipid formation, apoptosis, inflammation, and stress. These include necessary metabolites to form the phenotype. MiA was applied to study deregulated processes and regulatory metabolism is better characterized with available genome-scale networks.
Researchers studied how the brain's sense of smell, or olfaction, identifies a wide variety of odors despite their intensity. They found that "primacy coding," where the earliest responding receptors encode odor identity, provides a compact and efficient representation that the brain can interpret. This representation is independent of odor intensity and useful for tasks like identifying odors. Simulations showed that the number of receptor types in prim coding affects information, but not the size of the receptor repertoire. Interestingly, smaller repertoires can be advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests overly sensitive receptors can dominate and make the array useless, allowing prediction of receptor adaptation to environmental changes. Prim coding is more useful than binary coding because its sparsity is independent of odor statistics, unlike alternatives. It provides an efficient representation independent of intensity, helping identify odors in the olfactory cortex. 

A model of neural representations of olfactory stimuli was analyzed, where odors are identified by the strongest responding receptors. Primacy provides a sparse representation independent of intensity. Numerical and statistical analysis showed prim dimension affects information and discriminability. It provides a robust and compact representation over a wide range of odors, independent of intensity, outperforming other schemes. However, performance hinges on tuned sensitivities, suggesting selective pressure to adjust on evolutionary and short timescales. The prim code in the olfactory bulb is more useful than alternatives because statistics are independent of odor. The model predicts useful receptors respond similarly to incoming odors. Experiments show odors are robustly encoded by responding receptors within a time window. The identity can be encoded by a fixed number responding first, primacy. It is unclear how efficient and compares to alternatives. The model predicts lesions have a severe effect on animals with smaller reperto. The analysis suggests prim provides a robust, sparse, concentration-variant, and weakly dependent representation. For it to be useful, it needs to solve olfactory tasks.
Researchers studied a group of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnMA) that target the HIV virus. These antibodies, PG9, PG16, PGT, and P152, have shown unusual neutralization profiles with a non-sigmoid slope and a plateau at less than 100% neutralization. The study aimed to determine the extent of non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus at less than 100 for more bnMA. Using a panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4-T cell assay and 117 viruses in the TZ-bl assay, they found that bnMA targeting the spike had neutral profiles with at least one that plateaued at 90%. Across both panels, bnMA targeting the V apex of Env and gp41 were most likely to show neutral curves that plateaued 100. Conversely, bnMA targeting high-mose epitopes were less likely to show this behavior. CD4 binding Abs also showed this behavior infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was observed in a peripheral blood mononuclear cell-grown virus panel from patient swarms. Five bnMA were compared against 18-virus of clones produced in 293 cells and PBs and assayed in TZ-bl. Examples of plateaus 90 were seen with both types of virus with no consistent patterns. Incomplete neutralization and nonigmoid neutral curves are possible for all bnMA against a range of viruses and assayed in cell and primary cells with implications for use in therapy and vaccine design.
Researchers developed a computational model to study how cancer cells use glucose and glutamine to produce energy and biomass. They found that when glutamine levels are high, cells produce more lactate from glutamine instead of glucose, even in the presence of oxygen. This occurs when oxygen is not enough to fully oxidize glucose. The model showed that this pattern is optimal for cell growth and requires a branched TCA cycle and redox reactions. Experiments in a cancer cell line validated the model's predictions. The study suggests that competition between glucose and glutamine may drive cancer growth. Cancer cells often use glucose to produce lactate, but to understand glutamine use, researchers focused on a condition where glucose is redirected to lactate. They simulated 50,000 cell wirings with varying glucose and glutamine uptake while keeping oxygen constant. The model identified conditions that promote metabolic rewiring in cancer cells. A hallmark of cancer is extensive metabolic reorganization, including aerobic glycolysis and glutamine use for biosynthesis. The study used a constraint-based approach to evaluate metabolic wirings for biomass from glucose and glutamine under different conditions.
Researchers investigated the interactions of the prion protein (Pr) and its mammalian paralogs, Doppel (PrPnd) and Shadoo (Spr), in a cell culture model that allows prion replication. They found that the three proteins share a similar environment in neuroblastoma cells and interact with each other. The study also confirmed interactions between Pr and the cell adhesion molecule laminin, Na+/K ATPases, and protein disulfide isomerases (PDI), reconciling previous findings. Experiments showed that Pr interactions with PDIs may occur outside the endoplasmic reticulum and play a previously unknown role in PrSc accumulation. A hypothesis suggests that Pr organizes its environment by binding adhesion molecules with immunoglobulin-like domains, recognizing oligann-bearing membrane proteins.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to influenza virus infection in the lungs. They found that a type of immune cell called group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2) produces a cytokine called interleukin-5 (IL-5) during infection. IL-5 is important for making eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, mature and leave the bone marrow. The study showed that IL-5 is released into the airways during infection and eosinils accumulate in the lungs, especially after the virus is cleared. The source of IL-5 was IL2 cells in the lungs. These cells also produce more IL-5 when they interact with other immune cells called NKT and alveolar macrophages. This interaction leads to more IL-5 production and eosin accumulation in the lungs during recovery from infection.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial testing was performed on all organisms. 71% of NT patients were HIV-infected, 90% were adults, 71 were male, and 33 reported intravenous use. 26/92 (28%) with known outcome died, HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis Sequence (ST) 11 (43/89) and Typhimium (ST 19,34, 44) (23/89) were most identified serovars. Tyim was more common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates from HIV-inf patients were more susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037). NT is a severe infection in Vietnam with high mortality. In sub-Saharan, HIV was risk for death, majority burden in population HIV-inf adult.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify viral and phage proteins using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). Phages are viruses that infect bacteria and play a crucial role in their survival and ability to cause disease. However, most phage genes have unknown functions, making it difficult to understand their impact on microbial communities and human health. The new method uses ANNs to classify protein sequences based on amino acid frequency and isoelectric point, achieving high accuracy in detecting structural proteins. The ANNs were trained on sequences from phages, viruses that infect bacteria, archaea, and eukarya, and validated by electron microscopy. The results show that ANNs can identify proteins that are difficult or impossible to detect by other methods. This tool will aid in disease diagnosis, vaccine development, and understanding of viral impact on the environment. 

The researchers designed a computational method that doesn't rely on sequence similarity to identify viral components, specifically bacteriophages. They trained feed-forward, back-propagation networks classified protein sequences by amino acid composition and isoelectric point. The first goal was achieved with an ensemble of five networks that identified a broad spectrum of phage and viral proteins with 80% accuracy. The second goal was met with two ensembles of 10 networks that were more specific than the structural networks in identifying capsid or tail proteins.
Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is a cancer-causing virus with a large genome that encodes over 85 proteins, including unique and conserved herpesviral proteins. One of these proteins, SH ORF20, is part of the herpesiral UL24 family, but its function and role in the viral life cycle are not well understood. OR20 encodes three uncharacterized isoforms, mainly found in nuclei and nucleoli. Researchers used quantitative purification to mass spectrometry (q-AP-MS) to identify interacting partners of OR20, including ribosomal and interferon-stimulated gene (IS) oligoadylate synthase-like (OL) protein. Both endogenous and transiently transfected OL co-immunprecipitated with OR20, conserved among OR isoforms and OR20 homologs in other herpesviruses. Characterization of OL partners by-APMS showed a similar interactome to OR20. Both OR20 and OL copurified with 40 and 60 ribosomal subunits, associating with polys when coexpressed. OR20 did not affect translation, but enhanced IR-induced expression of endogenous OL in an IR3-dependent, IFN-independent manner. OL has antiviral activity against some viruses, but its role in gammaherpesviruses was unknown. Researchers found OL and OR20 expression increased after reactivation of latently infected HuLT-rSH.219 cells. Intriguingly, OL enhanced KSH infection, but not with OR20 mutant.
A study was conducted to determine the prevalence of Lassa fever virus disease (LVD) in children with fever and convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. The study included 913 febrile children aged 1-15 years admitted to a hospital over a year. Of these, 373 (40.9%) had fever, and 108 (29%) presented with convuls. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13.5% (95% CI 1.9-5.7) in febr admissions, 2.8% in children with convuls, and 3.8% without convuls. Only vomiting and bleeding were associated with increased prevalence of LVD. Lassa virus is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas, but not associated with convuls in feile children. Its prevalence and lack of clinical differentiation underscores the importance of high suspicion in diagnosis. Screening feile children with undifferent fever in endemic for L could be a medical and public health measure.
Researchers have identified a new genetic factor that helps plants resist drought, a major cause of crop yield loss worldwide. They studied Arabidopsis, a plant commonly used in research, and found a receptor called KIN2 that responds to a class of chemicals called karri found in smoke. Karri promote seed germination and seedling growth under stress. Mutations in K2 made plants more sensitive to water loss, leading to increased water loss, cell damage, and stomatal opening. They also had reduced anthocyan production and were less sensitive to a hormone ABA in stomatal closure and cotyledon opening. Genome analysis revealed associated genes involved in these changes. ABA and K2 signaling pathways interact in drought response. Comparison with another receptor mutant showed strigolones contribute to drought adaptation, but not cuticle development. The study suggests manipulating K2 and 14 signaling may improve drought resistance. K2 regulates drought through membrane, stomatal, cuticle, and anthyan production. It is activated by karri or an unknown signal, regulating downstream genes in these processes. This contributes to plant adaptation to drought. The study shows K2's role in Arabidopsis survival after water deficit and explains its function, highlighting an unknown signal and K2 pathway in drought resistance.
Researchers have investigated the role of insulin signaling in the growth and development of Schistosoma japonicum, a parasite that causes schistosomiasis in humans. They focused on the insulin receptors (SIR) of S. japonicum, which they had previously cloned and characterized. They found that human insulin binds to a specific part of the IR, called the L subdomain, using a technique called biolayer interferometry. They then used a method called RNA interference (RNAi) to reduce the expression of the IR in adult S. japon in a lab dish and found that this reduced the transcription of other genes involved in insulin signaling and glucose metabolism. They also observed a decrease in glucose uptake in the IR-knockdown worms compared to controls. In experiments with mice, they found that a vaccine made from a part of the IR, called SLD, reduced growth, intestinal worm density, and egg production in S. japon. These results suggest that the IR could be a target for a vaccine against schistosomiasis in China and the Philippines.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a leading cause of disability in the Pacific region, affecting over 96% of the 1.7 million population at risk of infection. Current mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced lymphatic filariasis prevalence, but mosquito biology complicates the strategy. In some regions, evidence suggests the goal of LF elimination cannot be attained via MDA alone. Obligate mosquitoes provide targets for breaking the LF cycle, but existing methods are ineffective for controlling the primary vector, Aedes aegypti, in the South. Researchers demonstrate that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in Aegypt strain 'CP' stably infected with endosymbiotic Wolbachia from Aedesalbopictus. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays show CP males are competitive, resulting in population elimination when introduced into wild Aegpt populations. This strategy is feasible and encourages field tests as a supplement to ongoing M efforts.
A study in Tanzania's Uram District estimated the burden of Rhodesian trypanosomiasis (HAT) in terms of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) and financial costs. Data from 143 patients admitted to Kali Health Centre in 2004 for HAT treatment were used. Direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. DALs were estimated using the Global Burden Project's methods and previous H estimates, assuming 45% under-reporting. The estimated DALs for H in Uram District with and without weighting were 215.7 (95% CI 155.3-287.5) and 281.6 (95% CI 209.1-362.6) respectively. When 45% underreporting was included, results were 622.5 (95% CI 155.3-109.9) and 978.9 (95 CI 201.1-187.8). The cost of treating 143 patients was $15,514, with patients paying $3,673 and services $11,841. Indirect non-medical costs for 143 were $9,781. The study shows H imposes a significant burden on rural communities in Tanzania, highlighting the need for location-specific estimates in countries with many infectious diseases concentrated in certain areas.
Researchers studied mice with a genetic mutation in the Ngly gene, which codes for an enzyme that removes sugar molecules from proteins. These mice were born with severe symptoms and died early in development. The study found that deleting another gene, Eng, which also removes sugar from proteins, partially saved the mice from death. This suggests that Ng enzyme's main function is to remove sugar from proteins. The study also found that changing the mice's genetic background to a mix of C57 and ICR strains partially saved the mice from death. However, mice with both Ng and Eng mutations had severe symptoms similar to humans with Ng mutation. Deleting Eng in these mice also reduced symptoms. The study suggests that mice with Ng or Ng/Eng mutations could be used to study human disease and that Ng enzyme could be a target for treatment.
Researchers studied how the gene expression of the hunch (hb) gene in fruit flies (Drosophila) is controlled by a maternal gradient of the Boid (B) protein. They found that gene expression is subject to noise, or variability, which must be constrained for development to be reproducible and coordinated. They identified how noise is controlled by characterizing the dependence of hb mRNA and protein output on promoter structure and transcription dynamics. A model of the hb promoter was created, where the number and strength of B and self-regulatory binding sites can be varied. Parameters were fit to data from wild-type, self-regulatory mutant, and lacZ reporter constructs using different portions of the promoter. Results indicate that wild-type self-regulatory hb noise is dependent on transcription and translation dynamics, not B fluctuations. Constructs lacking self-regulation show that multiple B binding sites in the promoter play a role in buffering noise. The model is robust to variation in B binding site number across fly species. This study shows how promoter structure and dynamics reduce noise in hb output, features common in many genes, such as multiple sites, cooperativity, and self-feedback, contributing to understanding of reproducibility and determinacy in early development.
Researchers have studied how selection acted against Neanderthal ancestry in modern humans after hybridization. They developed a new method to estimate the strength and density of selection against Neander alleles in human genomes. The study found that East Asians had more Neander ancestry than Europeans, even after accounting for selection. Most selection against Neander was due to weakly deleterious alleles that were neutral in Neander but became harmful in humans. These alleles had a big impact on early human-Neander hybrids. The study suggests population size may play a bigger role in shaping introgression than thought.

The researchers used data on Neander ancestry in modern humans to test their predictions. Their results show how selection shaped Neander contribution to human genomes and shed light on Neander-human hybridization. There is evidence selection against Neander autosomal alleles in anatomically modern humans.
