Frequent exposure to tset bites accelerates immunity, seen in areas with high tset exposure, such as woodlands compared to plains. This is the first epidemiological evidence of acquired immunity to trypan in any species, challenging the notion that immunity is impossible, making vaccines impractical.
Researchers used mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis to explore the idea that mechanistic models of human coagulation cascades, despite uncertainty, can be computationally screened for points of fragility, which could serve as therapeutic targets. They tested this hypothesis on a well-studied coagulation cascade model developed from literature. The model, composed of 92 proteins and 148 protein-protein interactions, was validated using 21 datasets from different in vitro coagulation models. Simulated platelet activation and thrombin profiles in presence and absence of anticoagulants were consistent with measured values, with a mean correlation of 0.87 across trials. Sensitivity coefficients, measuring robustness or fragility of a mechanism, were calculated using Monte Carlo. In absence anticoagul, and surface factor X/activated factor (Xa) and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were fragile, while IX/IX and V/VIII/VIII activation and activity were robust. Anti-Xa and thrombin inhibitors, classes of anticoagulants, have FDA approval for prevention of venous thromboembolism following surgical intervention and initial treatment deep venous thromosis pulmonary embolism. In vitro and vivo evidence supports prediction IXIX activity robust. Results support hypothesis computationally derived points of fragility human cascades as basis for target selection despite uncertainty.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study the interaction between bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria) and their host bacteria, specifically Campylobacterium jejuni, a foodborne pathogen. They tested the model in an in vitro system and found that it accurately predicted the growth of phage-sensitive and resistant bacteria populations. This is the first study to test a model against in vitro data that includes phage-resistant bacteria. The model suggests that "inundation and proliferation thresholds" are crucial for phage therapy. By fitting the model to data, the researchers estimated these thresholds and rate constants. They also found culture-density dependent features of phage infectivity that need further investigation. The study shows how combining empirical and theoretical approaches can enhance understanding of phage-bacteria interactions. In vitro studies are necessary to understand kinetic properties of phage in vivo.
Researchers have identified a Toll-like receptor (TLR) in the snail Biomphalaria glabr that plays a crucial role in the snail's immune response to the parasitic flatworm Schistoma mansoni. Schistomias is a disease that affects over 260 million people worldwide, mainly in tropical and subtropical regions. The snail is an essential host for the parasite's larval development, a trait shared among all digene trematodes. The study found that the TLR, called BTL, is more abundant in snails that are resistant to S. mansoni infection and its expression increases when challenged with the parasite. Knocking down BTL in resistant snails made them susceptible to infection. This is the first functional characterization of a gastropod TLR and shows BTL's importance in snail immune response to S. mansoni.
Researchers have developed a new tool to measure human exposure to disease-carrying mosquitoes in the Pacific islands of French Polynes. These mosquitoes, Aedes aegypt and Aedes polensis, transmit diseases such as dengue chikung and Zika, and Bancroftian filariasis. To assess the risk of disease transmission and effectiveness of control measures, scientists looked at the presence of antibodies against mosquito saliva proteins in human blood. An ELISA test was used to detect and quantify immunoglobulin G (Ig) against salivary gland extracts of Aedes aegpt and Aedes polensis in people exposed to these mosquitoes. In Tahiti and Moore islands, 98% and 68% of individuals had IgG against Aedes aeg and Aedesensis respectively. In contrast, 97% of people from metropolitan France, not exposed to these mosquitoes, had no Ig against saliv gland extracts. Analysis showed no cross-reactivity between Aedes aeg and Aensis saliv extracts. The study suggests Ig response to saliv extracts is a valid biomarker of human exposure to Aedes bites. This new tool will help understand exposure to mosquito bites, identify areas of high disease risk, and evaluate control strategies in Pacific and tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacteria that causes tuberculosis, has a unique ability to survive inside human cells called macrophages. To understand how it does this, researchers looked at how the bacteria affects the cell's metabolism. They found that the bacteria changes the cell's metabolic pathways to help it survive and grow. This is a key to its ability to cause disease. The study identified specific reactions in the cell that the bacteria targets to achieve this. Interestingly, this shows how both the host and bacteria work together to determine the severity of the disease. The bacteria's ability to survive is linked to the host's blood sugar levels, and the bacteria's virulence, or ability to cause disease, also plays a role in the outcome. 

The bacteria's ability to adapt to the cell's metabolism is a key to its pathogenicity, or ability to cause disease. The study used different strains of the bacteria with varying virulence, or ability to cause disease, to see how they affect the cell's metabolism over time. The results showed that the bacteria's ability to cause disease is linked to its ability to change the cell's metabolism. The study found that the bacteria regulates the cell's metabolism at the metabolic level, impacting disease pathology. The bacteria's strategies to cause disease were revealed by the study's design, which included different strains with various virulence traits. The study found that blood sugar levels contribute to disease by affecting the cell's ability to fight off the bacteria. This adds to the relationship between diabetes and TB, a known risk factor for the disease.
Researchers studied the role of ZHP-3, a protein in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, in meiotic recombination and chromosome segregation. Meiotic recombination and chiasma formation ensure proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during the first meiotic division. Z-3, the C. elegans ortholog of the yeast ZIP gene, is required for recombination. The study found that Z-3 protein is dynamic, shifting from the synaptonal complex (SC) to asymmetric localization on the SC and eventually to foci marking crossover events. A Z-3::GFP transgene partially complements a null mutation, promoting wild-type recombination but high aneuploidy among progeny, indicating defects in meiotic segregation. The bivalent structure is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting segregation defect from inability to remodel chromosomes in response to crosso. SMO-1 mutants exhibit similar phenotypes at higher temperatures, and SMO;Z-3G double mutants more severe meiotic defects than single, consistent with SUM role in SC assembly and bivalent differentiation. The study proposes coordination of recombination with SC assembly and bivalent formation reflects conserved role Zip/ZHP in recombination with morphogenesis.
Aedes albopus, a tropical mosquito species, has spread to temperate regions of Europe and the US, causing public health concerns due to its ability to transmit diseases and nuisance due to its daytime biting behavior. Researchers studied eco-climatic factors affecting Ae. albopus abundance in metropolitan and suburban areas in Rome, Italy, which was colonized in 1997 and is now one of the most infested areas in Southern Europe. Adult mosquitoes were monitored along a 70km-long transect across the metropolitan area, and two spatial-temporal datasets were used to analyze the effect of climatic and environmental variables on Ae. abundance. Results showed a strong association between urban habitats and high abundance in both metropolitan and suburban areas, with "green" islands" of abundance in metropolitan areas, and bimodal dynamics with a peak in autumn due to heavy rains and warm temperatures. The study suggests prioritizing mosquito control measures in urban areas where human-mos contact and disease transmission risk are higher, and public health risks after summer months with high mosquito densities.
Researchers have studied how Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), a bacterium that causes tuberculosis, invades host cells called macrophages. They found that a group of lipids called phiocer dimocates (DIM) play a key role in this process. DIM are major virulence factors of M, meaning they help the bacterium cause disease. To understand how DIM work, the researchers created mutants of M that couldn't make DIM. They found that DIM help M enter macrophages by changing the host cell's plasma membrane. This change makes it easier for M to be engulfed by the cell. The researchers also found that DIM prevent the acidification of the phagosome, a process that would normally kill the bacterium. They used drugs to remove cholesterol from the cell membrane and found that this abolished the difference between wild-type and mutant strains. Inserting a cholesterol probe showed that the membrane's hydrophobic core changed upon contact with M, but lateral diffusion was unaffected. This effect was dependent on DIM and consistent with a model. The researchers propose that DIM control M invasion by modifying the host membrane's lipid organization, making it more favorable for receptor-mediated phagocytosis. This contributes to the bacterium's survival in a protective niche.
Researchers have been using mean-field approximations to study large neural networks, but these methods don't accurately describe small networks of a few neurons. This is a problem in neuroscience, as many studies involve networks of tens of neurons. To address this, a new analysis of small networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons is developed. The dynamics of these networks are studied with a method that's analytically tractable and numerically, and global bifurcations are determined. It's found that strong inhibition leads to complex dynamics, with multiple solutions emerging through symmetry-breaking. This is a finite-size effect, revealing differences between mesoscopic circuits and mean-field approximations. Symmetry-breaking allows mesoscopic networks to regulate heterogeneity, reducing noise's effect on information processing.

The mean-field approximation differs when inhibitory weights are strong. Symmetry-breaking causes a pitchfork bifurcation, with multiple solutions emerging. New bifurcations occur, enriching complexity. The dynamics of small networks were pioneered by Beer, studying bifurcations with symmetric weights and asymptotic approximations. Most literature deals with 2-4 neurons, while methods for tens of neurons are limited. This work extends analysis to biologically plausible networks, deriving bifcation manifolds with less constraints. A finite-size model with excitatory and inhibitory populations is considered. Mean-field provides an approximation, neglecting phenomena like transitions and correlations.
Researchers investigated the presence and viability of Leishmania parasites in extraional sites during human dermal leishiasis. They used Leish 7RNA to estimate parasite burden and viability in extraional sites of dermal leishias patients. The study evaluated the feasibility of discriminating parasite viability by PCR of Leish 7RNA in relation to luciferase activity of transfected intracellular amastigotes in dose-response assays. Monocytes, tonsil swabs, and skin aspirates of 28 cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishias patients were screened by DNA amplification/Southern blot. Positive samples were analyzed by quantitative PCR of Leish 7RNA genes and transcripts. Results showed that 7RNA amplification coincided with lucifer activity, confirming parasite viability. Of 22 patients presenting DNA in extraional samples, Leish 7RNA or genes transcripts were detected in one or more DNA samples 100% and 73% respectively. Gene transcript number from extraional tissues were comparable to lesions. 7RNA were detected in 13/19 (68%) monocytes, 5/12 (42%) tonsil sw, 4/11 (36%) normal aspir, and 22/25 (88%) lesions. Viable parasites present in extraional sites, including monocytes, tons, and skin of dermalias patients. Leish 7RNA is informative for clinical and epidemiologic investigations of human leias.
Researchers have found a way to predict when DNA replication occurs in fruit fly cells using a combination of chromatin features, such as histone modifications and chromatin-binding proteins. Chromatin is the complex of DNA and proteins that makes up chromosomes. Histone modifications (HMs) and chromatin-binding proteins (CB) are crucial for DNA replication, but no single one is essential, suggesting they work together like a code. Unlike gene expression, the relationship between chromatin features and replication was unknown. The study used a comprehensive collection of 95 chrom features to predict DNA replication timing in fruit flies using statistical models. Combinations of chrom features showed moderate predictive power, while interactions between histone modifications led to accurate genome-wide predictions that can be improved by chromatin proteins. A simplified model of the relationship between chromatin and replication was derived, reaching 80% of the model's accuracy using six terms. Combinations of histone modifications also predicted DNA timing across different cell types. The study supports the existence of combinatorial histone patterns for replication and reveals cell-type elements, whose investigation might explain the regulation of this fundamental process.
Dengue virus, a mosquito-borne disease, affects 390 million people worldwide and causes at least 25,000 deaths annually, mainly in tropical and subtropical regions. Researchers studied the spread of three deng virus serotypes (DENV-1, DENV-2, and DENV-3) in Brazil using genetic data. They found that new lineages of each serotype were introduced every 7-10 years, likely from the Caribbean to North and Northeast Brazil, then spreading at a rate of 0.5 km/day. The study suggests that human and mosquito transportation, not mosquito infestation or distance, drives deng virus spread in Brazil. 

The researchers analyzed 178 Brazilian genome sequences to determine factors affecting deng spread nationwide using a spatial model. Predictors of spread included geographic distance, air traffic, mosquito infestation, population density, and area. They found that human and mosquito transportation played a key role in deng spread. The study shows distinct introductions and circulation of serotypes and genotypes, highlighting air's impact on deng spread in Brazil, with new lineages followed by outbreaks every 7-10 years. Epidemiological data supports this, with deng peaks coinciding with new lineage introductions every 7-10 years. However, caution is needed when predicting viral emergence, as recent deng serotype 4 introduction from Asia shows new lineages can be introduced by chance.
Scientists have long sought to understand how the brain processes sensory information and leads to perception and behavior, known as the neural code. A key aspect of this is how neurons interact with each other, as they are not independent but correlated. Correlations between neurons have a significant impact on coding. Researchers investigated how differences in the center-surround receptive field organization across three sensory maps in weakly electric fish influence correlations between electrosens pyram neurons. Using a model based on anatomical differences in field size and overlap, they predicted large differences in activity across maps. However, in vivo recordings showed contrary to predictions, electens pyram neurons in all three segments displayed nearly identical correlations. To explain this, the effects of surround were incorporated into the model. By varying the surround size relative to the center, multiple structures gave similar correlations. Incorporating physiological differences between maps in the model resulted in similar correlations. The study shows center alone does not determine correlations, important for understanding structure's influence on activity.
Researchers investigated how noise in the responses of neurons affects the ability to encode a stimulus in a population of neurons. They considered a general setting where the tuning curves and heterogeneity of the neurons were not specified, and varied the level of noise to see how it impacted performance. The results showed that if the noise between pairs of neurons had opposite signs to their signal correlations, coding improved compared to independent responses. This "sign rule" (SR) held for different metrics and levels of heterogeneity. However, it was not a necessary condition for good coding, as diverse correlation structures that violated it could also improve performance. The optimal structures were found to lie on the boundaries of possible correlations. A set of necessary and sufficient conditions was provided for performance to be as good as without noise. An example illustrated two regimes with different properties of noise leading to optimal coding. The SR was established for homogenous correlations, but also held for heterogenous populations. Conditions for chosen noise to yield performance as good as deterministic responses were identified, satisfied with high probability for large populations.
Researchers investigated how the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa affects the susceptibility of Staphylococcus aureus to antibiotics. They found that Pseudas aerugin alters S aureus susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a strain-dependent manner and identified three interactions that either antagonize or potentiate antibiotic activity against aureus. Pseud aerugin's Las endopeptase potentiates vancomycin's effect by breaking down aure's cell wall, rhamolids facilitate proton-motive-independent vancom uptake, and 2-hepty-4-hydroquinoline N-oxide (HQ) induces multidrug tolerance in aure by inhibiting cellular respiration and ATP production. The production of these factors varies between clinical isolates and correlates with their ability to alter aure susceptibility. In a mouse burn infection, vancom treatment of aure was potentiated by the presence of Las-producing P aerugin population. These findings show that susceptibility is not only dependent on the targeted pathogen's genotype, but also on interactions with other microorganisms in the environment. Considering these interactions will improve treatment of polymicrobial infections.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism of platelet clearance in patients with deng virus (DENV) infection, which contributes to thrombocytopenia and bleeding complications. They found that patients with deng had higher levels of von Wille factor (VWF), a protein that binds to platelets, and platelets had more VWF on their surface. The amount of VWF on platelets correlated with plate count. Sialic acid, a molecule on plate surface, was reduced in deng patients, but not due to virus neuraminidase activity. Instead, VWF binding to platelets caused sial loss through platelet neuraminase, an enzyme on plate surface. Inhibiting neuraminase with oseltivir reduced V-induced sial loss. The study suggests that excessive V binding to platelets in deng leads to neuraminase-mediated sial loss and clearance. Oseltiv may treat severe thrombocytopenia in deng.
Researchers have identified a new type of gene regulation in the human genome called bidirectional promoters, where two genes with opposite directions are controlled by a shared regulatory region. These promoters are often linked to genes involved in DNA repair and may play a role in cancer development. Using a database of expressed sequences, they found the most complete list of human genes under bidirectional control and discovered new promoters that function as alternative or novel transcripts. They found a significant enrichment of bidirectional promoters in cancer-related genes, including breast and ovarian cancer. The use of this structure in the genome suggests it regulates co-expression among groups of genes. Microarray data from 79 human tissues verified regulatory networks controlled by bidirectional promoters. Some promoters have similar transcription binding sites, including conserved ETS factor sites in ERBB, FCD, and BRCA.

A new algorithm was developed to map bidirectional promoters in the genome using expressed sequences. The set of promoters shows relationships among regulated by bidirectional through co-expression. A subset of promoters regulating breast and ovarian cancer genes contain common transcription sites. Misregulation of bidirectional promoters, especially with common sites, may contribute to cancer development. Data confirmed expression of flanking transcripts for 91%, 58%, and 65% of promoters in genes, EST, and datasets. Enrichment of bidirectional with DNA repair genes implies a link to cancer pathways. Data confirm association with somatic cancer and indicate type relevant. Bidirectional promoters in uter and ovarian cancers were examined. Expression-clustering showed bid not a single network or thousands of pairs, but intermediate relationships between. Ovarian genes showed one or both members significant with bid promoters.
Researchers have studied the sex chromosomes of flies, specifically Diptera, which include fruit flies like Drosophila melanogaster, to understand how sex is determined in these insects. They analyzed the genomes of 37 fly species from 22 different families and found a surprising diversity of sex chromosome types, with over a dozen different configurations. The small dot chromosome is often used as the sex chromosome, but some species have undifferentiated chromosomes, others replaced the dot with a different chromosome, or incorporated up to three elements into the sex chromosome, and some have female heterogamy (Z sex) chromosomes. Transcript analysis shows that dosage compensation, a mechanism to balance gene expression, evolved multiple times in flies by upregulating the single X in males. However, X chromosomes have fewer genes with male-biased expression, possibly due to sex-specific pressures.

Comparative studies of high-quality genomes and transcriptomes of species with independent sex chromosomes will reveal how X chromosomes became demasculized. The analysis reveals a diversity of sex chromosomes hidden underneath similar karyotypes. Chromosomes have been lost, gained, rearranged, or replaced multiple times in Dipt evolution. Data suggest Dipt ancestrally had homomorphic chromosomes and the dot became sex in flies, or the dot was ancestral but reverted to autosomal in mosquitoes and flies. Higher flies show diverse sex kary.
Researchers investigated blood samples from 18 mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and 12 who gave birth to healthy babies in Hawaii between 2009-2012. They tested the blood for Zika virus (ZIK) IgM and IgG antibodies using a commercial kit. One mother who delivered a baby with microaly tested positive for ZIK IgM (16.6%) and three tested positive for ZIK IgG (50%). ZIK showed a trend with microaly. Mothers with ZIK IgG antibodies were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those without (OR 11.0, 95% CI 0.8-147.9, p=0.083). Similarly, ZIK IgM positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microaly than those without (OR 6.8, 95 CI 0.2-195.1). These findings suggest a link between ZIK infection and microaly and presence of ZV cases in the US as early as 2009.
Researchers investigated the transmission of Mycobacterium ulcerans (MU) infections in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where Buruli ulcer (BU) is prevalent. Although previous studies linked MU to slow-moving water bodies, the exact mode of transmission was unclear. The team used Variable Number Tand Repeat (VN) typing to differentiate MU from other mycobacteria. They matched VN profiles of MU in human samples to environmental samples from 10 water bodies in four endemic communities. Four VN loci in the MU99 genome were used to genotype environmental and human isolates. Sequencing confirmed polymorphism. MU was found in three types of water, but higher in biofilm samples. Four genotypes W, X, Y, and Z were typed in both human and environmental samples. Other genotypes were only in water. A mouse with BU-like lesion was infected with MU. The study suggests patients may have been infected from community water bodies and small mammals within communities could be susceptible to MU.
Researchers analyzed a large database of bird species to understand what drives the global distribution of alien species. They found that the number of alien species in different areas is influenced by a combination of human and environmental factors, with human activities introducing species to new locations and environments allowing them to persist. However, the global and temporal drivers of alien species introduction and richness are not well understood. The study found that the origins and identities of alien birds were largely driven by European colonialism, mainly British, but recent introductions are more widespread and involve more species and countries, driven by economic activity. Globally, alien species richness is highest at mid-latitudes and determined by human effects, notably the number of introduced species. Environmental factors also play a role, with native and alien species positively associated. The study shows that colonization pressure is key to understanding species richness and areas with high native species are resistant to alien at a global scale, emphasizing threats to environments from introductions.
Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a protein that helps RNA polymerase I (RPol I) transcribe ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes. However, its ability to bind to any DNA and form nucleosome-like complexes suggests a broader role in chromatin structure. Research showed that depleting UBF reduced rRNA genes, but had little effect on synthesis or cell growth, leaving its role in R I transcription unclear. Using a mouse model, researchers found UBF is essential for embryo development beyond morula stage. Conditional deletion in cells revealed UBF is also essential for r gene transcription and defines chromatin conformation of enhancer sequences. Loss of U prevents SL/TIFB initiation and RPI/T1 complex recruitment, accompanied by H3K9, histone H1, and HPα, but not DNA methylation. Genes retain H4 and H2, suggesting rRNA can maintain active state without U. Unexpectedly, rRNA loss does not suppress 5, tRNA or snRNA, or hundreds of genes in ribosome biogenesis. U also induces formation of somatic nucleolar precursor body (NPB) containing r synthesis factors, but not r loci.
Researchers have challenged a long-held understanding of how the Wingless/Wnt signaling pathway, a crucial for cell growth and development in animals, works in the adult intestine. This pathway is often overactive in most colorectal cancers. In the past, it was thought that Wingless must be secreted and move to distant cells to signal properly pattern tissues. However, a recent study found that a membrane-bound form of Wingless produced normal adults, suggesting secretion and movement are not necessary for patterning. This study tested this principle in the adult intestine, where Wingless signals mark boundaries between compartments. Results show that Wingless is essential for regulating gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell fate, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling with the Decaplegic pathway, all disrupted by Wing tethering. These findings support the need for direct, long-range action of Wingless in patterning, relevant to development, tissue homeostasis, and Wnt-driven disease. 

The adult gut forms through different mechanisms than the larva and has unique demands, including continuous turnover and regeneration. The study focused on W pathway gradients in the intestine, demarcating major compartments. The role of morphogens in patterning was unclear until the 1990s, resolved by studies on conserved pathways Wingless and Decaplegic in Drosophila. Defects in W pathway in epithelium indicate W secretion and movement are critical for gut development. This identifies a context where direct action of W in patter is unambiguous, supporting previous studies in larval disc.

The Doph intestine, like mammalian, is maintained by stem cells and subdivided into compartments with different types, expression, histology, physiology, and function.
Researchers studied the role of urokinase plasogen activator (uPA) in Group A streptococcus (GAS) infections, a leading cause of global morbidity and mortality. They found that uPA contributes to plasmin recruitment and invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of host plasogen activators, streokinase was required for surface plmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of streokin, uPA was sufficient to promote surface plmin acquisition by strain 544 during incubation with plmin or human plasma. GAS also activated zym pro-uPA in human plasma. To assess u's contribution to invasive disease, a transgenic mouse model was used. C57/6 and AlbG mice expressing human plmin transgene were more susceptible to invasive disease than u− mice. Decreased virulence in u− mice correlated with decreased dissemination and reduced surface plmin by GAS. These findings have implications for understanding GAS pathogenesis and targeting plmin activation in bacterial infections.
Helicobacter pylori exploits a unique repertoire of Type IV secretion system components for pilus assembly at the bacteria-host interface. Colonization of the stomach by H. pylori is a significant risk factor for gastric cancer development. The H. pylori pathogenic island (cPA) encodes components of a Type IV system (TSS) that translocates the oncoprotein Cag into gastric epithelial cells, and Cag is a component of cTSS that binds host αβ1 integrin. Researchers used mass spectrometry to co-purify Cag, Cag (integrin-binding protein), and Cag (protein with sequence similarity to C). These proteins are encoded by contiguous genes in cPA and detectable on the bacterial surface. All proteins are required for C translocation into host cells and H. pyl-induced IL-8 secretion by epithelial cells. However, proteins are not homologous components of TSS in other species. Scanning microscopy reveals proteins involved in pilus formation between H. pyl and epithelial cells. Δag and ΔcL strains fail to form pilus, whereas ΔH strain exhibits hyperiliated and elongated pilus compared to wild-type. This suggests pilus dimensions regulated by C. A conserved C-terminal hexapeptide in C, C, C, and C. Deletion motifs abrogate C translocation and IL-8, and C-terminal motifs C and C required pilus formation.
Researchers studied gene expression in cattle vaccinated against bovine tuberculosis (bTB) to identify predictors of protection. Bovine TB is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium bovis, a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis group. Vaccination is a long-term solution to control the disease, with a focus on developing a cattle vaccine against TB. Identifying biomarkers remains elusive, and the goal is to find host correlates of protection. The team hypothesized that studying gene expression could identify in vitro predictors to help vaccine development. Cattle were vaccinated with BCG or heterologous B prime-adenovirus vectored subunit boosting. Efficacy was determined after M bovis challenge. RNA was prepared from P-stimulated PB from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected and unaccinated control prior Mbo challenge and expression by RNAseq. 668 genes were differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected compared vaccinated-un and unacc control. Cytokine-cytokine interaction was most related with IL-22 identified as dominant of protection besides INFγ. Expression of these genes by RNAseq was evaluated RT-qPCR in independent PB samples BCG vaccinated unacc. This confirmed IL as predictor of vaccine efficacy.
Researchers studied how microtubules are organized in cells, specifically at a structure called the non-centrosomal microtub organizing center (ncTOC). This structure is found in most cells, but how it regulates microtule organization is not well understood. They created a system to test the role of two proteins, γ-tulin ring complex (γ-TRC) and AIR-1/AurA, at the apical ncTO in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal cells. γ-TRC and AIR-1 are required to form microtules at the centrosome, but not at the apical ncTO. However, microtules remain organized at the apical ncTO when γ-T and AIR are depleted. This suggests different microule centers use distinct proteins for their function. The apical ncTO is composed of two populations: γu-dependent and -independent microtules that compete for resources.
Researchers compared 11 different methods for phasing human genomes, which is the process of determining the origin of genetic material from each parent. Most human genome initiatives do not do this due to cost and complexity. They used the NA128 genome as a standard. The methods included laboratory-based and computational approaches. Laboratory methods prepared DNA in unique ways to facilitate phasing, while computational methods used sequencing data and population haplotype information. Metrics included error rates, haplotype lengths, and phasing accuracy. A hybrid approach using population phasing, genome sequencing, and haplotype frequencies produced accurate results. Population phasing improved with genome data, and parental genotypes reduced errors by 10-fold. A voting scheme combining multiple predictions enhanced performance. Regions with phasing errors had low polymorphism and SNV density.
Researchers studied how the type-III protein secretion system in Salmonella enterica, a type of bacteria that causes disease in humans. This system is used to secrete proteins that help the bacteria move and infect host cells. They found that the system can work without an enzyme called ATPase, which was thought to be necessary for the process. Instead, the bacteria used energy from a force called proton motive force to secrete the proteins. This force is created by a difference in the concentration of protons across the cell membrane. The researchers also found that this force can bypass the need for another enzyme called Salmonella pathogenic island 1, which is important for the bacteria's virulence. Their results show that ATPase is not necessary for type-III protein secretion and propose its role is to help deliver substrates to the export apparatus and ensure efficient secretion. The study has implications for the evolution of the flagellum and type-III systems in bacteria.
Researchers studied a large family of simple biochemical networks, called gene regulatory networks (GRNs), which control essential biological functions like cell differentiation and cell cycle. They used a computational method called chemical reaction network theory to analyze over 40,000 possible networks formed by two-factor genes and their proteins, assuming basic biochemical processes. The study found that about 90% of these networks can be bistable, meaning they can switch between two or more states, including some without typical features associated with bistable systems. Most could only be identified as bistable through detailed analysis. The researchers identified 11 minimal bistable networks, which cannot be broken down into smaller bistable sub-networks. This suggests that bistable behavior in GRNs is common and not easily lost through evolution. To apply this method to real systems, they used data from yeast and found several GRNs predicted to be bistable. 

The study used a class of small GRNs with two-factor genes and proteins, finding 36,771 bistable networks out of 40,680. The entire family can be understood from 11 minimal bistable networks, which cannot be broken down into smaller bistable sub-networks. Analysis showed 36% of networks are bistable for some parameters, 9% have multiple states, and 6.5% are monostable regardless of parameters. The study focused on basic transcriptional regulation but did not include all mechanisms. One way to achieve nonlinearity is degradation of TF dimers, which protects against proteolysis. The identified networks are not guaranteed bistable but their topologies make them good candidates, providing hypotheses for experimentation. This approach can be used for other systems with available data.
Researchers have identified a new genetic cause of orofacial cleft, a common birth defect, in humans and mice. Mutations in the HY2 gene, which encodes hyaluronidase 2, an enzyme that breaks down hyaluronic acid, a key component of the developing palate and heart tissue, lead to the condition. Studies in mice showed that these mutations reduce hyalidase levels, resulting in craniofacial abnormalities, including submucal cleft palate. Some mice also had triatum sinister, a rare heart defect, and hearing loss. Similar features were found in humans with HY2 mutations. This is the first explanation for triatum sinister in humans. The study highlights the importance of hyal turnover for normal development in humans and mice.
Researchers have discovered a new details about how the inner hair cells in the ear detect sound. These cells have tiny links called stereocilia that convert sound into electrical signals. The links are made of two proteins, protocadherin 15 (PCD15) and cadherin 23 (CD23). Scientists thought the links were static, but now they found that they change. When sound hits the ear, links break and need to be fixed. Hair cells can fix links and restore hearing, but the process was unknown. Researchers used a special microscope to see the links and proteins. They found two types of links: one with PCD15 at both ends and one with P15 at one end and CD23 at the other. When links break, CD23 goes away and P15 moves to the side of the cell. New links form with P15 at both ends first, then change to P15 at one end and CD23 at the other. This process helps hair cells detect sound normally. The study shows how hair cells fix links and keep hearing.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a prevalent arbovirus that causes an estimated 100 million symptomatic deng infections every year, with a spectrum of clinical manifestations ranging from mild deng fever (DF) to life-threatening deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF). The transition from DF to DHF is not well understood. A mass spectrometry-based metabolomic profiling of sera from adult DF and DH patients at critical and recovery phases of infection identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Bile acids were up to 5-fold higher in DH compared to DF patients, correlated with higher aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transamin (ALT) levels, indicating liver injury. Uric acid, the most abundant antioxidant in blood, was 1.5-fold lower in DH compared to DF, suggesting decreased endogenous defense and oxidative stress. In the recovery phase, eight metabolites remained higher or lower in DH patients, including chodeoxyglycolic acid, a bile acid. This indicates prolonged liver impact from DENV in DH patients. Altered metabolic pathways linked to DH in critical and recovery phases of deng infection were identified, providing insights into host-DENV interactions between DF and DH. This study advances understanding of DH pathogenesis, suggesting novel targets for deng management.
Researchers have identified a key enzyme called guanine 5'-monophosphate reductase (GMPR) in the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypaniasis. This enzyme plays a crucial role in converting guanine 5'-monophosphate (GMP) to inosine 5'-monophosphate (IMP), maintaining the balance of purine nucleotides inside the parasite. The study found that the GR in T. brucei is distinct from those in animals, with a unique insertion of a cystathion synthase (CBS) domain. The recombinant protein of T. bruce GR catalyzed the conversion of G to IMP in the presence of NAD, with different affinities for G and NAD compared to animal GRs. The addition of monoval cations like K and NH4 increased GR activity of T. bruce, but not animal GRs. The purine analog ribavir inhibited T. br GR, but not animal GR. This suggests the mechanism of GR in T. br is different from animals. The study also showed that ribavir inhibited the growth of trypanosomes in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting its potential as a new therapeutic agent against trypanias.
Researchers used computer simulations to study how two drugs, benzocaine and phenyto, block sodium channels in cells. Sodium channels control electrical activity in cells and are used to treat seizures, arrhythmia, and pain. To develop new drugs that target specific channels, scientists need to know how current blockers work. The study used a crystal structure of a bacterial sodium channel, Nav, to find where benzaine and pheny bind and how they enter the channel. Both drugs bind in two areas with non-specific, hydrophobic interactions: one above the gate and at the entrance to the lipid-filled fenestrations. Three methods found the same sites and suggest binding at the gate is more favorable. The drugs can pass through fenestr with small energy, suggesting a hydroobic route. The study highlights important residues directing drugs into fenestr and forming binding sites.
Researchers investigated the role of MyD88 signaling in the immune response to intestinal infection with the pathogen C. rodium. My88 is a key component of the immune system that helps fight off infections, but its specific role in the intestine was not well understood. To study this, they created mice that could turn on or off My88 in specific cell types. They found that My88 in dendritic cells (DC) and intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) were crucial for fighting off the infection. In DC, My88 activated an early immune response called group 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILC) and Th17/Th cells. In IEC, My88 kept the epithelial barrier strong and made antimicrobial peptides. Without My88 in these cells, mice were more susceptible to infection. My in other cells, like macrophages and T cells, did not help much. The study shows that My88 in DC and IEC are essential for a full response to C. rodium infection.
Researchers are working to eliminate onchocerciasis, a parasitic worm disease, in Africa through annual or biannual mass drug administration (MDA). One tool to determine if transmission is interrupted and treatment can stop is an immunodiagnostic test detecting IgG antibodies in blood to Onchocerca volulus antigen Ov16. A mathematical model, ONOS, was extended to include Ov antibody serostatus of individuals. Seroconversion occurs when the worm establishes in host, before or after maturation or mf production. The study focused on serconversion in children, ignoring seroreversion. Yearly MDA reduces parasite rate in humans, lowering serconversion in newborns and young, while those serconverted remain positive. Microfilaria prevalence in 5+ and Ov antibody in under 10 declined with M duration. The association between indicators and predicted probability of elimination depends on endemic levels, serconversion trigger, and test sensitivity/specificity. Understanding Ov antibody dynamics is crucial for accurate interpretation and precise endpoint MDA. The study shows endpoint depends on endemic levels, to be considered in guidelines for stopping M.
Researchers have found that prions, a type of infectious protein, can change their properties when grown in different environments. When prions that were sensitive to a drug called swainine were grown in a cell line called PK1 in the presence of swine, drug-resistant variants emerged. This suggests that prions are made up of a mix of different variants, and the fittest ones are selected in a particular environment. Even after cloning, prion populations showed heterogeneity, indicating mutations occur at the conformation level. Brain-derived prions are naturally resistant to swine, so it was not surprising that pr that became sensitive after growth in cells could revert to resistance. However, pr grown in brain or PK cells are swine sensitive, researchers investigated if it was possible to select swine-resistant by growth in presence of drug. Interestingly, this was not possible with standard PK cells, but certain sublines of PK allowed swine-resistant, even swine-dependent (propagated more in presence of drug) to be isolated. Once established, they could be passed in PK cells without losing swine dependence. Misfolded pr protein (Pr) associated with swine variant was cleared faster in PK cells than its sensitive counterpart, indicating structural differences of misfold Pr underlie pr properties. Propagation of pr in inhibitory drug may cause selection of resistant pr and variants that propagate efficiently in presence drug. Adaptations likely due conformation changes abnormal pr protein.
Researchers have mapped out the vast space of all possible metabolic systems that extract energy from carbon sources, a fundamental to life. They analyzed 101 of these systems, each with all possible combinations of 51 reactions, to see how they work on 10 different carbon sources. This led to 102 possible outcomes, or "phenotypes". Most systems with one outcome make up a tiny fraction of the space, but there are over 100 million with the same outcome. These systems often form a network, where any can be reached from each other with a few changes. The distance between systems with different outcomes is small, allowing for new systems to adapt to new sources with few changes. However, some systems with many reactions struggle to survive. Increasing complexity helps systems adapt and innovate. 

The researchers looked at neighborhoods of systems on the same source to see if they have new outcomes. If so, which outcomes depend on where in space a system is located. They compared 100 pairs of systems, each with one reaction different, on a source. A system's outcome is a string of 10, with 1 for viable or 0 for not on a source. A change is innovative if leads to new outcomes on sources. To study this, they looked at a small space of 101 systems. Metabolism is attractive because it extracts energy from carbon and limited to 10 sources and 102 outcomes. Most systems are different, but many in one network. They asked how this applies to systems on multiple sources. This is harder, with 10 sources and 102 outcomes. They sampled 100 systems from each network on sources. Each outcome is a vector of 10, with 1 for viable or 0 on source. They asked if multiple new outcomes near a system exist.
Researchers studied the genetic variation and geographic distribution of the Triatoma dimata complex, a parasite that transmits Trypanosoma cruzi, the cause of Chagas disease, across Mexico and the Neotropics. They analyzed two fragments of the ND4 gene to identify specific haplogroups and found that genetic diversity was lowest in areas with most human modification, where T cruz infection was highest. Haplog 1 and 3 had more T cruz than expected, while hap 2 had less. There was a difference in DT and DTI frequencies in hap 1 and 3, but not in 2. All Neotropical hapgroups had moderate to high diversity, with greatest between 1 and 3. The complex diverged from its most recent common ancestor 0.97-0.85 million years ago, with primary divergence of 2 and 3. Effective population size of 1 and 2 increased 0.02-0.03 million years ago. This study supports the origin of the complex around the Tehante Isthmus and recent divergence of three haplogroups with differential T cruz infection and DT specificity, important for vector capacity.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFR) is a rod-borne disease caused by hantaviruses, mainly Hanta virus and Seoul virus. Environmental factors affect the risk of contracting hant infections by influencing rodent dynamics and human-rod contact. This study aimed to identify environmental factors favoring rod-to-human transmission to inform prevention and control strategies. Data from 2006-2015 on rodent hosts, havirus, epidemiology, and environment were analyzed. 709 HFR cases were included. Rod species in Chhou, a hotspot, were Rattus norvegicus, Musculus, Rflavius, and others. Species played different roles in various land types, all associated with transmission. Some were linked to FR in forest and water, while R norveicus and Ravius to grassland, and Mus and Ravi to built land. Rod community was associated with environmental variability. Predictive models showed cultivated land highest risk for FR incidence, matching 2014-201 statistics. Heterogeneity of FR may be influenced by rod community, associated with local conditions. Future work should focus on preventing FR in moist environments.
Researchers have found that mutations in the HRAS gene, which can cause Costello syndrome (CS), a rare genetic disorder, can also be found in cancer. They discovered a new mutation, c.35_36>T, in a 12-year-old boy with mild CS. Analysis showed high levels of exon 2 skipping in HRAS DNA. Using wild and mutant HR genes, they confirmed that c.35_36>T causes skipping by disrupting a splicing enhancer and creating a splicing silencer. They found that HR exon 2 is vulnerable due to a weak 3' splice site, making it dependent on splicing proteins like SRS2. Most cancer and CS-causing mutations are located here, affecting splicing differently. Results show that CS and cancer phenotype is not only determined by mutant HRAS transforming potential, but also by exon 2 inclusion efficiency from different mutations. A splicing oligonucleotide (SO) that blocks the enhancer causes skipping and halts cancer cell proliferation, revealing a potential for new cancer therapy.
Researchers have found that a specific enzyme called METTL3 plays a crucial role in the development of the cerebellum, a part of the brain responsible for motor control and coordination. METTL adds a chemical modification called m6 to RNA, which helps regulate gene expression and protein production. In mice without METTL, the cerebellum does not develop properly, leading to a condition called cerebellar hypoplasia. This is caused by the death of granule cells in the cerebellum, which are essential for its function. The study found that METTL's m6 modification affects the stability and splicing of RNA, leading to changes in gene expression and cell death. The researchers conclude that METTL is essential for cerebell development and m6 modification is key to its proper function.
Researchers have studied how transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG work together to regulate gene expression in embryonic stem (ES) cells. These cells can become any cell type in the developing embryo. They found that when these factors bind together, they are with a co-activator called H3ac and increase nearby gene expression. Many of these binding sites are active in early development. Comparing human and mouse ES cells, they found that only 5% of individual binding events are shared, but 15% of combinatorial binding and 53-63% of combinator binding at enhancers are conserved. This suggests that the combination of OCT, SO2, and NANOG is critical for ES cells and plays a role in early development by binding conserved enhancers. They also found that rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual binding, while "hotspots" bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues are under evolutionary constraints. In ES cells, combinatorial binding of OCT, SO2, and NAN identifies enhancers with H3ac and Med localization. Many combinatorially bound enhancers are active in early development. This implies conserved combinatorial events in ES control key genes involved in differentiation and connects pluripotency and development through OCT, SO2, and NANOG binding at enhancers.
AML/ETO, a protein resulting from a chromosomal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21, initiates acute myel leukemia by recruiting co-repressor complexes to DNA. It interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, A1, by targeting A1 binding sites. However, transcriptional regulation by A/ETO likely relies on a complex network, as the protein interacts with other transcription factors, including E-proteins, and targets other sites on DNA. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling identified AETO-dependent transcriptional regulation. AETO was found to co-localize with A, demonstrating the fusion follows the binding pattern of the wild protein but does not primarily displace it. The binding of E-protein H was rearranged upon AETO expression, and the protein co-localized with A and H on many regulated targets. Furthermore, the level of H was increased in primary and cell lines expressing AETO. Our results suggest a major role for the interaction of AETO with A and H in transcription regulation by the protein.
Researchers investigated the role of the Leishmania donani histone acetyltransferase H2 (H2) in regulating gene expression. They found that H2 acetylates histone H4 in vitro and in vivo, and is essential for cell growth and survival. Without H2, cells had defects in cell cycle progression and poor survival. The team discovered that downregulation of cyclins CY4 and CY9, responsible for S and G2/M phase defects in H2-depleted cells. Leish genes are arranged in unidirectional clusters, with genes coordinately transcribed as polyc units from divergent strand regions (SS), which initiate bidirectionally on opposite strands. CY4 and CY9 have their own promoters, activated in a cell-dependent manner. Two tiers of regulation exist: transcription of polyc units initiates at SS, likely constitutively, while a subset have their own promoters, some activated cell-dependently. The second tier is sensitive to H10 acylation, resulting in downregulation in H-de cells. This study reveals cell-specific activation of promoters in trypanoids, uncovering new facets of regulation in this family.
Researchers investigated how people infer the intentions of others in social interactions. They created a game where 16 pairs of volunteers played a probabilistic task, with one as "player" and one "adviser". The adviser had more information and gave a recommendation. The game made the adviser's incentives to help or mislead change over time. Using a Bayesian model, they found that players' behavior was best explained by hierarchical learning: they estimated the adviser's intentions to predict advice accuracy. Volatility also affected decisions: players trusted advice more when they thought adviser's intentions were stable. The model predicted players' ratings of adviser helpfulness and adviser's self-reported strategy. Results suggest people use hierarchical models to infer intentions, use volatility in decision-making, and combine advice with other info. The framework can measure individual differences and may help study maladaptive social cognition.

In the game, players with changing adviser intentions showed stronger hierarchical learning and used volatility to update advice. Participants with helpful advisers saw intentions as stable and weighted advice more. A model with hierarchical learning and volatility explained behavior best. Players' updating reflected adviser's policy and used advice in decisions. Those with helpful advisers saw intentions as stable and weighted advice more, shown by lower volatility and higher values.
Scrub typhus, a disease endemic in Asia, has been found in urban areas, including Seoul, South Korea's largest city. From 2010 to 2013, national data showed indigenous scrub typh cases in Seoul. Researchers analyzed clinical features of patients from a hospital and compared them to a control group. Chigger mites were collected in the city and identified using DNA sequencing. Eighty-eight cases of scrub typh were found in Seoul, mostly in mountain areas (56.8%), parks (20.5%), near homes (17%), and rivers (5.7%). Eighty-seven chigger mites were collected in Gak mountain, with 87.4% identified as Helenula miag and 9.2 as Leotridium. DNA from miag mites yielded O tsugushi Bong strain. Twenty-six patients had low APACHE score, low complication rate, and no hypalemia. The study found indigenous scrub in Seoul and a subgroup with mild features. Ch mites miag infected O tsugushi within the city in endemic area. Scrub ty needs to be considered a differential disease and target for prevention.

Patients visited hospital due to fever, 96.2 had maculopular skin rash. Studies have shown urban scrub in literature. This study investigated status and characteristics in Seoul at northern latitude. Prospectively determined causative mites within the city. Presence of O tsugushi in ch mites confirmed. Composition of miag m and infection Otsug are findings. Study shows scrub can spread into area under high incidence, though slow increase and magnitude. Mites infest mammals, birds, domestic cats, and dogs. Proportion of miag in high area with Otsug, dominant Bong, suggests may play role in infection. However, needs further data to determine role.
Researchers studied the role of a protein called HENN-1 in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, which is involved in the regulation of gene activity through a process called RNA interference (RNAi). They found that HENN-1 affects two types of RNA molecules, 26 and 21, which are involved in RNAi pathways. Surprisingly, the stability of 21 RNAs was only mildly affected by loss of H-1, while introduction of artificial 21 target RNA did not destabilize non-methylated 21 RN. In contrast, 26 RN displayed reduced stability and responded to loss of H- by increased 3-uridylation. Within the 26 class, they found that ER-1-bound 26 RN were modified by H- while AL-3/4-bound 26 were not. Global expression analysis of- mutants revealed mild effects, including downregulation of gerine-expressed genes. The study suggests that apart from direct effects on 26 RNA levels, most effects on gene expression are indirect.
Researchers have identified a new role for the protein Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1 (HNF1) in regulating the process of protein glycosylation, which is the addition of sugar molecules to proteins. Glycosylation affects protein function and is involved in many physiological and pathological processes. A study of 2,705 individuals in three populations found common variants in the HNF and fucyltransferase genes F6 and F8 influence glycan levels in plasma. HNF and its target H4 regulate expression of fucyltransfer and fucose biosynthesis genes. HNF is necessary and sufficient to drive expression of these genes in liver cells. This reveals H as a master regulator of multiple stages in glycosylation process. Implications for regulation of immunity, embryonic development, protein folding, and understanding mechanisms of cancer, heart disease, metabolic, and inflammatory disorders.
Researchers have found that a protein called Centromere Protein C (CPC) is stabilized by single-stranded RNA at the centromeres, which are the points where the genome attaches to the cytoskeleton. Centromeres bind to kinetochores, which in turn bind spindles and move chromosomes. However, the DNA sequence of centrom has little role in recruiting kinetocho. This is an example of genetic information being transmitted in a way that is independent of DNA sequence, or epigenetically. The researchers found that RNA from centrom remains within the kinetore region and is part of the epigen marking system. They studied maize CPC, a key kinore protein, and found that DNA binding is conferred by a region of 122 amino acids and is sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long single-stranded nucleic acids promote binding of CPC to DNA, and types of RNAs that stabilize binding match size and character of RN present in kineto in vivo. Removing the binding module causes partial localization of CPC in vivo. The data suggest centrom RNA recruits CPC to kinore by altering DNA characteristics.

 Maize centrom repeats are undermethylated and transcribed to stable RNAs that remain bound to chromatin. Centrom RNAs are 40-200 in length, transcribed from both strands and maintained single stranded. RNA may serve as structural template to recruit kinore. Researchers used in vitro and vivo studies to show maize CPC has DNA and RNA capacities, DNA/RNA domain localized to exon region and required for centere localization. RNA facilitates binding of CPC to DNA in vitro, providing mechanism for RNA involvement in centere specification. Single-stranded RNA has strong effect on binding, suggesting centrom RNA as epetic mark that mediates final assembly. CPC is recruited kinore by protein contacts then converted to DNA binding by centrom RNA.
Researchers have identified genetic variants associated with birth weight, childhood obesity, and body mass index in children. They examined the role of the placenta, a critical organ for fetal development and postnatal health, in mediating these genetic causes. The study found that genetic variants in the placenta significantly contribute to birth weight and body mass in children. In fact, the placenta is more important for determining weight at birth and body mass in children than other tissues such as fat and liver. The researchers discovered hundreds of genes controlled by genetic variants that influence these traits. The study reveals that placental transcription in the womb plays a key role in determining body size after birth. This may lead to new possibilities for preventing childhood obesity.

The study found extensive enrichment of genetic variants in the placenta associated with birth weight, childhood, and body mass. The placenta is relevant for determining weight at birth and body in children. Identifying genes mediating genetic predisposition for these traits is crucial for understanding mechanisms and developing prevention strategies. Integrative genomics can analyze genetic results. The study shows influence of genetically controlled expression linked to birth and body mass supports this. One key finding is that placental variants are more associated with body mass hits than variants from other tissues, including fat and liver.

The study compared placental genes with genes in adult tissues, including blood, artery, fat, and muscle. Over 3,000 genes were found to be controlled by genetics, showing the placenta is transcriptionally active. This activity is largely controlled by fetal genetics. A large analysis of birth, childhood, and body mass genome association studies identified multiple loci suggesting a strong determinant for these conditions.
A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to determine the burden of post-kala-azar dermal leishiasis (PKDL) in an endemic area and compare diagnostic methods for detecting the disease. PKDL is a chronic condition that follows successful treatment of visceral leishiasis (VL) and is not life-threatening, but often goes untreated due to its cosmetic nature. The study found a prevalence of 27.5% PKDL among antileman antibody positive cases, with 26 cases detected through active surveillance and confirmed by PCR diagnosis. Three diagnostic methods were used: PCR, slit smear, and r-39 strip. PCR was most sensitive at 88.46% for confirmation. Most lesions persisted after treatment but disappeared within 6-12 months, with two cases reappearing after 1.5 years of miltefine treatment. A significant number of PK patients remained undiagnosed without active surveys, highlighting the need for such in other areas to eliminate kalaazar. PCR is helpful for diagnosis, but a well-designed study with more samples is needed to determine if PK patients are parasite-free after treatment and which need longer treatment. PK occurs in 10-20% of VL cases in India, 50-60% in Sudan, and 2% of PK cases with no history of kalaazar. Unlike VL, PK is not life-threatening and patients don't seek care, maintaining parasites in population.
Researchers have discovered that the process of "competence" in Streptococcus pneumoniae, a type of bacteria, relies on a cell-to-cell contact mechanism. Competence is a genetic program that enables the bacteria to take up new genetic material from their environment, a process called horizontal gene transfer. In the past, it was known that a signaling molecule called Competence Stimulating Peptide (CSP) triggers this process, creating a positive feedback loop. However, how this process is coordinated across the entire population was unclear. Scientists monitored competence development in real-time in four distinct pneumocococcal lineages and found that it relies on a self-activated cell fraction that arises through a growth-dependent mechanism. They found that the CSP remains bound to cells during this event and the rate of competence corresponds to contact between activated and quiescent cells. A two-step cell sensing mechanism was validated by measuring competence during co-cultivation of strains altered to produce or respond to CSP. The protein ComD retains CSP, limiting its diffusion in the medium. It is proposed that competence cells originate stochastically in response to stress, forming a subpopulation that transmits CSP by cell contact.
Human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV) L2 protein acts as a chaper to transport the viral genome (vDNA) from endosomes to the trans-Gol network (TGN) and eventually the nucleus, where replication occurs. To reach the nucleus, the L2/v complex must cross intracellular membranes. Researchers developed a system using subcellular compartmentalization of enzyme BirA and its substrate to detect translocation of L2 from incoming virions. They found that L translocation requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell arrest causes retention of L/v at TGN; release and progression past G2 enables trans across limiting membrane and infection. Microscopy of Ed-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid shift in vDNA localization during mitosis. At G2/early phase v egress from T to pericentricular location, accumulating prometaph where it begins to associate with condensed chromosomes. By metaphase and anaphase v is bound to mitotic chromosomes, ensuring distribution into daughter nuclei. Mutations in defined chromatin binding of L blocked translocation, suggesting dependent on chromatin during prometaph. This is the first virus to functionally couple penetration of membranes to mitosis, explaining part of HPV tropism for mitotic keratinocytes.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework to measure the transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen compared to another, using data from experiments where animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains. They observed the mixture in each animal over time and multiple generations of transmission, using influenza in ferrets as an example. This is important in three contexts: when new strains of influenza arise and compete for hosts, during a pandemic where a new strain competes with existing ones, and with neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) that reduce transmission but promote resistant strains. The framework also estimates the size of the transmitted inoculum, or initial amount of pathogen.

The transibility of strains is crucial in determining the course of an outbreak and impact of interventions like NIs. The method is applicable to other viral and bacterial pathogens, as long as within-host dynamics and competitive effects are considered. Estimating the within-host reproduction number is a key in influenza research, and this method improves experimental design. It also estimates the number of infecting units transferred from donor to recipient, important for models of transmission and emergence of resistant strains. The method is applicable to other pathogens, requiring consideration of within-host dynamics and competitive effects.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called BBX21 plays a key role in how plants respond to light and a hormone called abscisic acid (ABA) during seed germination and early seedling development. ABA is a hormone that helps plants adapt to various environmental stresses and is involved in many stages of a plant's life cycle. Light is another important cue that regulates growth and development in plants. The study found that BB21 interacts with two other proteins, HY5 and ABI5, which are involved in ABA signaling. BB21 acts upstream of HY and ABI5 in controlling seed germination. HY activates ABI expression, and BB21 interferes with HY binding to ABI promoter. ABI also activates its own expression, but BB21 negatively regulates this by interacting with ABI. The study shows that BB21 coordinates with HY and ABI on ABI promoter and these regulators work together to integrate light and ABA in Arabidopsis thaliana. This integration is important for plant survival.
Researchers have studied the Mediator complex in Candida albicans, a pathogenic fungus, to understand its role in gene expression. The Mediator is a co-regulator of RNA polymerase II conserved in eukaryotes. The study focused on Med subunits Med31, Med20, and S9/M13. C. albicans Med shares some functions with model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizoscharomyces pombe, such as response to stresses and role of Med31 in genes regulated by activator Ace2. However, C. albicans Med has additional roles in virulence genes, such as morphogenesis and adhesins. Med31,20, and S9/M13 contribute to virulence of C. alb, filamentation, biofilm formation, and ALS is biologically relevant for biofilm development. Med affects virulence of C. alb in worm model. Med31 and S9/M13 regulate cell adhes genes differently in S. cerevisiae and C. alb, repressing FLO in S cerevis and activating ALS in C. alb. This suggests Med subunits regulate adhesion differently in two distantly related species.
Researchers studied how the bacteria Pseudomonas aeruginosa develops resistance to antibiotics when it forms a biofilm, a complex community of bacteria attached to a surface. Biofilms are more resistant to antibiotics than individual bacteria floating in liquid. To understand why, they created a large collection of mutant Pseudomonas aeruginosa and tested each one in two conditions: as a biofilm and floating in liquid, with and with or without the antibiotic tobramycin. This allowed them to see which genes contribute to resistance in each state. They found many genes that help biofilms resist tobrycin, but not floating bacteria, and vice versa. Some genes are important for resistance in both states, but most are more important in biofilms. This study helps explain why biofilms are hard to treat and could lead to new treatments.
Researchers have developed a new algorithm called Flexible Algorithm for Model Selection (FoS) to analyze complex biological systems with many interacting components and unknown dynamics. Finding the right model to describe these systems and identify key processes is challenging due to the vast number of possibilities. Traditional algorithms compare a few models or search the entire space, which can be impractical for large systems. The new algorithm uses local and non-local search methods to avoid getting stuck in local minima and account for similar processes. It was tested on simulated data and shown to handle various structures. The algorithm was also used to study CD4 and CD8 T cell proliferation under different conditions, revealing changes in proliferation in 3D cultures compared to suspension. The algorithm's flexibility makes it applicable to many biological problems and useful for evaluating complex model spaces.

The algorithm was designed to handle large model spaces and diverse structures, addressing a need for improved search and selection methods. It allows unbiased inference of parameters and processes by comparing different structures when prior knowledge is lacking. Other algorithms, like Mangan et al's, work well in recovering dynamics but rely on dense sampling and neglect compensating effects. Existing algorithms for dynamical systems rely on exhaustive searches or predefined structures. Fos was motivated for complex systems, but can be applied to various problems, unlike others designed for specific structures.
Researchers in Bolivia conducted a 12-month study to evaluate the effectiveness of benznidazole (BN) treatment in children infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite that causes Chagas disease. The study involved 103 seropositive children who received BN, with 3 dropping out due to side effects. Blood samples were taken before, during, and after treatment, and analyzed for serology, conventional PCR, and real-time PCR, and Th1/2/17 cytokines, including IL-17. 57 children completed the study, with 6 (11%) showing both PCR+ and qPCR+, 24 (42%) PCR- but q+, and 27 (47%) PCR- and q-. IL-17 levels were higher in seropitive children before treatment and decreased to normal levels after. IL-17 levels were positively related to parasite counts by qPCR. At 12 months, IL-17 levels in non-reactive subjects were higher than reactive or ambiguous, suggesting IL-17 as a potential biomarker for treatment response. Plasma IL-17 might detect persistent infection and inflammation.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary cause of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, nearly 2% of which is occupied by a small transposon called Coria. Researchers have identified eight subtypes of the element with four distinct transcriptional ends. Two of these ends encode strong promoters, with the strongest driven by a polymorphism Y128 at the right end. The elements can drive transcription of adjacent genes and may express non-coding RNAs. Comparing three meningococ genomes, more than two-thirds of Coria elements maintain the same subtype at a particular locus due to recombination switching between elements in a strain. Upon switching, a new subtype can spread through the population by natural transformation. This may be a new mechanism for variation in meningococcus. The strain-to-strain variability of Coria and number of strong promoters allows for widespread effects in the population. Defining the strength of promoters by subtypes Cor ends provides a resource to predict transcription effects of a subtype at a locus.
Researchers have identified two proteins, Chae and Vel, in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostus that regulate the production of a toxin called Txin. This toxin promotes virulence, or the ability of the pathogen to cause disease, in maize plants with a specific genetic trait called Texas sterile cytoplasm. The toxin production of Txin is increased in the dark and decreased in the absence of Chae and Vel. Expression of genes involved in Txin production is also increased in the dark and decreased in the absence of Chae and Vel. Overexpression of Vel increases Txin production in the dark, while overexpression of Chae increases it in the light. Chae and Vel mutants have altered virulence on maize with Texas sterile cytoplasm and normal cytoplasm. Deletion of Chae or Vel reduces tolerance to oxidative stress. Chae and Vel mutants have reduced expression of a gene CAT, one of three catalase genes, and decreased hyphal growth, asexual sporulation, and sterility. Chae overexpression is sterile while Vel overexpression is fertile. Ch and Vel repress melanin biosynthesis genes, leading to enhanced melanization in mutants and reduced in overexpression strains.
Researchers have studied the mechanism of ion selectivity in bacterial Nav channels, which are proteins that allow certain ions to pass through the cell membrane while blocking others. They used computer simulations to model how ions move through the channel and found that potassium ions can block the channel when forces are applied in one direction, but not the other. This block is due to an unstable state in the energy landscape of the ions, which can be locked in place by forces. In contrast, sodium ions move through the channel together as a unit in a "knock-on" mechanism in both directions. The simulations predicted energy needed to break the potassium block matches experimentally measured values for bacterial channels to allow potassium ions to pass. This study shows that including non-equilibrium factors in simulations can reveal mechanisms of selectivity not seen in crystal structures or equilibrium energy landscapes. The results differ from previous findings and match electrophysiological measurements of bacterial channels.
Researchers studied the spread of the rabies virus in the brains of dogs with furious and paralytic rabies, two forms of the disease. They found that the virus spread faster in the furious form, as measured by the amount of virus in brain cells and RNA. The study looked at the amount of virus in different parts of the brain and spinal cord in 5 dogs with furious and 5 with paralytic rabies. Results showed more virus in furious dogs at all levels, even when comparing similar amounts and percentages of infected cells. This suggests the virus spreads slower in paraly form, possibly due to differences in how it moves inside cells. This could be related to inflammation, as previous studies found more inflammation in paraly form. 

The study used images to show the spread of virus and compared to previous findings on virus in brain cells. Results match previous findings on virus in brain cells and RNA. Virus spread from back to front of brain to back in both forms, with most in spinal cord and brainstem. Amount of virus in cells decreased from front to back in both forms, with most in brainstem and spinal cord in furious dogs. The study suggests virus moves slower in paraly form, possibly due to differences in how it moves inside cells. This could be related to inflammation, as previous studies found more inflammation in par form.
Researchers studied the protein CTC in fruit flies to understand its role in gene regulation. CTC is a zinc-finger protein that blocks enhancers from interacting with promoters. In flies, only one CTC binding site was known, the Fab-8 in the Bithax complex (BX). The team used chromatin immunoprecipitation with microarray to find CTC sites in the BX and other regions. They found CTC binds to the Fab8, Fab6, and Mc insulators, and three new sites, Fab-2, Fab-3, and Fab-4. CTC is associated with all known or predicted insulators in BX, suggesting a common mechanism. They compared CTC sites with Polycomb sites and histone modifications to support BX regulation model.

The team used Ch-array to investigate C sites in BX and other regions. C binds to Fab8 and other boundaries. A study showed Fab8 contains CTC sites and mutation reduces its insulating activity. The team used Ch-array to find C sites in BX and other regions. C binds to Fab8, Fab, and Mc, and new sites Fab-2, Fab-3, Fab-4. C is associated with all or predicted insulators in BX, suggesting common mechanism.
