The researchers developed a framework to analyze data from these systems, revealing details of GTP cycling between the membrane and cytosol, which is key to differential regulation of these switches. Analysis of Rac cycling shows lower affinity of GDI for RacG compared to RacDP can be explained by faster dissociation of the latter from the membrane. Non-steady-state solutions for membrane of GTP are presented in multidimensional charts. This methodology is applied to glucose-stimulated cycling in pancreatic β-cells, illustrating effects of Gs/Gs and affinities between Gases and membrane or GDI on bound GTP. Similar charts can be used to assess targeted modifications for altered Gase-G balance in disease scenarios. The study demonstrates R-GTP cycling can access diverse pathways in different systems through experimental manipulations.
Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) programs collect data to assess the impact of interventions and progress towards World Health Organization (WHO) goals for schistosomiasis morbidity control and elimination. Typically, data are collected from school-aged children (SAC) as they are easy to sample and likely to be infected. However, adults are also likely to be infected. This study investigates how the age distribution of infection impacts mathematical model recommendations for preventive chemotherapy levels to achieve WHO goals. For moderate prevalence regions, treating only SAC may achieve goals, but for high prevalence with high adult infection, adult treatment is required. The optimal strategy for a region requires considering adult burden, not solely SAC prevalence. Past epidemiological data informed models, but more detailed data are needed to accurately determine treatment. Collecting data from a broader age range, including adults, is crucial to determine strategy. Additional data, such as individual adherence, should be collected in M&E. Including adults in treatment efforts, a large Schistoma burden remains untreated, creating a reservoir. In 2002, adults in high-risk areas and women of childbearing age were excluded from coverage. Mathematical models recommended adaptations, such as increased treatment levels or frequency. Burden in adults varies geographically, impacted by local and cultural factors, access to water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) facilities. Infection profile and burden in adults varies for schosome in countries and communities. This study explores how age profiles with low to high adult burdens impact model recommendations. Collecting age-specific data, including adults, is important in M&E. SAC are likely infected due to age-related contact and absence of immunity, treatment focused on this group to prevent morbidity.
Researchers have developed a computational model to predict surgery outcomes for patients with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), a disorder causing seizures. The model uses brain connectivity data from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) of 22 patients with TLE and 39 healthy controls. It simulates seizure onset and location to validate the model. The model shows patients with TLE tend to switch from non-epileptic to epileptic states more often than controls. Regions in the left hemisphere, particularly temporal and subcortical areas, are frequent starting points for seizures in patients. Contralateral and frontal regions may play a role in seizure spreading or resistance. The model predicts individualized surgery, not following a standard procedure, may lead to better outcomes than current clinical practice. This work is a step towards personalized modeling epilepsy surgery to inform treatment strategies.

The model simulates brain as a network, with regions as nodes and connections mapped through DTI. Seizure initiation and spreading can be modeled using individual connectivity. Previous studies used a subset of areas, not whole brain connectivity. The model aims to predict surgery outcomes after resective surgery, with 50-80% success rate. Hypothesis is that predictions will be in this range and subject-specific surgery will reduce seizures more than standard procedures.

The model is validated by examining initial seizure locations. In TLE, left temporal lobe seizures are expected. The top 10 nodes for patients and controls are shown in blue and red, with green in both.
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) uses several strategies to evade the host's antiviral defenses, including interference with interferon and apoptotic signaling. The virus encodes four interferon regulatory factors (IRFs) that function in a dominant negative manner to block cellular IR activities and target IR-induced proteins such as p53 and TGF-β-activated Smad factors. Researchers have identified a new mechanism by which HHV-8 inactivates the pro-apopt Bcl-2 family member Bim, a key regulator of HH-8 replication, through nuclear translocation of vIR-1. Immunofluorescence and western analysis revealed vIR-1 localization in infected cells, and co-localization of vIR-1 and Bim in nuclei of lytically infected endothelial cells. Co-precipitation assays showed a direct interaction between v-1 and Bim, with v-1 B-binding residues mapped by deletion and mutagenesis. Generation of B-refactory v-1 variants revealed the importance of v-1:B interaction in prolication and anti-apopt activity. Blocking the interaction with a cell-perme peptide confirmed the relevance of v-1:B association to v- prolication. This is the first report of an IR protein interacting with a B-2 family member and sequestering B or any member as a means of inactivation. The data reveal a novel mechanism used by virus to control replication-induced apoptosis and suggest inhibiting v-1:B interaction may provide an antiral strategy.
Researchers have found that a protein called epithelial integrin, specifically αVβ6, plays a crucial role in regulating the immune response of the lung to injury and infection. This protein is important for maintaining the lung's readiness to respond to invaders. When the lung is injured, αV6 is upregulated, but its role in this process is not well understood. The study shows that upregulation of α6 during influenza infection contributes to disease. Mice lacking α6 have increased survival during infection due to reduced viral spread into the alveolar spaces, leading to less lung injury. Although α6-deficient mice have normal lungs, they have constitutively activated CD11+ alolar macrophages and elevated type I interferon (IF) signaling. This is due to loss of α6-activated growth factor (TGFβ). Administering exogenous TGF to α6 mice reduces CD11+ macrophages, type IF activity, and protective phenotype during infection. Protection extends to other respiratory pathogens like Sendai virus and bacterial pneumonia. The study shows loss of one epithelial protein αβ integrin alters lung environment during homeostasis and infection, leading to reduced injury and improved survival.
Researchers at a reference center in Argentina analyzed 733 cases of cutaneous leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania Viia brazili, the most common species causing the disease in the Americas. The study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of the Leishin Skin Test (LST), a diagnostic tool based on delayed hypersensitivity to Leish antigens, as a complement to diagnosis. The test was performed on individuals with clinically compatible lesions between 2006-2015. Results showed that 65% of cases were confirmed through positive smears from skin or mucosal lesions, with only 6 having negative ST. Among those with negative smears, 190 were also negative by ST, but 69 had positive ST. Sensitivity of ST was similar across age groups, but lesions older than 21 days correlated with positive results for both smear and ST. These findings support the use of ST as a diagnostic complement for cutaneous leishiasis across age groups in endemic areas. The correlation with smear was high, suggesting standardization of the technique and further research into protocols will aid management of suspicious cases.
Researchers have identified a genetic mechanism that contributes to the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) by studying how the body's immune cells, called macrophages, respond to a type of bad cholesterol called oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL). When macrophages are exposed to oxLD, they transform into foam cells that contribute to the formation of atherosclerotic plaques, which can lead to heart attacks and strokes. The researchers used a technique called FA-seq to map the changes in the macro's genetic material, called chromatin, after exposure to oxLD. They found that oxLD changed the structure of chrom at specific sites, which affected the expression of nearby genes involved in foam cell formation and atherosclerosis. One of these genes, PP2, is regulated by a protein called CEB-beta, which was previously not known to be involved in foam cell formation. The researchers found that a variant of the PP2 gene, rs72624, is associated with CAD risk and is located in an oxLD-induced enhancer, a site where CEB binds. The protective allele of rs72624 increased CEB binding and enhancer activity. The study also showed that the PP2 protein, L3, is present in human atherosclerotic plaques and oxLD exposure increases its expression in macroages, leading to increased degradation of pro-inflammatory mediators. This research provides a new understanding of how genetic variants contribute to CAD and highlights the importance of studying epigenetic changes in disease processes involving environmental stimuli. It also provides a basis for studying approaches to prevent foam cell formation and atherosclerosis.
Researchers in Malawi conducted a study to evaluate the effectiveness of a single round of azithromycin mass treatment in districts with a trachoma prevalence of 5.0-9% in 1-9 year olds. The World Health Organization recommends three rounds of treatment in such districts, but this may not be practical due to the large number of endemic areas and resources required. The Malawi Ministry of Health administered one round of azithycin to 8 districts with baseline prevalence 5.0-9%, achieving 80% coverage. Surveys were conducted 6 months later in 18 evaluation units of the districts. Each unit had a trach prevalence less than 5%. The study shows that one round of azycin with 80% coverage can reduce trach prevalence to less than 5% in Malawi districts with 5.0-9% prevalence. This approach may be a cost-effective way to eliminate trach in these areas.
Scientists have discovered how plants use calcium-dependent protein kinases (CPs) to trigger immune responses to pathogens. Plants have a built-in defense system to fight off infections without a specialized immune system like humans have. A specific proteins called nucleotide-binding leucine repeat (NLR) recognize pathogens and activate immune responses, including cell death, oxygen production, and changes in gene expression. Researchers found six related CPs in Arabidopsis, a plant, that mediate immune responses activated by LR proteins R2 and RPM1. The activation of CP2 by pathogen effectors controls cell death, while sustained activation of CP4, 5, and 11 directly phosphorylates transcription factors WRKY28, 48 to regulate gene expression crucial for pathogen restriction. CP2, 4, and 11 also phosphorylate membrane NAD oxidases for oxygen production. This study reveals complex mechanisms of LR immune sensors mediated by CPs with distinct specificity and dynamics.

LR proteins in plants recognize pathogen effectors to initiate immune responses, increasing calcium concentration, gene expression, and cell death. In Arabidopsis, LR2 initiates resistance to Pseudomonas syringe effector Avr2, while RPM recognizes unrelated effectors Avr1 and AvB. CP1 and 2 phosphorylate RHD and RHF in vitro, reducing ROS production in cp1, 2 mutants. Genetic evidence shows calcium signaling via CPs plays a role in diverse signaling and resistance by intracellular LR sensors.

A subgroup of WR transcription factors act with CPs in LR signaling. Sustained activation of CP4, 5, 11 phosphorylates WRKY28, 48 for gene expression, while CP2, 4, 11 phosphorylate NAD oxidases for production and cell death. LR do not directly interact with pathogens but monitor host proteins to mount responses. Avr2 degrades Arabid R4 to activate R2, while Avr1 and B induce R4 phosphorylation via kinases to initiate RPM.
Researchers in Mali used a statistical method called state-space forecasting to predict the spread of Schistosoma haobium, a parasitic disease that affects millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. They analyzed data from 1996 to 2004 in the district of Nion, Mali, and found that their predictions were accurate for up to 5 months in advance. This method can help public health programs in developing countries manage and assess the impact of the disease and interventions. It also captured interactions between the disease and factors like climate, irrigation, and public health interventions, making it a useful tool for managing Schos haob in Mali and potentially in the Sahel region.
Researchers studied how the human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) interacts with host cells to infect them. CMV has a protein called pp150 that binds to cyclin A, a protein that helps cells divide, to prevent the virus from expressing its genes in the S2 phase of the cell cycle. This restriction makes cells resistant to infection. The researchers created a mutant virus that can't bind cyclin A to see what happens. Without cyclin, the virus expressed its genes in S2 and caused cells to arrest in the G2 phase, but not go into mitosis. A viral protein p21 destabilized cyclin to keep cells in G2. A double mutant with both pp and p21 unable to bind cyclin caused most cells to enter mitosis, harming cell and virus growth. This shows pp and p21 work together to keep cells in cycle and avoid cyclin to let the virus replicate.
Researchers investigated the genetic causes of sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a devastating neurodegenerative disease that leads to paralysis and death. They used a targeted sequencing approach to examine 169 known ALS genes in 242 sporadic cases and 129 controls, looking for novel variants linked to the disease. The study found a significant enrichment of novel and rare variants in cases, suggesting they are identifying disease-causing mutations. This study highlights the use of next-generation sequencing and functional analysis to understand the genetic basis of sporadic ALS.

The researchers used a candidate approach to find new mutations in relevant ALS genes in sporadic cases and studied newly identified variants with bioinformatics and functional analysis. They found a higher burden of deleterious mutations in cases than controls, indicating novel or rare mutations in key genes may contribute to sporadic ALS. Next-generation sequencing has opened a new era in disease study, but distinguishing disease-causing from benign variants is a challenge. New approaches are needed to make sequencing results clinically informative.

Familial ALS is more homogeneous than sporadic, with 20 genes explaining 60% of cases. The study found rare or novel variants in 144 of 242 patients, suggesting at least 40% of cases have no identified genetic cause. New variants were found in ALS and associated genes, but no association with previously identified SNPs in the population, except APO. New genes were identified through trio and RRM studies.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-6 (IL-6) in the development of immune cell memory to the influenza virus. They found that IL-6 is crucial for the formation of long-term CD4 T cell memory, but not CD8 cell memory. IL-6 limits the activity of regulatory T cells (Tregs), which are a type of immune cell that can suppress other immune responses. This allows virus-specific CD4 T cells to be more active, helping to clear the virus and keep the host healthy. The study used mice with and without IL-6 and found that those without IL-6 had impaired CD4 memory, but not CD8 memory. The effect of IL-6 on CD4 and CD8 cells is not due to its ability to signal, but its ability to suppress Tregs. IL-6 has been shown to suppress Tregs in other studies. The researchers found that Tregs from mice without IL-6 were more active and suppressed virus-specific CD4 cells, but those with IL-6 were not. This supports the idea that IL-6 inhibits Tregs. The study also found that IL-6 does not affect CD4 cell survival, as there was no difference in cell death between mice with and without IL6 after infection. The main target of IL-6 in this study is Tregs, not CD4 cells, as CD8 memory is not impaired in mice without IL6.
Researchers have discovered a new function of an enzyme called enol in the parasite Entamoeba histolytica, a type of amoeba that causes intestinal infections. Enol is known to convert a molecule called 2-phosphoglycerate to phospholpyruvate, a key step in glucose metabolism. However, the study found that enol also interacts with a protein called Dmt2, which adds methyl groups to DNA and RNA. This interaction was unexpected, as glycolytic enzymes like enol were thought to be only in the cytoplasm. Enol was found in both the cytoplasm and nucleus of the parasite and acts as an inhibitor of Dmt, reducing RNA methylation. Glucose levels control enol's activity, and when glucose is low, enol accumulates in the nucleus and forms a complex with Dnmt, reducing RNA methylation. The study also showed that enol is the first protein to interact with Dmt and that glucose metabolism affects Dmt activity. Further research is needed to understand the role of enol and Dmt in higher organisms.
Researchers have identified microRNAs (miRNAs) in the saliva of mosquitoes for the first time. miRNAs are small, non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression and are generally found inside cells. However, circulating miRN have been found in human serum and saliva. This study found 103 miRN in mosquito saliva, 31 of which were new. Some miRN were only present in mosquitoes infected with Chikungunya virus (CHV), a mosquito-borne pathogen. The researchers tested five of these miRN and found they play a role in CHV transmission and infection during feeding on a host. Inhibiting these mi decreased viral replication, suggesting they help CHV spread in the host. This is the first report of exogenous miRN in mosquito saliva.
Researchers have investigated the role of three proteins, Rad51, Rad52, and Rad59, in repairing damaged mitochondrial DNA in yeast cells. Mitochondria have their own DNA, separate from the cell's main DNA, which encodes proteins for energy production. Deletions in this DNA can cause inherited diseases and cancers. Most deletions are flanked by repetitive sequences, suggesting they result from recombination events. The study found that Rad51 and Rad59 are in the mitochondria's matrix and Rad51 binds to DNA. A tool was used to create a double-strand break in the mitochondrial DNA, allowing analysis of repair in yeast. Loss of these proteins decreased deletion rate and Rad51 and Rad59 impaired repair of induced breaks. This is the first study to show Rad51,52, and59 impact mtDNA repair. A system was improved to introduce a single break per genome to identify repair proteins. Mitochondrial base excision repair has been studied, showing conserved pathways exist. Evidence of homologous recombination repair in mitochondria of different species, including yeast, fruit flies, and mice. Rad51 and59 localize to mitochondria. Identifying factors interacting with Rad51,52,59 will help elucidate repair pathways. Double-strand break repair mechanisms are poorly understood, particularly in mitochondria. Homologous recombination in yeast, plant, and mammalian mtDNA has been reported, but few proteins in recombination identified. Control of break induction allowed study of mtDNA repair using genetic and molecular methods. Loss of proteins delayed break processing and deletion. Rad51 and59 in mitochondria argue effects are direct.
Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a significant global health burden, particularly among disadvantaged populations, resulting from acute rheumatic fever (AR), a complication of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection. The role of social and environmental factors in GAS infection and progression to AR/RHD is not well understood. This systematic review aimed to determine the association between social determinants of health and GAS, AR, and RHD, and the effect of interventions targeting these. Observational and experimental studies measuring crowding, dwelling, characteristics, education, employment, income, socioeconomic status, and nutrition were included. Findings were assessed against the Bradford criteria for evidence of causation. 1,164 publications were identified, 90 met criteria, comprising 91 studies, with 49% poor quality. Crowding was most assessed (14 studies GAS, 36 AR/RHD) followed by socioeconomic status (6, 36). Most studies reported a positive association with risk of GAS, AR/RHD. Crow and socioeconomic status met criteria for causation. There was substantial heterogeneity across studies. The literature lacks quality, mostly observational, not interventional. Crow as a cause of GAS and ARHD presents a target for prevention.

A systematic review of social and environmental factors for GAS, AR/RHD found only one previous study. Four reviews explored SES or poverty. This review examined socioeconomic and environmental factors GAS, AR/RHD, and interventions. PubMed, Cochr Library, Embase were searched. 3% studies showed mixed results. Socioeconomic position compared cases to non-cases was based on geographical, economic, social, or asset ownership. Socioeconomic status was in 6 studies GAS, 36 AR/RHD. This review is the most extensive on social determinants of health and GAS, ARHD. Exclusion of non-English articles and single reviewer appraisal were limitations. Positive findings were associated with publication after 1996, 100% of case studies reported at least one association, 64.9% other studies (p=0.002).
Researchers studied the Pho/PhP bacterial signaling network, a two-component system found in many bacteria. They found that a single mutation in the kinase PhQ protein, which abolishes its phosphatase activity, results in a striking change in the network's behavior. The mutant responds to stimuli in a bistable manner, meaning it has two distinct states, on and off, whereas the wild-type has a graded response. Mutant cells in these states have different morphologies and the state is inherited over generations. External conditions that repress signaling in the wild-type drive the mutant to the on state. Mathematical modeling suggests bistability depends on autoregulation of key proteins PhP and PhQ in the circuit. The mutant's characteristics come at a fitness cost, with the on state having lower fitness in rich medium. However, due to inheritance, a population of on cells can be epigenetically trapped in a low-fitness state. The study demonstrates the versatility of the two-component architecture and highlights tradeoffs in the Pho/PhP system.
Researchers have identified a potential new target for treating a rare and deadly brain infection called primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri. This infection is considered rare but has a high mortality rate and no established treatment, making it devastating. To develop new treatments, scientists are repurposing existing drugs used for other diseases. Naegia fleri needs ergoster, a building block of cell membranes, to survive. Disrupting sterol synthesis with small molecules is a strategy against fungal and agricultural pathogens. The amoeba encodes ster 14-demethylase CYP51, similar to fungal targets. This raises the possibility of repurposing antifungal drugs for P treatment. 

Studies showed that antifungal drugs azoles, conazoles, affect sterol synthesis and viability of Naegia trophotes. Identified the endogenous C51 substrate by mass spectrometry of lipids. Analyzed interactions between recombinant C51 and conoles by spectroscopy and x-ray. The data validated C51 as a target in Naegleri and conoles as candidates for P treatment. Fluconazole and micon have been used with other drugs in human P patients. Sterol biosynthesis occurs in most eukaryotes, including human pathogens like fungi and freeiving amoeb. The similarity raises possibility of repur antifungal drugs and az-based P therapy for P.
Researchers studied the role of interleukin-4 receptor alpha (IL-4α) in the immune response to nematode infections. Nematodes trigger a protective type 2 immune response in the host, and IL-4α plays a key role in this process. However, it was not known if IL-4α is needed to maintain this response after it is established. The researchers used a special mice model where the IL-4 gene can be turned on or off at will to study this. They found that IL-α is needed to keep the type 2 immune response going and to fight off the nematode Nippostrongus brasiliensis. They also showed that if IL-α is turned off before a second infection with N. brasiliensis, the immune response is not as strong and the nematodes are not cleared as quickly. This study shows that IL-α is needed to keep the type 2 immune response going, a new function beyond its role in starting it. The type 2 response is key to fighting nemodes, and IL-α plays a crucial role in this.
Researchers have analyzed the distribution of Bartonella bacteria in mammals to understand how it has evolved and switched hosts over time, which can reveal current patterns and potential for cross-species transmission. The study used the largest collection of Bartonella glA genotypes, including 67 new genotypes, and found that the pathogen likely originated as an environmental bacterium infecting insects before mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as reservoirs or key hosts for most Bartonella genotypes in humans. There is evidence of exchange between phylogenetically distant domestic and wildlife, likely due to increased contact. To protect health, care should be taken to avoid contact between humans, animals, and wildlife.

The study shows Bartonella is a system for examining impacts of humans on disease spread within and between species, across landscapes globally. Phylogenetic inferences should be interpreted with caution due to available data and taxa sampled. There may be missing links between inferred hosts not sampled. The pathogen is ideal for tracing zoonotic and impacts on native hosts. The study constructed global phylogenies of Barton from 16sRNA and citrate synth (glA) to determine evolutionary history, patterns, host switching, and spillo into humans from commals to wild.

Some host specificity of Bartonella is due to ecological factors rather than immunological incompatibility. Given diversity of zoonotic strains, including divergent with clinical presentations, physicians should consider broad hosts and Barton genotypes when investigating suspected infections. Certain species associated with humans, such as dogs, cats, cows, and rats, have brought strains globally. Rats are in the largest clade of rodent Barton (clade B. queensensis, B. elizabeth, B. triborum, B. massensis, B. rattassensis, B. inf). Humans influence on Barton categorized genotypes as found in rats, other rodents, humans, domestic, carnivores, wild, artiodactyl, wildiodact, shrews, and bats.
Long noncoding RNA MALAT plays a crucial role in regulating cell cycle progression by controlling the expression of oncogenic transcription factor BMYB. MALAT is upregulated in cancer tissues and associated with hyperproliferation, but its underlying mechanism was poorly understood. Researchers found that MALAT levels change during normal cell cycle progression. Genome-wide transcriptome analysis in human diploid fibroblasts revealed MALAT modulates expression of cell cycle genes and is required for G1 and mitotic progression. Depletion of MALAT leads to activation of p53 and its target genes. Cell defects in MALAT-depleted cells are sensitive to p53 levels, indicating p53 is a major mediator of MALAT activity. MALAT-depleted cells display reduced expression of BMYB, an oncogenic factor in G/M progression, due to altered splicing of BMY preRNA and aberrant splicing. In cells, MALAT promotes proliferation by modulating expression and preRNA of cycle transcription factors. Findings provide mechanistic insights into MALAT's role in regulating proliferation. MALAT's levels during cell cycle influence expression of genes involved in progression. Depletion in human diploid fibroblasts induces DNA damage and activation of p53 and target genes. Cell defects in MAL-depleted are sensitive to p levels, indicating p53 is effector of MAL function. Mitotic defects in MAL-de suggest MAL role in mitosis via expression/preRNA of mitosis genes or defect in p-deficient cells is result of DNA stalled forks. Mitosis is most canonical pathway downregulated in MAL-de fibblasts. Abnormal MAL expression in types or tissues results in aberrant splicing leading to misexpression of cycle genes, contributing to progression. MAL may influence key regulators activator or repressor, resulting in alteration of downstream cycle genes. Observed splicing changes in regulator BMY in MAL-de. Unlike MAL-de, p or p+MAL cells responded to serum by expression of cycle genes. Results indicate p vital to G arrest in MAL-de cells.
Juvenile hormone (JH) plays a crucial role in regulating insect growth, metamorphosis, and reproduction. While its role in repressing larval metamosis is well understood, the molecular basis of its action in promoting adult reproduction is not fully elucidated. Research has shown that Methoprene (Met), the J receptor, mediates J action during metamosis and vitelogenesis, but the precise mechanism behind the latter is lacking. This study used RNA interference (RNAi) to mimic a J-deprived condition in migratory locusts and found that J stimulates DNA replication and ploidy in preparation for vitelogenesis. Two genes, Mc4 and Mc7, in the DNA replication pathway were expressed in the presence of J and Met. Depletion of Mc or Mc7 inhibited novo synthesis and ploidy, resulting in reduced vitelogenin mRNA and impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian growth. Luciferase and electrophoretic mobility assays showed Met directly regulates Mc and Mc by binding to upstream sequences with E-box or E-like motifs. This suggests the J-receptor acts on Mc and Mc to regulate replication and ploidy for vitelogenesis and oocyte maturation.
Researchers conducted a study to determine the optimal duration of prednisone treatment for lepro patients with recent nerve function impairment (NFI). The study, called "Treatment Early Neurop in Lepy" (TENL), compared a 20-week and 32-week prednisone courses. 868 lepro patients with recent NFI (less than 6 months) were randomly assigned to either a 20-week or 32-week prednisone treatment. Prednisone was started at 45-60mg/day, then tapered. NFI was assessed by muscle testing and monofilament testing. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with improved or restored function at 78 weeks. Secondary outcomes included Reaction Scale, SAL Scale, and Participation Scale. Results showed no significant difference between groups: 78.1% in the 20-week arm and 77.5 in the 32 arm (p=0.821). Secondary outcomes also showed no difference, except a higher adverse events in the longer arm. A 20-week predone was as effective as 32 in improving and restoring NFI in lepro patients. Twenty weeks is the preferred initial treatment for lepro neuropathy, with a minority needing individualized treatment.
Researchers studied the vocalizations of male Rocky Mountain elk and European red deer to understand how sound production relates to anatomy and physiology. They created a computer model of the larynx and vocal tract based on elk anatomy and biomechanics to simulate sound production. The model produced a range of fundamental frequencies, from 65 to 140 Hz. Low frequencies required low vocal fold strain, high lung pressure, and large glottal flow, while high frequencies needed large muscular effort and lung pressure. Glottal efficiency, the ratio of radiated sound to aerodynamic power, was higher in elk, suggesting an advantage in high-pitched signaling. This is due to lower airflow requirements and acoustic radiation at higher frequencies. Both types are used by males during mating, serving as honest signals. The low-frequency call relates to body size, high-frequency to muscular strength and endurance. Contrary to expectation, some large mammals use high-pitched vocalization. The study simulated elk and red calls with a finite model of oscillating vocal folds and larynge cartilage, applying muscle activations and vocal tract propagation to understand the system. The lnx model was based on anatomy and biomechanics of Rocky elk and red laryes. Elk vocalizations were near the top, red vocalizations near the bottom. Fold oscillation was sustained at minimum 65 Hz and maximum 140 Hz. High pressures were necessary in both, calls were uttered at high rates in both species. Efficiency of aerodynamic to acoustic energy in the larynge source differed. Production with high F0 provided an advantage.
Researchers have developed a new approach to analyze chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-through sequencing (ChIP-seq) data, a technique used to map transcription factor binding and chromatin modifications. Current methods discard reads that map to multiple locations on the genome, known as multi-reads, to focus on reads that map uniquely to one location, known as uni-reads. This can omit up to 30% of alignable reads. The new approach allocates multi-read as fractional counts using a weighted scheme, increasing sequencing depth by 22-25% and 17% in STAT and GATA ChIP samples. Incorporating multi-read identifies novel peaks not detectable by uni-read and improves peak detection in mappable regions. Analysis shows multi-read peaks have similar characteristics to uni-read, but mostly reside in segmental duplications. Validation by quantitative real-time ChIP confirms novel GATA peaks and identifies target genes.
Researchers estimated the economic benefits of reaching the 2020 World Health Organization (WHO) targets for four neglected tropical diseases: Chagas disease, African trypaniasis, lepro, and visceral leishias. These diseases are difficult to control and costly to manage, and mainly affect disadvantaged populations in low- and middle-income countries. The study calculated the economic benefits of avoiding productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments due to these diseases by reaching the targets. 

The researchers combined data on productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments related to these diseases with projections of people suffering from each disease, country, and year 2011-2020 and 202-203. They compared an ideal scenario where the 2020 targets were met with a counterfactual scenario where the situation stayed the same as 1990. The economic benefit was the difference between the two scenarios. 

The total productivity gained for the four diseases was $23.1 billion in 201-202 and $35.9 in 202-203, corresponding to $10.7 and $16.6 billion. Reduction in out-of-pocket payments was $14 billion and $18 for the same periods. The study had limitations, such as no data for leprosy and combining data from various sources of variable quality. Despite this, the benefits of reaching targets are considerable and exceed investments by governments and partners. Given the frequency of diseases among the poorest, these investments represent good value for improving well-being and reducing inequity.
A long-held assumption in neuroscience is that highly selective neurons, which respond to a narrow range of sensory inputs, carry more information about external stimuli. In the auditory cortex, neurons initially respond to a wide range of sounds and then become highly selective in sustained responses. This has led to the idea that the first epoch encodes the presence and the second encodes content of a sound. Contrary to this, researchers found that the population conveys similar information across both epochs, despite selectivity differences. The amount of information encoded depends on the total number of spikes in the population, not selectivity. Inhomogeneous Poisson spiking behavior accounts for this property. These results suggest a new principle of encoding shared among sensory systems.

In the auditory cortex, selectivity increases as spiking evolves after sound onset. Initially, neurons respond to many sounds with high spiking rates, then settle to lower values. Adaptation leads to fewer active neurons, a sparser representation, and higher selectivity. This adaptation is shared among sensory systems. Based on selectivity, the theory posits unselective responses encode presence and selective responses encode identity. However, interpreting informativeness based on selectivity has caveats.

Current understanding of sensory processing is built on neurons responding to specific inputs. Highly selective neurons are thought to provide more information. Observations in the auditory cortex raise questions about dynamic encoding in sensory systems.
Researchers have found that a protein called OX40 plays a crucial role in controlling viral infections that persist in the body for a long time. Unlike short-term infections, where the immune system quickly clears the virus, long-term infections require the immune system to keep fighting the virus to prevent it from spreading. O40 is a co-stimulatory molecule that helps T cells, a type of immune cells, to stay active and fight the virus. Without O40, T cells fail to accumulate and the body's ability to produce antibodies and fight the virus is severely impaired. In mice without O40, the virus was not controlled over time, showing the importance of this pathway in long-term infections. 

 O40 promotes long-term survival of T cells, so researchers thought it might be more important in long-term infections. In contrast to short-term infections, O shapes both CD4 and CD8 T cell responses and antibody production in long-term infections. Mice without O40 had a severely impaired anti-viral response. While O's role in short-term infections is known, its role in long-term was unclear. O is important in driving T responses to several viruses, but dispensable in short-term LCM infection. O-deficient mice had impaired CD4 responses, but CD8 responses and virus control were unaffected. However, O's importance in long-term remained unclear. O and PD-1, another protein, correlated with O in both short and long-term infections, suggesting O's sustained expression is due to ongoing antigen recognition. O was stronger on CD4 cells, but some CD8 cells also expressed O. Findings establish O as key in sustaining cellular and humoral immunity in long-term and have implications for studying T dysfunction in humans.
Researchers have identified a remarkable example of convergent evolution in aquatic animals, where a mechanically optimal method of swimming with elongated fins has evolved independently at least eight times in both vertebrates and invertebrates across three phyla. This phenomenon is distinct from the convergent evolution of morphological features like wings, where a pattern of movement occurs across a morphologically diverse set of appendages in aquatic animals. These animals swim by undulating their fins while keeping their body relatively rigid, with fins running lengthwise along the body rather than crosswise like a trout's tail. The researchers hypothesize that the regulation of optimal wavelength, elongation, and fination in these phyla may reflect common genetic networks underlying convergent evolution, as seen in electric organs. They found that the optimal wavelength maximizes force generated by the body, also maximizing swimming speed. By dividing the length of undulation along an animal's fin by mean amplitude, the result is consistently 20, called the optimal wavelength (OS). This value can predict the number of undulations along a swimming animal's fin at any velocity. The study unifies a vast diversity of swimmers, from invertebrates like cuttlefish to vertebrates cartilaginous and bony fish.
Researchers have investigated the role of condens, a class of evolutionarily conserved protein complexes, in neural stem cell (NS) divisions during cerebral cortex development. They found that two types of condens, condens I and II, are essential for NS divisions and survival in mice. Simultaneous depletion of both condens causes severe defects in chromosome assembly and segregation, leading to DNA damage and p53-induced apoptosis. Individual depletions of condens I and II lead to slower loss of NS, with distinct mitotic defects: chromosome missegregation in condin II-depleted NS and mitotic delays in condin I-depleted NS. NS depleted of condin II display hyperclustering of perentric heterochatin and nucleoli, indicating condin II's role in establishing interphase architecture. These defects persist in postmit neurons. The study shows condens I and II have overlapping and non-overlapping functions in NS, providing insight into balancing acts of two condin complexes.
Researchers have studied the genetic and epigenetic changes that occur in the parasite Schistosoma mansoni, a type of flatworm that causes schistosomiasis in humans, as it develops from a larva to adult in a vertebrate host. This parasite is unusual because its sex is determined by a genetic system, but physical differences between males and females appear only after it infects a host. To understand how this process, the researchers compared the genetic activity of males and females at five stages of development: larva, early worm, and adult. They found 7,168 genes were different between sexes at least one stage, and 4,065 had known functions. They also looked at epigenetic marks, which are chemical changes to DNA that affect gene activity, and found differences between males and females. The study shows that sex in S. mansoni is linked to different genetic and epigenetic changes that affect how it interacts with the host and how it reproduces. These findings could lead to new targets for treating schosomiasis and understanding how the parasite develops in the host.
Researchers propose a new approach to handle disagreements among experts in large-scale annotation efforts by assigning a confidence value to each annotation, representing the probability of its correctness. They developed two probabilistic models to estimate individual annotator certainty and tested them on a dataset of 10,000 sentences annotated by eight experts, with a 1,000 sentences further annotated by five new experts. The approach significantly increases the probability of choosing the correct annotation even in the worst-case scenario where all annotators disagree. A corpus of 10,000 sentences annotated in several dimensions is made publicly available. The study aims to quantify certainty in individual annotations for a group of annotators, retaining the dataset for training and testing machine learning methods. Two probabilistic models are introduced based on the corpus, validated with a second annotation cycle by five new annotators on a 1,000-sentence subset. The goal is to generate a manually annotated corpus for training computers to perform tasks at scale.
Researchers have developed a new approach to produce antiviral antibodies to protect against hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), a deadly disease caused by Andes virus (AND) and related viruses in South America. They used a DNA vaccine platform in geese to produce antibodies, which can be purified in high concentrations from egg yolks. The geese were vaccinated with a DNA vaccine encoding AND virus glycoproteins and developed high levels of neutralizing antibodies, which lasted over a year. A booster vaccination resulted in extremely high levels of neutralizing antibodies. Analysis showed the antibodies were highly reactive to specific amino sequences of AND glycoprote. The researchers tested the ge-derived antibodies in a hamster model of lethal HPS and found they protected 8/8 and 7/8 hamsters when administered post-exposure. In contrast, all hamsters receiving normal ge antibodies or no treatment developed HPS. This demonstrates the DNA/goose platform can produce a candidate antiral product preventing lethal disease when administered post-exposure.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Dmta enzyme in cancer development by studying its effects on DNA methylation patterns in a mouse model of lung cancer. Dmta is responsible for establishing normal methylation patterns, and mutations in Dmt have been linked to leukemia. Deleting Dmt in a mouse model of lung cancer led to tumor progression, suggesting it might suppress development by stabilizing methylation. Whole-genome bisulf sequencing showed profound methylation changes in K-as-induced lung cancer. Dmt-type tumors had large hypomethyl domains in nuclear-associated regions, while Dmt-deficient tumors were uniformly hypomethylated. Further analysis revealed Dmt maintains methylation of active chromosome domains and Dmt-deficient tumors showed deregulation in these domains. The study defines features of cancer methylomes and Dmt's role in maintaining methylation in cancer.
Researchers have studied the neural activity patterns in the premotor cortex of songbirds to understand how they generate sequences of neural activity that control singing. They used multi-electrode recordings and calcium imaging to find that activity in this area is organized on a scale of 100 micrometers. Within this scale, basal ganglia-projecting excitatory neurons fire at a specific phase of a 30 Hz rhythm. This shows that premotor activity is inhomogeneous in time and space, and a mesoscopic pattern underlies the generation of neural sequences controlling song. 

In songbirds, the relationship between time and space in premotor area HVC is neither random nor globally organized as a wave, but clustered on 100 micrometer scale. A 30 Hz rhythm in local field potential correlated with inhibition of one neuron type, HX, and this rhythm is coherent over scale matching projection calcium activity. This suggests a microcircuit where multiple excitatory neurons drive interneurons. Inhibitory show pattern activity throughout song, whereas projection fire spars, with events correlated between neighbors. This suggests a microc where pools of excitatory drive interne populations.
Researchers have identified 64 genes in the worm Caenorhabditis elegans that are essential for development and also extend lifespan when inactivated. These genes are highly conserved from yeast to humans and play a role in insulin, metabolic, translation, RNA, and chromatin pathways. Many of these genes extend lifespan as much as the strongest regulators of aging. Early inactivation of these genes causes growth arrest at larval stages, and some animals live longer than wild-type adults. The gene daf-16 is required for survival of arrested larvae, suggesting increased longevity is a response to gene inactivation. Insulin-signaling plays a role in regulation of aging at any stage of life. 

The study screened 2,700 genes essential for C. elegans development and found 64 that extend lifespan when inactivated. These genes are conserved from yeast to humans and involved in insulin, metabolic, translation, RNA, and chromatin pathways. Many extend lifespan as much as strongest regulators of aging. Early inactivation causes growth arrest at larval stages and some live longer than wild-type adults. d-16 is required for survival of arrested larvae, suggesting increased longevity a response to inactivation. Insulin-signaling plays role in aging at any stage.
Researchers have identified a critical step in the process of zebraf fin regeneration: the creation of a specialized epidermis that guides growth from underlying tissue. They performed a genetic screen to find mutations that block this process and found a temperature-sensitive allele of lamin beta 1, a component of the extracellular matrix, that prevents regeneration. Lamin beta 1, not its paralog, is induced in a subset of epithelial cells after fin amputation and is required to establish a polarized epithelial layer. This leads to expression of morphogenetic factors, basolateral positioning of phosphorylated Ig1, patterning of osteoblasts, and regeneration of bone. Lamin 1 is dispensable for juvenile growth, homeostatic tissue, adult maintenance, repair of fins, or renewal of genetically ablated osteoblast. Mutations or transgenic receptor inhibition disrupt lamin 1 expression, linking growth factor to epithelial maturation during regeneration. The study reveals induction of lamin 1 in epithelial cells as a key step in formation of signaling-competent epidermis.
Researchers compared different methods for accounting for relatedness in genome-wide association studies using family data, specifically linear mixed models (LMM) approaches. Several LMM software packages have been developed, but it's unclear how they differ from previous implementations. They applied LMM to a genome-wide study of visceral leishiasis in 348 Brazilian families (362 individuals, 197 genotyped) and compared results to traditional family-based tests and alternative approaches. The LMM approaches showed strong concordance and controlled genome-wide error, except for some when applied to longitudinal data with repeated measures. They also correlated with alternative approaches, apart from transmission-based when SNPs had small or no effects. LMM performed well compared to competing methods, with concordance in most applications, making implementation choice based on speed and ease-of-use rather than power error considerations.

The study used real and simulated data from a genome association study of visceral leishias in 348 families (363 individuals, 197 with genotype and phenotype). The Brazilian data was used with a larger case-control set by Fola et al. The analysis was computationally convenient in L software, but slow in standard software like GWAS. The results relate to genotypes from a single data set, a Brazilian study of leishias.

The performance of LMM and alternative approaches were compared through application to real and simulated data from the Brazilian data. Kinship between individuals were estimated prior to fitting linear model on genome data, rather than theoretical values. Fitting a linear model for each SNP across genome was computationally challenging.
Researchers have developed a high-throughput screening assay to identify compounds that inhibit the growth of Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, in mammalian cells. A 200-compound library was screened using a recombinant T. cruzi strain expressing β-galactosidase. Three compounds, P1, NT, and CX, were selected for their high activity against T. cruz and low toxicity to host cells in vitro, with IC50 values of 54, 190, and 23 nM, respectively. Each compound has a different mechanism of action on intracellular T. cruz amigotes: CX shows trypanocidal activity, essential for chronic stage development, NT has tryostatic effect, and P1 affects division. These compounds also show activity against intracellular T. cruz from Y strain and related species Leishmania and L. Characterization of anti-T. cruz activity led to selection of two compounds with IC values 2M, P6 and CX, 100 times lower than current medicines. This provides new candidates for treatments against Chagas and leishiasis.
Researchers have developed a new, portable diagnostic tool for detecting Brugia parasites in mosquitoes, which cause lymphatic filariasis. The tool, called "Backpack PCR," uses a simple DNA extraction method and a test-based detection system, making it suitable for use in resource-limited areas. Traditional DNA extraction methods are time-consuming and expensive, requiring thermal cyclers or real-time instruments, which are not available in many endemic locations. The new platform combines a rapid NaOH DNA extraction with a battery-powered PCR and test-based detection, allowing for field use in minimal settings. The team compared the new method to standard column-based extraction and real-time PCR, finding it to be sensitive and specific. They also compared it to conventional PCR and gel electrophoresis, demonstrating its effectiveness. By using a miniaturized PCR, they showed the platform can be used at the point-of-collection, fitting in a small backpack. This eliminates reliance on expensive equipment without compromising detection sensitivity, providing an alternative to column-based extractions requiring infrastructure. The system increases feasibility of molecular monitoring in B. malayi-endemic areas and provides a framework for detecting W. bancfti, responsible for 90% of global burden.
Researchers have studied the self-assembly of elastom proteins, which are proteins that can stretch and recoil like rubber. These proteins are made up of repeating units called domains that provide elasticity and help the assembly process, and cross-linking elements that stabilize the structure. Changes in the number and arrangement of these domains affect the assembly and properties of the protein. A new computer model was created to simulate the self-assembly of these proteins with different architectures. The model showed that the size and number of domains can impact the structure and integrity of the protein. For example, proteins with more cross-link elements and smaller domains were more stable. This study provides insights into how elastom proteins evolved and can help design new materials with similar properties. Elastom proteins are made of alternating domains that provide elasticity and cross-link elements that stabilize the structure. A computer model was created to simulate the assembly of these proteins with different architectures. The model showed that the size and number of domains affect the structure and stability of the protein. For example, proteins with more cross-link elements and smaller domains were more stable. This study helps understand how elastom proteins evolved and can design new materials with similar properties.
Researchers have investigated the role of the 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) in the Ebola virus genome, which are longer than most other non-segmented negative-strand RNA viruses. They found that the 5-UTRs do not function as internal ribosomal entry sites, but instead regulate cap-dependent translation when placed upstream of a reporter gene. The 5-UT from the viral polymerase (L) mRNA strongly suppressed translation compared to a beta-actin 5-UT. The 5-UT has four upstream AUGs (uAUGs) and ablating each uUG enhanced translation of the primary open reading frame (ORF), most dramatically in the case of the L5-UT. The uUG was sufficient to initiate translation, surrounded by a weak Koz sequence and suppressed ORF translation in a position-dependent manner. Under conditions where e2 was phosphorylated, the presence of uOR maintained translation of LOR, indicating u modulates translation in response to cellular stress. To address the role of u in virus replication, a recombinant Ebola was generated with the u mutated to UCG. Mutating two nucleotides outside previously-defined protein and cis-regulatory sequences attenuated virus titers 10-100 lower than wild-type in Vero A549 cells. The mutant also exhibited RNA synthesis as early as 6 post-infection and sensitivity to stressor thapsargin. These data identify mechanisms by which Ebola regulates polymerase expression and demonstrate relevance to replication and a potential therapeutic target.
Researchers have developed a new method to map double-strand breaks (DSBs) in the human genome, which are breaks in the DNA that can lead to cancer and other diseases. They found that these breaks are not random, but occur in specific areas called domains, about 50-250 kilobases long, scattered along chromosomes. About 30% of these domains have genes that are turned on or off together, and the proteins PAR1 and HNPA2B1 bind to the ends of these domains. This suggests a new way genes are regulated by being turned on or off in groups, with breaks in the DNA and these proteins binding sites. This is important for understanding how chromosomes are organized and how genes are turned on or off, which can help with cancer and gene therapy.

The study found that breaks in DNA are not just random, but occur in specific areas that are protected from fragmentation. They also found that some of these areas have genes that are turned on together, suggesting a new way genes are regulated in groups. The proteins PAR1 and HN2B1 bind to the ends of these areas, which could influence how genes are turned on or off. This is a clue to how chromosomes are organized and how genes are regulated, which is important for understanding cancer and gene therapy.

The researchers also found that these breaks could be fragile sites in chromosomes, and their method can be used to study fragile sites in many types of human cells. The proteins PAR and HN2B have not been known to work together before, but H2 is known to interact with a protein that fixes DNA breaks. This study shows that H2 binds to thousands of sites in the genome, which can help understand its role in chromosome function.
Researchers studied trypanosomat infections in bats from two areas with different levels of preservation in the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. They analyzed 181 bat specimens from Reserva Ecológica Guçu (REG) and Estação Florestal Mata Atlântica (EFMA) and found 24 infected individuals (13%) with trypanosomatids. The most common parasite detected was Trypanosoma dionii (54%), followed by T. cruzi DTI and TIV and Tryosoma sp. in Neotropical phlost bats. Mixed infections were also observed. T. cruz DTI and TIV are involved in acute Chagas disease cases in Brazil and T. dionii was found in an infected child's heart. A new parasite, Crithidia mellific, was discovered infecting a vertebrate host in the Americas. Bats from the Atlantic Forest harbor a great diversity of trypanids, maintaining tryosid diversity in the sylvatic environment.
Ticks are the most common arthropod vectors of human and animal diseases in Europe, and Ixodes ricinus is a key species that transmits many bacteria, viruses, and parasites. These ticks can be co-infected with multiple pathogens, increasing the likelihood of transmission to humans or animals. However, little is known about co-infection rates and most studies focus on well-known pathogens. Ticks also carry symbionts that play roles in tick biology and may interfere with pathogen transmission. This study evaluated the prevalence of 38 pathogens and symbionts and co-infections, as well as interactions between pathogens and symbion. 267 Iodes ricinus females were collected in the Ardennes and analyzed for 37 pathogens by high-throughput real-time PCR, Tick-borne encephalitis virus by RT-PCR, and symbion by nested PCR. Results showed 45% of ticks were co-infected, carrying up to five pathogens. Adding symbion prevalence, all ticks were infected with at least one microorganism, up to eight in one tick. Interactions between pathogens suggested a strong association between Borrelia garini and B afii, no interactions between symbion and pathogens. This study reveals high pathogen co-infection rates, raising questions about co-transmission to humans and animals, and health consequences. High symbion coexistence with pathogens opens avenues for research on effects on pathogen transmission and vector competence.
Researchers have developed a computational model to understand how hematopoietic stem cells decide to become either erythroid or myeloid cells. This decision is governed by a genetic switch involving two master genes, PU.1 and GATA-1. Prior to commitment, these genes are expressed at low levels, a "primed" state. The model shows that mutual antagonism and autoregulation between these genes makes the system bistable, allowing for robust lineage determination. A new mechanism involving a cofactor regulated by one of the master genes is necessary for bistability and switch-like behavior. Suppressing the cofactor can lead to loss of cooperativity and a primed state. The PU.1-GATA switch also interacts with another antagonistic pair, FOG-1, which reinforces the decision through feedback loops, making it irreversible. This switch is an example of a network implementing both primed and committed states through cofactor recruitment. Perturbing feedback between regulators and targets suggests reprogramming strategies. The approach can aid lineage studies and search for determining genes.
Enterococcus faecalis, an opportunistic pathogen, has high resistance to lysozym, a key effector of the innate immune system, due to a complex network of transcription regulators and genes oat, pgA, dlt, and sig. Researchers sought to identify genes modulating E. faalis resistance to lyzym. Random transposon mutagenesis in a quadruple oat/pgA/dlt/sig mutant led to identification of insertions in the enteroccal polyschar antigen (EPA) region, downstream of conserved epA-ep genes, proposed to encode core machinery. The PA region was thought to be responsible for EPA decoration, but its role was unknown. This study shows EPA decoration contributes to resistance to antimicrobials and virulence in zebraf model by conferring resistance phagocytosis. Results indicate production of EPA backbone is not sufficient for E. faalis infections, revealing an essential role of modification for enteroccal pathogenesis. Several genes contributing to EPA decoration play a role in resistance to innate system and virulence. Deletion of pgA in L monocogen is associated with 32-fold decrease in resistance. Transposon mutagenesis of OP strain showed disruption of genes encoding EPA decoration increases E fa resistance lyzym. In-frame deletion in wild-type background had same effect. Contribution of oat, pgA, dlt, and sig to lyzym resistance was carried out using E fa J2 as background, avirulent in zraf model. Mapping transon sites revealed 16 insertions downstream conserved epAep region, encoding core apparatus producing EPA. Region displays variability and proposed responsible for EPA decoration. This study shows quadruple mutant oat/pgA/dlt/sig still high resistance lyzym compared to Firmutes.
Researchers have developed a new model called RER to analyze how genes are regulated in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a type of blood cancer. This model combines data from two large databases: The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE). These databases contain information on genetic and epigenetic factors that affect gene expression, such as copy number variation, DNA methylation, transcription factors, and microRNA post-transcription regulation. The new model, RER, infers sample-specific regulatory activities of transcription factors and microRNAs, which are then used to infer their interactions. This two-stage framework overcomes a challenge of integrating generic cell-line data from ENCODE with sample-specific TC measurements. The researchers tested R on AML data from TC and related binding data from K562 cells in EN. They verified the model's accuracy with 10-fold cross-validation and showed it outperformed existing methods in detecting microRNA/transcription factor targets. Additionally, they identified 18 regulators whose activities clustered with cytogenetic risk and one, miR-548, which targets were enriched in leukemia-related pathways, suggesting its role in AML pathogenesis. Survival analysis using inferred activities as a potential AML prognostic marker. The study provides a framework that integrates TC and EN data, revealing AML regulatory program at a global level.
Researchers studied the role of RNA interference (RNAi) in the fungus Colletotrichum higginsum, a pathogen that infects various crops worldwide. They created mutants lacking genes for three key RNAi proteins: RDR, DCL, and AGO. The mutants grew normally on regular and minimal media, but showed defects in producing spores and spore morphology. The team analyzed RNA and small RNA populations in parental and mutant strains, finding greatest effects in Δcl, ΔclΔcl, and Δago strains. A previously unknown virus, Colotrichum higginsum non-segmented RNA virus 1 (ChV1), was repressed in these mutants. Phylogenetic analysis showed ChV is related to segmented viruses. Immunoprecipitation of small RNAs with AG1 showed abundant 5'U-containing siRNAs. Higginsum and Δcl strains cured of ChV showed spore and morphology defects were caused by ChV. RNAi involving DCL and AG in C is proposed as an antiviral mechanism.
Researchers have studied the role of histone acetyltransferase MOF in meiotic expansion of H2 phosphorylation during spermatogenesis in mice. They found that MOF is involved in all three waves of H2 phosphorylation, which occur during different stages of meiotic prophase. The first wave is ATM-dependent and occurs at leptotene, the second and third are ATR-dependent at zygot and pachene, respectively. The third wave marks unsynapsed chromosomes. MO deletion in spermatocytes caused loss of H4ac and H2 phosphorylation in leptene and zgot spermatocytes. In almost 40% of early-mid pachene spermatocytes, H2 and M1 were detected along unsyn axes but failed to expand, causing meiotic sex inactivation failure. MO also facilitates meiotic double-strand break repair after RAD51 recruitment. The study shows MO regulates meiosis and expansion of H2 phosphorylation from lept to pene stages initiated by ATM and ATR.
Researchers studied the effects of Human T-cell leukemia virus 1 (HTLV-1) on the development of T-cells in the immune system. They used a special mice model called "Immune System" Rag-2/-c/-, which has a weakened immune system. The mice were infected with HT-1 at an early stage when three types of T-cells were present. The virus was found in T-cells in all infected mice and increased over time. In infected mice, T development was altered, with more mature T-cells and fewer immature ones. Mature T-c accumulated in the spleen and were activated, shown by a marker CD25. This was linked to the presence of Tax and increased expression of anti-apoptotic gene bfl-1 in T-cells. Lymphoma and leukemia were found in infected mice several months after infection. These results show the potential of the model to study the initial steps of leukemogenic process by HT-1.

HT-1 infection expanded mature T-cells in the periphery of infected mice. Tax activated genes involved in survival and proliferation in the thym of infected mice, favoring expansion of mature T-cells. A correlation was found between proviral load and alterations of T development in infected mice. CD4 and CD8 expression was analyzed on T-c of less mature and more mature subpopulations in mock and infected mice with low and high proviral load. Mature-c predominated over immature in mice with high proviral load, indicating HT-1 perturbs T development at immature level, propelling towards mature stages. Increased transcription of b-1 was found in T of infected mice. Mature-c accumulated in thym and spleen of infected and increased CD25 CD+ T-cells. Pathological features in some mice might be related to disturbances of T development by HT- infection.
In Sudan, schistosomiasis remains a major public health concern, particularly Schistosoma haematium infection. An integrated control program was implemented in Jabal locality, White State, Sudan from 2009-2011. The study aimed to reduce the disease prevalence of schosomiasis among 482,902 residents, with 78,615 primary school students as the main target group. Urine and stool specimens were examined using sedimentation and Kato-Kato-Katz methods to assess the prevalence of S. haematium and S. mansoni at baseline and follow-up. The prevalence of S. haematium decreased from 28.5% to 13.5% after 6-9 months post-treatment, with higher reduction in girls and rural residents compared to boys and urban. Health education increased awareness about schosiasis, and a water facility was built in Alida village, reducing infection rates compared to a neighboring village. However, S. mansoni prevalence remained unchanged. Approximately 200,000 received praziquantel therapy, education, or clean water. The project achieved a 50% reduction in S. haematium prevalence.
Researchers have discovered that the matrix protein of the Nipah virus (NiV), a highly pathogenic paramyxovirus, plays a crucial role in viral budding by trafficking between the nucleus and cytoplasm. Unlike other paramyxiruses, which replicate in the cytoplasm, NiV's matrix protein was found in the nucleus early stages of infection before localizing to the plasma membrane. Mutations in the bipartite nuclear localization signal and leucine-rich nuclear export signal in Ni-M impaired its trafficking and abolished budding. A conserved lysine residue in the NLS mediated nuclear import and was also a site for monoubiquination regulating export. Overexpression of ubiquitin enhanced NiV budding, while depletion of ubiquitin blocked it. Live NiV budding was sensitive to proteasome inhibitors, with an IC50 of 2.7nM, a concentration achievable in humans. This suggests a potential therapeutic target for acute Ni infection.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how non-enveloped viruses, such as poliovirus, enter and deliver their genetic material into cells. These viruses are difficult to study because their entry mechanisms are not well understood due to technical challenges in visualizing the process and distinguishing between productive and non-productive pathways. The new method combines live-cell imaging of viral capsid and genome with infectivity assays to track early events in poliovirus infection. The study found that polirus genome release is efficient and rapid, not limiting overall infectivity or infection rate. The virus binds to cell surface receptors and enters through a clath, caveolin, flotillin, and microtubule-independent, but tyrosine and actin-dependent endocytic mechanism. After internalization, genome release occurs from vesicles or membrane invaginations within 100-200 nm of plasma membrane. This settles debate on whether polirus directly breaks membrane or relies on endocyt to deliver genome into cell. The method is expected to be applicable to other nonvelop viruses.
Dengue fever remains a significant public health concern in Cambodia, particularly affecting children. The National Dengue Control Program (NDC) relies heavily on education as a means of prevention and control, delivering it to communities and schools. An ethnographic study conducted in 2003-2004 in eastern Cambodia explored the approaches used in education and their effectiveness in controlling deng. Community education is provided through health centre activities and campaigns, but is underfunded and irregular; school education is limited in time and lacks follow-up. As a result, adherence is partial.

Health education plays a key role in informing people to prevent and participate in controlling deng, but in resource-poor countries, efficacy is complicated by economic and infrastructural factors. In Cambodia, deng education through outreach and school programs is insufficient and underfunded. This doesn't mean a reduced need for education, however. Local control activities involving members through education in community and schools can reduce deng, but this can't occur where education is poorly resourced and knowledge isn't translated to practice.

Two factors impact outreach: political commitment and resources. We explore input and effectiveness of community and school education to address this gap. Challenges facing deng control in Cambodia are elucidated. No specific model was used for health activities or education; strategy and content included various activities, information and practices to reduce deng and mortality. Community education is through radio, television, billboards, banners, posters, and leaflets. Existing deng materials must be redefined practical and relevant. Little training in health education for practitioners, they lack skills and perceive education not part of work.
Researchers have identified circulating microRNAs (miRNAs) released by filarial nematodes, parasites that cause chronic and debilitating diseases in humans and animals, in the bloodstream of infected hosts. Using a novel technology, they found over 200 miRNA sequences of nematode origin in Dirofia imis-infected dog plasma and 21 in Onchocerca volulus-infected human serum. Two miRNAs, mi-71 and mi-34, were detected in D. imis-infected dog plasma and discriminated infected from uninfected samples. However, miRNA numbers did not correlate with microfilaria (mf) counts. This may be due to imprecision in mf counts or mi contributions from unknown number of adult worms. Parasite-derived miRNAs were found in plasma or serum of species that do not live in the bloodstream. A large number of candidate miRNAs were found in mammalian hosts infected with several filarial nematodes, 245 in D. imis-infected dog plasma and 261 in B. pangi-infected dog. RT-qPCR assays were developed to discriminate infected from uninf samples, but did not reflect mf counts. B. pangi adults live in lymphatic vessels, while O. volulus life stages do not have direct contact with blood. Two miRNAs, mi-71 and mi-34, were detected in all D. imis-infected dogs and previously reported in whole worm extracts.
Researchers have created a detailed model to study how a type of enzyme called Src kinase changes shape when it becomes active. Src kinases play a key role in cell signaling, helping cells communicate with each other. The change from inactive to active state involves significant changes in shape. The team built a simplified model of the active part of the enzyme, called the catalytic domain, using structures of two stable states. They simulated the shape changes between these states and mapped the energy landscape of possible shapes. Two main paths for activation were found. In the first, interactions between a specific parts of the enzyme changed together. In the second, a part of the enzyme unfolded. The team also looked at how a specific part, the α helix, and activation loop, interacted. They tested a statistical model to see if it could explain the changes in shape. The results provide a framework for understanding how Src changes shape when it becomes active.
Researchers have identified the genetic basis of lethality in offspring from crosses between Arabidopsis thaliana plants with different numbers of chromosomes. They found a single gene, TT2, which is active in the mother plant, controls the viability of offspring with extra chromosomes. Mutations in TT2 reduced lethality in offspring from crosses with extra chromosomes. The gene TT2 also affects the formation of cells in the endosperm, the part of the seed. The study suggests that lethality in offspring with extra chromosomes can evolve quickly due to single gene mutations. The mother's gene TT2 plays a role in preparing the offspring for the extra chromosomes, making them viable. The research shows that lethality in offspring is a barrier to speciation, or the formation of new species, in plants. 

The study found a single gene, DSL1, which is linked to TT2, and affects lethality in offspring with extra chromosomes. Mutations in DSL reduced lethality in offspring. The gene is active in the mother and affects the formation of cells in the endperm. The study suggests lethality in offspring with extra chromosomes can evolve quickly due to single mutations. The mother's gene TT2 prepares offspring for extra chromosomes, making them viable. The research shows lethality in offspring is a barrier to speciation, or new species formation in plants.
Researchers studied the co-evolution of bacteria and their hosts in bats and rodents using Bartonella and Leptira as models. They analyzed genetic data from 51 Bartonella genotypes in 24 bat species, 129 Bartonella in 38 rodents, and 26 Leptira in 20 bats. The results showed that Bartonella and their bat hosts had a significant co-evolutionary fit, meaning they evolved together over time. Bartonella and rodent hosts also had a strong pattern of co-speciation, meaning they evolved together. However, Leptira and bats did not have a significant co-evolution, meaning they did not evolve together. Separate analysis of New and Old World data showed the same results. Event-based phylogeny was used to reconstruct evolutionary histories of each pathogen and host. Leptira bats had the most host switches, while Bartonella had the fewest. Bartonella in bats and rodents had co-evolution with minimal host switching, while Leptira bats had no congruence with host and many switches. Differences in disease transmission and host ecology may explain these co-evolution patterns. Understanding co-evolution and host-switching will help predict spillo between mammal reservoirs and humans.
Researchers have developed a new framework to understand how animals like fish and eels move through the water using a "undulatory" motion. This motion involves a wave-like movement of the body that creates forward motion. The question is whether muscle contractions or the fluid around the animal cause this movement is key to understanding how animals swim. A forced oscillation framework was applied to a chain model of undulatory swimming to see how forcing leads to movement. The study found that muscle contractions trigger the first movements of the body, which cause forward motion. Simple patterns can create complex movements that lead to swimming. The frequency of muscle contractions relative to the natural movement of the system is important for the shape of the body during swimming. This approach also helps understand the best movement for fast swimming. Results from a chain model were confirmed by computer simulations. Previous findings on the best stiffness for speed are explained.

A chain model of undulatory swimming was used to study how movement emerges from forcing. The system is forced by muscles, fluid, or both. Deformations from muscles and fluid are not separated. The system is forced by muscles, fluid, or both. A framework was applied to undulatory to understand movement from muscular and environmental forcing. For muscle activation, the frequency of the system is important for body shape. Quantitatively, how muscle work is used in deformation and dissipated into fluid is shown. A expression for swimming velocity is derived from equations.

Movement of undulatory swimmers starts from muscle activation. Two issues are in undulatory. First, muscle to deformation. Second, deformation to movement. The forced oscillation formulation is presented, then used to generate motion. Examples of active and passive swimming are presented, including typical motions involve lower modes. Power transfer during swimming is discussed.
Researchers have found that genetic recombination between the parasite Trypanosoma brucei from humans and animals can create new strains of the human pathogen responsible for sleeping sickness in Africa, known as African Trypanosomias or HAT. This is similar to how the pandemic H1N1/09 flu virus emerged from a mix of swine and human influenza viruses.
